HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Getting There Is Challenge For Latin America E-Tailing

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
Any one of the 500 million people who live in Latin America can sign on to the Internet, given access to a computer and a phone line. They can buy a book, CD or anything else offered for sale on the Internet, given a credit card. And they can have their purchase delivered to their home or office, given luck.
In many parts of Latin America, postal service outside of major business centers is erratic at best. At times, the only reliable national delivery system belongs to the soft drink and potato chip manufacturers that stock the bodegas and mom-and-pop stores that do business in almost every community, no matter how small or remote. 
 Even in the cities, packages from abroad can be delayed in customs for days, and letters arrive weeks late, if at all.
That, to a large extent, leaves the final leg of electronic commerce in Latin America the province of private services. Each big city has a few local fast-freight companies, and recently specialized e-commerce companies like Sky Box Services allow Latin Americans to have Internet purchases sent to an address in the United States. Sky Box then carries them south and delivers them to homes and offices, bypassing often unreliable local carriers.
The most visible deliverers are the large international companies like United Parcel Service, FedEx and DHL, and all are expected to play a part in the growth of e-commerce in Latin America. They have been preparing to handle the new business, although they do not expect it to boom anytime soon.
"We liken the status of the Internet in Latin America to being where the United States was in 1996," said John Menna, vice president at U.P.S. for marketing for Latin America and the Caribbean. "It'll take about four or five years to start seeing anything substantial develop there. Nonetheless, U.P.S. is putting in place all the pieces and the infrastructure to facilitate electronic commerce and the buying and selling of goods throughout Latin America."
According to the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean, the number of computers connected to the Internet last year rose more rapidly in Latin America than in any other part of the world. Even so, while the region accounts for 8 percent of the world's population, it represents just 3.5 percent of Internet users and less than 1 percent of global e-commerce.
Many obstacles hamper development of the Internet in Latin America. Poverty is so persistent that many people still lack access to a telephone, and the possibility of buying a computer, let alone logging onto the Internet, is reserved for a relatively small group of city dwellers with sufficient incomes. Few people have credit cards, which still are essential for e-commerce to work. Computer literacy lags far behind levels in other parts of the world, and telephone service competition has not yet brought down the cost of Internet access.
And then there is the issue of delivery. "Local delivery of goods is something that many people in Latin America associate with the local postal service, which in the past has been a very poor service indeed," Mr. Menna said.
To strengthen its Latin American operations, U.P.S. is buying Challenge Air Cargo, an airline that serves Latin America from Miami. Besides increasing the U.P.S. fleet, the acquisition provides landing rights in virtually every developed country in Latin America, a process that could have taken years had it been negotiated nation by nation.
The Challenge purchase "clearly says that we think Latin America is a growing region," Mr. Menna said. But e-commerce, he added, "is still all potential."
Competition is intense among the air delivery services. DHL Worldwide Express has spent $30 million the last two years preparing for more cargo, including substantially more e-commerce deliveries. In 1998, the company bought three Boeing 727's, upgraded its hub in Panama City and built a new hub in Buenos Aires. Last year DHL also acquired DHL S.A., a contract operation in Argentina that was run by a local company. DHL is spending up to $10 million to improve service in Argentina.
"Latin America has an awful lot of people, an awful lot of land and huge potential," said Colum Joyce, an electronic commerce manager at DHL's headquarters in Brussels. "But it's no different from anywhere else in the world. There are a few relatively concentrated points of consumption, and pickup on the Internet is concentrating on those socioeconomic segments of the community."
The other big air delivery service in the region, FedEx, is building a larger cargo handling operation at Miami International Airport, the gateway through which most shipments to Latin America pass. But its real focus is on streamlining the process for getting goods in and out of Latin America.
Juan N. Cento, president of FedEx Express International's Latin America division, said his company was helping customers, like the hammock manufacturer in Merida, Mexico, he visited recently, design and build their Web pages to take full advantage of the global market available on the Internet.
"They say, 'Here's what we need,' and we help them with everything from building a Web page to monitoring the shipping, tracking and tracing of packages," Mr. Cento said.
FedEx is also working to reduce customs delays for packages coming into Latin America. It recently opened a new clearing house at the Toluca Airport outside Mexico City that enables local customs agents to clear shipments worth less than $200 on the day they arrive. A similar system is planned for Campinas, Brazil, near Sao Paolo, and will later be replicated throughout the region.
"E-commerce is an increasingly integral part of the business environment in certain markets in the region," said Gregory M. Rossiter, a FedEx spokesman. "But quite candidly, for FedEx, the potential for e-commerce in the region as a whole is still a number of years away."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Blue Chips Slump Again; Nasdaq Gains Are Modest

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks stumbled lower yesterday as worries about a slower pace of consumer spending dogged retailers for a second day and investors continued to lock in profits on recent gains.
Technology shares, however, clung to modest gains, as positive earnings news buoyed individual stocks and the semiconductor sector resumed its rebound. 
 Investors took news of slightly stronger-than-expected consumer prices in stride, viewing the data as unlikely to rattle the market's confidence that the Federal Reserve will leave rates steady on Tuesday.
The Consumer Price Index for July showed a rise of 0.2 percent, higher than the gain of 0.1 percent expected by economists polled by Reuters, but well below June's increase of 0.6 percent. Excluding volatile energy and food components, the core index rose 0.2 percent in July, in line with expectations.
But that news failed to lift most stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average, slumped 58.61 points, or 0.5 percent, to 11,008.39. That drop came on top of the Dow's 109.14-point loss on Tuesday.
The Dow and the Nasdaq have neared the upper end of recent trading ranges, said Francis Gannon, senior portfolio manager for United States equities at SunAmerica Asset Management.
"People are getting nervous that we will get up near those resistance levels and back off," Mr. Gannon said, "and that is perhaps what we are seeing today."
Broader market measures also slipped, with the Standard & Poor's 500 index down 4.58 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,479.85.
The Nasdaq composite index, meanwhile, rose 9.54 points, or 0.3 percent, to 3,861.20.
The 30-stock Dow index suffered largely from the weight of its floundering retailing components.
Home Depot declined 2 3/4, to 51, after a number of Wall Street analysts lowered their opinions of the stock. On Tuesday, the company reported fiscal second-quarter earnings that met expectations, but disappointed investors who had been hoping for better results.
Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, fell 2 1/16, to 49 11/16.
"The retailers seem to be in a very bearish mood. I think that's more of a function of overall consumer spending slowing down," said Donald Berdine, chief investment officer at PNC Advisers. "They were priced maybe higher than they should have been, given the slowing in the economy that we all expect."
Adding further to retailers' woes, Heilig-Meyers, a home furnishings company, said it would file for bankruptcy protection and close some stores. Trading in the stock was halted in the late morning.
The Dow's financial services stocks weakened, giving up strong gains made recently amid growing conviction that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates. American Express was off 1 7/8, to 57 5/16, while J. P. Morgan tumbled 4 1/4, to 142 7/16.
"The group had a terrific bounce a couple of weeks ago, and it has been slowly giving it up," said Lawrence Cohn, banking analyst at Ryan, Beck & Company.
But the Dow's losses were offset in part by gains in the shares of the oil giant ExxonMobil, which rose 1 29/64, to 82 49/64. Oil services shares also floated broadly higher as crude oil prices headed back toward 10-year highs. The Standard & Poor's international oil index climbed 1.24 percent.
On the Nasdaq, Analog Devices jumped 17 5/8, to 94 7/16, after saying third-quarter earnings nearly tripled, beating analysts' estimates.
BEA Systems also gained on the Nasdaq, adding 8 1/8, to 57, after the company, a software maker, posted second-quarter profits that beat Wall Street forecasts.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
China's Censor Is Customer No. 1

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
When Saatchi & Saatchi set out to create a Chinese television commercial for Daktarin, an athlete's foot medication made by a unit of Johnson & Johnson, the advertising firm faced a predicament. Chinese government regulations prohibit advertisements from showing patients or symptoms -- critical elements for a pharmaceutical commercial.
Saatchi & Saatchi eventually resolved the problem by using weeds as a visual analogy for a foot fungus. That satisfied the regulators, but frustrated the ad agency. 
 "Creatively, we could be 10 times better than now if it wasn't for the regulations," lamented Philip Li, executive creative director for Saatchi & Saatchi's Beijing office.
Rigid government control, however, is the price to enter one of the world's fastest-growing advertising markets. Mr. Li said he had often had to rework commercials to address the objections of Chinese censors -- or to avoid running afoul of them in the first place. "The regulations are always in the back of your mind," he said.
Advertising is just as problematic for the government. In China's march from a centrally planned economy to a market economy, officials have promoted advertising as an accelerator of economic development and welcomed it as a way to supplant government subsidies for many television stations and periodicals. On the other hand, the government has also criticized advertising as a conduit for both fraud and unwelcome foreign ideas.
"They will try to be as lenient as possible, but whenever anything touches cultural values or political stability, it is something they have to crush right away," said Louisa Ha, president of Dr. Ad Marketing International, a consulting firm based in the United States that focuses on China.
Coca-Cola, for example, recently withdrew a multimillion-dollar campaign for its Sprite soda because the ads featured a popular Taiwanese singer, A-Mei, who had sung Taiwan's national anthem at the inauguration of President Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan. China regards Taiwan as a renegade province.
"If they allowed her to be on the commercial, they would be allowing dissidence," Dr. Ha said. "Politics is above everything else in this country's agenda, whatever economic interests are sacrificed."
Those interests are not insignificant. In the 21 years since a Shanghai station showed China's first television commercial, for a Chinese tonic wine, advertising spending in China has soared from zero to more than $7 billion, and by some estimates is as high as $12 billion. The range results from discrepancies between published rates and discounted rates that advertisers are actually charged, coupled with the weakness of China's accounting system.
While that is a fraction of the $165 billion spent on advertising in the United States last year, China is one of the world's fastest-growing markets. It has surpassed South Korea to become Asia's second-largest market behind Japan.
As advertising has mushroomed, so has the government's determination to keep it under control. In a country where the media are monitored carefully for their political and social influence, advertising is considered a privilege bestowed by the government and not a commercial extension of the right of free speech.
In adjusting this privilege, the government has updated its advertising rules more than 30 times in the last six years.
The guidelines range from vague principles, like insisting that advertisements not "jeopardize the social order," to specific prohibitions, like those that forbid the use of state symbols like the flag or national anthem. Companies are also not allowed to use superlative terms like "best" or compare their products with those of competitors.
The prohibitions have scuttled ads for such products as the Bristol-Myers Squibb painkiller Bufferin, which claimed to be "the best," and Colgate's diamond-headed toothbrush, which the company asserted was superior to traditional rectangular toothbrushes. However, Budweiser's slogan that it is "America's favorite beer" was allowed after its brewer, St. Louis-based Anheuser-Busch, provided statistical evidence to support the claim.
While the regulations may seem severe, the government considers them a necessary consumer-protection measure in a country where soaps have claimed to help people lose weight and tonics have promised to make people smarter. In the United States, consumer sophistication backed by government regulations has convinced most advertisers that it is in their own best interest to shun exaggerated claims and outright falsehoods in advertising.
"Self-regulation is the hallmark of maturity in an advertising industry," said Hong Cheng, a professor of communications at Bradley University in Peoria, Ill. "This kind of system is still in the making in China. That is why the government has to act as a Big Brother."
Since the regulations went into effect, the government said it had found 160,000 examples of false or misleading advertisements and had imposed penalties of more than $54 million. The number of "advertising malpractice" cases handled by the authorities rose 36 percent last year, led by ads for drugs, medical services and food.
These included products called Jiannan Capsules (which translates as Healthy Male Capsules) and Alaska Shengmin Lixiong Platinum (Alaska Life Strength Chest Platinum). Several of the cited products trade on the Chinese translation of Viagra, the impotence treatment, which is not trademarked in China. The government did not identify the manufacturers.
"The shadow of the regulations hangs over the advertising creative process from beginning to end," said Louis Wong, president of Beijing-based Megacom Advertising, who estimates that half of his commercials have to be modified during the approval process. "It is annoying, but this is reality."
Television commercials, which receive the greatest scrutiny because of their wide viewership, must be submitted to each regional office of the State Administration for Industry and Commerce before being shown. Many companies submit their storyboards and script before filming just as a precaution.
The approval process is subjective and fragmented, with some regional offices approving commercials that other offices reject. A shampoo commercial that showed a glimpse of a bather's shoulder was accepted in cosmopolitan Shanghai, for example, but banned in a conservative neighboring province. Other commercials that received storyboard approval were rejected after the final edit. Some commercials are censored after they go on the air.
Commercials that violate standards can sometimes be salvaged by rewriting the script or making other adjustments, but some are banned.
"Most of our problems are pharmaceuticals and things related to underwear," Mr. Wong said. "The problem is often over-exaggeration of a product, or that it goes against the general moral standards of the Chinese population."
Pharmaceuticals face the strictest regulations. That industry, the largest spender in advertising, faces reviews by public health officials as well as advertising regulators. And, because of a history of exaggerated claims for medicines, advertisers in China are not allowed to show patients, children or symptoms. Nor can they associate products with the names of doctors or hospitals.
Sexual modesty is also emphasized by the government. Models must be covered at least 15 centimeters (5.9 inches) down from their necks and 15 centimeters up from their knees, which can be inconvenient for companies trying to sell shampoo or underwear.
"If you are the marketer for the underwear, you want to demonstrate that a piece of underwear fits well," said Mr. Wong, whose firm is working on an account for Embroform, a Hong Kong underwear company. "But if you just featured a face of a woman up to the shoulders, then what is the point of an underwear commercial?"
His firm is looking into using computer animation for the commercial, hoping in that way to avoid the fate of a previous ad that was censored because authorities thought a model's miniskirt was too short.
Foreign manufacturers are not the only advertisers who have run into trouble. The government itself has on occasion run afoul of the censors. A commercial advocating condom use to avoid AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases was pulled late last year, two days after it first appeared, when the State Administration for Industry and Commerce decided it was too risque
Regulations not only restrict the content of advertisements, but the structure of the industry. China has 50,000 advertising firms employing almost half a million people, an average of just under 10 people a company. To protect domestic agencies from foreign competition and to limit foreign cultural influence, multinational advertising agencies are required to set up joint ventures and are limited in their equity. Foreign advertising executives said they expect China to relax or eliminate that requirement if the country is admitted to the World Trade Organization.
While China's advertising market is experiencing surging revenue growth, creative growth is unremarkable as a consequence of all the restrictions.
"If you look at all the award-winning commercials in the Cannes festivals, I can bet 80 percent could not be in China because of the content," Mr. Wong said. It's frustrating, he said, but he and others knew to expect it when they walked into China.
"If you want fun and creative," Mr. Li concurred, "that's not China."

HEADLINE: Bankruptcy Filings Continue to Decline

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
Fewer individuals and businesses filed for bankruptcy in the second quarter of 2000, the Administrative Office of the United States Courts reported this week.
The total number of new bankruptcy filings from April 1 through the end of June fell to 321,729, down 7 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier and the lowest number of filings in any second quarter since 1996. 
 Bankruptcies filed for the 12 months that ended on June 30 totaled 1,276,922, an 8.3 percent decrease from the period that ended in June 1999.
Congress is working on an overhaul of the bankruptcy code, motivated by rises in filings to a record high of 1.44 million in 1998. But consumer bankruptcies, the focus of the effort, have recently been declining.
"The continued drop in bankruptcy filings reflects the positive impact that our strong economy has had on household balance sheets," Samuel Gerdano, executive director of the American Bankruptcy Institute, said.
Personal bankruptcy filings totaled 312,486 in the second quarter, down 6.9 percent from the second quarter of last year. For the year to June 30, personal filings fell to 1,240,012, an 8.3 percent decrease compared with the corresponding period in 1999.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Vouchers for summer school could help halt the learning slide.

BYLINE: By Alan B. Krueger; This column appears here every Thursday. Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim Professor of Economics and Public Affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. Four economic analysts -- Professor Krueger, Hal R. Varian, Jeff Madrick and Virginia Postrel -- rotate as contributors.

 BODY:
A Gallup poll taken in July discovered the obvious: the Harry Potter books are being read by everyone this summer. Well, almost everyone. Children in low-income families are much less likely to read Harry than their counterparts in middle- and upper-income families.
This finding will not surprise education experts or teachers, who have known for decades that economically disadvantaged children fall behind during the summer months compared with their peers. The problem is that children from low-income families are less likely to read Harry Potter or much else during the summer, which causes their skills to atrophy when school is out of session. 
 What might be called the "Harry Potter divide" -- the depressed level of academic engagement in poor households when school is out -- is responsible for a major portion of the gap in achievement between low- and high-income students.
The achievement gap has important economic consequences. Several studies indicate that students who score one standard deviation higher on math and reading tests -- comparing those at the 15th percentile to those at the 50th percentile, say -- earn, on average, 15 to 20 percent more a year as adults. And a new study by Christopher Jencks of Harvard University and Meredith Phillips of the University of California at Los Angeles found that high school is not too late to make a difference: those whose math test scores increased between 10th and 12th grade achieved higher incomes later in life compared with those who started at the same level but did not raise their scores.
Clearly, raising achievement pays off, and it pays off more today than in the past because the information age has increased the demand for skilled workers.
Labor force projections, however, indicate a slowdown in the growth of skilled workers in the next two decades, so the achievement gap between lower-income students and their counterparts from more affluent families could crimp the expansion of the economy. In my view, the summer learning deficit is much more worrisome for economic growth than the trade deficit.
The latest and probably best research on the summer learning gap is in a 1997 book, "Children, Schools and Inequality" (Westview Press) by Doris Entwisle, Karl Alexander and Linda Olson of Johns Hopkins University. The three sociologists have been studying a random sample of 800 Baltimore public school students since they entered first grade in 1982. At the beginning and end of each school year, students took the California Achievement Test.
The researchers examined gains and losses in test scores over the school year and summer break. Students were classified into groups based on their parents' socioeconomic status, which depended on education, occupation and income.
Remarkably, children from families of high and low socioeconomic status made equivalent gains on math and reading exams during the school year. But the achievement level of children from low-income families either fell or stagnated during the summer, while children from higher income families continued to make progress.
The entire achievement gap between children from low- and high-income families arises from periods when school is out and the period before children enroll in school. This pattern, which also holds in other studies, suggests public schools are doing more to help poor children overcome the obstacles they face in their homes and neighborhoods than is commonly appreciated.
While Republicans and Democrats spar over using vouchers to reform public schools, a potential solution to the achievement gap has been overlooked. Why not give low-income parents a scholarship, or voucher, to send their children to some type of a summer learning program?
The idea of school vouchers, which is frequently attributed to Milton Friedman but dates back at least to Thomas Paine, has become "radioactive" among Democrats, as Jonathan Orzsag, a former official for President Clinton's National Economic Council, put it. So call this something else, such as Summer Opportunity Scholarships -- S.O.S. for short.
Only 9 percent of students in the United States attend summer school. Unlike other voucher programs, summer school scholarships would supplement, rather than substitute for, the traditional public school system.
The 180-day school year in the United States -- a legacy of a bygone era when children were needed to work the farm in the summer -- is short by international standards. By the end of high school, children in Japan, for example, have had the equivalent of four more years of schooling than American children. Although it would be desirable to use the 180-day school year more constructively, one thing is clear: more time on task helps students learn.
Summer school bolsters achievement if it is focused on specific academic goals, said Harris Cooper of the University of Missouri. Professor Cooper, who just published a review of 93 evaluations of separate summer school programs, said the effect of summer school on student achievement was "clearly positive" when performance was compared either with participants' pre-summer scores or with a randomly selected control group of nonparticipants.
But summer school runs into a roadblock. Many families and teachers do not want to be in school year round. Mandated summer school attendance also carries a stigma, and such programs typically cater to older children who are already far behind.
Summer scholarships offer a solution. Families could be given a refundable tax credit or cash grant if they sent their children to a competent academic enrichment program during the summer. A range of options already exist, including public school-sponsored summer schools, private tutoring organizations like the Sylvan and Kumon learning centers, and education-oriented camps.
Too many children are forced to endure summers like the mythical Harry Potter of Privet Drive. No books, no trips, no visits to the library; only a television and loyal owl for company. Giving low-income families scholarships to send their children to summer enrichment programs could help narrow the achievement gap and better prepare the work force of tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Pace of Consumer Inflation Registers Only a Slight Gain

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Consumer inflation increased only slightly last month, the Labor Department said yesterday, reassuring analysts that the Federal Reserve would find no need to raise interest rates again when it meets Tuesday.
The Consumer Price Index rose a relatively modest 0.2 percent in July, as oil and other energy prices showed little change after gyrating for most of the year. 
 "This puts the final nail in the coffin of a rate hike next week," said Bill Sharp, senior United States economist at Chase Securities.
Adding to the case for Fed forbearance, the Commerce Department said that builders had broken ground on 3.3 percent fewer new homes last month than in June, the slowest pace since late 1997.
The price report contained few surprises, but allayed lingering fears that the Fed, which has raised rates six times in the last 13 1/2 months, would be forced to keep raising them to prevent an outbreak of inflation. A report of strong retail sales last week had kept such fears alive. Not counting energy and food, the rise was 0.2 percent for the fourth consecutive month.
The July results reduced the 12-month inflation rate to 3.5 percent from 3.7 percent.
Nonetheless, economists noted a gradual uptick in the pace of inflation this year that they said would need eventually to be arrested -- even though it largely results from higher prices for a volatile item like gasoline. Inflation increased at a 4 percent pace for the first seven months of the year, compared with a 2.7 percent pace for the 1999 calendar year.
"We are seeing some inflation pressures," said Marilyn Schaja, senior economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. "You can't rule out a rate hike in the fall."
Ms. Schaja said the weakness in yesterday's home-building report might have been exaggerated by poor weather. She also noted that the decline in starts -- to an annual rate of 1,512,000 units -- was confined to one region, the South.
The bond market found little comfort in the reports, with traders and investors promptly pushing rates up a bit from Tuesday's levels.
It was the energy component, which accounts for 7 percent of the Consumer Price Index, that accounted for most of the deceleration. After surging 5.6 percent in June, energy edged up 0.1 percent last month as a 2 percent rise for energy services was largely offset by a 1.6 percent decline for petroleum-based energy.
Gasoline fell 2 percent after an 8.8 percent jump in June but is still 18.3 percent higher so far this year after soaring 30.1 percent in 1999. Airline fares, 0.7 percent higher last month, are up 9.7 percent so far this year.
Food prices climbed 0.5 percent after rising just 0.1 percent in June, an acceleration that Patrick C. Jackman, a senior official at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said he could not explain in light of an excellent growing season. Perhaps, he speculated, there was some delayed impact from higher costs of transporting food.
Medical care rose 0.3 percent last month and 4.1 percent for the latest 12 months. A subindex dominated by prescription drugs, the cost of which is likely to become an increasingly contentious subject of political debate, has risen 4.2 percent in the last 12 months. This compares with a 6.1 percent increase in the 1999 calendar year.
But hospital costs have accelerated this year, to a 7.2 percent annual pace in the six months through July, compared with 5.3 percent for the six months ended in January.
The so-called core inflation rate, which excludes food and energy, has now risen at a 2.6 percent rate so far this year compared with 1.9 percent in 1999.
"We've picked up a bit but it's not accelerating," said Robert G. Dederick, economic consultant to the Northern Trust Company in Chicago. But while the current pace "seems to be within the range of Federal Reserve acceptability," Mr. Dederick said, it remains an open question whether the economy will slow enough in coming months to keep inflation in check without further rate increases later this year or early in 2001.
The consumer price report also showed that inflation in the New York metropolitan area ran at a 3.1 percent rate over the last 12 months compared with 3.5 percent for the average of American cities. Dallas-Fort Worth, with 5 percent, was the highest of the seven areas identified by name, with Chicago lowest, at 3 percent.
The purchasing power of the 1982-84 consumer dollar now stands at 57.9 cents, with the 1967 dollar at 19.3 cents.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
With oil prices increasing and the election season at hand, the cry goes up for OPEC to raise output.

BYLINE: By Jonathan Fuerbringer 

 BODY:
THE price of crude oil increased again yesterday, even after an American Petroleum Institute report the day before said that inventories rose by an unexpected 7.4 million barrels last week and the federal Energy Information Agency cited a smaller, but still strong increase of 3.4 million barrels.
The price jump, with oil for September delivery up 13 cents, to $31.80 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, pretty much sums up the current outlook for oil prices. 
 With inventories in the United States still near 24-year lows, the hope for price relief is in another significant rise in output by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. And that boils down to OPEC's approving increased production from Saudi Arabia -- or Saudi Arabia going it alone. The group's next meeting begins early next month.
Some analysts think more oil will be pumped because, they say, OPEC and especially the Saudis do not want to threaten economic growth by leaving the price above $30 a barrel for the American crude oil benchmark, West Texas intermediate.
In addition, pressure from the United States on Saudi Arabia and other suppliers, inside OPEC as well as outside, to produce more oil will build quickly if the price does not retreat soon. It is not far from the nine-and-a-half-year high of $34.14 a barrel it touched in March just before OPEC's first production increase.
This week, there have been new rumblings of concern from the Clinton administration, which lobbied hard for increased OPEC production before the supplier nations' meeting in June.
It was reported on Monday that Energy Secretary Bill Richardson had told a group of energy analysts a few days earlier that the administration was re-examining ways to lend oil to refiners from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve, presumably lowering prices as the available supplies rose.
Oil would certainly become a presidential campaign issue if the price remained high, especially because of the connections to the oil industry of the Republican ticket of George W. Bush and Dick Cheney.
Home heating oil prices are already on the rise again. Heating oil for September delivery rose 0.37 cent a gallon yesterday, to 86.88 cents. It is up 13 percent in the last two and a half weeks and is 26 percent above the average price from October through February.
"I think informally or otherwise, there is likely to be a supply response" from OPEC before the meeting begins, said Michael Rothman, senior energy analyst at Merrill Lynch.
But the low inventory situation -- and traders' and speculators' focus on it -- is leaving the oil market far more vulnerable to upward price pressure than it was earlier in the year, when OPEC members debated their first two production increases.
"We have no shock absorbers," said Gary N. Ross, chief executive of the PIRA Energy Group, "and we are vulnerable to price spikes."
Some analysts think that it will be difficult to quickly rebuild inventories. They say that most OPEC nations cannot increase their overall capacity to produce oil, providing them little interest in higher output quotas that benefit only a few. Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are the only OPEC nations that could produce significantly more oil, the analysts say.
Then last week, the International Energy Agency reported that several OPEC countries, including the Emirates, were in fact producing below their capacity. Mr. Rothman quoted the agency's monthly report for July as saying that the second-quarter inventory buildup in the 29 members of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a group of the world's wealthier nations, had been far less than normal for that time of year.
Saudi Arabia seemed to have succeeded in taking the pressure off oil prices -- and the focus off inventory levels -- when it finally convinced traders, analysts and speculators last month that it would produce 500,000 barrels more a day, a promise it first surprised the oil market with on July 3.
After wrangling within OPEC, the Saudi message got though as its extra oil began to move. And with that, the price dropped to $27.43 a barrel on July 31 from $30.93 at the beginning of the month.
But on Aug. 1, the American Petroleum Institute reported that crude oil inventories in the United States had dropped by a surprising nine million barrels in the week ended July 28, leaving inventory more than 40 million barrels below the level a year earlier. The following week, total inventory fell by 2.1 million barrels more, bringing it to a 24-year low of 282.6 million barrels. The price of crude oil was back above $30 the next day.
Tuesday's report from the American Petroleum Institute revised the previous week still lower, so that the 7.4-million-barrel increase brought inventories for the week ended on Aug. 11 to 286.4 million barrels.
The only positive factor in the oil price's remaining above $30 a barrel is that OPEC members have an informal agreement to raise production by 500,000 barrels a day if prices stay above a set level for 20 cnsecutive trading days. That level works out to a bit more than $30 a barrel for West Texas intermediate, and the 20 days would be up just before an OPEC meeting the second week of September.
Of course, the producers' group could choose to ignore this trigger. Or, a little jawboning would be enough to push the price below $30 for a day, starting the 20-day period again. So the upward bias on oil prices would remain until there were clear increases in production.

HEADLINE: Why Blacks Doubt Lieberman

BYLINE: By David A. Bositis; David A. Bositis is senior political analyst at the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a group that researches issues involving black Americans.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
At the Democratic convention this week, good manners reign supreme. Despite many doubts, most African-American delegates are supporting Al Gore's choice for a running mate, Senator Joseph Lieberman. Even Maxine Waters, the outspoken congresswoman from California, has announced that after talking to Mr. Lieberman about his views on affirmative action, she is now on board.
But outward party unity doesn't mean that internal fissures have disappeared. Indeed, the selection of Mr. Lieberman points to some real differences between Mr. Gore and black Democrats. And these differences are important to his chances in November. 
 There is general agreement among political analysts that the election will be close and that the states between New Jersey and Missouri (plus North Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Louisiana, Arkansas and Tennessee) are likely to determine the next president.
These states have significant numbers of black voters, who are reliably Democratic, that is, if they go to the polls. To win this election, Mr. Gore will have to ensure that black turnout is high.
The problem? It's hard to imagine that his selection of Mr. Lieberman will galvanize them to vote. As a pollster and researcher who has long followed African-American politics, I know that of all the people mentioned as Mr. Gore's possible running mate, Mr. Lieberman was the one least likely to appeal to African-Americans.
There are political reasons why this is so. Despite his reassurances this week, he was not known as a supporter of affirmative action, especially after his favorable comments about California's proposition that outlawed affirmative action in all state programs. In addition, for four years, he has been chairman of the Democratic Leadership Council, which represents moderate and conservative Democrats as a counterweight to liberals like Jesse Jackson.
Some observers have said that anti-Semitism among a minority of the black population could play a role. There have been several surveys, most notably those done for the Anti-Defamation League, that suggest African-Americans are more anti-Semitic than white Americans. I don't entirely buy the results of these surveys, in part because anti-Semitism, like racism, is a difficult thing to assess.
In surveys, for example, I have heard African-Americans refer to Jewish wealth, but many working class and poor African-Americans talk that way about all white people.
In the case of the Democratic ticket, there is more a sense of "why not us?" Many black Americans feel they have been the most loyal Democrats and wonder why a black politician hasn't been selected by now. This feeling is not about anti-Semitism, but about once again being left out.
The root of black ambivalence about Mr. Lieberman, however, could be more specific. The vice president chose the one man who carries with him an implicit, some would say open, repudiation of Bill Clinton.
Mr. Lieberman's speech calling Mr. Clinton's actions immoral in the Monica Lewinsky scandal was widely praised. Indeed, after Mr. Lieberman was selected, this factor was cited favorably, and seen as helping Al Gore distance himself from the president.
Here's a news flash for you: Black Americans want to celebrate Mr. Clinton. They don't care about his personal life. During his administration, African-Americans have prospered as never before. Incomes have risen faster than those of whites. Affirmative action has been protected. Mr. Clinton made Africa part of his foreign policy. The cabinet has been inclusive.
In short, Bill Clinton already has a legacy -- he is the first president to fully embrace black America.
In the last eight years, African-Americans have gotten used to being taken seriously. They want that influence to continue, and are waiting for Mr. Gore to send a signal that it will. Unfortunately, his selection of Mr. Lieberman sends a different signal.
Mr. Gore now finds himself in a position of having to assure black voters that they will have a real voice in his administration, that their concerns will be addressed. The pollsters can talk all they want about reaching out to swing voters. But Al Gore knows he cannot win without his party's most loyal voters.

HEADLINE: Concorde Is Stripped of Certification to Fly

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 16

 BODY:
British and French aviation regulators withdrew airworthiness certification from the Concorde today, effectively ruling the world's only commercial supersonic airliner unfit to fly until it can be protected against the catastrophic safety flaws behind last month's fatal crash near Paris.
Narrowing their assessment of what caused the crash, investigators said they believed that a tire blowout had sent chunks of rubber flying into a fuel tank, rupturing it and causing it to burst into flames as the plane sped toward takeoff at 195 miles an hour. 
 Previously, French investigators said a 16-inch piece of metal on the runway had burst the tire, setting off the sequence of apparently freakish events that caused the plane to crash within 90 seconds of takeoff.
"What is uniquely different in this case is that tire debris alone is thought to have led to this catastrophic accident," said Sir Malcolm Field, the chairman of Britain's Civil Aviation Authority, the regulatory agency that ordered the grounding of British Airways' Concordes today.
Later in the day, the French aviation agency took the same action.
The revocation of the Concorde's airworthiness certificate -- the document that permits airplanes to fly in the airspace of the authority that issues it -- was the first such action since the United States grounded the McDonnell-Douglas DC-10 for five weeks in 1979, aviation experts said.
Even if Air France and British Airways -- the only airlines operating the Concorde -- decide that it is technically and economically feasible to modify the aircraft or introduce new safety procedures, the process could take "months rather than weeks," said Mike Bell, a senior official of the British aviation authority.
Echoing the assessment of some aviation industry analysts, Kieran Daly, editor of Air Transport Intelligence, an aviation Web site, said that "it will be a finely balanced financial question whether to do these modifications or not."
British Airways said it had canceled Concorde service through early September but would resume it on 24 hours' notice if the airworthiness certification was restored.
Air France grounded its five remaining Concordes immediately after the crash on July 25 of the New York-bound Concorde Flight AF 4590, which killed 113 people in the first fatal accident involving the Concorde. British Airways grounded its fleet of seven Concordes on Tuesday after learning that the airworthiness certificate would be revoked today.
British Airways gave no clear indication whether it believed that the aircraft, which crosses the Atlantic in about three and a half hours at up to twice the speed of sound, would ever return to commercial service.
The Concorde has been plying scheduled trans-Atlantic and other charter routes for almost 25 years and came to be seen as an icon of prestigious travel for executives and superstars ready to pay up to $10,000 for a round-trip journey taking half the time of a subsonic flight.
As British Airways' flagship, Concorde was also seen as an important magnet in drawing high-end travelers to the airline.
Sir Malcolm, the chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, said today, "It is clear to all of us in the C.A.A. that a tire burst alone should never cause the loss of a public transport aircraft."
Sir Malcolm said the authority had asked the Concorde's manufacturers -- BAE Systems, Airbus Industrie and Aerospatiale Matra -- to devise a plan to ensure that accidents could not be caused by burst tires.
Under aviation regulations, airplanes whose fuel tanks are vulnerable to catastrophic damage from tire debris may not be certified as airworthy.
Concorde's spindly, storklike landing gear is positioned directly below the wings, fuel tanks and engines. But British aviation experts say that the British Concordes were modified to protect the wings from burst tires, but that the Air France Concordes were not modified.
Burst tires have been a worry for Concorde pilots since the plane entered service in early 1976, British aviation experts say.
Since then, there have been seven known tire blowouts in which fragments struck fuel tanks without causing fires, the experts said. The modifications to the British Airways Concordes in 1993 involved changes to a water deflector on the undercarriage to "reduce the energy" from a tire blowout, said Derek Blackhall, the head of the certification section of the Civil Aviation Authority. Air France's Concordes did not have the same modification.
But Mike Bell, a senior official of the aviation authority, told a news conference that it was "quite unique, an unprecedented event" for a burst tire alone to cause an air disaster.
Sir Malcolm rejected the idea that the demand for modifications effectively meant that the Concorde would never fly again. "We would wish Concorde to fly again," he said.
Jean-Claude Gayssot, the French transport minister, said the measures did not necessarily imply the end of supersonic travel. "Anyone who says it's the end for supersonic flights has got it wrong," he told the daily Liberation. "Traveling fast is going to be increasingly in demand."
A British investigator, Ken Smart of Britain's Air Accident Investigation Branch, said the precise links between the sequence of events that doomed Flight AF 4590 last month remained to be established in detail.
But he did say the tire blowout had sent debris flying, puncturing one or more fuel tanks and allowing fuel to spill out and catch fire within seconds.
The airplane lost thrust in one engine, then in two, Mr. Smart said. "The crew had no means to make them aware of the nature of the fire nor to take action against it," he said at a news conference.
He said the safety issues relating to the tires would take "some time to resolve."
The head of France's Accident Investigation Bureau, Paul-Louis Arslanian, told reporters in Paris: "I hope the Concorde will fly again, but I am an investigator of accidents, not a witch doctor. I cannot read crystal balls."

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 459 words

HEADLINE: A Metropolis of Poor Children

 BODY:
Every so often during a national convention, a politician says something that shines right through the accumulated oratory hanging like fog above the convention floor, creating an image that requires deeper contemplation. Though hardly known for his speaking skills, former Senator Bill Bradley did just that the other night when he told the Democratic convention that if all the 13.5 million poor children in America were gathered in one place, they would form a city bigger than New York -- and "we would then see child poverty as the slow-motion national disaster that it is."
This Dickensian vision was a wonderfully descriptive way of saying that while Americans can sympathize with individual cases of poverty, and "would never turn their backs on a starving child," it is next to impossible for them to imagine the totality of the problem. Put all these children in one place in the mind's eye, and the reality becomes inescapable. 
 Mr. Bradley's imagery was part of a passionate plea to his party to reaffirm its historic connection to America's underclass. So, too, was his use of another geographical metaphor, in which he noted that the 44 million Americans without health insurance equal all the people living in 12 states between the Mississippi and the Rocky Mountains. But it was also a reminder to affluent Americans of their moral obligation to do something about America's "ill-fed, ill-housed and ill-educated" children. "If we don't end child poverty in our lifetime," Mr. Bradley said, "shame on me, shame on you, shame on all of us."
As he made clear during his unsuccessful primary run against Al Gore, Mr. Bradley does not think his own party has done enough on this score. But it has at least done and promised more than the Republican opposition. Both sides have pledged to devote substantial resources to early childhood education, an important issue to Mr. Gore and almost a signature issue for George W. Bush. The Democrats have also offered proposals like expanding the earned-income tax credit and raising the minimum wage that would quickly put real dollars in the pockets of the poor.
But Mr. Bradley was talking about more than individual programs, however worthy. What he was talking about was the need for a sustained, systematic effort to reach out to the one-fifth of American children living in families making less than $13,000 a year. These are damning statistics in a nation whose convention orators keep congratulating themselves on America's present prosperity, and where the main political debate involves how to spend the giant surplus generated by that affluence. There is no better place to spend that surplus than on the vast city of poverty that Bill Bradley brought to life on Tuesday night.

HEADLINE: Congressman Squares Off With Brooklyn Challenger

SERIES: NEW YORK PRIMARY: 10th Congressional District

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Standing next to the entrance of a Brooklyn subway station on a recent sweltering morning, Representative Edolphus Towns shook hands with the last in a trickling stream of rush hour workers and paused to make an observation about his campaign.
"Last time, I didn't do too much of this," the 66-year-old congressman said of his last primary race, in 1998. "But this time is different. I'm out here, and I'm focused." 
 In that Democratic primary two years ago, he received just 52 percent of the vote, making it the weakest showing of any incumbent member of Congress that year. Now, Mr. Towns, an 18-year incumbent who has been immersed in Brooklyn politics for a generation, is looking for a victory that will be overwhelming.
Unlike that three-way primary in 1998, Mr. Towns this year is facing just one opponent: Barry D. Ford, 37, a lawyer. Mr. Ford came in second to Mr. Towns in that earlier race, with 36 percent of the vote. Virtually since the returns were counted two years ago, Mr. Ford has been working nearly nonstop at a second chance to oppose Mr. Towns.
Mr. Ford, a Harvard graduate who also graduated from the university's law school, says a one-on-one race against the congressman makes his prospects far brighter. He believes Mr. Towns is highly vulnerable.
"This time, I think it is easier for me to win," Mr. Ford said. "But challenging an incumbent is never easy. The fundamental thing I have to do is to become even better known. And I am doing door-to-door and have devised an extensive field operation. This is a ground campaign, and I'm meeting as many people as I can."
While both candidates have put together an army of volunteers and have raised sizable amounts of money, they have each taken to the streets of the 10th Congressional District with a frenzy.
Mr. Ford, in meeting with voters in the heavily Democratic district, lists a battery of complaints against the incumbent congressman. Foremost is highlighting Mr. Towns's 1997 endorsement of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican.
"Given the treatment of the mayor to this particular part of New York City, that endorsement is inexplicable," Mr. Ford said. He also accused Mr. Towns of being silent during the highly public accusations of police misconduct against black and Hispanic New Yorkers.
"He did not participate in any of the protests about Diallo, Louima or Dorismond," he said, referring to two unarmed black men, Amadou Diallo and Patrick M. Dorismond, who were killed by New York City police officers, and to a third black man, Abner Louima, who was tortured in a Brooklyn police station. "And that's because of his cozy relationship with Mayor Giuliani."
Mr. Ford asserts that the congressman's record had been lackluster, complaining that Mr. Towns missed about one in seven votes in his 18 years in Congress. "And in the last 18 years, he has been the prime sponsor of only two bills and two amendments," Mr. Ford said.
He also chastised Mr. Towns for accepting tobacco industry campaign contributions, saying the congressman has voted against restrictions on tobacco use and for federally supported tobacco crop insurance.
Mr. Ford said he would push for more federal money for school construction and teacher training and to begin the process again for an empowerment zone in Brooklyn.
Mr. Towns has acknowledged that his endorsement of Mr. Giuliani has placed him on the defensive in a Congressional district where the mayor received about a third of the vote in the last mayoral election. But he said he was motivated to endorse Mr. Giuliani as a means of gaining his cooperation on securing a federal empowerment zone, where public funds are used to spur commercial redevelopment.
"As it turned out, we didn't get the empowerment zone and so I don't feel good about it," he said of the Giuliani endorsement. "If I had gotten the empowerment zone, it would have been a different story.
Mr. Towns said that at the urging of his staff, he would not accept money from tobacco companies this year. The congressman, a Baptist minister born in North Carolina, said he remained sympathetic to the concerns of the tobacco industry. "When you look at tobacco companies, they are conglomerates that get money from all kinds of businesses," he said. "I have family and friends who are involved in tobacco for their livelihood. It's a complicated issue."
On his work in Congress, Mr. Towns said that he had been an effective congressman and that he had high ratings from labor unions, health care workers and education groups. "I have a 100 percent voting record on every major vote," Mr. Towns said. "Some votes are procedural votes that are less significant. I have an A rating with all of these groups. They must feel that I have the ability to lead."
He added that he was at the forefront on several economic developments in Brooklyn, principally the Metrotech Center, an office complex. Mr. Towns also flashed campaign literature that included an endorsement from Mr. Louima, saying he had been involved in behind-the-scenes meetings with officials at the Justice Department about police abuses.
"That's the way I work," he said. "I don't jump up for the cameras."
Mr. Towns said his 52 percent showing two years ago was largely the result of his having been preoccupied with assisting in the re-election campaign of his son, Darryl C. Towns, a member of the State Assembly. The younger Mr. Towns had faced a bitter campaign against Martin Malave-Dilan, a city councilman and former ally of the Towns family.
While the younger Mr. Towns is once again facing Mr. Malave-Dilan in an Assembly primary, the congressman is not managing that campaign this year. Therefore, he maintained, he will devote more time in the primary against Mr. Ford.
By Mr. Towns's own forecast, he will double what he spent in the 1998 primary, with a plan to spend $600,000 this year. Mr. Ford said he intended to spend about $250,000.
The 10th Congressional District stretches from East New York and Bedford-Stuyvesant through Fort Greene into Brooklyn Heights and Cobble Hill. The district is 56 percent black and about 20 percent Hispanic and 2 percent Asian-American, according to the 1990 census. Non-Hispanic white residents make up 21 percent of the district.
The battle between Mr. Towns and Mr. Ford, unlike high-profile statewide races, will not be waged through television advertising, but by door-to-door campaigning and mailings specifically aimed at voters identified by the candidates as likely supporters. And so it is a typical New York City campaign, almost entirely on the streets.
Mr. Towns said that was the reason he had returned to active campaigning in neighborhoods. "I will meet Barry Ford at every corner, every civic association meeting and every subway stop," the congressman said. "This time, I will be everywhere in this district. And everyone will know it."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2008 words

HEADLINE: Legal Firms Cutting Back On Free Services for Poor

BYLINE: By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
Many of the nation's biggest law firms -- inundated with more business than they can often handle and pressing lawyers to raise their billable hours to pay escalating salaries -- have cut back on pro bono work so sharply that they fall far below professional guidelines for representing people who cannot afford to pay.
The roughly 50,000 lawyers at the nation's 100 highest-grossing firms spent an average of just eight minutes a day on pro bono cases in 1999, according to a survey last month by American Lawyer magazine. That comes out to about 36 hours a year, down significantly from 56 hours in 1992, when the magazine started tracking firms' volunteer hours. Yet with the economy booming, firms are enjoying record profits, the survey also found. 
 "The phenomenon of being so busy that you don't have as much time for pro bono work is quite real," said Jack Londen, a partner at Morrison & Foerster. The San Francisco firm has a long tradition of taking charitable cases, but since the recession of the early 1990's, its lawyers have cut their average pro bono hours in half, the survey showed.
"When there is more work than lawyers to do it, and there are not enough new lawyers out there to hire, the pro bono gets shelved," Mr. Londen said.
The decline is troubling for many in the legal profession, both because of cuts in government-sponsored legal aid programs and because the American Bar Association urges lawyers to do at least 50 hours of pro bono work each year. Only 18 of the 100 firms surveyed reported that their lawyers averaged that many hours or more in 1999, less than half the number seven years earlier.
Even in cities with strong pro bono legacies, where public service is a particular point of pride, the trend has emerged, leading to concern that a cultural shift may be under way. In February, a committee of the District of Columbia circuit court conducted a survey of 142 private law firms in Washington, a center of pro bono activity. Less than 25 percent of their lawyers spent 50 hours or more representing clients who could not pay, it found.
"What we're seeing is a sea change, rather than just a rogue wave," said Eugene R. Fidell, head of an advisory committee of the Federal District Court in Washington.
Since many large firms raised starting pay for new associates by as much as $25,000 this year, hoping to dissuade them from flocking to Internet start-ups, many worry that the ebb in pro bono work will only accelerate.
"We're under pressure to work hard to pay for these rising salaries," said John Payton, a partner at Wilmer, Cutler & Pickering and president-elect of the Bar Association of Washington. "I don't think it's going to wipe out the tradition of pro bono, but it's clearly going to have some impact."
Susan Hoffman, the partner in charge of pro bono assignments at Crowell & Moring, has taken to cornering lawyers in hallways at the big Washington firm. Her e-mail pleas go unanswered, memos no longer work and phone calls leave her colleagues unmoved.
"I know there's somebody out here who has time to do it," she said. "I just have to find that person."
The drop-off in pro bono work comes when the legal community can least afford it, many public interest groups say. Since 1996, the Legal Services Corporation, a major source of representation for low-income people in noncriminal cases, has lost a quarter of its financing from the federal government -- the source of the bulk of its budget -- leading to hundreds of layoffs among its legal staff nationwide.
Also in 1996, Congress prohibited lawyers who get legal-services money from engaging in class-action lawsuits or taking cases on a number of issues, including abortion, illegal immigration and welfare revision. To fill the gap, many say private firms need to increase their volunteer efforts, not retreat from them.
"Without a sustained level of pro bono, a lot of people who need legal advice, or who need their rights protected, are not going to have the same access to justice," said Robert Weiner, the pro bono chairman of the American Bar Association.
As practices shy away from pro bono work, many civil rights lawyers say it is becoming increasingly difficult to find volunteers for cases that would have elicited quick responses years ago. Hilary Chiz, the executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in West Virginia, says she searched for a law firm to represent students who were told to pray in school but had no takers after a year.
"It's a hot issue; it's sexy; it's First Amendment," she said. "I would have thought it would have been easy to place.'
Vera E. Kennedy, 55, is also frustrated by the lack of free legal representation. Ms. Kennedy's apartment is one of about 270 units at Hunter's View, a San Francisco public housing development that the city wants to demolish and rebuild.
When similar buildings were torn down a few years ago, prominent firms made sure residents had adequate interim housing and would be allowed to move back when work was finished. Local public interest lawyers have been scrambling unsuccessfully for months to find a firm to do the same for Ms. Kennedy and the other tenants. "There are mothers with young children here," she said. "They need the protection of having a place to live."
To be sure, civil rights lawyers, advocates and poor people themselves have long lamented the difficulty of finding lawyers with the imposing resources often needed to bring forward big lawsuits. A 1993 study by the American Bar Association showed that less than 30 percent of low-income people who needed a lawyer for a civil matter actually got one -- proof that, even at its best, volunteerism may not solve the legal difficulties of the poor.
"But a problem that was bad in 1993 is only going to be exacerbated by the fact that you have fewer lawyers doing pro bono," said Deputy Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., who has been directed by President Clinton to monitor and promote pro bono work in minority communities.
Not that big firms do all the unpaid work. Small practices and one-lawyer offices take on the bulk of pro bono cases, though their volunteer hours often go uncounted. Many of these lawyers continue to take on a wealth of unpaid assignments, even though they are busy, given recent surges in employment, disability and sexual harassment litigation. But in some rural areas, where small law offices often comprise the entire legal community, many firms have become as preoccupied as have their larger counterparts in cities.
"They can't say yes to everybody," said Angele Court, pro bono coordinator for Vermont's legal services program. "So they say no to the more difficult case."
Representing the poor is an integral part of being a lawyer, ingrained in the profession since its origins in ancient Rome. In the United States, the commitment to pro bono work is in the code of ethics that has governed the profession for nearly a century. For many, the leadership of corporate firms is critical for setting the tone that pro bono work is still more a responsibility than an act of charity.
"The big law firms provide the litmus test for the legal community," said Steven B. Scudder, counsel to American Bar Association's standing committee on public service.
Most firms say it is not their commitment that has waned, just their ability to take on as many cases as in the past. While lawyers typically billed 1,700 hours annually just a few years ago, today they routinely bill 2,200 to 2,300 hours, said Esther F. Lardent, director of the Pro Bono Institute at the Georgetown University Law Center.
The rush of new business has also meant rapid growth within firms, sometimes by as much as 40 percent a year. Practices have sprouted new offices around the country, often in cities where the firms have few community ties. The lawyers hired to run them are so frantically managing busy practices that it will take time before they can branch out and take pro bono cases, firms say.
And it is not as if lawyers are turning their backs on the poor. With more than 150,000 lawyers at their disposal, the top 500 firms still set aside about two million pro bono hours each year, according to the Pro Bono Institute. Some firms are donating more money than ever to legal services organizations to compensate for their declining hours, while 21 of the top 100 firms have stepped up their volunteer efforts, or at least kept them from dwindling.
Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, which in 1999 became the first law firm to gross more than $1 billion in a year, now flies new associates to its headquarters in New York for a pro bono pep talk, gives public-service awards to high achievers and has expanded its placement of lawyers in community organizations for several months at a time. But the firm only began these initiatives after its pro bono hours started to slip in 1998.
"It wasn't a horrible downturn, but it was enough of one," said Ronald J. Tabak, the firm's pro bono coordinator. In the current climate, Mr. Tabak added, keeping up pro bono hours takes a concerted effort, since the demands of paying clients alone occupy far more than a 40-hour workweek and the competition for new lawyers has greatly intensified.
To pay for rising salaries, most firms have raised the minimum number of hours lawyers are expected to bill clients, yet often do not count pro bono work in the totals.
"We didn't want to be in a position where the associates would decide between doing their fee-paying work or not," said R. Bruce McLean, chairman of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Field in Washington. Last year, the firm decided not to credit pro bono time until lawyers billed at least 2,000 hours in a given year.
Some worry that such changes may chill lawyers' willingness to take pro bono cases. Michael Harris, assistant director of the Lawyers' Committee for Civil Rights of the San Francisco Bay Area, says that lawyers who would otherwise take cases are unusually tentative this year, waiting to see how pro bono hours will be treated at bonus time. The cases they do take, he says, tend to be short and easy, lest the lawyers become stuck with long-term commitments that may end up counting against them. "If the people who did pro bono work get rewarded at the end of the year," he said, "the people who have been standing on the sidelines will come back."
But even when volunteer hours are, in theory, given equal weight, some associates feel that their careers will be better served by concentrating on paying clients and steering new business to the firm.
"It's a long race going up the partnership track," said Randi L. Strudler, a partner with Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue in New York. "Rightly or wrongly, not everyone values pro bono work the same as client work."
Since President Clinton asked asked lawyers last year to step up their volunteer service, there have been a number of initiatives to stimulate pro bono work.
One of the leading efforts, called Lawyers for One America, is composed of corporate law firms, law schools and bar associations nationwide. The group, based in San Francisco, seeks to draw from the growing ranks of business lawyers -- the largest segment of many large firms, particularly in Silicon Valley.
Because many corporate lawyers focus solely on transactions and never go to court, they often feel out of place handling the mainstays of pro bono work -- divorces, tenant-landlord disputes or social security cases. Officials at Lawyers for One America and other public interest groups hope to soften that discomfort by matching business lawyers with low-income people looking to start companies of their own.
But they say the concept is only starting to take root at firms, and some question whether the standing of pro bono work has diminished.
"The dollars are so astronomical that they're blinding people to public service," said Teveia R. Barnes, the group's executive director. "It does a disservice to the legal profession and our reputation."

HEADLINE: For Ferry Plans, 1 Nautical Mile Forward, 2 Back

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 16

 BODY:
Every so often a team of market researchers shows up at one or another Metro-North Railroad station to gauge commuters' interest in high-speed ferry service from Connecticut to New York City. And every once in a while, business and community leaders board a boat for a much-publicized test run, like the one in May from Stamford to East 34th Street, to show that the trip can be faster by water than by car or train.
But the vision of a ferry ride from Fairfield County to the financial district, without the clogged traffic on I-95 or a struggle through the harried crowds at Grand Central Terminal, remains unrealized. At least three different companies that are trying to make it a reality have encountered numerous obstacles, from difficulty in raising capital to regulatory bureaucracy to local concerns about parking. 
 One company, SeaConn L.L.C. of New Haven, which initially projected that its planned fleet of super-fast luxury ferries would be launched in the spring of 1999, now says that service will not begin until the end of 2001 or later. Another company, Lighthouse Landings Inc., which currently operates ferries between New York and New Jersey, had hoped to begin Connecticut service this summer but has postponed it until next May or June at the earliest.
And a third company, U.S. Multi-Hull Inc., which had been all set in late 1997 to start fast catamaran service from Norwalk to La Guardia Airport, has dropped that idea, at least for the time being. Instead, the company will focus on a potential ferry run between New Haven and Rye, N.Y., with four stops in between, for commuters who live in one suburb and work in another. But the company's owner, Dale Strand, said he had no idea when that service might begin -- if ever -- and that most likely it would not be profitable without a subsidy from the state.
"We have all been fighting the armies, haven't we," Mr. Strand said of himself and his struggling competitors. "Everybody has a different battlefront I guess." Mr. Strand's effort to start a Norwalk to La Guardia route was stymied by Norwalk officials. Concerned about traffic, parking and environmental problems near the city's Cove Marina, they threatened endless delays for zoning and other approvals.
For the president of SeaConn, Doren Voetch, who has the most ambitious plans, the battle has been raising capital to pay for his vision of a fleet of super-fast "pentamarans," boats built with five hulls for speed and stability. Each boat, with luxurious business class amenities, would cost about $22 million. Mr. Voetch said that he had finally found a backer to finance his first three boats, but that it had taken much longer than he had expected.
The text on the company's jazzy Web site, www.seaconn.com, is overly optimistic: "Coming in the Spring of 2001, the first major advance in transportation in the Connecticut/ Manhattan Corridor in 50 years."
"We're not going to make that," Mr. Voetch conceded. "The Web site has not been updated recently."
Now that the financing is in place, Mr. Voetch faces a barrage of details: legal documents to be drawn up, vendors to hire, bids to consider for building the boats. But the highest hurdle has been cleared, he said. "We have never been more certain that we are going to be in the water and operating."
For cities like Bridgeport and Stamford, the ferries offer easier commuting for residents who work in New York, but they could also make it feasible for residents of New York City or Long Island to take jobs in Connecticut without a miserable commute. And for companies with business relationships on both sides of Long Island Sound, the ferries would allow face-to-face meetings.
"When you look at the rest of the world, if you are in Hong Kong, if you are in Denmark, if you are in many parts of the world, ferry service is part of daily life," said Denis W. Patterson, Stamford's senior executive officer of economic development. "People use it. As a concept, we are very enthusiastic about it and it's been very well received by the business community. There is a tremendous level of excitement here."
Lighthouse Landings Inc. hopes to be the first company to offer Stamford-to-New York service. The company's president, Anthony Cappaze, said it had recently signed a contract with Derecktor Shipyard in Mamaroneck, N.Y., to build the first of three new boats for the Connecticut route.
In addition to the completion of its first new boat, Mr. Cappaze said, Lighthouse Landings was awaiting approval -- another source of potential delay -- from the Connecticut Department of Environmental Protection on numerous issues, including its proposed dock in Stamford.
Mr. Cappaze said that his company's boats, which would hold up to 350 passengers, would travel at speeds of up to 40 knots, or 46 miles an hour. He expected the trip from Stamford to Wall Street would take about an hour, cutting as much as a half-hour off the trip each way for commuters who now take Metro-North and switch to the subway at Grand Central. A ticket for 40 trips would cost about $535, including parking, he estimated.
Mr. Voetch has even grander plans, with even faster boats. SeaConn's pentamarans, with a capacity similar to Lighthouse Landings' boats, have six engines each and are expected to travel at speeds of up to 72 knots, about 83 miles an hour. For a commuter from Fairfield, Conn., who now spends close to two hours getting to Lower Manhattan by train, the trip could be cut to about an hour, Mr. Voetch said; the trip from Stamford would be about 45 minutes.
Mr. Voetch said that a monthly ticket from Stamford would likely cost $637 including parking, but that the ticket would be good for unlimited rides throughout the month. By comparison, a monthly ticket for unlimited rides on Metro-North, for the same route, costs $218.
"We are really developing a whole new culture," Mr. Voetch said. "Our cheap seats are like business class on an airliner. The upper deck, the club deck, is a much higher level of service." He said he believed commuters would pay more to spend less time traveling.
"We're doing something entirely different," he said. "For the first time that I know of anywhere in the world, we are racing the cars and trains in the same direction that they are going and we are winning." Of course, they have to build the boats first.
