SECTION: Section 7; Page 26; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1093 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Were

BYLINE: By Adam Hochschild; Adam Hochschild's most recent book is "King Leopold's Ghost: A Story of Greed, Terror, and Heroism in Colonial Africa."

 BODY:

 AMERICA REBORN
 A Twentieth-Century Narrative
 in Twenty-six Lives.
 By Martin Walker.
 Illustrated. 393 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $29.95. 
 Historians, who write about the past, and journalists, who write about the present, are usually completely different species. But not so in Britain. John Keegan, perhaps the greatest military historian alive, is also defense editor of The Daily Telegraph. Jan (formerly James) Morris spent years reporting for The Guardian and still writes travel pieces, but is also the author of a three-volume history of the British Empire. Even without going as far as Morris, who changed genders as well as genres, few Americans feel at home on the pages of both history book and newspaper. Most American newspapers prefer to hire someone with a graduate degree in journalism rather than history, and our press is the poorer for it.
Martin Walker is in the tradition of literate Britons who didn't stop thinking about history when they took up daily journalism. A former bureau chief for The Guardian in Washington, he has written books on the cold war, Bill Clinton and other subjects. His new book, "America Reborn: A Twentieth-Century Narrative in Twenty-six Lives," reviews 100 years of American history by way of essays on some of the era's key figures, from Frank Lloyd Wright and Duke Ellington to Woodrow Wilson and George Marshall.
Walker's 26 chapters are only in part capsule biographies; they also use someone's life as a springboard to comment on a larger trend or idea. The chapter on Albert Einstein, for example, talks less about him than about the tremendous boost to American intellectual life given by refugees from Nazism -- not just by scientists, but by the Frankfurt school sociologists, the Bauhaus architects and film directors like Fritz Lang and Billy Wilder. The chapter on "Winston Churchill and the American Diaspora" takes a man about whom one would think it impossible to say anything new and points out that he was a product of a late 19th- and early 20th-century fashion: marriages between American robber-baron wealth and British titles. There were over 100 of these alliances, including one between Consuelo Vanderbilt and the Duke of Marlborough, whose final price tag came to $20 million and financed the rebuilding of Blenheim Palace. Walker uses these marriages to reflect on how 20th-century superpower status shifted from Britain to the United States.
A very different kind of archetype is found in Walker's appreciative essay on Emma Goldman. "She became the model for the emerging complicity between the state and the media, which demonstrated the American ability to demonize and thus marginalize its more dangerous dissidents. The judicial authorities named her as a witness, or as a suspect, or as a conspirator in various cases, and the popular press then made her into a symbol of menace to the American way of life. Once the media had made her sufficiently infamous, with her politics and her free love and her defiance of laws against promoting birth control combining into a heady stew of Red lust, further judicial action was made both easier and inevitable. . . . The pattern was to be repeated throughout the 20th century, against militant labor leaders, against Communists and their sympathizers, against civil rights activists and against the antiwar protesters of the Vietnam era." Ironically, it made no difference to Goldman's persecutor, F.B.I. director J. Edgar Hoover, that radicals hated her outspoken, prescient denunciations of Soviet Russia.
Walker looks at his other subjects with a similar eye for the larger pattern -- and for the British comparison. He sees Henry Ford, for example, not as an auto manufacturer but as a systems engineer who refined into a more compact, modern form the first great manufacturing system, the "18th-century British Royal Navy, with its mass-produced ships and cannon, its factories for ropes and sails and barrels." Walker sees the automobile itself as affecting far more than roads and the oil industry: "The automobile transformed the face of the American countryside, making the horse redundant and forcing farmers to grow new crops to replace the hay the horses used to eat. It force-fed a financial revolution to provide the decentralized credit system that allowed customers to buy them." And, as he points out in a later chapter on Katharine Hepburn and Hollywood, Ford's vertical control of manufacturing provided the model for the big studios, which controlled the movie industry assembly line from stars to theaters.
There is no grand theme to this book, which some readers may consider a flaw. But there is a shrewd eye for the significance of people and events we otherwise take for granted, and a consistent undertone of gentle demythologizing. In his chapter on William Boeing, for example, Walker shows that the most important advances in American aviation came not from the lone pioneering inventors celebrated on postage stamps, but from massive government spending during World War II and the cold war. In his chapter on Betty Friedan, he points out that "the real sexual revolution" of the 1960's and 70's was not the erotic one the news media fixated on, but the steady movement of women into the workplace. And writing of Martin Luther King Jr., he shows that King in his last years spoke forcefully against the war in Vietnam and for economic justice, only to be posthumously sanctified by those who represented everything he had fought against. He fell victim, Walker writes, to America's "sublime selectiveness of memory."
Walker's last essay is on Bill Clinton. The 42nd president will be remembered, he says, not for Monica Lewinsky or impeachment, but for his single-minded pursuit of free trade. True enough, although it's a pity the book did not go to press late enough for Walker to comment on the wide discrepancy in recent months between Clinton's public statements about environmental and human rights safeguards, and his private lobbying for trade deals that largely ignore these.
Something else missing from Walker's book is any serious consideration of television and the Internet, which these days are surely as important as arms and diplomacy, if not more so, in spreading American influence abroad. Walker has two generals but no computer industry person, five presidents but no television mogul. But, these quibbles aside, "America Reborn" is a quirky, readable and thoughtful look at the American century by an outsider who knows us very well indeed.

HEADLINE: Risky Business

BYLINE: By Leslie Kaufman; Leslie Kaufman is a business reporter for The Times.

 BODY:

 THE LEAP
 A Memoir of Love and Madness
 in the Internet Gold Rush.
 By Tom Ashbrook.
 295 pp. Boston:
 Houghton Mifflin Company. $25. 
 Who among us has not at least daydreamed about chucking that ho-hum desk job and heading off to join an Internet start-up? It all sounds so adventuresome, so new frontier, so, well, so tantalizingly lucrative.
Few of us, of course, have the nerve to make the jump. But for those who want to experience vicariously the vicissitudes of starting an e-business, there is Tom Ashbrook's alternately informative and overwrought chronicle of his own exploits in the new economy.
The story opens as Ashbrook, a former foreign correspondent who seems to relish danger, is being tempted from his secure but unchallenging job as an editor with The Boston Globe. The bait: a chance to join an old Yale pal in developing a home-design CD-ROM that eventually becomes a Web-site business called HomePortfolio.com.
Almost half the book is taken up by Ashbrook's tortured soul-searching over whether to join the start-up, forcing the reader to plow through the same soliloquy more than once. From Chapter 1: "I had played out the better part of a first career and found some of its limits -- and some of my own. It was time to make the leap." Then three chapters later: "It was time to wade in, I thought. I needed to wade in all the way over my head and come out fresh, come out new." And, again, 60 pages down the road: "So I had a choice. I could stay where I was, hoping the old world would see me through. Or I could jump. I could make the leap to the new world, a new economy." For God's sake, man, just do it already!
When Ashbrook finally commits to his new venture, the book picks up. At its best, it guides us step by step along the rocky path from brainstorming on the back porch to creating a real, live business. Time after time, our novice entrepreneurs are forced to amend and simplify their vision to make it workable. They travel endlessly to persuade skeptical manufacturers to come on board. And they seek help -- advice, solace, cash -- from just about everyone they encounter, from next-door neighbors to Harvard Business School professors.
It is the search for capital to keep the enterprise afloat that forms the leitmotif of the book. Indeed, the hunt for money is all-absorbing -- and often humiliating. Just to meet their meager payroll, our dreamers must prostrate themselves repeatedly before those with fat bank accounts. At one point they call on a former college friend, a television news anchor, who tells them he is eager to help. He never calls back. And so it goes.
The pressure to raise money also takes a personal toll. Ashbrook runs up his credit cards to the maximum and pushes his family's finances to near ruin. His wife -- who makes this adventure possible by providing a regular income, caring for their three children and making ends meet out of dwindling savings -- tolerates his 18-hour days, but she, too, falls prey to anxiety. Once she sends him an e-mail message to explain that the stress has become so overwhelming that she vomited at work. Our hero, who seems to believe that his own selfishness is somehow negated by his candor in acknowledging it, feels her pain -- and then barrels ahead anyway.
Yet despite the ups and downs of the money hunt and the other insights Ashbrook offers into how single-minded one must be to succeed as an entrepreneur, there is still not enough material in "The Leap" to sustain a 300-page book.
Ashbrook seems aware of this, which may explain why he frequently resorts to melodrama. There can be little doubt, for example, that Ashbrook's business dealings were tough on his family. But do we really need to know how, after a fight, his wife tore up the little paper hearts with which she had covered the bathroom mirror for Valentine's Day?
Perhaps the most disappointing thing about "The Leap" is that it is not really about the Internet, as its subtitle suggests. All the difficulties Ashbrook tackles would be familiar to anyone who built a business before the new technology. His narrative ends abruptly just at the moment we might learn about the peculiar problems of running an e-business -- when the money arrives.
In an epilogue, Ashbrook informs us that the company was blessed with $25 million in capital and quickly took on nearly 100 employees. So the Web site will live! But to find out how such a business overcomes obstacles like establishing a customer base, designing an attractive, workable Web site and responding to a flood of new competitors, we will have to wait for someone else's memoir.

HEADLINE: How to Speak Australian

BYLINE: By Annette Kobak; Annette Kobak is the author of "Isabelle," a biography of the 19th-century traveler Isabelle Eberhardt.

 BODY:

 IN A SUNBURNED COUNTRY
 By Bill Bryson.
 307 pp. New York:
 Broadway Books. $25.
 
 SYDNEY
 The Story of a City.
 By Geoffrey Moorhouse.
 292 pp. New York:
 Harcourt. $25. 
 "This is a terrific country," Bill Bryson says to a park ranger in a moment of frank bliss midway through his new book about Australia. (The title is an ironic spin on a line in a patriotic jingle, "I love a sunburnt country.") Such moments of pure compatibility bubble up throughout his travels, which take him by rail from Sydney across to Perth, then to Canberra, Adelaide and Melbourne in the south and Cairns and Darwin in the north. From there he drives cross-country to Uluru (the former Ayers Rock) in the country's desert center. Having imagined Australia from afar as "a sort of 'Baywatch' with cricket" -- which already had its charms -- he fell for the real place on his first visit in 1992: "I liked it, straight off, without quibble or doubt, in a way I had never expected to. Something about it just agreed with me." As a result, the book exudes Bryson's sheer pleasure in the untapped narrative possibilities of this vast island continent.
In return, Australia serves Bryson brilliantly. It is, for a start, a statistician's paradise, and one of Bryson's talents is his way with numbers. Australia is, he reminds us, above all empty: its population of 18 million is less than the annual population growth in China. And while the average world population density is 117 people per square mile, that of the United States 76 and that of Macao a claustrophobic's nightmare of 69,000, Australia's is only 6 -- and even that is skewed because 86 percent of the population bunch together along the coast.
For each man or woman in Australia there are two sheep and over 16 rabbits, the latter introduced in 1859 by one enterprising man who brought 24 wild rabbits from England in an effort to ginger up the landscape and remind him of home. This is only one of the madcap introductions of species that have been effected, like the activities of some demented dating agency, to bring in everything from rampant blackberries to giraffes and camels -- all of which stand as symbols for the way Australia has been plagued throughout its 200-odd-year settlement by weird projections of what kind of a country it actually was and what it should be. And natural things aren't all that run wild, once introduced here. Consider, for example, the "pokies," the hugely popular slot machines. With less than 1 percent of the world's population, Australia has more than 20 percent of its slot machines. That's some statistic.
What appeals most to Bryson, though, is the way that Australia is a genuine, admirable model of normalcy -- the Norway of the Southern Hemisphere" -- played out against a fantasmagorically surreal backdrop that most Australians blithely ignore or play down. The ritual incantation "no worries" has particular charm when set against a background of man-eating crocodiles, ferocious sea rips that "pass you round like an unwanted parcel" and creatures that "seemed to have evolved as if they had misread the manual" -- all of them nicely suited to Bryson's mock-heroic travel writing.
Australia is also home to the oldest continuous culture in the world, one that was probably the first to depict itself, to fish and to make boats and yet whose literally aboriginal significance no one much notices, least of all the Australians themselves. It is a country so vast that a Japanese doomsday sect could mount a dry-run nuclear explosion in the wilderness and nobody twigged until years later. (I have an Australian postcard that vividly shows the sheer size of the place, superimposing a map of Australia over Europe. It stretches from Ireland right over to Moscow, the Black Sea and Turkey.) Australia is a country where a prime minister, Harold Holt, could simply disappear into the ocean, in what Bryson calls the "Swim That Needs No Towel," and hardly be missed.
It was on his quest to find the beach Holt disappeared from that Bryson met that park ranger on a magnificent headland and exclaimed his praise. But it wasn't the splendor of the view that prompted this bliss, it was the utter compatibility of his sense of humor with Australia's. The ranger told Bryson that a memorial had been built in Melbourne to honor the departed prime minister: " 'Know what it was? . . . He grinned very slightly. 'A municipal swimming pool.' 'Seriously?' His grin broadened, but the nod was sincere. 'This is a terrific country,' I said." The thing that Bryson most loves about Australia -- its "effortlessly dry, direct way of viewing the world" -- is, in fact, his own. They're a perfect fit.
Yet underlying the appealing side of the "no worries" Australia is something much darker, which Bryson also anatomizes. He characteristically warms to the fact that "outside the cities it is still 1958" -- which means there are "gas stations with old-fashioned pumps and no canopies over the forecourt, so that you pumped your gas in full sun, as I am sure God intended it." However, keeping the 1950's also means keeping its underside, repression. This has been the bane of Australia since 1787, when Capt. Arthur Phillip loaded up his cargo of petty British convicts and dumped them on the other side of the world. "Never before had so many people been moved such a great distance at such expense -- and all to be incarcerated," says Bryson, moved to Churchillian cadence.
Convict ancestry was until recently a source of unmentionable shame -- called "the Stain." Another aspect of Australia's repression was that the very existence of the Aborigines was blocked off: until 1967 they weren't even counted in the census, and, notoriously, their culture and spirit came close to obliteration. Also on the minus side is the fact that a surprisingly large chunk of English-language literature was banned right up to the 1960's -- and the list of banned books was itself banned, so you couldn't even find out what you weren't allowed to read. Clearly, Australia has had some serious amnesia zones to explore, and this it has been doing over the past generation. In these circumstances, books like Bryson's and that of another "foreigner," the eminent and versatile British travel writer Geoffrey Moorhouse, aren't just tie-ins to the 2000 Olympic Games. They are part of the uncovering of Australia's hidden past.
In "Sydney: The Story of a City," Moorhouse's long opening description of an imaginary mariner -- our sea captain" -- approaching the fabled harbor does have unfortunate colonial echoes, and a rather distancing effect. However, the body of the book is a virtuoso exposition of the gritty layers of social history that have formed Sydney -- the first place where Europeans settled and so, to some extent, a paradigm for the rest of the country.
With a wealth of narrative detail, Moorhouse shows how Sydney has always been, above all, a workingman's town, as cities like London and New York no longer are: "This truth includes all the bloody-minded camaraderie, all the bitterly unforgiven memories, all the crude defensiveness, all the fundamental decency and all the occasional cruelty that goes with the working man's territory. Here is a place where such people fight for what they've got and never, never back down, even though they risk being broken and cast aside. No one can really understand Sydney unless he grasps this fact." Knowing this, we understand why, for example, the first performance at the Sydney Opera House was given for construction workers. Or why, while the government supported America in the Vietnam War with troops, "wharfies" in Melbourne and Sydney occasionally refused to load ships bound for South Vietnam.
Woven into the dense narrative are other telling historical details: how four merino sheep imported from San Francisco in 1793 were the making of Australia's economy; how the gold rushes of the 1850's first attracted the Chinese to Sydney; how it was only in 1975 that Aborigines were legally entitled to own land. (It took 17 more years for the Australian High Court to formally repudiate the concept of "terra nullius," that the Europeans had arrived to colonize an empty land.) Moorhouse also shows how multicultural Sydney -- part of the "last great social melting pot on earth" -- has been layered by immigrants from every one of the countries it engulfs on that postcard map of Europe, and then some. One of the consequences, he writes, is that "for a swelling proportion of citizens, the names of Luting, Dien Bien Phu and My Lai will always be much more evocative than those of Kokoda, Tobruk and Gallipoli." Another of the consequences is that, come September, no team in the Olympics will be short of home support in this most ravishing of cities, whose population already includes almost every nationality under the sun.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 20; Column 2; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1437 words

HEADLINE: American Hero

BYLINE: By Dante Ramos; Dante Ramos is an editorial writer for The Times-Picayune in New Orleans.

 BODY:

 GRANT
 By Max Byrd.
 359 pp. New York:
 Bantam Books. $23.95.
 
 GRANT SPEAKS
 By Ev Ehrlich.
 401 pp. New York:
 Warner Books. $25.95.
 
 THAT FATEFUL LIGHTNING
 A Novel of Ulysses S. Grant.
 By Richard Parry.
 355 pp. New York:
 Ballantine Books. $24.95. 
 Ulysses S. Grant could have ended up a nobody, but he didn't. A West Point graduate, he served with distinction in the Mexican War but quit the Army in 1854 -- or was drummed out for drunkenness, depending on whom you believe. Afterward, he failed spectacularly as a farmer, as a businessman and as a bill collector. When South Carolina became the first state to secede in 1860, the future general and president was a 38-year-old clerk in his father's leather-goods store in Galena, Ill. In other words, he was a ruined man. And then he led the Union to victory.
Or so goes the upbeat version of Grant's life. During his lifetime and ever since, critics have cited the carnage at Shiloh in 1862 and pronounced the general a butcher; they've argued that it was almost inevitable that the industrialized North would defeat the sparsely populated South, no matter who was in charge of the Army; and they've viewed Grant's presidency and subsequent financial troubles as evidence of incompetence and navete.
But a backlash against the backlash is well under way. Recent biographies have shown Grant in a more flattering light. Last year, the Modern Library published a new edition of the "Personal Memoirs" Grant wrote near the end of his life to save his wife from penury. There's even a recent business book -- Cigars, Whiskey & Winning: Leadership Lessons from Ulysses S. Grant" -- that praises his management skills. And now three novels have arrived that depict Grant as an exemplar of timeless values like honor, commitment and diligence.
Three novels about Ulysses S. Grant? Why the sudden fuss? Well, it may simply be that the public's interest in the Civil War is once again on the rise, to judge from the resurgent debate on the use of the Confederate battle flag. What's more, Grant's presidency bears a passing resemblance to Bill Clinton's; like Clinton, Grant endured a series of scandals during his two terms. And perhaps at the turn of the millennium it's only natural to reflect on a leader whose career spanned an era that was, in some ways, more tumultuous than our own.
The simplest of these novels is "That Fateful Lightning," a dramatization of Grant's progress in the field during the Civil War and, later, his struggle to complete his memoirs as his throat cancer worsened. Richard Parry does a credible job of depicting the complex tactical decisions that confronted the general, and here and there you sense the anguish that the historical Grant must have felt about what he put his family through. As Grant fights his cancer, he asks his wife, "Where did our life go, Julia? I seem to have frittered it away." But that's about as poignant as it gets. Parry has also written three novels about Wyatt Earp, and perhaps his style wears better in a western; most of the dialogue here sounds stilted, and the characters are cardboard. Parry has obviously done his research for this novel, and too much of it shows. Little factoids about Grant pop up at all the wrong times.
By contrast, Ev Ehrlich gives himself more room to tinker with the facts, to clown around. His "Grant Speaks" pretends to be a first draft of Grant's memoirs, and it does follow the basic outlines of the historical record. There's one big gimmick, however. In reality, the general was born Hiram Ulysses Grant and acquired the nickname "Useless"; he became Ulysses Simpson Grant (Simpson was his mother's maiden name) through a bureaucratic error. In his novel, Ehrlich stirs things up by inventing a real Ulysses Grant, nicknamed "Useful," who lives in the same Ohio town as the awkward Hiram.
Polished and privileged, Useful wins a spot at West Point but runs away after losing his memory in an accident. So Hiram takes over where the amnesiac leaves off. As a young soldier in Mexico, Grant comes face to face with destiny while tripped out on peyote. A robed horseman named Mescalito appears and prophesies, "Ulysses Grant will lead great masses of men in the glorious cause of their human redemption." But Grant spends the rest of his life wondering whom Mescalito meant, because Useful, who never regains his memory, keeps showing up to remind Useless of his shortcomings. Grant's Civil War victories reassure him that Mescalito's prophecy was meant for him, but the economic crises and corruption scandals that plagued his presidency only amplify his doubts. Ehrlich is an economist by training, and he spent four years as undersecretary of commerce in the Clinton administration. But there's nothing bureaucratic about his populist streak or his prose style, which is breezy and almost effortless. Ehrlich writes about his subject with affection and admiration, and he gives his imagination free rein.
Max Byrd's "Grant," by contrast, is a much more serious, intricate novel. Apart from the numerous flashbacks to the Civil War, nearly all the action happens in the 1880's, when the effects of the war are finally starting to come into focus. "There was a great story waiting for someone to tell it," Byrd writes, "not about the war, but about the reborn nation, on the other side of the war."
Byrd tells that story not through Grant's eyes but through those of Sylvanus Cadwallader, an actual friend of Grant's during the Civil War, and those of an invented journalist named Nicholas Trist, a Union veteran who lost an arm while fighting under Grant's command. (Trist has returned from France to cover Grant's campaign for a third presidential term.) These days, it's hard to conceive of a party convention where the final result is uncertain, but Byrd offers a gripping account of one where it was. In the end, Grant's old slogans -- He hails from Appomattox" -- turn out not to work anymore, and he can't get enough delegates to secure the Republican nomination. For the first half of the novel Byrd leaves the impression that Grant's best days are long past. But naturally, the general turns out to have some fight left in him. His investment firm goes bankrupt because of a partner's treachery, and his fortune disappears with it. So Grant begins writing to earn a living for his family. He secures a book contract for his memoirs with Mark Twain's publishing company. And even as his health deteriorates, Grant will not be dissuaded from his work. "I mean you shall have this book," Grant tells Twain. The general is earnest and determined to the end.
Of course, novels usually turn on impulses that are far more baroque than these, and Byrd adroitly deploys a small ensemble of Washington socialites, journalists and politicians to provide the sins and petty cruelties that push "Grant" along. Henry Adams, who in real life viewed Grant as "pre-intellectual" and "simple-minded," appears here as "a little engine of patrician self-amusement" who is all but blind to his wife's artistic talents. Byrd builds his characters with a remarkable accretion of details -- down to the speed of Clover Adams's hands as they sweep along crowded bookshelves, the quality of her handwriting, the white tissue paper she uses to wrap each of her photographs. The author of novels about Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson, Byrd is an expert at linking the products of his own imagination with historical facts. The fictitious Trist has an affair with a real Pennsylvania senator's wife who was known to get around. All these machinations produce a couple of different results: They make an appealing tale about love and death in late 19th-century America, and they flatter the sturdy, homely general by comparison.
For somebody who grew up with the nickname "Useless," Grant was astonishingly successful. In Byrd's book, the Twain character holds Grant up as an example of "what he called the 'self-invented' man, that strange American ability to be two completely different people in one lifetime." Twain adds that "in the fiery crucible of battle Grant had actually created a whole new self -- a second nature." In an author's note, Ehrlich describes his novel as an attempt to understand "what it means to have a destiny and to be an American." What it means, these three books suggest, is that you can remake and redeem yourself again and again. As you read these novels, you can't help marveling at how a single life can accommodate such extremes of accomplishment and failure -- and how suddenly one turns into the other.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 760 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Michael Molyneux

 BODY:

LONG REMEMBER, by MacKinlay Kantor. (Forge/Tom Doherty, $14.95.) In this Civil War novel, Kantor (at right) tells the story of a man who tries to live as a pacifist in, of all places, Gettysburg, Pa., but is inexorably drawn into the fighting. This is "a very fine book," Peter Monro Jack wrote here in 1934, "a novel that tastes and smells of war." The war's Washington front is examined in ABRAHAM LINCOLN: A Press Portrait, edited by Herbert Mitgang (Fordham University, $19.95). The anthology, with a new introduction, draws on more than 100 newspapers and periodicals from the United States and Europe. Lincoln was a devoted reader of newspapers at a time when they had little pretense of objectivity. The passages "illuminate as only contemporary writings can," Gerald Carson said in these pages in 1971.
 
HEARTS IN ATLANTIS, by Stephen King. (Pocket Books, $7.99.) This sprawling work -- two novellas, two stories and an epilogue -- is permeated by Vietnam and the survivor guilt among those who did not go. "We know now what Stephen King, the master of horror, is afraid of," Caleb Crain wrote here last year, even though, he added, the war itself "remains offstage."
 
TIME, LOVE, MEMORY: A Great Biologist and His Quest for the Origins of Behavior, by Jonathan Weiner. (Vintage, $14.) From his study of the humble fruit fly, Seymour Benzer has achieved great insights into the connections between DNA and behavior, both insect and human. This is "a lovely book about a lovely scientist" and "a wonderful description of biologists at work together," Lewis Wolpert said in the Book Review last year.
 
EMPIRE EXPRESS: Building the First Transcontinental Railroad, by David Haward Bain. (Penguin, $18.) The legendary golden spike was an ordinary iron one, according to this definitive history. From the drawing rooms of magnates like Leland Stanford to the "hell on wheels" where laborers binged, Bain brings an epic project to life. "The building of the Pacific railroad," Robert M. Utley said here last year, has never been recounted "so thoroughly, authoritatively and engagingly."
 
NOTHING BUT THE NIGHT, by Bill Pronzini. (Walker, $8.95.) In this noir suspense thriller set in Northern California, two men are caught together in raging flood waters. One is a vintner tormented by a childhood horror; the other is a trucker obsessed with finding the hit-and-run driver who left his wife in a coma. "It's a dark and twisty road to the big smashup," Marilyn Stasio wrote in these pages in 1999, "but these characters travel well."
 
SISTER WOLF, by Ann Arensberg. (Ballantine, $14.) A daughter of a noble Hungarian family lives alone on 1,000 acres in the Berkshires, which she has turned into a sanctuary for wild animals. "This is a first novel of striking originality," Ella Leffland wrote in the Book Review in 1980, calling it "crisp, urbane, alive with wit."
 
THE PRODUCTIVE EDGE: A New Strategy for Economic Growth, by Richard K. Lester. (Norton, $16.95.) America's standard of living depends on authentic gains in productivity, and the nation has much more to do to get its economy back on track, according to this analysis by a researcher at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The book is "a necessary corrective to all this economic triumphalism," Jeff Madrick said here in 1998, praising its "cogent ideas."
 
I COULD TELL YOU STORIES: Sojourns in the Land of Memory, by Patricia Hampl. (Norton, $13.) This collection of essays explores the art of memoir, as the author moves back and forth between a series of recollections and accounts of reading others' memoirs. Writing in the Book Review in 1999, Linda Simon called Hampl's prose "rich and idiosyncratic."
 
BOY IN THE WATER, by Stephen Dobyns. (St. Martin's, $6.99.) In Dobyns's 20th novel, the headmaster of a failing New Hampshire boarding school investigates a murder on campus. "His prose is fluent and the plot races along like clockwork," Erik Burns said in these pages last year.
 
LIFE THE MOVIE: How Entertainment Conquered Reality, by Neal Gabler. (Vintage, $14.) A cultural critic sees events like the O. J. Simpson trial and the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, as national obsessions that overshadow ideas and ideology. Gabler "has a fine old time showing how entertainment values have come to permeate every nook and cranny of American life," Peter Biskind said here last year. "It is impossible to put down this book unconvinced of the cataclysmic effect of celebrity on every area of American life." Michael Molyneux

PUB-DATE: August 20, 2000

SECTION: Section 6; Page 42; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 3703 words

HEADLINE: Austin, We Have a Problem

BYLINE: By Helen Thorpe; Helen Thorpe last wrote for the magazine about Salon.com.

 BODY:
Earlier this summer, I went for a swim at Barton Springs, a freshwater pool that lies at the geographical and spiritual center of Austin. Under an oak tree, I found Stuart Stevens of the Bush campaign, typing on a Dell laptop. He was writing the script for the video that would be shown at the Republican National Convention. All around him, half-naked kids with ornate tattoos lolled on the grass, working on nothing except their tans.
Austin has always been a city of distinct worlds -- a college town, a state capital and a live-music center all in one. But lately the number of worlds that Austin contains has been multiplying, and now, everywhere you look, there is the spectacle of worldviews clashing. 
 Over the last century, the population of Austin has doubled every 20 years, and in the metropolitan area there are now more than one million residents. Thirty-five thousand people, the equivalent of a fair-sized town, moved here last year alone. And in the last five years, Austin has produced or acquired 17,000 new millionaires. Now an upper class of tech barons lord it over a middle class of state government and university workers; a national Republican campaign machine whirs above a local Democratic power structure; yuppies infiltrate the habitat of punk rockers. It's as if every Austin stereotype has spawned its opposite: easy-going Slackers live beside hard-driving Techies, and old-school liberals drink at the same bars as new-school conservatives.
The magnitude of this transformation was not wholly apparent to me until I spoke with John Thornton in mid-April. Thornton is a general partner at Austin Ventures, the most powerful venture capital firm in town. That puts him at the epicenter of the New Economy. "The rate of change in activity in venture capital has been larger in Austin than probably anywhere else in the country," Thornton told me. "In 1996, venture capitalists spent $67 million in Austin. In 1999, we told people that we thought, Gee golly, $700 million would be spent. The actual number ended up being about $1.1 billion."
The impact of all this new money on Austin is debated endlessly over breakfast tacos and barbecue dinners. Is the laid-back hipster's paradise doomed to become another mess of a big city? People talk a lot about it, but few end up doing anything. An exception, Thornton told me, is a guy named Ross Garber, one of the city's freshly minted tech millionaires. After Thornton introduced us via e-mail, Garber and I arranged to meet at a Starbucks in his neighborhood southwest of downtown. Garber's mild-mannered looks disguise an intense personality. He began his career in the tech corridor along Route 128 in Boston, he told me, and moved with his wife to Austin in 1994. Their reasons for coming, I learned, were remarkably similar to those of most Austin newcomers. Jobs, yes, but also that amorphous allure known as "quality of life." With its bars, bands and barbecue joints, its lakes, parks, low crime and temperate winters, Austin is a lifestyle mecca that attracts all kinds.
Garber and I took a driving tour of Austin when we met for the second time. As we nosed under an elevated highway, we came face to face with a modern-looking fortress of red brick and glass. "That's Vignette," he said, tapping on the window. He helped start Vignette four and a half years ago; today it is the largest e-business software firm in the world. "Vignette has created about $3 billion worth of employee wealth," he noted with pride. Garber himself is 33, and his net worth is somewhere upward of $200 million. On Garber's side of town, brand-new mansions have spread as rapidly as cedar trees across the rolling limestone hills. The recent history of Austin is written on those hills. For a generation, the definition of a political fight was a developer wrestling with environmentalists over how fast the city should grow. Those fights seem almost quaint compared with what's on the horizon.
Because of all the new people, Austin now suffers from world-class traffic jams, polluted air, a serious lack of affordable housing and a school system in disarray. Eager to become part of the solution, Garber recently formed a coalition of tech leaders to hustle a light-rail project through the city's cumbersome political process. "We're like Dorothy, you know?" Garber told me. "We've left Kansas, we're walking down the Yellow Brick Road and we're going to end up somewhere. I'll tell you where it's not going to be -- Kansas. 'Cause we ain't going back. We're either going to the Emerald City, or we're going to the witch's castle to fly around on green brooms." The Oz rhetoric may be overblown, but Garber's perspective on Austin -- that its extreme rate of growth threatens to wipe out the very qualities that attracted people in the first place -- may be the one notion that finds support across the city's disparate worlds.
Of all the pretty state capitals, of all the funky university towns, only Austin also plays the role of Nashville's little sister. Music, not high tech or politics, put this town on the map. Barbara MacDonald, better known as Barbara K, is a central figure in local music circles, and I caught up with her one night in May at a club called the Speakeasy. She had a black guitar slung at hip level, and was jamming on a song from her solo debut. Barbara K used to be in a band called Timbuk3, which had a hit called "The Future's So Bright I Gotta Wear Shades."
That was in 1986, four years before the movie "Slacker" came out, and Austin was in the grip of a profound economic malaise. Rent "Slacker" today, and it's like flipping through a scrapbook of how much has been eradicated in one busy, busy decade. Gone are the vacant lots, the Quack's coffee shop near campus, the bookstore staffed by J.F.K. conspiracy nuts. Gone is Les Amis restaurant, where one character snapped: "To hell with the kind of work you have to do to earn a living!" Today the local paper publishes breathless stories about $500 bottles of wine.
On the surface, it would seem as if the boom has been kind to people like Barbara K. She lives in a large, rambling house, bought with money from recording deals. The place is now worth almost three times what she paid for it. Most days, she considers herself lucky, but not when she gets her new property tax statement. "Oh, man, I got slammed so hard," she told me. Next year, she will owe $800 per month in property taxes alone. And though Austin still brags that it is "the Live Music Capital of the World," for most musicians, acquiring property in town has become impossible. Bukka Allen, who plays accordion on Barbara K's latest CD, recently bought a house in Buda, 13 miles south of Austin. He's part of a silent diaspora, one of countless musicians who have been forced out by the boom.
Meanwhile, the maker of "Slacker," Richard Linklater, has appropriated technology for his own ends. He is working on an animated feature called "Waking Life." When I visited him at Detour Filmproduction, every room was filled with artists sitting in front of Macintosh computers, transforming film footage into animated action. "It's very human," said Linklater of the results. "It's a great marriage of film and computer. I think Austin is the kind of place where that cross-pollination can happen." On the other hand, Linklater doesn't think he could start out here today. "I came to Austin 16 years ago. My rent was $133 a month, all bills paid, and I could live on $3,500 a year. So I spent all my time watching movies, editing, shooting. Film students are like, How do you do it? I don't know. If you have to work all day just to pay your rent, I don't know. If I was just starting out now? Might go to San Antonio."
People moving here today come for different reasons. In June, I drove out to a fancy subdivision named Rob Roy, up in the hills. It was a bone-dry, brilliant day. In almost every vast and perfectly manicured front yard, brown-skinned men clipped and trimmed and dug. The houses were ridiculously large, like caricatures of houses. Parked in the driveways were Porsches, Jaguars, Mercedeses and all manner of S.U.V.'s. Within minutes, a green Audi was tailing me. Security. The driver snapped photographs with a little digital camera. I don't know what he saw; what I saw was the balance of things shifting.
Unlike the rest of Texas, Austin has always been a place where what mattered most -- music, film, education, public policy -- was supposedly motivated by concerns that were not entirely commercial. Now Austin has developed an indigenous business scene. First came Dell, later Tivoli, Trilogy and Vignette. These days Austin has a 1.9 percent unemployment rate and has been named the best city in the country for doing business by Fortune and Forbes.
Day-to-day living, however, has become harder for a lot of people. The public schools, for example, used to be considered pretty solid; now the Austin Independent School District struggles to keep up with the profound population shifts. For every new computer programmer who arrives in town, a gardener, a housecleaner and a couple of construction laborers follow. In recent years, the greatest job growth has been not in the software industry but in the restaurant sector: busboys, dishwashers, short-order cooks, waitresses. These service workers are generally poor -- their incomes have not kept pace with the rising cost of living -- and the school system struggles to find a place for their children. One thousand new kids converge on schools in the southern part of the district every year.
One bright spot is Travis High School, which, by all rights, should be a catastrophe. Travis is a hodgepodge of yellow brick buildings that stand alongside I-35, on the edge of East Austin, which is the poor side of town. The student body is 90 percent minority, 80 percent low-income. So many students get pregnant that there is a waiting list for their infants to get into the nursery that Principal Nelda Howton set up. I met with Howton in May. She has a blond bob and was wearing a lemon-colored linen dress, but she's a lot tougher than she looks. Her job includes figuring out whether her students have a place to sleep, food to eat, responsible parents to watch over them. "We had a kid who had been receiving assistance for diabetes," she told me. "Turns 18 and it's cut off. Well, the kid kept not coming to school, and we find out it's nothing except he can't get out of bed because he's in a comatose state. Then we had to get him back on insulin."
Four years ago, Howton was working as a principal of a middle school in Temple, about 60 miles away, when she heard that Austin was looking for a high school principal -- a step up, she thought. "I didn't know that I was coming to this school," she sighed. "I cried when I saw it. There was graffiti everywhere; we had two kids shot outside; lots of gangs, lots of gangs." Howton took the job anyway; after studying what 21st-century high schools were supposed to look like, she realized that she couldn't possibly afford to create such a place on her budget and set up a foundation to accept donations of money and equipment. Howton is good at marketing. She says what she thinks, uses plain English and tells stories that deliver an emotional wallop. So when she set up meetings with executives at companies in town, they responded generously -- particularly hardware companies like AMD and 3M.
Howton looked at what was happening in Austin and decided to start classes in C++ and Java computer languages, and set up a multimedia lab where students build Web sites. (They were doing one for the L.B.J. ranch when I visited.) She filled classrooms with orange and aqua i-Macs, got every kid an e-mail address and wired up the shabby brick building with fiber-optic lines. She marched me down the hallway to show me the black Novell servers stacked in an old janitor's closet. It's a blinking, glowing declaration of progress where you'd least expect to find it. Since the servers were installed, there have been no gang problems at Travis. "A lot of it was consistent discipline, but the other thing was getting the kids to believe they can do something," Howton said. In the multimedia lab, Howton introduced me to Sylvia, who moved to Austin from Nicaragua at age 4. Her mother cleans houses for a living. This year, Sylvia won first prize in the South by South West contest for student-designed Web sites. Another student finished school and got a job making $65,000 a year at a local software firm.
Howton's work is inspirational, but it hardly seems like a replicable model -- based as it is on the extraordinary force of her personality. And money's getting tighter. This year, for the first time, Austin has been declared a "property rich" district, which means it has to give away $26 million in revenues to poorer districts in the state, and to forgo $22 million in financing that it formerly received. The law is intended to take money away from affluent students and give to students of need, but that's not the effect it's having in Austin.
Superintendent Pat Forgione arrived in town 11 months ago and can't believe his lot. When I met with him in June, he jumped up off a couch in his office and grabbed a binder of statistics to illustrate the differences between Austin and other "property rich" districts. "If you take the percent that are considered 'disadvantaged,' in the typical district, it's a quarter of their kids," Forgione said. "We're double that. Notice 'at risk.' That means truant, absent, bringing guns, don't have parents, those issues. The average is 24 percent -- we're 42 percent. The average property-rich district has one out of six students for whom English is not the first language. We're one out of four!" This is the paradox of the boom: people like Ross Garber build luxury homes on one side of town, while the other fills up with poor kids and suddenly there's $48 million less to spend on education.
Austin's politics have been changing right along with the economy. Mayor Kirk Watson represents a fusion of old and new priorities and has earned a reputation as perhaps the most effective mayor in memory. Early in May, Watson wooed the New Economy crowd at a mixer to raise money for his re-election. Watson wore a white ruffled shirt, charcoal bow tie and gray tuxedo pants as he stood on the steps of a limestone mansion that belonged to Jeff Garvey, chief administrative partner of Austin Ventures. Venture capitalists and software C.E.O.'s lined up to shake Watson's hand, then write him a check. It has been a difficult constituency to seduce. Many hardware companies have a long tradition of civic engagement. But the software types are younger, more arrogant, less responsible. Their start-ups also have no tradition of corporate philanthropy, and few, if any, local clients.
National politics has a certain luster to it, and many of Austin's tech lords have gotten swept up in George W. Bush's bid for the White House. Two local tech stars, the hardware king Michael Dell and the software guru Steve Papermaster, have formed a team of high-tech executives to advise the campaign; I spotted both of them at a recent gathering of the team at the Dell Jewish Community Center. Back in 1998, Papermaster gave a party for 500 at his mansion in Rob Roy to introduce Bush to the local tech crowd. Later, Papermaster squired Bush around Silicon Valley, helping make connections and raise money. "Directly and indirectly, it's certainly been in the millions -- many millions," said Papermaster of the sums he has delivered to the Bush campaign. Papermaster went to U.T. and used to hang out at the Armadillo World Headquarters. Doesn't he think it's weird that this liberal enclave should become the launching pad for a possible Republican presidency? "Austin has changed from being a purely liberal city into being more centered, though still with a liberal bent," asserted Papermaster. "It's a place that has aggressively embraced growth. And that reasonably approximates the governor's philosophy. It's not a clash. It's closer to a parallel, and perhaps even a convergence."
Stuart Stevens agrees that the mellow gestalt of Austin has influenced the Bush camp. "Being in Austin creates a nonhierarchical campaign," he said. "There's a certain lack of self-importance. Nobody at the Bush campaign cares about wearing ties. Nobody worries about getting in the gossip columns, because there aren't any gossip columns."
As for local affairs, the various tasks of making a city function, well, that just isn't as sexy, compared with national politics. Earlier this year, at a gathering of local software C.E.O.'s called the Austin 360 Summit (which Papermaster helped start), Mayor Watson delivered an impassioned speech about the challenges facing the city. While the mayor was talking, a baby-faced C.E.O. raised his hand. "Why are you looking at us to help with these community issues?" asked the software C.E.O. "That's your job."
Just when it seemed as if the tech barons deserved to be cast as villains, matters took an unexpected turn. Last year, after Vignette went public, Ross Garber sold a large amount of stock, turned down a bunch of job offers and spent nine months wondering what to do with his time. "I always thought if I won the lottery I would retire and go to the beach for the rest of my life," he said. "But you find out that it's really hard, because it's isolating, and you can't retire at 33. Retire is a word for when you're like 65 and you go to Miami to play mah-jongg."
In March, Garber was sitting in traffic when his cell phone rang. It was Lee Walker, whom he knew from the 360 Summit. Walker is Old Austin (he has shoulder-length white hair and wears a suede hat) but possesses a New Austin resume (he was the first president of Dell). He's now the volunteer chairman of Capital Metro, the city's public transportation system.
Walker approached Garber with a small request. In November, the city was going to vote on whether to build a light-rail system. By law, Capital Metro could not campaign for the ballot initiative. And the idea faced stiff opposition from people like Gerald Daugherty, a conservative figure in Old Austin circles who had formed an antirail group called Reclaim Our Allocated Dollars, or ROADS.
"I need a high-tech poster boy," Walker told Garber.
In Texas, light rail is a deeply countercultural idea. Natives consider the pickup truck roughly equivalent to the American flag in symbolic value, and public transportation a Kremlinesque conspiracy to undermine their way of life. But Dallas, of all places, built a light-rail line that has proved surprisingly popular, and now Austin's leaders were convinced that they could, too.
Garber had his doubts about working with Old Austin. "The pace thing is hard, it's very frustrating," Garber told me. "Most of the tech guys are working with huge Wall Street pressure. They're not going to come to a four-hour meeting once a week for nine months and finally decide who's going to get to make a decision." But he had more time now, and he'd been looking for a cause. Garber formed a team of techies to consider light rail. John Thornton joined it, and so did Steve Papermaster, among others. Light rail was imperative, the group determined; the city's air was becoming so dirty that it would soon violate federal health standards. Garber got all fired up. "I'm not a train hugger," he vowed. "But this place is exploding."
Garber then embarked on something that might be called a 21st-century political campaign. Early in May, we drove past rainbow-colored bungalows smoldering in the heat in search of Garber's billboards. Downtown, Garber spotted one: MORE TRAFFIC AHEAD. PERIOD. The black letters leapt from a green metallic background, and a small oval depicted train tracks receding into the distance. We headed over to I-35, a main north-south artery. A yellow billboard announced: FREE PARKING AVAILABLE ON I-35. Then we drove west. Metallic blue, same train logo. TRAFFIC BITES. BITE BACK.
Garber liked his handiwork. "Aren't the colors great?" he asked.
The colors were great, the look was clean, the lines were snappy. But what really got my attention was this imported fondness for rail. By choosing mass transit as their cause, the techies were picking a fight with Austin's traditional business groups, the real estate developers, car dealers, and oilmen who have always loved highways. Garber himself went through culture shock. "Different language, different pace," he reported. "With Old Austin, the art is the process -- the listening, the communicating, the cajoling, the time it takes. In tech, you just don't work that way."
It had been clear what would happen if the tech people had remained secluded in their parallel universe. This dusty Eden would turn into another Silicon Valley, then everybody who could afford to would move on to the next paradise. But what if Old and New Austin learned to work together instead? This was what was so promising about the rail project: maybe someday Austin could become the kind of place where the private sector gets involved and stays involved, instead of just sitting idly by while the public sector falls apart. A school like Travis might become the rule, not the exception.
But as time passes, the balance of things keeps tilting the other way. In July, Nelda Howton gave up. The buzz around Austin was that she wasn't appreciated sufficiently. Howton said that wasn't true. "I couldn't get to work!" she told me. She lives in a town called Salado, and she used to be able to get to work in 45 minutes. But as Austin kept expanding, her commute did, too, until it swelled to two hours. "I was spending 20 hours a week on the road," she said. There was a lightness in her voice, as if some great frustration had eased. She was going to open a brand-new school in Killeen, about 60 miles from Austin, and now it would be somebody else's job to worry about whether the children of Austin's housekeepers and gardeners and short-order cooks had food, or beds, or access to modern marvels like the i-Mac.

Austin's powers: Thornton, the venture capitalist; Garber, the millionaire and rail champion; Howton, the wired principal. (Jennifer D. Small for The New York Times)

PUB-DATE: August 20, 2000

SECTION: Section 11; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 1387 words

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
Luxury Rentals Rising on North Bergen Shoreline

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: NORTH BERGEN

 BODY:
WHILE much of the land along the 18-mile Hudson River shoreline has sprouted housing in the last few years, a 10-acre slice of waterfront in this Hudson County township has long sat dormant except for a stand of cattails that swayed to the river breezes.
Now the site, which juts out to the river across from the West 70's in Manhattan, is filling with the first of two planned luxury rental buildings that will contain 507 one- to three-bedroom apartments, some with terraces. Each of the 12-story beige-brick buildings will have a health club and parking garage. 
 The project is called Half Moon Harbour, a name that refers both to the shape of part of the site and to Henry Hudson's sailing ship. The developer, the Barrett Companies of Fort Lee, is proceeding after six and a half years of debate and legal haggling over neighbors' concerns about the project's density and its impact on traffic and Manhattan skyline views, among other issues. An out-of-court settlement ended the debate in 1998.
The total development cost of the project is estimated at more than $20 million. The architect is the Edgewater firm of Cybul & Cybul. Construction of the first building is nearing completion and leasing of its 176 apartments is to start this fall.
Though projects in other Hudson County riverfront towns, like Jersey City or Hoboken, as well as Edgewater in neighboring Bergen County, have attracted more attention, Half Moon Harbour will be only the second housing development to rise on North Bergen's quarter-mile waterfront. It will also occupy one of the last large tracts at the river's edge there.
During the 1980's building boom, the site was owned by another developer, who hoped to put up a various types of housing on it, including three 17-story buildings. But only 70 town houses were built on an adjacent riverfront parcel before the developer ran into financial difficulties and lost the property through tax and mortgage foreclosures.
Twenty-eight unsold town houses in that 70-unit development, called Roc Harbor, were eventually sold by the lender to investors. By late 1994, the Barrett Companies had bought or contracted to buy the four individual parcels that make up the 10-acre Half Moon Harbour site for what Thomas Barrett, the company's president, would only say was a reasonable price.
Of the ensuing legal wrangling, he said, given the site's location and potential, "it was worth fighting for." This is the first riverfront housing project for the company, which has built residential and commercial developments in New Jersey and New York.
For North Bergen, an ethnically diverse community of 55,000 people with an annual median income of $33,000, the Half Moon Harbour project is part of a delayed economic turnaround. With limited waterfront land, the 5.5-square-mile township -- which, like Union City, its neighbor, was noted more as a center for embroidery than shipping -- missed out on the mid-80's construction boom. As other riverfront towns gentrified, North Bergen's chances to boost its declining economic base were stymied by an inadequate road and transportation system. By 1985, the township was basically bankrupt and the state took over its finances.
BUT since then, North Bergen, which has both modest single-family houses and high-rise towers on the Palisade cliffs, has been trying to turn around its image, both as a place to live and to do business. In the last several years, it has made some strides.
"It was time for the township to change and to take advantage of the strong economy," said Mayor Nicholas J. Sacco, who is also a state senator. But the goal, he said, is that the community rebound in a way that benefits its residents and builds on the distinct character of each of its neighborhoods.
In the last few years, North Bergen has received $100 million in public money to improve its roads, primarily three overpasses on which work has begun or will begin soon. Projects, representing $200 million in private investment, are also in various stages of development throughout the township that will produce some 800 residences and 500,000 square feet of commercial space, said Joseph R. Auriemma, the township's administrator.
One completed project is Columbia Park, a 350,000-square-foot retail center that includes a Shop Rite supermarket and a movie theater on 17 acres on Kennedy Boulevard. It replaced a small supermarket, a billiards parlor and the remnants of a failed housing project.
Plans are advancing for several other projects, including a 300-unit rental complex, which will rise on a full block where an old warehouse now stands. Developers also want to replace a hodgepodge of industrial and commercial uses along a 10-block stretch of Tonnelle Avenue, a main commercial thoroughfare, with big-box retailers such as Lowe's, the hardware chain. And beyond Half Moon Harbour, an assisted-living development for the elderly is being planned for 2.5 acres on the waterfront.
"Something had to be done on the waterfront," Mr. Auriemma said, noting estimates that the Half Moon Harbour project, when completed, will generate slightly more than $1 million in new tax revenue to the township a year.
Even before Barrett bought the site, there had been opposition to the earlier developer's plan for it, particularly putting up the three 17-story buildings. which objectors said would shrunk the views of Manhattan for people living on the Palisade cliffs. So when his company became interested in the site in 1992, Mr. Barrett said he negotiated with the key objector, the North Bergen Action Group, for the project's current scale. And the township preserved land on the top of the cliffs for a public park.
But in 1994, neighboring property owners -- the 70-unit Roc Harbor condominium and the smaller Evelyn Estates condominium -- objected to the Barrett plan. The condominiums in several lawsuits contended among other things that the buildings blocked views and would worsen traffic and that Barrett should meet certain obligation unfulfilled by the earlier developer, including providing amenities. They also contested the township's 1997 rezoning of the site. Barrett countersued.
After four years of litigation the parties hammered out what Joseph Ferriero, a lawyer who represented the condominiums, called a "good settlement."
Mr. Barrett said while the litigation cost his company time and money, the delay could work to the benefit of the project because the waterfront has progressed. As proof he pointed to the thousands of square feet of retail space that has gone up in neighboring Edgewater.
THE project's first building is nearing completion when, despite a slowing in the state's housing market, there continues to be a demand for waterfront rentals. Lennard Schwartz, who owns Smart Realty in Edgewater, said the demand was coming mainly from young professionals "who want views, access to ferry service to Manhattan and new product."
But rents "are starting to stabilize until everyone gets a handle on the impact of the new inventory," which will take time to absorb, he said. On average, a typical one-bedroom, 850-square-foot apartment rents for $2,000 a month, he said.
Mr. Barrett said, and Mr. Schwartz agreed, that Half Moon Harbour was distinct from the mostly low- and mid-rise riverfront projects now leasing from Weehawken north to Fort Lee and therefore "not in direct competition."
The one- to three-bedroom apartments in the first building will have 750 to 1,500 square feet of space. There will be 15 different apartment layouts available. To start, rents will range from $1,600 to $4,700 a month. The first building, like the second, which will have 331 apartments, will be placed at an angle to lessen their impact on neighbors' views from the Palisades and maximize those of tenants.
Each building will be connected by a causeway to a three-story parking garage. Atop each garage will be the amenities planned for the buildings, including a health club with a swimming pool and one or two tennis courts. There will also be a riverfront walkway, which is a state requirement for all projects within 500 feet of the water's edge.
Mr. Barrett said the first building would be completed in December. He will start the second building once the first is half rented.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Available Through a Federal Program;
Discount Houses For Teachers

 BODY:
The federal government has come forward with a way to enable schoolteachers to buy a house at a bargain price -- if it's in the right place.
The place has to a neighborhood that the government defines as economically distressed. The Department of Housing and Urban Development has no shortage of houses that it has acquired in those areas through mortgage defaults. Through its Teacher Next Door program, it is now offering them to teachers through a bidding process at 50 percent of the appraised value. 
 If the buyer chooses to obtain financing through HUD, only $100 in cash is needed for the down payment, and closing costs are paid through the mortgage. Teachers normally have to work in the school district where the house is purchased, but New York City is an exception. Under the program it is considered one school district.
The HUD regional office said that there are 53 qualifying areas in New York City, and about 50 in surrounding counties. The sales in these communities came to about 45 houses over the last eight months.
The program is similar to another called Officer Next Door, which does for police officers what HUD is now trying to do for teachers.
For more information, call (800) 217-6970, or go to the Web sites www.hud.gov/teacher or www.firstpreston.com, where information about the houses is available.

HEADLINE: A Senate Candidate in a New Spotlight

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL

 BODY:
WHEN Waterbury's Mayor, Philip A. Giordano, announced earlier this year that he would run against Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, state Republican party leaders and Gov. John G. Rowland tried to talk him out of it.
They advised Mr. Giordano that Mr. Lieberman was a formidable foe for an obscure mayor of a moderate-sized Connecticut city who had no hope of raising anything close to the millions that were already in the Senator's campaign chest. 
 But in Connecticut there was no one else willing to take on Mr. Lieberman, a two-term incumbent with a 74 percent approval rating in most polls and a reputation as a centrist Democrat with a moderate image that had attracted Republican and independent voters.
And that was before Vice President Al Gore picked Mr. Lieberman as his running mate for the November presidential election.
When Mr. Lieberman was suddenly thrust into the national spotlight, so was his little-known opponent in the Senate race. Mr. Giordano gained prime media coverage and at the same time picked up an obvious campaign issue -- why is Mr. Lieberman running for both vice president and re-election to the Senate at the same time? And what kind of message does that send to Connecticut voters?
"I'll tell you what kind of message it sends: by running in both races he's making Connecticut a consolation prize and telling voters how little confidence he has in the Gore-Lieberman ticket," said Mr. Giordano, a 37-year-old lawyer serving his third two-year term as mayor of Waterbury, a city of 104,000 that is the fourth largest in the state.
Describing himself as a "true conservative" driven to win a race he is still told is not winnable, Mr. Giordano said, "I love the state of Connecticut and would never use it as a consolation prize the way Mr. Lieberman is in this race."
Mr. Giordano, who was born in Caracas, Venezuela, came to the United States with his family at the age of 5. He grew up in Waterbury, attended the city's schools and, after spending four years in the Marine Corps, graduated from the University of Connecticut with a degree in political science and history.
After earning a law degree at the Thomas M. Cooley Law School in Michigan, Mr. Giordano returned to Waterbury where he worked as a legal assistant for the corporation counsel's office in the early 90's, and was soon promoted to assistant to the corporation counsel. He also opened his own law practice in 1992.
In January 1995 Mr. Giordano was elected as state representative from the 71st General Assembly District and shortly afterward, at the age of 32, was elected mayor of Waterbury. He has been twice re-elected since then.
Before the two-race issue landed in his lap, Mr. Giordano concentrated on trying to make the case that Mr. Lieberman was much more liberal than voters had been led to believe.
"For 12 years he has gone unchallenged, and we want to expose his liberal voting record for what it truly is," said Mr. Giordano. "He can't go around saying he's a moderate and against things like partial-birth abortions and then vote against a bill that would ban them."
Dan Gerstein, communications director for Mr. Lieberman, dismissed Mr. Giordano's comments as "pure hogwash." "When you're 55 points behind in the race I guess you having nothing left but meaningless personal attacks," said Mr. Gerstein.
Addressing the question of why Mr. Lieberman was running two races, Mr. Gerstein said: "To withdraw from the Senate race at this late juncture would create tremendous chaos in the party and lead to an un-democratic democratic process of selecting another candidate. We believe very much that the Gore-Lieberman ticket will win in November, and then a special election can be scheduled for selection of a permanent replacement in the Senate."
The State Attorney General, Richard Blumenthal, has ruled that under Connecticut law candidates can run for both vice president and the United States Senate, just as two former Texas senators did while running for vice president -- Lyndon B. Johnson in 1960 and Lloyd Bentsen in 1988.
But Mr. Lieberman would not be allowed to serve in both capacities. If he is elected vice president, Governor Rowland, a Republican, would be able to appoint a member of his party temporarily to the vacant Senate seat until a special election could be held.
Governor Rowland has refused to speculate on who he would appoint to replace Mr. Lieberman, insisting it will be a "non-issue" because he expects George W. Bush to win the November election.
Governor Rowland's press secretary, Dean Pagani, said that while the Governor was initially skeptical about Mr. Giordano's bid to unseat Mr. Lieberman, "he now fully supports him" and has made appearances with him around the state.
While it is unclear whether a special election could be scheduled early in 2001 in the event Mr. Lieberman is elected vice president, the Secretary of State, Susan Bysiewicz, has indicated that the state's Democratic controlled legislature could pass a bill to allow a special United States Senate election in November 2001.
Connecticut Democratic party leaders, including the state chairman, Edward L. Marcus, and Senator Christopher J. Dodd, have encouraged Mr. Lieberman to run in both races for two reasons: if he and Mr. Gore lose he obviously still provides the Democrats their best chance at retaining the Senate seat, and if he wins he gives his party more time to find a suitable candidate.
"None of us can say with absolute certainty what's going to happen in 12 weeks," Mr. Dodd recently told The Hartford Courant. "And I think the people of Connecticut would like to have the option of having Joe as their senator if the ticket doesn't prevail, and would be thrilled if he were elected vice president and had to then choose another candidate for the Senate.'
That view is not shared by Mr. Giordano and his staff, who are nonetheless happy to take advantage of an issue they believe they can use relentlessly throughout a campaign they insist they can win.
"I think the voters of Connecticut would prefer to have Mr. Lieberman here at home defending his record of flip-flopping and trying to pass himself off as a moderate while his voting record is clearly liberal," said Mr. Giordano's campaign manager, Tim Longino. "He can't be running around the country telling people he's a moderate while voting for the country's largest tax increase ever in 1993 that included a gas tax that is coming back to haunt us now."
Mr. Giordano said another key campaign issue would that while Connecticut ranks first out of the 50 states in providing per capita tax revenue to Washington, it is last in what it receives in federal dollars.
"I think as one of the Connecticut's United States senators, serving for 12 years now, that Mr. Lieberman has to accept some responsibility for the dismal fact that Connecticut has placed 50th, that's dead last, in federal tax ratio," said Mr. Giordano, who likes to take credit for "making the tough decisions" that he says have started to turn around the faltering economy of his city.
He says he is most proud of having produced three consecutive balanced budgets in Waterbury without raising taxes, and of cutting crime by 25 percent by increasing the police force.
Those who know Mr. Giordano best say it would be a mistake for his opponent -- even a vice-presidential candidate with national stature -- to underestimate him the way former Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. underestimated Mr. Lieberman in 1988. That's when Mr. Lieberman stunned the three-term incumbent despite polls at one time showing him more than 20 points behind.
"I've known Phil for more than a decade and when he decides he wants something and that it's important he usually gets it," said Angela Juliani, a partner in his Waterbury law firm. "When he announced he would run for mayor in 1995 few people gave him any chance to win. I'm hearing the same thing now about this race and I know better than to ever say Phil Giordano can't do something, no matter how long the odds."
