HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Windsor Locks, Conn.;
Bradley Airport Is Getting $200 Million Expansion

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
WHEN Robert F. Juliano arrived at the Connecticut Department of Transportation, Bradley Airport in Windsor Locks was a single terminal surrounded by tobacco fields. There were no security fences or checkpoints and only a few domestic carriers servicing the field, which is about 20 minutes north of Hartford.
"At that time, we were hoping to get up to a million and a half passengers," said Mr. Juliano, who is now the chief of the department's Bureau of Aviation and Ports. "Now, we're probably going to break seven million this year." In June, almost 646,000 passengers arrived at or departed from Bradley, up 26.5 percent from a year earlier. 
 Airport and business officials hope that a $200 million expansion under way that will add a terminal, concourse and parking garage will not only accommodate the airport's double-digit growth but also make Bradley International Airport, as it is now known, a portal to more international destinations. The airport now has regular flights to Canada and charters to the Caribbean.
"If Bradley could draw the same percentage of international travel as it does domestic travel in its market area, it would have 600,000 passengers a year going to Europe; that would be enough for four flights a day," said Dean B. Hill, executive vice president of Campbell Hill Aviation Group in Alexandria, Va., a consulting firm. "Bradley's share of domestic flights is already growing far beyond national average. That shows Bradley is attractive when the services are there. We'll use that when we talk to international carriers."
Local officials, meanwhile, say that Bradley has become the driver of the economy in the former farming communities that surround it and they are hopeful that the expansion will bring more development.
Edward A. Ferrari, a Windsor Locks first selectman, said that since the 1960's the airport had attracted chain restaurants, hotels, parking services, gas stations and other services. But two years ago, Federal Express opened a large operation there, and the town is talking with a large trucking company that wants to put in a terminal and a developer who has proposed a conference center.
"It's going to have a gigantic spinoff effect for the town," Mr. Ferrari said. "We're constantly looking and talking. Those are the kind of projects that we're trying to woo into town."
Peter M. Gioia, an economist with the Connecticut Business and Industry Association, said that the economic impact from Bradley's expansion reached throughout Connecticut. One study, by the University of Connecticut Center for Economic Analysis, found that for every million passengers, Bradley generated $100 million in economic activity for the state and created 2,500 jobs.
"If I were to create a list of things that have a significant potential economic upside for Connecticut, Bradley is going to be right at the top," Mr. Gioia said.
Bradley, which opened during World War II as a military airfield, is named for Lt. Eugene Morris Bradley, who died in a training accident there on Aug. 21, 1941. The first commercial flight was in 1947, and the airport came under state control in 1948.
The last major modernization project was in 1982, when the state spent $100 million to add a new terminal and concourse and other improvements. Since then, airport use has grown considerably -- to five million passengers in 1995 and this year's expected seven million.
MUCH of that has been due to what the Federal Aviation Administration has called the Southwest effect. Southwest Airlines began offering service from Bradley last October, bringing its no-hassle low-fare philosophy to a market that was previously known for high prices. Since then, the airport estimates that the average unrestricted air fare has dropped 32 percent, as other carriers have scrambled to compete.
"Hartford has met all of our projections and is growing," said Whitney Brewer, a Southwest spokeswoman. Southwest is now operating 12 daily nonstop flights to Baltimore, Chicago, Nashville and Orlando.
A new terminal complex will be 521,000 square feet with 34 gates, compared with 24 gates in slightly less than 446,000 square feet of terminal space now. There will also be a dedicated two-gate international section. Most of the new and renovated space will be completed in 2002, Mr. Juliano said.
A new garage will provide 3,453 new parking spaces, with 1,655 spaces set for completion next May and the rest a year later.
Mr. Juliano said the expansion was needed just to accommodate the growth that has already taken place. Since 1995, 8 new carriers have come into Bradley, and the number of nonstop destinations has increased to 41 from 27 -- more than 300 nonstop flights a day leave Bradley now. Seasonal slowdowns have disappeared: passenger traffic has grown for 27 straight months.
"People talk about Bradley getting to the next level," Mr. Juliano said. "Well, it is at the next level. You have just about every domestic service you can ask for, and the frequency of flights has gone up dramatically."
When the project is completed, Bradley will be able to handle 12 million passengers a year. Andre J. Libert, director of marketing for the airport, said he expected the expanded and improved airport to draw from as far as mid-Vermont to the north and to make inroads even into New York City.
"We're seeing Westchester County traffic in numbers we've never seen before, Stamford and Greenwich in numbers that we have never seen before," Mr. Libert said.
A decade ago, Fairfield County travelers represented about 2.5 percent of the business at Bradley. "It's now pushing 10 percent, and growing very quickly," Mr. Libert said. "We don't know where it might cap out at."
But Bradley intends to push it along, with a major marketing drive in Fairfield County on billboards, in newspapers, on radio and cable television.
Joseph McGee, vice president for public policy and programs at the Southwest Area Commerce and Industry Association in Stamford, said Bradley could capture more of the southwestern Connecticut business and leisure travel market.
Mr. Gioia of the Connecticut Business and Industry Association said that with the airport promotional campaign, and some growth that will likely come from other sources, Bradley might soon outgrow its expanded quarters.
Both Logan Airport to the north and Kennedy International Airport to the south are getting more crowded, and crowded highways make them difficult to reach during business hours, he said. And Connecticut is seeing significant growth in high-technology companies and exporters, two industries that rely heavily on air travel.
W E'RE seeing double-digit growth rates in both transportation of individuals and transport of cargo, and that hasn't even taken into account that there may be a lot more overflow from Logan or Kennedy that could be coming down the line, and the growth in industries that are going to put a lot more pressure on our transportation resources," Mr. Gioia said. "I think everyone realizes the expansion that's going on at Bradley right now is only stopgap."
But there are some concerns that the management structure at Bradley might limit its development. It is one of only four major airports that is owned by a state government and by statute must be self-sustaining. That means certain limits on its rate of growth and in the kind of risks it might take. The Legislature's Programs Review and Investigations Committee is reviewing the management situation at Bradley to determine whether changes are needed.
"The department has been very competent and effective over the years at managing Bradley, but their mission has been very limited, which is to do the maintenance and don't spend too much money," Mr. Gioia said. "That doesn't leave them much room to be innovative. I think it's time for them to get some new instructions.
Daniel J. Carstens, who owns CargoZone-BDL, a Bradley-based cargo operation, and the publisher of Airport News, which covers Bradley, said Baltimore-Washington International Airport in Maryland had a marketing staff of 14 people and an annual budget of $3 million; Bradley has a marketing staff of three, and a budget of less than $500,000, which must also cover five smaller state airports, two ferries and a state port operation.
"I think they've done a very good job marketing, as evidenced by their growth," Mr. Carstens said. But that comparison raises questions about whether Bradley is reaching its full potential, he said.
"On the other hand, you don't want to overexpand -- can you imagine the outcry if they built twice what they needed, and five years from now people are asking why we built such a big airport if no one is using it?" Mr. Carstens asked.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 6; Column 4; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 784 words

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Mother Fixation and Other Issues

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
THOSE doomsayers who have been forecasting the death of musicals are in a New York state of mind. All they have to do is get out of town. The myth of Broadway as the center of theater persists because myths are needed, more so by tourists from distant lands and the status-starved who are nearer, moneyed or just pretending.
At Goodspeed Opera's developmental theater, the Norma Terris in Chester, a musical adaptation of the popular movie "Summer of '42" is running through Sept. 10, while the East Haddam home theater goes on bringing back oldies, currently "George M!". Even the Westport Country Playhouse is to present a musical premiere, the 12th-century French fable "Nicolette and Aucassin" starting tomorrow. 
 At the National Music Theater Conference of the O'Neill Theater Center in Waterford, which ended last Sunday, the search for and development of new musicals has been going on for 23 years. And it was Paulette Haupt, the conference's artistic director, who paired Wally Harper and Sherman Yellin for a new collaboration, "Say Yes!", which opened Wednesday at the Berkshire Theater Festival in Stockbridge, Mass.
In the Berkshires, new spins on old and new (but not so new) musicals have been thriving this summer. A beguiling example of that second category, "No Way to Treat a Lady," with book, music and lyrics by Douglas J. Cohen, is resurfacing at Barrington Stage Company in Sheffield.
Here is a musical (first a novel by William Goldman) that has been around since 1987 Off Off Broadway. And the musical version of the 1968 movie (with Lee Remick, Eileen Heckart, Rod Steiger and George Segal) was briefly seen Off Broadway nine years later. Audiences at Coconut Grove in Florida, in London and in Germany, saw it.
Mr. Cohen's score is a reassuring fusion, a mastery of traditional musical comedy style adorning and informing an offbeat story. The songs, merrily and provocatively, take on a romantic lilt when the subject is pathological and macabre. Sample: An ostensibly grown-up son, never allowed the space to please his abusive mother, sings to her, for approval and repentance, now that she is dead. But she will never be successfully dead. In the song ("What Shall I Sing for You?") the son sings of Shakespeare and Shaw, of Porter and Gershwin.
The son is named Kit, an actor and the musical's serial killer who phones in reports of his conquests (read corpses) to Moe, a detective who is really just a cop, his horrid mother laughingly reminds him.
Both Kit and Moe have very severe mother fixations, which enables Moe's actual inamorata to say that she is jealous of a killer, not just because Moe obsesses about catching the creep. It is eerily clear that the killer is playing disapproving mother to the cop, calling him a middle-aged mama's boy, demanding his gratitude for the fame this front-page case is affording him.
Well, what else is an unemployed actor to do but act out -- and kill? The quest for celebrity, in whatever form, is just one of the themes of a musical that is to be taken seriously, if only because it does not take itself seriously.
Mr. Cohen (whose very good musical, "The Gig," evolved from Waterford to Chester, then to regional theaters) is not concerned about stretching the boundaries of musicals through reinvention and all those other trendy terms. Nor is he formulaic or derivative, no matter the familiar echoes.
The dread meeting between inamorata and horrid mother, Sarah and Flora, is transformed into a funny song ("So Much in Common") and it all begins with each man's plea: "I Need a Life."
The ingenuity of the musical's staging by Rob Ruggiero, associate artistic director of Theater Works in Hartford, takes multiple casting to an audience-astonishing level. "No Way to Treat a Lady" is to be the Hartford theater's first musical production next year.
In addition to Karen Murphy taking on five roles, unrecognizably and disparately, Bradley Dean as Kit kills suavely and scarily in such guises as the kindly Father Fitzgerald; a flamenco dancer named Ramon and Tony, who bakes "the pizza you die for."
Sandy Binion as Sarah, "one of the beautiful people," gives a performance that really travels. She is lonely. She is assertive. She is funny. She is level-headed and she is hot-headed. And she scores a home run with every song.
Which leaves Adam Heller, a fine schlumpy and touching Moe, and now you can count the actors, but not the roles.
Mr. Cohen's homicidal musical comedy keeps going around, and he keeps writing more.
"No Way to Treat a Lady," Barrington Stage Company, Consolati Performing Arts Center, Sheffield, Mass. (413) 528-8888. Performances through next Sunday.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 1; Long Island Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 2587 words

HEADLINE: Is It a House or a Synagogue?;
And Other Questions That Have Jewish Tempers Flaring in the Five Towns

BYLINE: By VIVIAN S. TOY

DATELINE: LAWRENCE

 BODY:
ALMOST any non-Orthodox Jew in the Five Towns can tell you about the boycott threats that their Orthodox brethren have made to shopkeepers who dare to open on the Sabbath.
Some say the threats started 20 years ago with the initial growth of the modern Orthodox community, which observes the Sabbath closely but which also mixes freely with the modern world. Others say the intimidation of business owners didn't start until about five years ago, with the influx of more strictly Orthodox families who are a little more insular. 
 But trying to find a shopkeeper who has actually been pressured to close on Saturdays by the Orthodox is like trying to find the alligator that swims in New York City's sewer system. Everyone's heard about it, but the evidence is lacking.
"The stories about boycotts and threats are all apocryphal," said Jay Todtman, owner of Toddy's Appetizers, a deli that has been in the heart of Cedarhurst's downtown since 1946. "Everyone wants to paint the Orthodox as this evil cancer that's infesting the Five Towns, but I've found nothing of the sort."
Toddy's began closing on Saturdays and came under strict kosher supervision back in 1987, but Mr. Todtman insists the decision had nothing to do with the Orthodox community. Instead, he said, it was because many of the non-Orthodox synagogues that Toddy's catered to had started using kosher caterers. "We did it not to go after the Orthodox community, but we got it anyway," he said. Go figure.
Still, the fact that the rumors have persisted is a clear sign of the misperceptions and mistrust that exists in the Five Towns, an area that has been a stronghold of Jewish suburbia for generations and that has more recently become an Orthodox destination of choice.
A more tangible source of tension between the Orthodox and their more secular neighbors is the growing number of shtiebels, private houses that serve as synagogues. As the congregations grow and seek building permits to expand, the complaints about zoning and parking violations mount.
For many of these Orthodox congregations, zoning appeals boards and the Nassau County Supreme Court have become familiar battlegrounds. The Orthodox go to these sites to fight for their constitutional right to worship. Their neighbors go to enforce the zoning ordinances underpinning a tranquil suburban life where the streets seem immune to large crowds and parking problems.
In many cases, compromises have been made and congregations have continued to worship in their converted homes. But there are at least three active lawsuits connected to Orthodox synagogues or shtiebels, one in Cedarhurst and two in Lawrence.
The Orthodox have, in many ways, come to define the Five Towns even though they only make up about 30 percent of the total population. Certain neighborhoods, particularly in Woodmere, Cedarhurst and Lawrence, have become almost exclusively Orthodox. Even though some neighbors might believe otherwise, the Orthodox have moved into these areas in large numbers not with any intent to conquer, but out of religious necessity, because they must be able to walk to a synagogue on the Sabbath. And the non-Orthodox families they have replaced haven't so much fled the Orthodox, who tend to be young professionals with large families, as they have aged out of their empty-nest homes.
Many business owners say that while the growing Orthodox community has changed the complexion of Central Avenue, the shopping street that runs through Cedarhurst and Lawrence, it has also helped revive a once-sagging retail district. But there are those who long for the days when Central Avenue was not home to quite so many kosher food stores and Judaica shops and was more like the Rodeo Drive of Long Island, overflowing with boutiques and fancy dress shops.
For years, the Orthodox of the Five Towns coexisted easily with the non-Orthodox because they were predominantly modern Orthodox Jews. Like Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, the Democratic vice presidential candidate, they studiously observed the Sabbath and kept kosher, but the men did not always wear yarmulkes and the women did not always cover their hair.
But as more observant Orthodox families started moving in about 10 years ago, unease that sprouted from their different rituals began to surface, according to William B. Helmreich, a professor of sociology and Judaic studies at the City College of New York. "The arrival in the Five Towns of so many Jews who are more right-wing Orthodox has exacerbated tensions," he said.
The practices of the more observant Orthodox fall somewhere between those of modern Orthodox and ultra-Orthodox groups. They don't wear the characteristic long black coats and beards of the ultra-Orthodox, but the women tend to wear wigs and dress conservatively and the men always wear hats or skullcaps. Parts of Lawrence are known as "black hat" neighborhoods, Dr. Helmreich said.
"In many ways, the stricter Orthodox are more allied with the Hasidim than with the modern Orthodox," he said. "They believe in compromising with outside society only when necessary, whereas the modern Orthodox believe in compromising whenever possible."
Many non-Orthodox feel as though the very public practices of the Orthodox are an open rebuke of their choice not to be as religious. For example, if clusters of Orthodox leaving a Sabbath service happen to linger around the driveway of a non-Orthodox resident to chat, the non-Orthodox person may think he is being given a message not to drive, Dr. Helmreich said.
Orthodox leaders, for their part, don't see what the fuss is all about.
"Some of our traditions may be different," said Jacob Mordechai, president of the Sephardic Congregation of the Five Towns in Cedarhurst. "But that doesn't mean better or worse, just different. If anything, we see one of the most beautiful coexistence of all levels of Orthodox, whether more or less Orthodox, we can visit one another's synagogues and feel very close to one another."
Many of the stricter Orthodox families moved to the Five Towns from neighborhoods in Brooklyn where kosher food stores and yeshivas were plentiful. And over the years, the same infrastructure has developed in the Five Towns.
They have a choice of kosher supermarkets and delis, as well as kosher restaurants, pizza parlors and a kosher Dunkin' Donuts. Both the Hebrew Academy of Long Beach and the Hebrew Academy of the Five Towns and Rockaway have recently built new schools. The first Orthodox university in the area, Sh'or Yoshuv, is under construction in Lawrence. The Postal Service has even expanded its hours to accommodate the Orthodox, keeping its Lawrence office open on Sundays.
Jerry Cohen, the owner of Trees Accessories and Handbags shop, which his father opened in Cedarhurst in 1946, said the downtown area had gone through booms and busts over the years. The five-block area, encompassing about 250 stores, rode high in the 1960's and 70's when it attracted shoppers from far and wide. But the advent of malls and shopping centers sent the downtown, like so many others across Long Island, into decline.
The 1990's have seen a revival, with the opening of at least 12 major chain stores, including the Gap, Victoria's Secret and, most recently, an Omaha Steaks -- a non-kosher business that felt the Five Towns would be a strong market despite the heavy Orthodox influence.
"The Orthodox community is one of the best things that has happened to us since we've been in business," Mr. Cohen said. "It's given us a whole new audience, and the bonus for us is, it's one of the most affluent Orthodox communities in the country."
Ivan Greenberg, who runs the Davey Shop, a lingerie shop that has been in his family since 1946, said he became frustrated when people complain that the business district has changed. "I say to them, 'Look in the mirror, haven't you changed?' " he said. "Why shouldn't the town change?"
On Saturday the downtown may not bustle as much as it once did, because about a third of the stores are closed either in deference to the Orthodox or because they are owned by Orthodox, but Sundays often more than make up for that, Mr. Greenberg said.
But Mr. Cohen said the perception that the Five Towns have become predominantly Orthodox has hurt business. "A lot of people just assume we're closed on Saturdays and they don't come out," he said. "But there are a lot of misperceptions out there."
Mimi Bernstein, the owner of Mieka Ltd., a women's clothing shop that has been a staple along Central Avenue for 18 years, rankles a little at the talk that the Orthodox have forced stores to close on the Sabbath. "That's a myth, an old wive's tale," she said. "I'm open seven days a week and if anything, the Orthodox walk by on Saturdays and we smile and say 'Good Sabbath.' "
Relationships in residential neighborhoods are sometimes a little less cordial. Neighbors complain that even though the Orthodox do not drive on the Sabbath, parking problems arise when members drive to the synagogues for weekday services or when they drive to the synagogue before sundown on Friday and then leave the car parked on the street until after sundown on Saturday.
In the Lawrence Bay Park subdivision, where neighbors tried unsuccessfully to stop Congregation Bais Medrash from building an extension on a home that had been converted to a synagogue, many of the neighbors say they feel intimidated by the Orthodox congregation.
One homeowner who asked that she not be identified said that on one Sabbath, four Orthodox couples were walking side by side in the street as she drove toward home. "Instead of walking behind one another when they saw me or moving to the curb, they stayed right in the middle of the street," she said. "And they yelled at me when I finally honked at them. They didn't want me to drive, but you don't have to have this arrogance."
Despite the neighbors' opposition, Lawrence officials approved Bais Medrash's expansion plan, and an extension big enough to seat 122 members was completed in early 1999. The neighbors sued in state Supreme Court and a judge ruled in their favor last June, annulling the village's approval of the extension. But the congregation and village officials appealed, and are awaiting the higher court's opinion.
Thomas Pantelis, the attorney for the synagogue, said the neighbors' negative perceptions of the congregation were based in misunderstanding. He said he is hopeful that Bais Medrash's right to worship where it wants ultimately will be upheld by the appeals court.
"There's no reason why we can't strike a balance between the right of religious exercise versus the concerns of neighbors with respect to parking, traffic and quality of life issues," he said.
In the case of Congregation Bais Yakov, which is also in Lawrence, a neighbor, Howard Legum, has sued the village for allowing the synagogue, which seats 105, to operate with only four parking spaces. Steven Legum, who represents his parents in the case, said that parking is not a problem on the Sabbath, but up to 20 cars are routinely parked along the streets near the synagogue each morning during daily services.
"This is not a religious issue," Mr. Legum said, noting that his family has long been part of Congregation Beth Shalom, one of the oldest modern Orthodox synagogues in the Five Towns. "We have had commercial operations closed down in the area for similar reasons."
He said he was appalled that the village would allow someone to build an addition on a personal residence to create a synagogue and then take the structure off of the tax rolls even though it is also still being used as a home. "My personal opinion is that village officials are pandering to certain parts of the community when they let this kind of thing go on," he said.
Mayor Lawrence A. Blatte took exception to that charge. "Pandering is an unattractive word and it's extremely unfair," he said. "To the extent we have a large and growing Orthodox community with needs, we're trying to accommodate their needs."
Lawrence, like the other Five Towns, has gone through demographic changes, Mayor Blatte said, moving from a largely gentile population to a more Jewish one and now to Orthodox Jewish. "We have always invited people to come into the community and we have always been successful in managing the change," he said. "That's been the source of renewal for the village, and that won't change."
Cedarhurst, on the other hand, has been accused of the opposite, of unfairly trying to keep Orthodox shtiebels and synagogues out.
The Sephardic Congregation of the Five Towns has sued the village, claiming that an ordinance that would require the synagogue to pay the village $180,000 to waive parking requirements is unconstitutional. The local law requires one parking spot for every four occupants and requires a fee of $5,000 for each waived parking spot to help the village create or improve public parking nearby. The 176-seat synagogue has provided a plan for 8 parking spots, but is required to have 44.
"They call it a tax on religion, but we charge it to any commercial applicant," said Jerry Levenberg, village attorney for Cedarhurst. "Like any community, the Orthodox are in most ways a positive element in the village, but some groups are more cooperative when it comes to opening these facilities than others and are more attuned to what secular law requires."
Mr. Levenberg said he understands the religious imperative that has prompted the growing number of shtiebels -- officials estimate about 10 have opened throughout the Five Towns in the last few years.
"As a resident, what I don't understand is people have moved out here because of the aesthetics of the suburban village and yet they're bringing these very urban type of practices here," he said. "Nobody is saying we don't want you here, we just want something reasonable for everyone."
Mr. Mordechai, the synagogue's president, said the congregation had already modified its plans to meet the concerns of its neighbors. He maintained that the parking fee was unfair because parking is an issue only on rare occasions because the congregation is Orthodox and because the synagogue is a nonprofit organization.
Samuel G. Freedman, a journalism professor at Columbia University whose book "Jew vs. Jew" will be published this month, said the shtiebel conflicts were "a classic example of the culture of orthodoxy running headlong into suburban zoning laws."
Shtiebels have a long history in America, going back to prayer groups that met in Lower East Side tenement apartments at the turn of the century. "In cities they existed without running afoul of zoning and building-code violations," Mr. Freedman said. "But in the suburbs the sanctity of private property is a major part of life, so naturally they are an irritant."
But even as these individual cases work their way through the system, the Orthodox community in the Five Towns continues to grow and thrive. And that, Mr. Freedman said, in many ways defines the American experience of Jewry.
"It's a sign that the modern Orthodox have made it economically in America, just like the non-Orthodox did a few generations before them," he said. "That's really a barometer of American Jewry at large because the feeling a generation ago was that the Orthodox would wither away or they would just be the poor economic relations. Hardly any experts foresaw 25 years ago that they would make it to suburbia."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 10; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1085 words

HEADLINE: Personal Business;
Ready or Not, Welcome to the 401(k) Plan

BYLINE: By EVE TAHMINCIOGLU

 BODY:
MARGARET FULLER, manager of profit sharing at 7-Eleven Inc., is proud that three-quarters of the company's nearly 15,000 eligible employees now participate in its 401(k) retirement savings plan. Three years ago, only half had signed up.
The big increase wasn't caused by a surge in the company's matching contribution or a change in the plan's investment offerings. All it took was a bow to human nature. 
 Instead of leaving it up to employees to complete enrollment forms and return them -- and having many of them procrastinate or shy away -- 7-Eleven started enrolling employees automatically on the first anniversary of their hiring; only those who want to opt out of participation needed to lift a finger.
The company, based in Dallas, is one of about 50 large corporations that have begun automatic enrollment in recent years, as many other employers waited for the federal government to take a stand on the practice. Last month, however, regulators in two federal departments gave it a solid go-ahead, and the Internal Revenue Service announced several rulings clarifying the automatic-enrollment ground rules for businesses, nonprofit organizations and school systems.
In a joint statement, Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman and Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers said they saw automatic enrollment as a "promising method of encouraging participation by those who disproportionately have been missing the benefits of a regular, disciplined approach to retirement saving," meaning the many younger and lower-paid workers who put off saving for retirement because they feel they cannot spare any of their pay.
In fact, experts say, most people cannot afford not to contribute to the plans. Even if the current Social Security system is maintained indefinitely, the dwindling of traditional, defined-benefit pension plans means that few workers can count on a financially secure retirement without putting aside money of their own.
Hewitt Associates, a benefits research firm in Lincolnshire, Ill., estimates that three-fourths of eligible American workers are enrolled in 401(k) plans. But that still leaves millions of Americans without any retirement savings program.
David Wray, president of the Profit Sharing/401(k) Council of America in Chicago, said he expected the number of companies using automatic enrollment to double annually for the next five years, and that more than half of all plans would use the method by 2005. In addition, the new I.R.S. rulings make it possible to automatically enroll all workers, not just new hires, in 401(k) plans and their close cousins, 403(b)'s (for public schools and charities) and 457(b)'s (for state and local government workers).
In automatic enrollment, the initial percentage of pay to be set aside is left to the employer's discretion. (7-Eleven's plan sets aside 3 percent of gross pay, a typical rate, and the company matches employee contributions at 36 cents on the dollar.)
Employers also decide how the money will initially be invested. According to Mark Iwry, the benefits tax counsel for the Treasury Department, employers are encouraged to put savings of automatic enrollees into a balanced fund, rather than a more risky stock fund or a low-return money market fund. "The plans are typically very careful in the investments they select for employees," he said.
Once enrolled, employees are generally free to select different rates and investment vehicles according to plan rules.
The experience of 7-Eleven shows that automatic sign-up can go a long way toward closing the enrollment gap for lower-paid employees -- an important issue for all participants, because federal rules sharply restrict benefits for top earners if too few of their lower-paid co-workers take part.
Still, some critics wonder whether herding uninterested workers into the plans accomplishes much in the long run. "The government is leading the horse to water, but they haven't focused on teaching them to want to drink," said Ric Edelman, an author and financial planner in Fairfax, Va. He cited Hewitt statistics showing that fewer than one-third of people who leave jobs with 401(k)'s roll over the money into individual retirement accounts; the remainder simply pocket -- and pay taxes on -- the cash payout from the plans.
Other analysts worry that automatic enrollees will be too passive as savers. In a study of one company's workers, the National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass., found that most left their starting contribution rates unchanged and never moved out of the low-yielding money market fund in which the company put them.
But Leslie Kramerich, an acting assistant labor secretary, said it was most important that the workers become savers in the first place. "Once they get started, then we can tackle whether they're too conservative or too cautious," she said.
Getting more workers involved in 401(k)'s makes the plans more effective as morale builders, employers say. Ben Goldstein, director of strategic human resource planning for Primex Technologies, an aerospace company in St. Petersburg, Fla., said that when his company's workers receive their quarterly 401(k) statements and see the 50 percent matching contribution from the company, they are more motivated to stay on. "It's like free money," he said.
Two years ago, before Primex started using automatic enrollment, about 35 percent of workers took part in the plan; now four-fifths do, Mr. Goldstein said.
STILL, some workers who are automatically enrolled in 401(k) plans ought to opt out, because even plans with generous matching rates are not the best choice for everyone, experts say. Lower-paid people in their 20's and 30's may be better off putting their limited resources toward a down payment on a first home or paying off debts like college loans, said Robert Clark, professor of business and economics at North Carolina State University. And union officials say that however advantageous the plans might be, some of their members genuinely cannot spare the money.
If workers decide to leave automatic-enrollment plans after the deductions have already begun from their paychecks, they face the same early-withdrawal penalties that other 401(k) members do: 10 percent of the balance, plus income tax. But Ms. Fuller of 7-Eleven said few workers had complained about being unwittingly swept into the company's plan. "When they get the statement at the end of the quarter," she said, "they're usually very happy."

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Page 11; Column 2; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1315 words

HEADLINE: THE GREAT OUTDOORS;
They Know How Your Garden Grows

BYLINE: By ELISABETH GINSBURG

 BODY:
HALF a century ago, Beverley Nichols, an English journalist, defied common sense and the advice of friends and bought himself a small country estate. Upon inspection he found that the property came with several fixtures, the most permanent of which was Oldfield, the gardener, who had worked on the place for more than 40 years, and outlasted the two previous owners.
Although the relationship began with caution and a degree of skepticism on both sides, Mr. Nichols gradually realized that the old gardener was invaluable. Together they created a showplace, a process that Mr. Nichols described in three books, "Merry Hall," "Sunlight on the Lawn" and "Laughter on the Stairs." 
 Times have changed, but the need for professional gardeners has not. With the economy growing like chickweed in the spring, more and more people have both the desire and the means for significant gardens. A well-designed planting design can be a work of art, with the power to elevate a brand-new faux chateau to a higher aesthetic realm. But a garden, unlike a painting or a piece of sculpture, needs constant care and maintenance. Most landscapers and lawn care crews don't have the necessary expertise, and these days, people like Oldfield are hard to come by.
They do exist, however. Kathy Parsons is one of them. For the past 20 years, she has spent a good portion of her professional time caring for other people's gardens in Essex and Bergen Counties. Working mostly by herself, Ms. Parsons waters, feeds, weeds, deadheads and monitors annual and perennial plants for diseases and pests. She also stakes, thins, prunes and divides -- tasks that often intimidate gardeners.
Not all of her clients have extensive property. "I've done everything from a golf club to a small suburban home," she said.
Ms. Parsons characterized her average client as a "relatively wealthy and independent" person who loves his or her garden, but is simply too busy with career, family or community service to look after the plants without help.
Those crowded schedules and demanding lives mean that often the professional gardener can use a certain amount of latitude when it comes to plant choice and installation.
"I don't get specifics," said Ms. Parsons, who added that the ability to do "a lot of mind reading" is as important as knowing when to apply the rose food.
If Beverley Nichols's Oldfield had a spiritual descendant, he would be Andy Durbridge, a professional gardener, designer and estate manager on Long Island's North Shore. In the business for 10 years, the English-born Mr. Durbridge has spent the last four working for his current employers and living on their estate. His job combines hands-on tasks like planning for planting, tending the estate rose garden and monitoring for pests and diseases, and administrative responsibilities like supervising arborists and other ground-care professionals.
Mr. Durbridgealso does design work and maintenance planning for other clients. "Maintenance is the first thing you address when you design," he said. "Any designer who doesn't talk about maintenance will probably make mistakes."
Fanny Clark, who is soon to retire after many years as a professional gardener in the Montclair area, values the personal relationships that she has cultivated along with her clients' plants and shrubs. Those relationships begin with lots of questions.
"I want to know what colors they like, which windows they look out of in their homes," she said. "I find out how much they will be outside and when, and whether they go away in the summer.
"Clients know the look and feel they want," she added. "I translate that into what's doable."
Like Ms. Parsons, Mrs. Clark cares for a variety of gardens. She has often been called on to tame a neglected estate garden. Her favorite gardens are those laid out during the 1920's and 30's, an era she refers to as the golden age of American garden design.
According to Mrs. Clark, these older gardens benefit from having great "bones," defining structures like walls, terraces and walkways, as well as mature trees.
Once a garden is under control, Mrs. Clark maintains it weekly. Both she and Ms. Parsons are also frequently called on to spruce up clients' gardens before parties and other events.
Over the years, Ms. Parsons and Mrs. Clark have noticed a demographic shift among their clients.
"Economics has changed the face of gardening," said Mrs. Clark. "Clients have gotten younger, and are now often two-income couples in their 30's." These people, she said, frequently reject traditional workhorse plants like impatiens and hostas in favor of newer and more exotic materials.
Some of the professional gardeners have clients who like to get out and do some work in their own gardens. For them, Fanny Clark maintains the beds to make the prospect of that work a pleasure rather than a burden.
"A garden should be a place that people can fuss in a little bit when they come home at the end of the day," she said.
Jody Staunton of New Canaan, Conn., is a garden designer whose work leads her to garden maintenance.
"I only maintain the gardens I design," said Ms. Staunton, who cares for gardens in New Jersey, Westchester and Connecticut. "Maintenance is so important in keeping the shape and form of the garden, that maintenance and design are really one and the same."
Some of her clients are interested in new plant colors and varieties, and she travels around the United States and Europe to find them.
Each gardener arrived at the vocation by a different route. Andy Durbridge said he came from a family of green thumbs and he did "many things aside from horticulture" before settling into gardening.
Mrs. Clark grew up on a farm and attended a school run by Quakers, a group with a traditional interest in horticulture. By the time her children no longer needed constant supervision, she had become an avid gardener.
A serendipitous meeting with Montclair's celebrated landscape designer and gardener, Avis Campbell, led to a job offer. When Miss Campbell died she left Mrs. Clark "her clients and her library." Fanny Clark hung out her own shingle. Working alone, she had, at the peak of her career, 13 regular clients, whose gardens she visited once a week. During the gardening season she worked from 8 a.m. until 6 p.m. every day. "By the end of each day I was absolutely dead," she said.
Ms. Parsons began her professional career by working for a commercial nursery and also worked for a time for Avis Campbell. Eventually she went into business for herself. Now she maintains gardens of her own design, as well as some designed by others.
Ms. Staunton has worked in the landscape design and garden maintenance business for 15 years. After studying at Radcliff, worked at a Boston company that specializes in indoor landscape design, wholesale nurseries and a landscape designer, and seven years ago went into business for herself.
Mrs. Clark has always worked alone, preferring to maintain an intensely personal relationship with her clients and their gardens. Ms. Staunton and Ms. Parsons would like to hire gardeners to help with maintenance, but the supply of knowledgeable people is limited.
"There is such a shortage of talented gardeners who know what they are doing," said Ms. Staunton, who added that many people seem more attracted to design than maintenance. This, she said, may be partly because of the "physical challenges" in maintenance.
Each of the four gardeners stressed that in horticulture the learning never stops. Mr. Durbridge, for example, maintains trial beds in his personal garden on the estate where he works.
On the verge of retirement, Mrs. Clark remains philosophical. "Just when you think you have a handle on shade gardening," she said, "you get a client who has nothing but full sun. It's the most humbling profession in the world."

Julie Strauss-Gabel, David Feldman

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
A Casbah for Clothes Is Bustling in California.

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Davenport Institute for Public Policy at Pepperdine University. His column on the Main Street economy appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail may be sent to
grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IT is just a short walk from the Staples Center, where the Democrats, the news media and assorted demonstrators spent the week playing out the politics of the information age. But the thriving Los Angeles fashion district has more in common with 12th-century Baghdad than the California of the new millennium.
The 80-block jumble of prewar commercial buildings, hastily constructed low-rise arcades commingled with a few modern towers, is home to 5,000 companies employing 50,000 people and taking in $8 billion a year in wholesale and retail sales. And it epitomizes raw capitalism in both its glory and its shame. 
 The district has a reputation for paying its lowest rung of workers brutally low wages -- which drew the ire of demonstrators last week -- and for having too little respect for trademark laws and tax codes. But for many of those who work here, including some who have made fortunes, the district also reflects the essence of the American dream. It is a place where recent immigrants can build successful businesses and new lives in an environment not dissimilar to those found in many developing countries.
"What we have here is a souk," said Uri Harkham, one of the major property owners in the district. "It's open to everyone, and it's the kind of place you can go to buy something for $3 or $300."
MR. HARKHAM, who was born in Iraq and is chief executive of Jonathan Martin, one of the area's leading garment manufacturers with more than $100 million in annual sales, is reluctant to talk specifically about the extent of his holdings in the district. But they are big and growing. One new building that he is constructing with his Moroccan-born partner, Moshe Aflalo, has space for 13 retail stores and more than 60 companies clamoring to fill them.
The district, just southeast of the center of downtown Los Angeles, was widely perceived as dirty and dangerous five years ago, but it has since blossomed. Property values have more than doubled and vacancies, particularly for ground-floor properties, are almost impossible to find in much of the area, said Ed Zoraster, a vice president at CB Richard Ellis, a real estate broker. The city has issued more than 650 building permits for renovations or new construction in the district since 1995.
Mr. Zoraster gives some credit for the revival to a business improvement district, organized that year, that has improved the neighborhood's appearance and security. But the most important factor, he said, has been the drive of immigrants like Mr. Harkham, 52, who came to Los Angeles in 1975 after living in Israel and Australia.
Like many of his peers, Mr. Harkham brought with him the bazaar culture of his native land, with its love of bargaining, jostling and quick, seat-of-the-pants decision-making. "At the end of the day, the Middle Easterners are all traders at heart -- Arab, Jew and Persian, Christian, Muslim, it doesn't matter," he said. "We have the ambition and the drive others don't. The fashion business is so fast you have to be willing to be a gambler, and live on the edge."
Jerry Sullivan, the editor of California Apparel News, a trade paper, said newcomers from the Middle East and North Africa had largely replaced the American-born Jewish entrepreneurs, many transplanted from New York, who helped establish Los Angeles as a leading center for sportswear and women's garment manufacturing in the 1950's. Though Middle Easterners own only 7 percent of the district's apparel manufacturers and account for a negligible part of the factory work force, they own most of the area's premier brands, including Guess, Hot Kiss, Bissou Bissou and BCBG, and control much of the region's textile trade.
"These guys are better at developing brands and styles than anyone else who has been here," Mr. Sullivan said. "They are more aggressive than the native-born. They know what sexy is. They are willing to strike their own path and offer no apologies."
The restaurant scene in the district has come to reflect the new ethnic order. Many Israeli, Persian and North African establishments have opened, and many get the bulk of their sales from meals they deliver to their perpetually harried customers. Korean eateries are also popping up, reflecting Korean immigrants' emergence as the second powerful ethnic influence in the increasingly polyglot district.
UNLIKE those from the Middle East, who dominate the local industry's high-fashion end, the Korean entrepreneurs tend to make their presence felt in the lower price ranges and in manufacturing. Victor C. Kim, owner of Cherish International, a consulting firm in the district, said people of Korean background own at least 600 wholesale and retail operations, as many as 1,000 contractors -- the companies who actually do the sewing under contract from marketers and design houses -- and hundreds of knitting and other manufacturing operations.
Mr. Kim said many business people of Korean descent in the district felt unfairly tarred with negative stereotypes -- that Koreans rely on knockoffs of styles developed by others; that the worst wages and most abusive labor practices are found in their factories; that they dodge paying taxes. In fact, he said, Koreans are more likely than other groups to be victims of unfair business practices, like landlords' demands for astronomical rents and "key money," an upfront payment to obtain a lease that can run as high as $200,000. Protests by Korean groups against this practice have been laced with talk about "Merchant of Venice" figures, a none-too-subtle stereotyping of the landlords, many of whom are Jewish, Mr. Sullivan said.
The tensions may ease as the Korean segment of the district becomes more self-sufficient, Mr. Kim said, with Korean-owned banks and real estate companies coming to the fore and with Korean-owned garment companies like Koo's Manufacturing, Bubblegum USA and Impression developing their own fashion sensibility, often by hiring recent Korean-American graduates of the nearby Fashion Institute of Design and Merchandising and other local design schools.
Latinos constitute the third major ethnic element in the district, accounting for the majority of the work force, including 85 percent of factory workers; most retail shoppers in the district are Hispanic as well. Spanish-speaking immigrants have only begun to be a business force in the district, through the rise of locally trained designers of Latin background and through ownership of sewing shops.
Sewing is proving to be the part of the industry most vulnerable to overseas competition, said Joe Rodriguez, the executive director of the Garment Contractors Association of Southern California. The number of production jobs has fallen by 10,000 since the peak in 1997, and low unemployment has made the remaining jobs harder to fill with legal workers.
Ordinarily, Mr. Rodriguez said, such conditions might lead to higher wages. But most shops cannot afford to go much above the $7-an-hour average paid by most contractors, because of intense price pressures from retail customers and the ease with which production can be moved outside the country, especially to Mexico.
THOSE pressures have also hampered union organizers, who, after decades of trying, have yet to penetrate virtually any of the district's small factories, most employing 50 or fewer workers. Goetz Wolff, research director for the County Federation of Labor, cited overseas competition, fragmentation and the ready supply of illegal workers available to less scrupulous operators.
"There are still lots of illegal shops," said Mr. Wolff, an economist who has studied the garment industry for years. "Everyone says they don't know about it, or someone else is doing it. But somebody is buying the product."
Still, Mr. Wolff and other economists predict that the district will continue to thrive, partly because of the fashion world's rapid pace of change and the resulting need for quick turnaround by manufacturers. They also point to the growing influence of Los Angeles as a design center and to the region's huge and highly diverse consumer base.
"This kind of thing can't be stopped," said Mr. Harkham at his real estate office in the heart of the district. "It's a very unique place, and it serves the region's melting pot. There's a comfort level to being here. You have the good, bad and the ugly, but it works."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
The Whole of Volatility Is Less Than Its Parts

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week.
E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IT may be difficult to imagine that any decade in American stock market history saw the magnitude or number of violent swings witnessed in the 1990's.
Believe it or not, however, the market volatility of the last 10 years was no higher than the average of the last seven decades. In fact, there was less volatility in the 1990's than in either of the two previous decades -- 21 percent less than the 1970's and 31 percent less than the 1980's. 
 Those are among the more startling conclusions of a new stock volatility study by Prof. John Campbell of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Martin Lettau, senior economist at the New York Federal Reserve Bank; Prof. Burton Malkiel of Princeton; and Prof. Yexiao Xu of the University of Texas at Dallas.
Why, then, do the recent gyrations seem so severe? One possible explanation is in another of the researchers' findings: that even though the overall market may be no more volatile than in the past, the average stock is much more so. In fact, the volatility of the typical stock in the 1990's was about twice as high as in the early 1960's. That is because the correlation between individual stocks' gyrations has fallen -- in other words, more stocks are rising sharply at the same time that other stocks plunge.
So on a day when an Internet retailer misses earnings expectations and immediately sheds a third of its market value, the stock of another company is skyrocketing because it has just reported unexpectedly good news. The extent of the volatility for any given company is indeed a modern phenomenon. But across the entire stock market of more than 7,000 companies, these gyrations largely cancel one another out, leaving the overall market no more volatile than it was in previous decades.
This combination of higher volatility and reduced correlation has profound implications for how many stocks an investor needs in a portfolio in order to achieve adequate diversification. For years, statisticians have argued that a portfolio of about 20 stocks, in a variety of industries, is large enough to diversify away 90 percent of the volatility associated with owning a single stock. According to the new study, however, given that the average stock's volatility is twice as high as it was during the 1960's and 1970's, the number of stocks needed to achieve such diversification is now closer to 50.
If your portfolio does not have that many stocks, chances are that you will have more sleepless nights and yet no greater returns to show for it, than you would with a larger portfolio. Your greater suffering will be in vain.
That melancholy conclusion comes from the market's structure. In a stock market as efficient as ours, investors are for the most part rewarded only for taking unavoidable risks. But the volatility and risk associated with smaller portfolios are entirely avoidable -- and thus you shouldn't expect higher returns for incurring them.
What accounts for the average stock's much-increased volatility? Answering with any certainty will require additional research, but the authors of the new study point to two contributing factors. The first is the trend over the last decade away from conglomerates and toward companies whose businesses are more focused. In a conglomerate, poor earnings from a single division have a relatively small impact on the price of the company's stock. If that division is spun off and becomes publicly traded on its own, a similarly poor earnings report will have a much greater impact.
A RELATED factor is that a greater number of younger and smaller companies are publicly traded today. Because investors feel far less certain about the long-term prospects of these companies, their stock prices are much more sensitive to good or bad news than are those of larger, more established concerns.
Regardless of the reasons, the wider gyrations of individual stocks teach a broad lesson: Diversification, which has always been an important way to gain immunity from volatility, is now more crucial than ever. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: COUNTERINTELLIGENCE;
At Hotels, the Butlers Are Doing It

BYLINE: By Alex Witchel

 BODY:
WHEN I stayed at the St. Regis Hotel a few years ago, I opened the door to a young woman dressed in white tie and tails who identified herself as the butler. Since I had no idea what to do with her, I sent her on her way. A female butler. What a funny idea.
During my fifth hour of butler training last week, I was no longer amused. Maybe it was having to wear the white tie and tails in 80-degree heat. Or maybe it was that the butlers who were training me had a quality -- a stillness, a patience, an obedience of sorts -- that I will never have in this lifetime. If I could have gotten my hands on the guest who left her underwear piled in the bathtub and her shirt draped over a bedroom lamp, she would not be alive today. 
 Though I was clearly a bust at butling, St. Regis Hotels and Resorts has had no trouble finding more appropriate candidates since it started the training program in 1991. While initially, most guests were as puzzled as I was by the notion of a butler, in the last two years the service has taken off, increasing occupancy rates and customer loyalty. Other luxury hotels have started imitating it, especially as the economy booms and people have more money than time.
Richard Cotter, a vice president and managing director of St. Regis, said that before joining the hotel he worked at the Waldorf-Astoria and New York Palace, where "we put butlers in the towers of both hotels in imitation of the St. Regis." Under his watch, the St. Regis has recently expanded its butler services to its hotels in Houston and Washington. This winter, ski butlers will arrive at the St. Regis in Aspen, "which will extend our service right to the slopes, so no one has to worry about their gear," Mr. Cotter said.
Off the slopes, the St. Regis butlers -- there is one on each floor -- are considered the primary contact for guests, who can channel all requests through them, without ever calling the concierge or housekeeping. "We live at such a frantic pace, and having the butler, someone whom you trust, is important," Sharon Telesca, the director of sales and marketing for the St. Regis New York, said. "Sixty-five percent of our business is repeat, and these people have come to consider the butler their personal assistant at the hotel."
Wendy Reisman, director of public relations for the Ritz Carlton in Philadelphia, which uses the term "club concierge" for many of the tasks that fall under the butler's purview at the St. Regis, said: "The term butler, in America, anyway, gives the connotation of luxury and a higher level of service, even though that service has always been available by another name."
Yet, Ritz-Carlton has recently added a technology butler, who fixes computers, beepers and cell phones, and a bath butler, who will draw a guest's bath from a menu of options.
Ms. Telesca conceded, "People have said it's a marketing gimmick, and it is, but it is also a service people are looking for."
Some guests like the service so much, they have hired the butlers away for their very own. The St. Regis recruits graduates from butler and hotel schools, but unlike the loyal family retainer in England who will carry the tray forever, here the butler is on a management track. In addition to providing guest services, each butler manages the 20 rooms on each floor and deals with all the other departments in the hotel. One former St. Regis butler now manages the Carlyle Hotel; another manages a chain of hotels in Holland.
Benjamin Lau, also a former butler, is now the training manager for the program at all St. Regis properties, including the branch that is to open in Los Angeles next month, and the St. Regis Club, 105 rooms that will be managed by St. Regis at the Essex House in New York, also opening next month.
"Our first generation of butlers were trained by Ivor Spencer," Mr. Lau said, referring to the premier butler trainer in England. "We took the master skills from a private house and used them in a hotel setting for our guests, who are C.E.O.'s, celebrities and royalty. The butler is the nerve center of the hotel for the guest."
The usual training period for a St. Regis butler is 30 days, during which time trainees trail a butler, learning everything from cutting a cigar to opening a bottle of Champagne. Mr. Lau said trainees also "do a lot of role-playing, trying to anticipate the guest's needs."
Mr. Lau showed me to the presidential suite, where the nightly fee is $11,500. As we settled at the dining room table, he surveyed it sideways. "This needs polishing," he noted. He also had the unsettling habit of running his hands along the walls or on moldings in the hallways, checking for dust, and more than once, he bent over to remove a small speck of something from the floor or a table, tucking it into his pocket.
"You're trained to pay attention to detail," he said, enumerating the butler's myriad duties, including my personal favorite, packing and unpacking. Do people really want a stranger going through their things?
Mr. Lau nodded. "We never unpack toiletries unless requested," he said, "but guests often send their luggage ahead and have the butler unpack, using his or her judgment about what needs to be pressed.
"We are often asked to hang the clothes by color, which is how some people organize their closets," he continued. "But if you don't like us to unpack, we will include it in your guest history and won't offer the service again. A lot of people love it."
He told of one guest who travels with an enormous assortment of vitamins; the butler must arrange them from Vitamin A onward, but never on a surface where the guest has to bend down.
He's kidding, right? Mr. Lau shook his head seriously. "When I was a butler, I found this to be very interesting about other people's lifestyles," he said. "It's something for your life library."
Other selections might include the night that the guest in the presidential suite requested Mr. Lau and two other butlers to stand along the wall like movie extras, while a party of 10 was served dinner. Then, there was the morning a C.E.O.'s shined shoes disappeared; it seemed another guest found the sight of them in the hallway aesthetically unpleasing and threw them away. The hotel, needless to say, replaced them. Did they kick out that guest?
Mr. Lau looked surprised. "No," he said. "He comes back often, and when he does, we are very careful to keep all the shined shoes in the pantry until the wake-up calls."
With these kinds of considerations, don't the butlers ever feel like slaves? "No," Mr. Lau said firmly. "They are managing the lifestyle of the guest. And it is a stepping stone for their careers."
It certainly is for Keiley Rea, the 16th-floor butler to whom I was assigned. A 24-year-old native of Northampton, England, she has been at the St. Regis for five months and is already, Mr. Lau said, quite promising.
Ms. Rea familiarized me with the large board in the butler's pantry, where the status of every room and its guests is updated hourly -- vacant or occupied, clean or dirty, inspected or not. When she brings anything to a room, she does not use a cart, since the hotel's idea of the butler is to remind a guest of home. Or the home they wished they lived in.
I looked through some guest histories. One "loves Grgich Hills white wine as amenity upon arrival," and another "waited too long for breakfast" in March of 1998. That incident remains listed as a reminder not to do it again.
I accompanied Ms. Rea on inspections of cleaned rooms, and Mr. Lau came along, to check on his charge. She put on one white glove to check dust on the moldings and the headboard, then got down on her hands and knees behind the desk. She opened each drawer and swept her hand underneath the paper liners. She looked beneath the sofa cushions for crumbs and arranged the chocolates, so that all the St. Regis logos faced up. She held the bar glasses up to the light to see if they were clean and double-checked the expiration dates on items in the mini bar.
In the bathroom, she ran her gloveless hand over the insides of the bathtub, checking for stray hairs (yuck!), and when she checked the bathrobes, she rearranged a satin hanger, so its bow faced forward.
The entire process took 15 minutes. Mr. Lau then pointed out that one bathroom sconce had a light bulb with the wrong wattage. Except for the tips of her ears turning red, she remained composed. "Yes, thank you," she said evenly. I would have smacked him.
As we moved on to the occupied rooms, she was distressed to find an ash in an ashtray, but went into the bathroom and emerged, relieved. "The guest has been back," she said. "There is a used washcloth as well." She put it on her silver tray and made a note to have it replaced. She also refolded the toilet paper.
"It's nice for the guest to see that the butler's been in," she said comfortably, heading back to the pantry for the umpteenth time. I nodded. And I couldn't help but think that it was ever so much nicer to have a butler, than to be one.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Automakers Paying The Price of Higher Rates

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
WHEN automakers brought out their 2000 models last fall, executives were jubilant. Their companies were enjoying record sales, and the Federal Reserve's two interest rate increases seemed to be having little effect; the manufacturers simply offset them by subsidizing their discounted auto loans more heavily.
Auto sales remain strong, but the optimism has faded. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, has pushed up short-term interest rates four more times since last autumn. Trying to avoid raising interest rates for their discounted loans, automakers stepped up the subsidies even further, but the mounting costs crimped profit margins. They wound up having to raise rates anyway on their lowest-rate loans this summer. 
 "Greenspan was trying to slow it down and we didn't believe it -- we thought it was just a bump; we'll eat it," said Tom McAlear, the chief operating officer of DaimlerChrysler Financial Services, the North American lending unit of the German automaker. "Finally, we said, 'Alan, you're serious, we believe you.' "
Economists are fond of repeating the adage that monetary policy affects the real economy with long and variable lags. The lag has seemed longer than usual for the current round of rate increases. The continued strength of the stock market has played a role, but so has the remarkable stamina of auto sales even as rates have risen.
When the Fed raised interest rates in 1994 in leaps of half a point and even three-quarters of a point at a time, the automakers' finance subsidiaries reacted with alarm, swiftly passing on matching rate increases to their loan customers. The automakers, particularly General Motors, were still reeling from the 1991 recession and in no mood then for a war of discounts.
But the current round of Fed increases crept up on an industry that has been very profitable since the mid-1990's. All but one of the increases came in just a quarter-point increment, and most have been hailed on Wall Street as the last. One result has been a gradual ratcheting up of incentive costs, escalating into a discounting war that no automaker is willing to lose, even as everyone in the industry hopes that the Fed will not act again.
"There's a little heat on -- we're hoping for no more increases," said G. Richard Wagoner Jr., G.M.'s chief executive.
While Internet and computer companies now rule Wall Street, the auto industry remains a cornerstone of the real economy. Autos still account for about 4 percent of the nation's economy, a percentage that has barely budged in decades. General Motors, Ford Motor and DaimlerChrysler are each eight times the size of Microsoft in sales, and economic output is measured by final sales of goods and services, not by stock prices. Yet G.M.'s market value is now just a tenth of Microsoft's, one reason that Carl Icahn bought a big stake in G.M. last week.
Consumer interest rates are the crucial economic factor in auto sales. Four-fifths of all vehicle buyers finance their cars, minivans, pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles through loans or leases. They closely study monthly payments, which depend on interest rates. By contrast, the price of filling up the tank, high this summer, has rarely had much impact on auto sales over the years, except when the overall economy was weak.
Banks raised their auto loan rates repeatedly over the last year in response to Fed actions. The average bank rate for four-year auto loans is now just over 10 percent, compared with 8.3 percent in the spring of last year, said David L. Littmann, the senior economist at Comerica Bank in Detroit.
After the recent increases, automakers' finance subsidiaries are now charging an average of about 7 percent. Their average for the second quarter, 6.48 percent, was actually a few hundredths of a point lower than a year earlier. Automakers tried to raise their finance subsidiaries' rates last winter, but they retreated rather than lose market share to rivals.
Not surprisingly, the manufacturers have been financing a growing number of their customers' purchases, and the subsidies to keep rates so low have pushed automakers' marketing costs to as much as $2,300 a vehicle. Sales continue to roll along at a very strong pace of 17.5 million cars and light trucks a year, a little slower than last winter on a seasonally adjusted basis but still ahead of last year.
The question is how much longer it will be before the auto industry gives in and raises or restricts its subsidized rates, at the risk of losing sales. James P. Holden, the chief executive of the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler, says this has begun to happen, but slowly. "We have stopped matching every Fed increase and holding flat payments," he said. "Payments have gone up."

HEADLINE: Investing;
The Pocketbook Issues In the Future of Coach

BYLINE: By KATE BERRY

 BODY:
INVESTORS who are awaiting the initial public offering of Coach Inc., the luxury leather goods maker, are likely to be disappointed, analysts warn, because Coach's parent, the Sara Lee Corporation, might well do better if it sells the unit than if it takes it public.
Sara Lee reached a similar conclusion last week when it agreed to sell its PYA/Monarch food service unit to Koninklijke Ahold N.V., the Dutch supermarket giant, for $1.57 billion. In June, PYA/Monarch filed with the Securities and Exchange Corporation to raise $160 million in an initial offering to be managed by Goldman Sachs, Bear Stearns and Salomon Smith Barney. 
 In each case, Sara Lee intended initially to keep 80 percent of the company and offer 20 percent to the public.
"With the direct sale of PYA/Monarch to Ahold, Sara Lee obtains cash now, eliminates market uncertainty and secures a multiyear supply contract, creating significant value for Sara Lee shareholders," said C. Steven McMillan, chief executive of Sara Lee.
Mr. McMillan was the architect of the company's plan to sell some assets and focus on its core businesses. Though it is best known for its baked goods, Sara Lee also owns brands including Ball Park franks, L'eggs hosiery, Hanes underwear, Wonderbra, Endust furniture cleaner and Kiwi shoe polish.
A Sara Lee spokeswoman, Julie Ketay, said after the PYA/Monarch deal that the $140 million Coach offering, to be managed by Goldman Sachs, was still on track to be completed by the end of the year, but some fund managers and analysts are not convinced.
LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, the French luxury goods group, is among the many names being tossed up as potential buyers of Coach. Last year LVMH teamed up with its archrival Prada S.p.A. to win a bidding war with the Gucci Group for another high-class brand, Fendi, the Italian apparel and accessories group. They paid one trillion lire, or $483.6 million, for a 51 percent stake in Fendi.
"For some reason, the market will put a higher multiple on the same business with the same earnings if Bernard Arnault owned this company," said Greg Fontana, vice president and co-manager for the John Hancock funds in Boston, referring to the LVMH chairman.
PEDRO BERNAL, an analyst at Wachovia Securities in Charlotte, N.C., said: "The most likely choice is for it to be sold than to do an I.P.O. Just about everybody has been mentioned, so it's not a question of who, but what price."
To be sure, some fashion stocks have performed poorly, like Donna Karan International and Tommy Hilfiger. But those with expanded product lines like jewelry, shoes and handbags, have proved that pricey baubles have a place on Wall Street. Coach, with sales of $507 million in the fiscal year ended July 3, 1999, according to its prospectus, may be aiming for a valuation akin to that of Kenneth Cole, the shoe designer that also makes handbags and accessories, analysts say. Kenneth Cole, which has seen its shares jump to $45.3125, from below $10 a share in 1998, has a market capitalization of $925.05 million.
Jeffrey Kanter, an analyst at Prudential Securities, said Coach had plenty of momentum behind it. "It's bouncing back from a difficult environment over the past few years where Asia reduced their purchasing power," he said.
Sales grew at a compounded annual rate of 32 percent a year, to $540.4 million in 1997, from $19 million in 1985 when Sara Lee acquired the family-owned business, only to slide as a result of Asia's financial crisis. Sales dipped 3.4 percent in 1998 and 2.8 percent in 1999 but are now starting to recover.
The company, which has 106 American retail stores, hopes to rebound with an ambitious plan to open 50 new stores in the next three years, remodel existing ones and expand its international presence. Similar strategies helped fatten revenue for Tiffany, Gucci , and LVMH, all of which have expanded their product lines to attract upper middle-class shoppers -- those that have fared so well in today's economy.
Coach, which also sells through several catalogs and 63 factory outlets, sees big growth opportunities in Japan, where consumers spend substantially more for handbags than in the United States. The company has a fashionably modern Web site and is branching into products for the home, like leather director's chairs, and even into pet supplies, from collars to beds. But analysts caution that fashion trends change quickly in high-end luxury goods.
If there is an initial offering, Coach could gain points because, unlike many others going public, it is profitable. In the first 39 weeks of fiscal 2000, Coach's net income jumped 67 percent, to $32.3 million, as sales rose 9.7 percent, to $427.2 million, according to its S.E.C. filing.
Proceeds from the initial offering would be used to repay a portion of debt to Sara Lee. Coach also plans to enter into a revolving credit facility with Sara Lee under which it may borrow up to $75 million. (It expects to borrow about $50 million in the first quarter of fiscal 2001.)
Within 18 months of the initial offering, Sara Lee plans to sell its 80.1 percent stake in Coach. Sara Lee also plans to shed Champion sportswear, with $500 million in annual sales, and its recently acquired International Fabrics division of the British retailer Courtaulds Textiles, with $400 million in sales.
In announcing the divestiture plans, Mr. McMillan said that the sales would bring in at least $2.5 billion, giving the company enough cash to buy other companies that fit better with the brands it is keeping.
"Steve McMillan will spend the peak of his career disassembling the conglomerate that he built," said Mr. Fontana, at John Hancock funds. "I don't believe conglomerates make sense unless you're Jack Welch."
