HEADLINE: Health Care Bonds Pass a Credit Test

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
ALTHOUGH still under the shadows of a government investigation into its billing practices, HCA-The Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest hospital chain, made a successful foray into the debt markets on Friday.
Strong investor demand allowed HCA, formerly called the Columbia/ HCA Healthcare Corporation, to increase the size of its issue by 50 percent, to $750 million. 
 The debt offering was a key test of whether HCA had regained the trust of investors, and apparently it had: they placed more than $2 billion in orders for the 10-year notes. It was also a test of whether the for-profit health care industry was recovering after years in critical care.
The reception that investors gave the HCA issue added to evidence from the stock market that it is. Shares of publicly traded hospital companies have soared this year, even as the overall stock market has stumbled on concerns about rising interest rates and slowing corporate growth.
Kathleen F. Lamb, a high-yield health care analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, called the market hot for hospital credit issues. "Issuers not taking advantage of this are asleep at the wheel," she said.
Through underwriters led by Chase Securities and Goldman, Sachs, HCA priced 10-year senior unsecured notes at 99.53 to yield 8.821 percent, or about 305 basis points more than a 10-year Treasury note with a comparable maturity. (A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.) Price talk ahead of the sale was of a spread over Treasuries of 312.5 to 325 basis points. The notes, which were given an 8.75 percent coupon, have a maturity date of Sept. 1, 2010.
HCA, based in Nashville, is considered a bellwether in the hospital industry. It initially planned to issue two maturities but settled on one. Moody's Investors Services rated the 10-year note Ba-2, its second-highest junk grade. The Standard & Poor's Corporation gave it a low investment grade, BB+.
Stephen Carter, senior market analyst at MCM CorporateWatch, a research firm, said the deal included a make-whole call provision. "In effect what this means is that the issue is essentially noncallable because the price is so high and will only be called if Treasury yields move significantly lower and it makes economic sense to do so," he said. "This is a regular feature on many investment grade and upper-level-rated high-yield bond issues."
HCA said the proceeds from the financing would be used for general corporate purposes including repayment of bank debt. In May, the company agreed to pay $745 million in civil penalties to settle part of a broad government inquiry into whether its success was achieved in part by cheating federal health programs.
Still, criminal and other civil investigations that have long been at the heart of the case remain unresolved. They concern whether the company's hospitals fraudulently overstated expenses to increase reimbursement from Medicare and other federal health programs and engaged in illegal financial relationships with doctors. Under the terms of the partial settlement, both Columbia and the government are under pressure to resolve the entire case before the end of this year.
THE debt sale last week represented the company's first trip to the bond market since 1997, when government agents raided the company's offices and hospitals in seven states, seizing documents. Last year, under the old corporate name, HCA tried to sell $250 million of shorter-maturity securities, but withdrew before they could sell, citing market conditions.
Amid the government's investigation, the hospital chain has changed its name and installed a strong new management team to the delight of some portfolio managers. It has also improved its balance sheet by shedding 140 hospitals from a peak of 340 in 1997 and reduced its debt by about $2.4 billion, to just a little less than $7 billion, trimmed costs and bargained for better terms with private insurers who pay patient bills.
In addition to HCA, a large number of other companies issued debt last week, selling over $12 billion in investment grade securities, according to MCM CorporateWatch.

HEADLINE: The Powers Behind the Auctions

BYLINE: By LISA GUERNSEY

 BODY:
WHEN people think of online auctions, they probably envision retirees selling bean bags from their basements and collectors trading baseball cards or limited-edition lunch boxes. After all, the founder of eBay, Pierre M. Omidyar, and its chief executive, Meg Whitman, are considered ingenious precisely because they created the first efficient global marketplace where consumers could sell directly to one another.
But occasional sellers are hardly what have made eBay, with more than $87.9 million in online revenue in the second quarter, one of the most successful Internet businesses to date. Log on to eBay and you can easily find brand-new air-conditioners, boxes of unused printer cartridges and cases of 7-inch zippers, all nylon, all black. Rather than just items destined for garage sales, plenty of new merchandise is available. "This is not just mom and pop cleaning out their attics," said Evie Black Dykema, a senior analyst at Forrester Research. "There is this whole subeconomy of small businesses who use eBay." 
 The real powers behind eBay's success are those small operators -- the liquidators, wholesalers, small retail shops and stay-at-home entrepreneurs -- that offer the bulk of goods for sale on eBay, underpinning its entire business.
Call them power sellers -- eBay does. By putting dozens of new items up for sale every day, these sellers keep buyers coming back to bid and bid again. Of the four million items listed on the site on any given day, the top 20 sellers are responsible for 72,000 listings, and the top 38,000 sellers account for 2.7 million items, according to AuctionWatch.com, an online auction services company. At last count, eBay had 15.8 million registered users, or Internet names for people who use the site to buy or sell or both.
And because power sellers, like all other sellers, pay eBay listing fees and commissions ranging from 1.25 to 5 percent of the value of each item sold, they contribute a huge proportion of the company's revenues.
Some sellers list goods on other auction sites, either as an alternative or supplement to eBay. Yahoo Auctions, the biggest of those rivals, has 2.5 million listings. But as the first company to exploit the online auction model, eBay dominates, holding nearly 90 percent of the online auction market, measured by sales. That sheer volume, said Steven Johnson, director of the e-commerce program at Andersen Consulting, drives more buyers to eBay, which in turn attracts even more high-volume sellers.
Who are these overachievers? A power seller, by eBay's definition, has met at least one of three levels of standards in volume and customer service -- designated as bronze, silver and gold. To earn the bronze label, a seller must have minimum monthly sales of $2,000; for silver, $10,000 a month; for gold, at least $25,000 a month -- more than many small businesses ever achieve, online or off. Would-be power sellers must also have received at least 100 comments from buyers in the feedback forum, where buyers and sellers rate each others' performance, and 98 percent of their ratings must be positive.
EBay says it has 20,000 to 25,000 power sellers, though it will not disclose how many have hit any particular level. But those numbers do not include people who may be meeting the power-seller standards but have not had the time or the inclination to join eBay's program, which offers them perks like full-time customer service support and permission to display an official power-seller logo.
EBay declined to disclose financial details about the sellers who make its business hum. But Andale Inc., an auction management company in Mountain View, Calif. that provides e-mail tools and database services to online sellers, has pored over eBay's listings and determined that 10 percent of eBay's sellers are responsible for 80 percent of its sales. That 10 percent thus sold about $1 billion of the $1.3 billion worth of toys, jewelry, computers, sporting goods, real estate and other merchandise that changed hands on eBay in the last quarter.
And they may be making hefty profits. Again, eBay would not give details of its users' businesses, but a survey conducted by Andale in March found that sellers made a 40 percent profit margin, on average. By contrast, many online retailers are not yet in the black, according to Forrester. According to a report that Forrester released in April, and based in part on interviews with 50 companies, less than 40 percent of the e-tailers expected to make money before 2002.
"Online auctions are a seriously lucrative way to sell," said Munjal Shah, chief executive of Andale. "There are a whole troop of merchants that have grown up around that realization."
For these sellers, there are obvious advantages, mainly that they can attract buyers without spending money on marketing and that commissions are low. By contrast, Amazon.com spent about 25 percent of its sales on marketing last year -- and that proportion is "significantly lower than everyone else's online," according to Mike May, a senior analyst for Jupiter Communications.
EBay's role as an inexpensive marketing channel, however, may also make it a breeding ground for fraud. The company does not attempt to police transactions, enabling it to keep its own costs low. But that raises the possibility that sellers may be hawking stolen, counterfeit, damaged or fake merchandise on its site. One dissatisfied buyer is trying to organize a class action suit by customers who believe they were defrauded by big sellers.
And while some buyers, in comments left on feedback forums, rave about individual power sellers, others complain that eBay coddles its power sellers at the expense of buyers.
But as long as eBay thrives, power sellers appear to be here to stay, and their numbers will probably grow. In recent months, a new category of businesses has emerged that is dedicated to helping them. These companies, like Andale, AuctionWorks and AuctionWatch.com, provide billing and shipping services and software to track and respond to hundreds of auction listings simultaneously. "This has become a real business," said Ms. Dykema of Forrester, "and there are now real tools to manage it."
So exactly who are these small businesses that use eBay as a staging ground for e-commerce? Here are four whose revenues meet power-seller standards.
 
The Retailer
A Small Business Triples Its Volume
On a Sunday night a year and a half ago, Nang Nguyen was sitting at his computer, looking at jewelry listings on eBay. He had decided to bid on a diamond ring in a platinum setting; it would be a present for his wife, Kim. The ring was listed by a store he had never heard of -- Sun Jewelry, a tiny shop in a Los Angeles shopping mall, thousands of miles from his home in Hershey, Pa.
When he won the bidding, he and his wife were thrilled. "The price was incredible," remembered Mr. Nguyen (pronounced "win"). He immediately called Los Angeles to talk with the shop's owner, Abit Uygan. They hit it off.
Mr. Uygan said he was a new seller on eBay. Mr. Nguyen responded that he was a rookie buyer. Mr. Uygan described the bad luck he had experienced with other forms of online sales, including several failed attempts to run a Web site. Mr. Nguyen, who was working in his father's shoe store in Hershey, offered to help Mr. Uygan sell other pieces of jewelry on eBay.
Their partnership, Mr. Nguyen said, has thrived. Since last year, the two men have owned Sun Jewelry together. While Mr. Uygan continues to oversee the production of the jewelry, which he and a few employees make by hand in the back room of the Los Angeles shop, Mr. Nguyen runs the administrative side, including the eBay listings, from an office next door to his father's shoe store in Hershey.
Sun's sales have tripled in the last year and a half, Mr. Nguyen said. They sell up to 800 pieces of jewelry a month, about 90 percent online. The two men are now considering taking the company public.
"Without the online auction, I don't think it would be possible to be where we are today, thinking about an I.P.O.," Mr. Nguyen said.
But at the beginning, he was not sure that eBay was the answer. Sun Jewelry already had its own Web site (www.sunjewelry.com) and Mr. Nguyen had decided to try several Internet marketing avenues at once. Those included banner and classified advertising, links with other Web sites and requests for listing on search engines.
"Listing your Web site -- trust me, it doesn't work," he said. Selling items through eBay was the only thing that did. "It has put us in an area where everyone can see us," he added. "Before, we were just a small store, tucked away." Now Mr. Nguyen does not even try to advertise the Sun Jewelry Web site, although it still attracts customers who remember seeing it on eBay.
Mr. Nguyen has also started using eBay as a test bed for pricing. He will list a ring on eBay and watch how many bids it gets, and how many people click through to see the photograph and the closing price. If the ring sells well, he may offer a few more of a similar design on eBay or decide to showcase it on his Web site at a set price.
Of course, the surge in business has brought trials. During the holiday season last year, the company had a three-week backup in orders. And maintaining friendly and accessible customer service has been a challenge. Mr. Nguyen said he calls almost every one of his customers himself. His phone bill, he said, runs from $800 to $1,000 a month.
In the last few months, he has bought services from Andale, the auction-management company that automates his listings, allows for different forms of payment and reminds him to send feedback to each buyer.
Amid all the activity, in fact, he still has not yet visited the Sun Jewelry store in Los Angeles, or even met his partner face to face. "I have no idea what he looks like," Mr. Nguyen said. "But I'm going out to his wedding next year, so I'll finally see him there."
 
The Home Business
Clearing Out Closets And Making Money
Three years ago, Kimberly Crockett was working for a regional investment company, selling mutual funds from her home in Panama City Beach, Fla. Still in her 20's, she had already built a fine life, with a three-bedroom house within walking distance of the beach on the Gulf of Mexico.
But these days, Ms. Crockett does not have much time to get to the beach, and her fund work is on the back burner. Since the spring of 1998, she has built a booming business from her home, selling collectible toys on eBay.
Always enchanted by "The Wizard of Oz," Ms. Crockett had secretly hoped she might be able to make money by collecting television and movie memorabilia. In 1989, she decided on a whim to buy two shopping carts full of Pee Wee Herman toys that were on sale in a store for a few dollars apiece. It was a smart gamble: several pieces now sell for more than $200 each.
But until the Web came along, she never imagined being able to make a good living from her hobby. Today, she sells 1,000 to 2,000 toys a month on eBay, and has just hired her first employee. She declined to divulge details of her profits, but said she was having no trouble making money.
"I always double my money," Ms. Crockett said in a phone interview from her home, barely distracted by her light-brown cat, Panama, which sat beside her crouched on a Three Stooges mouse pad.
Ms. Crockett, who goes by the name SillyOzibul on eBay, started collecting toys with a fervor about three years ago, after helping a "Star Wars" fan find a rare Princess Leia figurine. After a few months of scouring toy shows, garage sales and collectors' conventions, she realized that she had developed a sizable collection without any plan for what to do with it.
"One day I opened one of the bedroom doors, and there were just bags and bags of stuff," she said. "I couldn't even walk in. And I said: 'What are you doing, Kim? You just can't horde this stuff.' "
Ms. Crockett decided to try eBay. The first item, one of those Pee Wee Herman dolls, sold for $18, and within a few months she had built a company called Oz Wars Toys, a title that blends "Wizard of Oz" and "Star Wars." Two of the three bedrooms in her house are now storage areas, and the living room is a packaging site, strewn with boxes and bubble wrap. The kitchen is the only area that is devoid of collectibles -- except for the Oz plates that hang above the cabinets.
Her house is so full of toys, Ms. Crockett said, that she is looking to rent about 1,000 square feet of space nearby where she can operate the online business and sell a few items to local residents who stop by.
As the business grows, it is becoming more professional. She has bought services from AuctionWorks to help manage the business; the move saved her the 30 hours a week she had spent writing e-mail messages to customers and filling out feedback forms rating her buyers.
But regardless of how much her business grows, Ms. Crockett said, she is not ready to part with all of her collectibles, especially those related to Dorothy and the Yellow Brick Road. "I've just sold a bunch of 'Wizard of Oz' flags for $50 apiece," she said. "They are really nice ruby-slippers flags, with slippers that sparkle and a sign that says, 'No Place Like Home.' "
"Several bidders fought over them on eBay," she said, "but I've got to keep one for me."
 
The Liquidator
A Hot Market For Unsold Clothes
Andrew J. Waites, a tall, tan, well-dressed man with a thick Southern accent, jumped into e-commerce last year. But he has no intention of moving his liquidating business to Silicon Valley from West Front Street in Hattiesburg, Miss.
For starters, he would not fit in, he declared in a recent interview. "In south Mississippi," he said with a playful smile, "we're not smart enough to figure out how to make money by selling merchandise and losing money on each item."
Instead, he has turned to eBay, which he will use as the infrastructure for a new site, eValueville.com. His company, Inventory Procurement Services, specializes in selling the shirts, coats, jeans and dresses that retail shops want to get rid of, usually because they want to make room for new styles and more seasonable clothing.
Previously, he distributed those goods to small retail shops that have closeouts. Then, last summer, he received a box of Kenneth Cole leather coats of different shapes and sizes. "We said, 'How are we going to sell these in the summer in Hattiesburg, Mississippi?' " he recalled. "We put them on eBay, and we were amazed at the final sales price." As a result, something that would have been almost impossible to sell at $69 in his hometown became a hot $200 item.
But one real advantage of the online auction sites, he said, is the ability to reduce expenses, especially for marketing. Sometimes, he said, he does not bother paying eBay's $2 fee for putting a listing in bold type, yet he has sold 100 percent of the clothing that he has tried to sell and has made a profit on each item.
Mr. Waites also uses eBay as a hook. He sometimes starts items at $1 each, regardless of what they must sell for to recover costs, to draw just-lookers -- in hopes that they will go to the Evalueville site. By mid-September, he added, he will be listing 5,000 items a week on eBay.
He has also been visiting department stores and manufacturers, trying to sell them on his new business plan. He is betting that he will be able to get them better prices than they might through conventional liquidation channels. "I think we can improve their recovery by 2 to 3 percentage points," he said. "We think eBay will be for us the biggest outlet mall in the world."
 
The Wholesaler
Giving the Consumer Economies of Scale
For more than 20 years, Larry Bence has been supplying retail stores with collectible cards and coins. And he has been using computers for 15 years -- he was part of a proprietary network of dealers who were sending messages back and forth in the very early days of the Internet. So in the mid-1990's, when everyone started talking about expanding commerce on the Web, he was all for it.
But after setting up a Web site, he found that the effort was not worth it. He and his staff, including his daughter, Julie, would spend hours listing the prices of sports cards, posters, toy cars, and dinnerware with football logos. Then something in the news would bump the prices up or down, and the site would have to be updated.
"It's just impossible to maintain that many different pricing ranges," said Mr. Bence, whose company is called Abon Cards and Coins Ltd. After trying six times with different Web site designs, he gave up.
"The only people that I've seen who make money on Web sites," he said, "are the people who design them." Mr. Bence still has a Web site, but it is just a few pages.
As a wholesaler with more than 100,000 square feet of warehouse space in Ohio, Mr. Bence did not have to worry about finding a place for inventory to feed his online business. And he could have settled for a continuation of his conventional business, selling pallets of cards and memorabilia to retailers. But he wanted to tap into the consumer market, too, without doing any advertising.
That is why he turned to eBay, he said. He now assigns about a dozen of his 22 staff members to manage his eBay listings of cards, coins and related items. His eBay business is now large enough that he has chosen to become an eBay gold power seller. He has developed software to help his company manage all of the accounts; one of his homemade software packages runs checks on credit card numbers and addresses to make sure that a buyer is not using a stolen card. "It's hairy," he said. "We are gritting our teeth. That's the one area that is very vulnerable."
The venture has turned his business into a blend of wholesale and retail, a mix that he said is becoming increasingly common on the Internet. Ultimately, he is able to sell small quantities of goods to consumers at wholesale prices, while still selling pallets of merchandise to retailers.
Mr. Bence said his presence on eBay had also built his contact base, enabling him find more items to sell: "There are people who see us on eBay who contact us and say, 'I wonder if he'll want to buy stuff.' " he added. "I just bought a bunch of collegiate dinnerware -- Michigan State dinnerware. In Ohio, not many people may want Michigan State dinnerware. But on the Internet, there are probably plenty of Michigan State fans who will have no problem paying up."

HEADLINE: The Nation: The Wave;
The Conventions Are Over. The Party's Just Starting.

BYLINE: By ROBIN TONER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
FOR all the talk about the great race to the center this year, nobody who watched the two conventions, skimmed the parties' platforms or scrutinized the candidates' stands would mistake the Democrat for the Republican.
Yes, much of the time a certain rhetorical sameness wafted from the main stages of the convention halls, and there was little of the partisan bite of yesteryear. But political passions kept bubbling up, just offstage. And even among the voters at large, at a time of peace and prosperity, with few great burning issues pushing people in one direction or another, two-thirds of Americans still consider themselves Democrats or Republicans. 
 Party, in other words, still matters.
Party attachment is still considered one of the best predictors of how people will vote -- if they vote. But appealing to those loyalties, while still wooing the Independents who decide elections, is a complicated challenge these days. Particularly for Vice President Al Gore, many analysts say.
The New York Times/CBS News Poll shows that the Democrats have a slight edge when it comes to party affiliation: Asked in four national polls this year how they identify themselves, an average of 35 percent of Americans said they were Democrats, 30 percent Republicans, 28 percent Independents and 7 percent (probably the least likely to vote) said they had no opinions.
In a Times/CBS poll conducted last month, the Democratic Party was still considered the party that would do a better job on health care, education and "making the right decisions" on Social Security -- all issues high on the voters' agenda.
The Republican Party was given the edge on upholding traditional family values, making sure the military stays strong and ensuring a healthy economy. Each party, in other words, brings its nominee certain strengths this fall.
But until last week, Democratic voters have not embraced Mr. Gore's candidacy with the enthusiasm Republicans have brought to Gov. George W. Bush; the last pre-convention Times/CBS poll showed Mr. Gore drawing 75 percent of the Democrats, while Mr. Bush got 86 percent of the Republicans. "I think they wasted half their convention just trying to get strong Democrats and soft Democrats home," said Bill McInturff, a Republican pollster. (Post-convention polls will tell how successful they were.)
There are obvious reasons why Mr. Gore has had to work harder for voters who should be rightfully his: The Democratic Party has held the presidency for eight years. The strains are showing between liberals and "New Democrats" who want to keep the party in the center. And the Gore candidacy has had its fits and starts.
This was the landscape for Mr. Gore's acceptance speech Thursday night: He needed to energize his base, but he was also keenly aware of the swing voters turned off by partisan appeals. On one level, his speech was profoundly Democratic. He offered himself as a populist crusader willing to fight "powerful forces" -- like big H.M.O.'s and profit-hungry pharmaceutical companies -- on behalf of "working families."
But in sharp contrast to convention speeches of yesteryear, Mr. Gore's never mentioned the words Democrat or Republican, noted Martin Wattenberg, a political scientist at the University of California-Irvine.
"It's populist, but it's a broad populism," said Stan Greenberg, Mr. Gore's pollster. "It's saying, let's make sure the whole society is able to do well."
To galvanize his party, and to pull back many of the Independents who lean their way, Mr. Gore needs to draw sharp contrasts with the Republicans, many Democratic strategists agree, particularly on basic issues like tax cuts and health care.
But Republicans have not made it easy.
Frustrated Democrats say Mr. Bush is preaching a message -- that he is a different kind of Republican, more sensitive and moderate -- that is distinctly at odds with his basic conservatism.
"Part of the task that Gore and the Democrats face in the fall is to tell voters that George W. Bush really is an old-style Republican," said Geoff Garin, a Democratic pollster. In other words, to block Mr. Bush's move to the center, now that he has consolidated his own party.
Many Democrats are eager to make that case and highlight the stakes: What kind of Supreme Court justices would a Bush administration, operating with a Republican Senate, appoint?
Who would most profit from his tax cuts?
What would his budget proposals mean for Medicare?
How does Mr. Bush's health care record in Texas, which ranks high among states in the percentage of uninsured, gibe with his promise to provide health coverage nationwide?
But the Gore campaign is in something of a strategic box, one Republican strategist argued, speaking on condition that he not be identified. While the Democrats need to highlight the differences between the parties, overt partisanship gives the Bush campaign the higher moral ground.
Day after day, the Bush campaign chastised the Democrats for any hint of partisan attacks at their convention. In fact, party strategists say, Mr. Bush is convinced that the voters are weary of such fights.
"Bush has seriously studied what has happened since Republicans gained control of Congress in 1994," said Linda DiVall, a Republican poll taker. "Frankly, Republicans don't do well when we get into a fight with Clinton or a fight among ourselves."
Mr. Bush, of course, has the luxury of denouncing partisanship and muting the differences. Eight years in the wilderness, and a profound disdain for the Clinton administration, go a long way toward keeping Republican voters unified and motivated.
Moreover, Mr. Bush has ably capitalized on his party's traditional strengths -- most notably, in the aftermath of the Clinton scandals, the notion that Republicans have stronger moral values. And he has dealt with his party's vulnerabilities, presenting a multi-ethnic, family-friendly convention program.
WITH all his "rhetorical convergence," as the political scientist Thomas Mann puts it, some voters might well ask just whether there's much difference between the parties -- an argument at the heart of Ralph Nader's third-party campaign.
But, of course, in their attitudes toward government, their approach to social issues like abortion and gay rights, their economic philosophy and their approach to restructuring Medicare and Social Security, the differences are large and enduring.
And each party's reliable supporters are quite distinctive, too.
Party affiliation is still, quite often, passed down from parent to child, some political scientists say.
Economic status is still strongly linked with party attachment, although Republicans have attracted more lower-income members through the party's embrace of social conservatives, while Democrats have drawn more white-collar voters.
Larry Bartels, a professor of politics at Princeton University, maintains that party loyalty was a greater factor in presidential voting in the 1990's than at any time since the 1950's.
And Mr. McInturff notes that, if anything, partisan voters have become even more so thanks to the polarizing figures of President Clinton and former Speaker Newt Gingrich -- but for the same reason people in the middle may have become even more turned off by partisanship.
All of which suggests the complicated politics that awaits the voters this fall: a fierce, nonpartisan partisan struggle. For Mr. Gore, the campaign will be about "fighting for working families," and for Mr. Bush, "compassionate conservatism." In other words, the parties are dead, long live the parties.

Coverage of the Republican convention drew more viewers below age 34, on average, while the Democrats attracted more viewers in older age groups.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Why Foresters Prefer to Fight Fire With Fire

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN

DATELINE: SEATTLE

 BODY:
NINETY years ago today, in the choking heat of a summer without rain in the northern Rockies, the sun disappeared from the sky and a sound not unlike cannon fire began rattling throughout Montana and Idaho. The Big Burn, as the three-million-acre firestorm of 1910 was called, eventually consumed entire towns, killed 87 people and burned a lesson into the fledgling United States Forest Service.
Thereafter, the service vowed, it would snuff out every fire, at one point swearing to do so by 10 a.m. on the day after the fire started. The best-known forester of that time, Gifford Pinchot, equated wildfire with slavery as a historic scourge of the nation. Another, Bernhard Fernow, blamed "bad habits and loose morals" for the fires. 
 Now, in the midst of the worst wildfire year in nearly half a century, a new round of finger-pointing is under way. Touring Montana last week, J. Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House, blamed the Clinton administration for not logging the tinder-dry forests. Environmentalists pointed at the timber industry and development for altering forest ecology and creating an artificial landscape ripe for catastrophe.
But the Forest Service remains focused on its own primary culprit: the symbol of fire eradication, Smokey Bear.
The era of prevention and suppression represented by Smokey and his shovel may have been good for safety, but it was not the best thing for forests. The agency had reached that conclusion even before the additional evidence foresters drew from the fires that tore through almost half of Yellowstone National Park in 1988.
Fire is as much a part of nature as creeks and wildflowers. Most forests have a natural cycle, in which a purging burn comes through every 10, 20, 50 or 100 years. The cycle may be suppressed, foresters say, but only at the cost of more powerful fires when it re-emerges.
"We have a problem when people say these fires are destroying all these areas," said Mr. Wiebe, the former Smokejumper. "It's just not correct to say a forest is destroyed by fire."
During the decades when fires were routinely suppressed, forests choked themselves with excess growth, creating better habitats for tree-killing insects. The dying trees became tinder.
"These forests are long overdue," said Mick Harrington, a research fire ecologist with the Forest Service in Montana, a state that has just been declared a disaster area. "They were just ready to go."
The fires that have already run through five million acres this year are hotter, faster-burning, more ferocious than any burns of modern times, the people battling them say. And a number of reports say future fire seasons may be worse, identifying about 40 million acres of public land as being at risk of catastrophic fire.
Fire suppression is only part of the problem. In some forests, experts say, logging has removed the biggest and most fire-resistant trees. Their replacements -- some planted, some natural -- are crowded stands of young and disease-prone trees, with 500 or more to the acre, where there used to be 50. Foresters also point to other elements -- excessive grazing by cattle and sheep, diversion of rivers to newly developing areas -- that have contributed to what some call ghost forests, spectral stands of diseased and dying timber now baking, if not yet burning, in the August sun.
In addition, there are many new areas demanding fire protection. Homes and vacation cottages that have sprung up at the edge of national forest boundaries have become firefighters' front lines.
"We've become so good at putting out fires because that's what the public wants," said Lindon Wiebe, a fire ecology specialist with the Forest Service in Washington, and a former Smokejumper, as the service's firefighters are called. "But what we can do is pretty small compared to what Mother Nature wants to do."
Just as people have gradually learned not to build homes in areas prone to flooding, they need to understand the danger of erecting structures in fire zones, says Dr. Phil Omi, a professor of forest fire science at Colorado State University and director of the Western Forest Fire Research Center.
"Somebody has got to get the message to these people that they are putting themselves at risk, whether it's the insurance industry or the government," Dr. Omi said. But he said he could not blame the Forest Service, or homeowners, for being slow to understand the nature of wild fire in the West. "Our understanding of forest fire ecology is relatively new," he said.
Those trying to address the future fire threat are focusing on two solutions: taking out more trees by logging or thinning, and deliberately setting fires.
Under Mr. Clinton, logging in national forests has declined by nearly 75 percent, and some critics blame this decline for the explosive fires. A number of Western senators back the idea of allowing the timber industry to remove more trees.
However, environmental groups point out that the biggest fires in Montana and Idaho are burning not in wilderness areas, but in land that has been developed or logged. Such areas also account for 90 percent of the acreage identified as most vulnerable to wildfire, the Forest Service says.
"Commercial logging is not a prescription for forest health -- it is one of the major causes of unhealthy forest conditions," said Thomas Powers, chairman of the economics department at the University of Montana, whose specialty is natural resource issues.
The other solution -- planned fire -- has become a public relations debacle. Last year, a record 1.4 million acres of Forest Service land was deliberately burned. Most prescribed burns go off without trouble. But it only takes one to stir public ire. And this year, the one that got away, a 43,000-acre blaze set by the National Park Service near Los Alamos, N.M., destroyed more than 200 homes.
And no matter how convinced the experts are that Los Alamos was an exception, the fires now raging in every state of the West look horrific on television, blackening national treasures like Mesa Verde National Park and raining embers on popular campgrounds.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: After the Big Burn, in 1910. Fires aren't always as bad as they look, forest experts say. (United States Forest Service)(pg. 5)
 
Chart: "A Century Of Fanning Flames"
Contrary to the wisdom that dominated the past hundred years, wildfires are native to the ecological rhythm of the forest, purging the underbrush of debris, enriching the soil, and contributing to the stability of robust, old-growth trees. But decades of development and a steady practice of stifling flames at all costs have changed the character of forest fires for the worse. A look at some of the biggest missteps:
 
HAZARDOUS HOMES
Building a home in or near the edge of forest land brings the risk of fire, but many homeowners and builders fail to take simple precautions that could reduce damage.
 
LOGGING AND CLEAR-CUTTING
In many areas, logging removed the oldest, most fire-resistant trees. The smaller, denser tree stands that grew in their absence burn more easily. Logging can also leave behind debris that acts as kindling for wildfires.
 
WATER DIVERSION
Diverting the natural waterways to serve growing communities can also change the ecology of surrounding forests, leaving them dry and undernourished. Also, rivers that once served as natural barriers to fast-moving wildfires have been narrowed, enabling flames to leap to neighboring groups of trees easily.
 
GRAZING
The growth of cattle raising throughout the 19th and 20th centuries reduced grasslands, which fuel natural forest fires and keep the flames low to the ground.
 
FIRE SUPPRESSION
Development in general led to a consistent policy of stifling fires, but this inhibited the natural process of burning and allowed stands of fire-prone trees to grow.
 
ROOFING
Metal, tile and fiberglass are best; common materials like asphalt shingles and tar paper are more flammable.
 
OUTER WALLS
Although it seems natural to build a forest home of wood, the danger is obvious. Stone, brick and metal are best.
 
AIR POCKETS
An open foundation and raised decks can stoke flames as they pass through. Storing fuel tanks in these areas is particularly dangerous.
 
BUILDING ON SLOPES
Although a hillside may offer the best views, slopes create a natural chimney for advancing flames.
 
Thicker Is Not Better
Under normal old-growth conditions, cyclical ground fires burn low through the underbrush and leave the tree stand intact.
 
When natural fires are prevented, new trees and forest debris proliferate, providing more fuel for fires when they start.
 
In the worst cases, natural burning has been prevented for decades, creating enough fuel to drive flames into the forest canopy.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 720 words

HEADLINE: The Populist Al Gore

BYLINE: By John B. Judis; John B. Judis is senior editor of The New Republic and author of "The Paradox of American Democracy."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Does a populist appeal have resonance in prosperous times? In his acceptance speech at the Democratic convention, Al Gore defined the difference between Republicans and Democrats in strict populist terms. "They're for the powerful, we're for the people," he declared.
This appeal, if updated, can be effective, even when people are doing well economically. One commentator compared Mr. Gore to William Jennings Bryan, the firebrand of 1896, but the proper comparison is with Franklin Roosevelt. Bryan's populism was the politics of an embattled minority, the last cry of Western small farmers. 
 In the 1930's, Roosevelt revived populism as a majority politics of the new urban working class. By identifying Democrats with the common man and Republicans with the "economic royalists," Roosevelt and his successors controlled Congress for 44 of the next 48 years and won eight of 12 presidential elections.
The constituency for Roosevelt's populism has not disappeared, but it became bitterly divided after 1964, largely as a result of civil rights struggles and the birth of the new left.
Under Ronald Reagan, Republicans were able to create a new conservative majority by combining their well-to-do base with disenchanted white Democrats in the South and Midwest who blamed Democrats for their falling incomes and for rising crime rates.
Bill Clinton's political achievement has been to revive the perception that Democrats represent the people while the Republicans represent special interests and the wealthy. Mr. Clinton did this by forcing Democrats to abandon the post-1960's attitude on crime and welfare that had turned off these swing voters in the first place.
Al Gore now has an opportunity to build on what Mr. Clinton has achieved -- to restore in full the older populist majority, but not on exactly the same terms as Roosevelt did.
America's "common man" has changed: he -- and she -- are more likely white-collar than blue-collar and more likely to live in suburbs than cities. And this populist majority, for the most part, doesn't want government expansion. These voters want to preserve existing social programs like Social Security and Medicare, and they want new, but modest, programs to help their families thrive in the new economy. But they are skeptical of large-scale programs that could lead to higher taxes.
What they fear is that government will become more responsive to the powerful rather than to them -- a fear evidenced in the popularity of maverick politicians like Ross Perot and John McCain and in the continuing support for campaign finance reform. Mr. Gore seems to understand this. His acceptance speech was long on defending his own modest initiatives against the threat of "big tobacco, big oil, the big polluters, the pharmaceutical companies, the H.M.O.'s."
His populism could also help where he needs it most, in energizing the Democratic base and attracting swing voters in battleground states of the Midwest.
As Ruy Teixeira and Joel Rogers demonstrate in their book, "America's Forgotten Majority," these swing voters don't live in Cleveland's upscale Shaker Heights, but in neighboring Lorain County. They are middle-income whites, most of whom have not graduated from college. Once Democrats, they backed Mr. Reagan in 1980 and 1984, but gravitated to Mr. Clinton and Mr. Perot in 1992 and 1996. They have proved responsive to a populism directed at special interests.
For instance, in the Lorain County district now represented by the Democrat Sherrod Brown, Mr. Reagan won by 19 percent in 1984. But in 1992, Mr. Clinton won 38 percent of the vote; Mr. Bush, 35 percent; and Mr. Perot, 27 percent. In 1996, Mr. Clinton won 46 percent; Bob Dole, 39 percent; and Mr. Perot, 14 percent.
It was because of the shift away from the G.O.P. among these voters that Mr. Clinton took Ohio and Michigan, as well as Missouri and Pennsylvania, in the last two elections.
Mr. Gore begins at a certain disadvantage with these voters, who may be put off by his sometimes aloof manner. But a populist approach could help him overcome his lack of personal appeal. He might not convince these voters that he is a more relaxed guy than his opponent, but if he can convince them that he is on their side and that Mr. Bush is not, he may well be the next president.

HEADLINE: INVESTING: DIARY;
Dot-Com Wariness Found in Survey

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
The new what? Most Americans have heard of the Dow Jones industrial average and the Nasdaq index, but surprisingly few have heard or read about the new economy, according to a recent survey by Scudder Kemper Investments.
Among people who said they knew what the phrase "new economy" meant, only 28 percent cited the "high-tech economy" or "high-tech stocks." A majority (61 percent) said that they found talk of dot-com companies to be confusing. The crankiest ones (38 percent) reported being fed up with hearing about technology and Internet companies. 
 "The dot-com revolution has inevitably led to more content and commentary about investing, and at increasing levels of detail and sophistication," said Joan Cannon Wood, senior vice president for Scudder Kemper Investments in Boston. "But the majority of Americans said that there's too much hype coming at them about the new economy, and many people are confused."
Indeed, the survey results show conflicting attitudes. While respondents expressed an overall cautious optimism about the economy as a whole and confidence in the long-term prospects of Internet companies and the "dot-com revolution," they were generally reluctant to invest in those companies.
Even so, the dot-com hype has created sky-high expectations among the respondents as to what returns can reasonably be expected on investments. The average return considered reasonable today is 21.7 percent. That is slightly more than the 20 percent return of the stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index over the last seven years, but nearly double the annual average return on equities of 12.1 percent from 1926 to 1990, according to Ibbotson Associates in Chicago.
The survey, conducted from April 18 through May 1, was based on 1,300 telephone interviews of randomly selected people over the age of 18. Carole Gould

HEADLINE: U.N. Reform Group Assesses U.S. Candidates

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 18

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore would give more unqualified support to the United Nations and be more willing to sign international treaties than his Republican opponent, George W. Bush, an independent United Nations watchdog organization said this week.
But Mr. Gore is still hedging his support for some important international initiatives, as President Clinton did when he met stiff resistance from Republicans in Congress. 
 The group, the Campaign for United Nations Reform, which is based in Washington, sent both major candidates in this year's race a comprehensive questionnaire on topics involving United States participation in international affairs. Congressional candidates were also polled.
Mr. Bush replied in a brief letter to Don Kraus, executive director of the Campaign for United Nations Reform, saying that while he believed that international organizations can serve the cause of peace, he would never place American troops under United Nations command. He would pay United States debts to the organization, he said, only when its bureaucracy has been reformed and American dues lowered. He also said that he wanted reforms at the International Monetary Fund and World Bank, but he did not elaborate.
Mr. Gore responded to more than a dozen questions, often at some length. He said that it was time the United States paid its dues to the United Nations "in full, on time and without conditions." He added that there had already been substantial reforms in the United Nations system. He said that agencies of the United Nations "offer the U.S. an effective means of doing our fair share to alleviate suffering in some of the most miserable corners of the globe."
On outstanding treaties not signed by the United States, Mr. Gore gave unequivocal support to the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, the Convention on the Rights of the Child, the Law of the Sea Treaty and the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty to stop the testing of nuclear arms.
But Mr. Gore continued to call for changes in an international agreement banning land mines, reflecting longstanding objections from the Pentagon. And he declined to endorse the International Criminal Court, now taking shape without American support. His said in his reply that the court's treaty still had "significant flaws."
The Campaign for United Nations Reform is a 25-year-old organization that advocates stronger American support for the United Nations.
Among Congressional responses to the organization's questionnaire, attitudes to the United Nations ranged very widely, said Jennifer Taylor, program director for the campaign. Some members of Congress were very supportive of the United Nations adherence to international treaties. But others, a small minority, responded by advocating that the United States quit the organization, which they said did not serve American interests.

HEADLINE: Venezuela Finds Source of Wealth Is Also a Curse

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CARACAS, Venezuela

 BODY:
Like motorists everywhere, Venezuelans love to complain about the price of gasoline, and they have been doing a lot of that lately. But one thing sets them apart from almost everyone else in the world: at less than 40 cents a gallon, gas is cheaper than bottled water here.
To Americans who are now paying nearly $2 a gallon for gas, such carping may seem absurd. But the constant griping about gasoline prices among Venezuelans is emblematic of their complicated and conflicted relationship with a commodity that so dominates their national life that it accounts for half of all government revenues and four-fifths of this country's exports. 
 This nation of 23 million people has the greatest petroleum reserves outside the Middle East. Venezuela has also been the largest oil supplier to the United States in recent years and, with prices now at their highest level in a decade, it is looking forward to record oil revenues of $21 billion this year. Yet oil has come to be regarded here not as a blessing but as a curse.
When petroleum first emerged as the core of the economy back in the 1930's, governments were urged to follow a policy of "sowing the oil," in the famous phrase of the writer Arturo Uslar Pietri, to encourage investment instead of mindless consumption. But the reality turned out to be different, and a saying often heard here in recent years cynically summarizes Venezuelan history this way: "Columbus discovered us, Bolivar liberated us, and oil ruined us."
"This is a sick society, and it is sick as a result of an illness called oil," said Anibal Romero, a professor of political science at Simon Bolivar University here. "Oil is easy to produce, it can be done by others with imported equipment, and it always sells. As a result, it has asphyxiated the rest of the economy and led the majority of Venezuelans to believe that if they are not rich, it is because someone has stolen what belongs to them."
Indeed, in poll after poll conducted over the past decade, Alfredo Keller and Associates, a leading public opinion research firm here, has found that 80 percent of Venezuelans believe that theirs is "one of the richest countries in the world" because of its oil reserves.
Roughly the same percentage believe that the main function of government is "to share this wealth among all" but also complain that they themselves "have not benefited from these riches."
But rather than point their fingers at an economic model that favors oil over all other activities, thus engendering a bonanza mentality and discouraging individual initiative, Venezuelans prefer to blame their leaders. Up to 80 percent believe, Mr. Keller said, that the responsibility for their own poverty "lies with government and politicians," and that it is "because of corruption" that the state has failed to serve them.
"People here have never thought of this country's problem as economic," said Carlos Sabino, a sociologist at the Central University of Venezuela who has written extensively about oil's impact on Venezuelan society. "They have always considered it a moral and political problem."
It was exactly that sense of resentment and moral outrage that President Hugo Chavez rode to power in the December 1998 presidential election, in which he won 58 percent of the vote. But with the price of Venezuelan crude having quadrupled in the 18 months since he was sworn in, he too is facing pressure to deliver the "golden age" of prosperity and social justice that Venezuelans expect and that he promised as a candidate.
Mr. Chavez, 46, a former army colonel who in 1992 led an unsuccessful coup, has stoked such expectations by claiming to have almost singlehandedly engineered the worldwide rise in oil prices. During his successful campaign for re-election last month to a new six year term, he reminded voters that it was his decision to cut back production that has given a new vigor to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, or OPEC.
As a result, the current boom in oil prices may have reawakened memories of the 1970's and expectations that a new round of spending and subsidies will follow. The 1970's, after all, were an era in which oil revenues were so plentiful and Venezuelans so affluent that other Latin Americans referred to them as "los damedos," or "the gimme twos," a reference to their lavish spending habits.
"To get out of the mess we put ourselves in then, we are going to have to make sacrifices," said Luis Cortillo, 69, a retired airline crew supervisor. "But we don't want to accept that solution; we want to go on living just like in the days when the money flowed like water."
That sense of entitlement is so deeply ingrained that past governments here have attempted to raise gasoline prices at their peril. In February 1989, President Carlos Andres Perez did just that, and the immediate result was riots, looting and hundreds of people killed -- events followed three years later by Mr. Perez's fall from power and Mr. Chavez's own coup attempt.
"The country is rich, but its people are not," said Lido Araque, a 48-year-old gas station attendant who earns about $200 a month, when asked why Venezuelans should continue to enjoy low energy costs.
"So I would say the price of gasoline has to be kept at this level for at least three more years, because when gas prices go up, food and transportation costs rise too."
Mr. Chavez calls his movement to reform the Venezuelan state a "revolution," and he clearly has the support of the overwhelming majority of the population.
But his government appears just as intimidated as its predecessors by the specter of popular resistance to any effort to bring local gasoline prices in line with international rates and thereby discourage excessive consumption.
"In determining the prices of energy, it is not just economic factors that must be taken into account," Ali Rodriguez, minister of energy and mines, said in a recent interview. "We have a critical social situation."
Eventually, "there will be an adjustment made in the price of gasoline," Mr. Rodriguez, who is also the president of OPEC, added. "But it has to be done at the proper time, when there is an economic recovery and employment is picking up."
At the moment, however, Mr. Chavez faces a situation that has no precedent in Venezuelan history. Even with the price of a barrel of locally produced crude rising so dramatically, the Venezuelan economy shrank by 7.2 percent last year, and more than half the work force is either unemployed or working off the books in what is euphemistically called "the informal economy."
To placate his supporters, Mr. Chavez has spent hundreds of millions of dollars on a military-run civic assistance program called Plan Bolivar 2000, providing subsidized food and free medical care. He has also proposed populist initiatives like the subsidized manufacture of a relatively cheap "People's Car" that would obviously encourage even greater gasoline consumption.
But he has conspicuously hesitated to take steps that might hit ordinary Venezuelans in their pocketbooks. Even the idea of trying to prepare for the day when oil prices start to decline again by raising taxes is controversial, and not just because the economy is mired in a recession.
"Historically, the problem of the state here has not been how to obtain resources through taxes to cover public spending, but how to distribute this growing income," Mr. Rodriguez said. "For that reason, because money was so abundant, we were not charged taxes, and that had a cultural impact on Venezuelan society, in the sense that no one here developed the habit of paying taxes or a sense that not to pay taxes is a crime."
In a speech in early August, just before he embarked on a tour of OPEC nations aimed at keeping oil prices at their current high levels, Mr. Chavez announced ambitious plans to develop tourism, agriculture, mining and fishing.
But the reality, with the rest of the economy hobbled by a recession, is that Venezuela is probably more reliant on oil than ever, and thus more susceptible to the impact of a downturn when it eventually comes.
"Governments here are always like a gambler at a casino," Dr. Sabino said. "They have their run of luck, and they come to believe that everything can be resolved with an increase in the price of oil. Nothing that Chavez is doing tells me that he is any different from the others, and that is the problem."

HEADLINE: Philippine Leader, Facing Bad Reviews, Is Ready for a Change in His Image

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: MANILA, Aug. 17

 BODY:
"If they want war, we will give them defeat," declared President Joseph Estrada not long ago in the latest version of his tough-guy political credo: "Don't dare me."
He was speaking this time about Muslim rebels and, like his earlier turns at belligerence, this one worked. His poll numbers went up this week. 
 The public is desperate for its president to pull himself together and start getting things done. A former movie actor with a lackadaisical approach to government, Mr. Estrada has increasingly become the subject of jokes, gossip and that old Philippine staple, coup rumors.
Halfway into his six-year term, the economy is faltering, corruption and cronyism seem to be ascendant and Muslim separatists and kidnappers are getting out of hand in the southern Philippines.
Now, with his options narrowed, Mr. Estrada has unleashed his army in a cathartic take-no-prisoners campaign against the rebels on the island of Mindanao. He is also determined to resolve a kidnapping of Western vacationers that has continued for almost four months on the tiny neighboring island of Jolo.
Apparently as a result of the effort to end the hostage situation, those polled gave the president a positive rating of over 50 percent for the first time in months.
But political commentators seemed unimpressed. Representative Raul Gonzales recalled the boost former President George Bush enjoyed after the Persian Gulf war in 1991 -- only to be undercut by his perceived failure to manage the economy.
Even that comparison is on the rosy side, said Amando Doronila, a columnist for The Philippine Daily Inquirer. Mr. Bush had just won a war; Mr. Estrada does not even have a workable strategy for victory.
Fighting has flared in the three-decade-old insurgency following his failure to build on the peacemaking and economic development policies of his predecessor, Fidel V. Ramos. Analysts here say there cannot be a lasting peace unless those policies are creatively pursued.
A recent spate of bombings in Manila that many people attribute to the Muslim rebels heightened popular fears about the president's inaction. At least now, people say, Mr. Estrada is doing something. Last month, soldiers captured the headquarters in Mindanao of the main insurgent group, the Moro National Liberation Front, and Mr. Estrada traveled there to hoist the Philippine flag.
"He's enjoying a sort of windfall from Mindanao, but that windfall is like opium," Mr. Doronila said. "The opium deadens people's awareness to the really serious problems that are hurting them. They have temporarily forgotten the corruption and the economic issues."
The country's growth rate of less than 4 percent is well below projections, slower than the growth in most other nations in the region and far too low to absorb soaring birthrates. One-third of the population of 76 million remains below the poverty line and unemployment has risen to more than 13 percent.
What is particularly damaging among investors is the atmosphere of old-style cronyism that surrounds Mr. Estrada's government, with favored friends receiving both political appointments and protection in questionable business deals. The World Bank recently estimated that corruption was costing the Philippines $46 million a year.
Eschewing the hard work of making policy and legislation -- as a senator, he once said his favorite moment was when the speaker shouted, "Recess!" -- Mr. Estrada has fallen back on presidential decrees, issuing hundreds of them in his first two years.
"His presidency is very erratic, not driven by any coherent vision or planning," Mr. Doronila said. "It's very much an ad hoc presidency. But he has a sure touch for what is popular."
Mr. Estrada, a former B-movie actor who cultivates an image as a man of the people, is entranced by the example of Ronald Reagan, but the parallels go only so far. Unlike his American hero, he has little philosophy of government and is not leading the nation in any clear direction.
And unlike Mr. Reagan, he is not a natural in the role of president.
"One has the feeling that in reacting to a situation his first words are, 'How do I play this scene?' -- not whatever issues are there," said the Rev. John Carroll, an American sociologist who teaches here.
But like Mr. Reagan, Mr. Estrada enjoys seeing the world in movie images. The persona he projects as president -- along with the public perception of him -- is based on his movie roles as a pugnacious little guy who faces down the slick and the powerful.
Because of this image, his base of support is among the nation's poor. With most of the political and economic elite against him, he swept to office in May 1998 with a huge plurality of 40 percent in the field of nine.
Now even the poor have begun to turn against him. Drivers of the gaudy converted Jeeps known as Jeepneys and used as public minibuses have said they no longer want him to use the Jeepney as his symbol.
So he has promised a new President Estrada.
"A nation's life is like a motion picture," he said last year. "With proper direction, the next scenes will change."
The new scenes he has written look like this: he will get to work at 8 a.m. -- rather than in the afternoon -- and he will stay on the job all day long. He will set aside his beloved Johnnie Walker whiskey and drink red wine instead.
And, he promised, he will curtail his "midnight cabinet," all-night karaoke-bar-style sessions with his cronies that one aide said sometimes produced presidential decrees that had to be quickly countermanded in the light of day.
"At 4 in the morning, I am the only sober one in the room," said the aide, Aprodocio Laquian, last March. He was promptly forced to resign.

Hostage Release Breaks Down
JOLO, Philippines, Aug. 19, (AP) -- Negotiators returned empty-handed today from an attempt to win the freedom of 25 hostages held by Muslim rebels in the southern Philippine jungle.
"We have to come back another day and renegotiate," said Rajab Azzarouq, a former Libyan ambassador who is part of the negotiating team that traveled to the camp of the Abu Sayyaf rebels.
Shaking his head and visibly tired and disappointed, Mr. Azzarouq said he would return when the rebels were ready to talk, but gave no time frame.
Two vans that were to carry the hostages, some of whom have been held for almost four months, returned empty from the rebels' area on remote Jolo island, and military escorts and armored personnel carriers were withdrawn.
The breakdown occurred when the guerrillas insisted on freeing the hostages in two batches for security reasons. President Estrada had ordered negotiators to win the release of all the hostages in a single group. His order raised suspicion among the guerrillas that they would face a military attack soon after the release.
The government's chief negotiator, Robert Aventajado, denied any such threat. He read a statement from the rebels saying that they had decided to free only two Europeans today. The negotiators refused the offer.
Abu Sayyaf is the smaller of two major Muslim rebel groups that have been fighting to create an independent Islamic nation in the southern Philippines. The rebels abducted 21 people from a Malaysian diving resort on April 23 and later seized three French journalists and a dozen Filipino Christian evangelists who had visited the rebel camp to pray for the hostages.
They have so far released nine Malaysians, a Filipino and a German woman, but continue to hold 25 hostages in primitive jungle huts.

HEADLINE: Pat Hearn, Art Dealer In New York, Dies at 45

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Pat Hearn, one of the leading art dealers of the last two decades, a founder of the Gramercy International Art Fair and a pioneer of the art scene in the East Village, SoHo and Chelsea, died on Friday at her vacation home in Provincetown, Mass. She was 45 and lived in Manhattan.
The cause was liver cancer, said her husband, Colin de Land. 
 In her 17 years as a dealer, Ms. Hearn was widely respected as unusually empathetic to artists, open to new art and willing to share artists and ideas with other dealers. When her cancer was first diagnosed and it seemed that her insurance company would not cover her treatment (although it eventually paid for some of it), her friends organized a benefit to which hundreds of artists and dealers donated work and money.
Her gallery was in some ways a continually evolving artwork in which everything, from the 1950's-ish cursive letterhead to the furniture and design of her different spaces, expressed a distinct personality and sensibility. Yet none of this competed with the art on view, which reflected an eclectic mix of artistic generations and media -- painting, Conceptual Art and video art -- and a viewpoint that evolved from somewhat kitschy neo-pop to neo-geo to an ecumenical feminism.
The artists to whom Ms. Hearn gave first shows, or first New York shows, included the painters Philip Taffee, Milan Kunc, Peter Schuyff, Jutta Koether, Monique Prieto and, most recently, Jeff Elrod, and the Conceptualists Susan Hiller, Renee Green, Lincoln Tobier and Simon Leung. She showed artists she knew from her school days in Boston, including the painter George Condo, the installation artist Jack Pierson and the photographer Mark Morrisroe, and fostered the careers of such older artists as the painter Mary Heilmann, the video artist Joan Jonas and the Conceptualist Lutz Bacher. She was especially proud that she was able to mount posthumous shows of the work of Eva Hesse and Ana Mendieta.
Behind all this was a very complex woman, at once sophisticated and wholesome, stringent in her taste, yet extremely generous. Slim, dark-haired and usually dressed in a stylish mixture of designer and vintage clothes, Ms. Hearn resembled a bohemian Holly Golightly. In the early years she was usually trailed around her gallery by a nervous, adoring Chihuahua named Chi-Chi. She liked to give Easter Sunday parties and in the late 90's she held an annual Christmas party, complete with decorated tree, in her Chelsea gallery.
Ms. Hearn was born in Providence, R.I.. She studied painting and video at the Boston Museum School, sang with a band called Wild and Wonderful, and had a brief encounter with performance art before becoming an art dealer. She spent a year in Paris on a travel grant from the museum school in 1981, and while working at an alternative space called Usine Pali Kao began to realize that she was more interested in other artists' work than in her own. She returned to Boston, and while living on unemployment insurance, started a performance space in her home -- a ground-floor room in the Hemenway Hotel -- that she and her friends called the Poly Cow. A few months later she left for New York and a few months after that, in November of 1983, she opened her first gallery.
In terms of location, Ms. Hearn tended to be the first art dealer on the block. When most East village galleries were situated between First Avenue and Avenue A, she opened on Avenue B and Sixth Street and then expanded to a big SoHo-style space with polished wood floors on Ninth Street near Avenue D. In 1988 she moved to the relatively gallery-free southwest corner of SoHo, on Wooster Street near Grand, which soon teemed with new, experimental galleries. And in 1995, hers was one of three galleries to open on a deserted stretch of West 22nd Street in the wilds of west Chelsea on the same snowy February night. The other two were the Matthew Mark Gallery and the Morris-Healy Gallery, and the joint opening signaled a radical reshuffling of the downtown art scene that would eventually bring nearly 150 new galleries to Chelsea.
The year before, Ms. Hearn, Mr. Marks and Paul Morris of Morris-Healy had begun to explore the idea of a New York art fair for younger dealers. The result was the Gramercy International, a lively, live-in fair that took place at the Gramercy Hotel on Lexington Avenue and 21st Street for five years before graduating to larger spaces. The 2001 Gramercy International will be held on Pier 90 and will include 160 participants, nearly double the number of last year's fair at the Javits Center.
Ms. Hearn's first marriage ended in divorce. She and Mr. de Land, whose SoHo gallery, American Fine Arts, is as much an art piece as her own, were married last year after almost 10 years together.
In addition to Mr. de Land, Ms. Hearn is survived by her mother, Alice Darcy Hearn of Cranston, R.I.; two sisters, Marie, of Providence, and Marion, of Warren, R.I.; and two brothers, John, of Providence, and William J., of Cranston.

HEADLINE: BACKTALK;
The Continuing Battles Inside and Outside the Lines

BYLINE: By ROBERT LIPSYTE

 BODY:
Rivellino Jones of the misspelled name was refereeing a soccer game in Manhattan last week, a moral victory for Coach Marty Jacobson. Perhaps those other embattled friends of thelipsite@aol.com, Linda Bensel-Meyers and Billy Bean, could take heart from Jake, although hang in there is almost always the hardest advice to follow.
Bensel-Meyers, the whistle-blower at the University of Tennessee, is facing the start of a football season in which she has been portrayed as the Volunteers' most dangerous opponent. The team has just started practicing and Bensel-Meyers has already informed the National Collegiate Athletic Association of three freshman players who turned in remarkably similar compositions. She calls it institutional plagiarism and blames it on the mores of the university rather than on the athletes or tutors. 
 Most people in Knoxville call it harassing the program. The N.C.A.A. might not even find it in violation of whatever it is that concerns that trade organization.
Bensel-Meyers has been decrying, for some time now, what she sees as the exploitation of athletes and the subversion of the humanistic values of the academy. A professor of Renaissance literature and drama, she is also in charge of the first-year composition program. She is only recently being heard beyond the world of the Orange.
In what I found the most cynical and clear-eyed approach to the issue, Frank Cagle, the managing editor of The Knoxville News-Sentinel, simply brushed it off. He wrote that the "fate of the football team has a deep impact on the morale, the business and the general economy of East Tennessee" and that what might be construed as corruption in college sports was a "national scandal, not a local one. And it requires a national solution." In other words, keeping our boys eligible by any means necessary is a priority not to be tampered with unless every other school goes honest, too.
Bensel-Meyers is idealistic and fuzzy-minded; she sees universities using a bottom-line corporate model in which athletes are resources. Even the coaches and athletic administrators end up being victimized, especially if they don't win.
"My immediate problem is how do I avoid being cast as a harridan because I harp on the issue," she said last week. "The administration's problem is that you can't put the peel back on the orange once you see what's underneath."
Bean, an outfielder whose six major league seasons on three teams were haunted by the secret of his homosexuality, has decided he wants to be back in baseball, the binding thread of his life since childhood. Since he used his sports background to build functioning teams in two restaurants, he thinks he can use his business background in a front office. He would offer a rare combination of experience and skills, as well as a test of sports' institutional homophobia.
His open, often moving description of life in a major league closet last year in a front-page story in The New York Times led to a number of speaking engagements and television appearances. In talking about baseball, he realized he had not resolved that critical part of his life; he had left before his career was over. Even now, at 35, he tries to stay in playing shape and appear regularly on talk radio; he is still gripping the ball.
Bean is in the process of selling his current Miami Beach restaurant, Mayya, and writing to baseball club executives. He said last week that he understands that a team would have to be "courageous" to hire him.
Coach Jake's message has always been simple: don't quit. A recovering drug abuser long clean, a soccer coach in a basketball culture, an advocate for kids among clock-watching bureaucrats, Jacobson's saga has been struggle.
Since 1996, when his Martin Luther King Jr. High School team won the first of its three straight city championships, mostly with recent immigrants from the West Indies and West Africa, Jake has been controversial in and out of his school. He was suspended from coaching for 11 months last year when rival coaches accused several of his players of being ineligible. He was reinstated and vindicated, although his team lost in last year's championship final.
Like Bensel-Meyers, he is self-righteous and insistent on putting the needs of the individual student ahead of the institution. Like Bean, his charm masks a willingness to work harder than most. And like them both, he has a larger vision. Jake thinks the future of American soccer will rise from the cities.
To that end, the New York City Parks Department's inspired partnership with the Parmalat milk company finished its six-week Summer of Soccer 2000 yesterday. On weekday nights in Riverside Park in Manhattan and Flushing Meadows-Corona Park in Queens, youngsters played six-on-six games under the supervision of parkies and soccer coaches and college players like Rivellino Jones. Jacobson ran the Manhattan program, which included washing the mesh scrimmage vests.
"Look at that passion," he crowed last week as teenagers from Senegal and Brazil and Trinidad stormed up and down the turf with bursts of heart-stopping athleticism. "This is going to be the urban game. These kids are going to be our future."
Rivellino Jones, 22, named for Roberto Rivelino, the Brazilian star, is a symbol of that future. As a 16-year-old Trinidadian overwhelmed by homesickness and a huge, chaotic high school, Jones found his new roots at midfield on the King varsity. He was on Jake's first title team and expects to graduate from Medgar Evers College this year. He says he wants to be a public school guidance counselor and coach. Like Jake.
