HEADLINE: New Economy;
An old-style deal maker takes up the cause of high technology with manufacturing over the Internet.

BYLINE: By Barnaby J. Feder 

 BODY:
UNTIL recently, it was obvious which prominent Irwin Jacobs was the business executive exemplar of the new economy. That would be Irwin M. Jacobs, the computer scientist and electrical engineer who founded Qualcomm in San Diego in 1985. He built it into a thriving Fortune 500 company through pioneering innovations in cellular communications.
The other Irwin Jacobs, Irwin L. Jacobs, is an irrepressible deal maker and bargain hunter based in Minneapolis. He became wealthy by taking big stakes in Fortune 500 conglomerates in the 1970's and 1980's, usually with the goal of unlocking value by breaking them up. 
 New technology was never high on Irwin L.'s list of fascinations. His idea of an electronics venture was to sell surplus and returned consumer electronics devices obtained from big retailers through the Jacobs Trading Company. His effort to sell such goods directly to consumers over the Web (wgdeal.com, for "world's greatest deal") was a bust. The only major business he retains from his days as a corporate raider -- Genmar Holdings, the nation's second-largest leisure boat manufacturer -- is in a labor-intensive segment of the economy that has been among the slowest to invest in new technology.
Irwin L.'s image may get a cybersheen at the end of this month, though. That is when Genmar plans to hold an open house at its Little Falls, Minn., factory to show off a compact, enclosed computer-controlled manufacturing system that can be remotely operated over the Internet.
Visitors will see 18-foot hulls, which used to take eight hours to produce, pop out every 35 minutes. Pollution, waste and labor will be sharply reduced, while quality will be so much higher that Genmar is offering a lifetime guarantee instead of the industry standard of five years. Genmar says the total cost is comparable to that for boats made by conventional techniques -- and should become lower over time.
Time Magazine, given a preview tour and a sales pitch on how the system could be adapted to many other products, called it "the revolution in a box" and suggested it could make large centralized factories "obsolete." Bruce Bobbins, Mr. Jacob's publicist, calls the process, known as virtual engineered composite, or V.E.C., "the most important manufacturing revolution in the past half century" and says that Genmar has been inundated with inquiries from other manufacturers, including producers of cars, household products and construction materials.
The technology was invented by Gene Kirila II and Robert McCollum, two Pennsylvanians who envision scattering leased VEC manufacturing cells around the world that would produce a variety of products close to where they would be used. The expertise to run the systems could reside at a central control center thanks to the Internet, so that workers at the production sites would not need extensive training.
Mr. Jacobs was so impressed with how well the virtual engineered composite process had fitted Genmar's needs that he bought Pyramid Operating Systems, the company Mr. Kirila and Mr. McCollum created in 1993 to develop VEC. Genmar's control room is hundreds of miles from Little Falls, in Greenville, Pa., where Mr. Kirila, Mr. McCollum and an expanding team of engineers are searching for new VEC applications.
Manufacturing experts say Mr. Jacobs would be justified in bragging about the process at any high-technology gathering. That does not mean that other manufacturers will jump at Mr. Jacobs's offer to sell them access to the technology. Their reaction matters because Mr. Jacobs is counting on more than stronger sales at Genmar to justify the $30 million he has invested in VEC so far. Interest in VEC could provide the fuel for taking Genmar public, a move Mr. Jacobs has talked about for years.
But like a 20-something Silicon Valley entrepreneur with the latest Web-based strategy for going from zero to millionaire in a matter of weeks, Mr. Jacobs and other backers of his technology face the temptation to oversell VEC's future. In addition to underestimating the costs and risks other manufacturers could encounter in moving to their new technology, proponents of the process, like true believers in any new technology, are probably underestimating the strengths and potential of competing technologies.
No wonder, as the history of robotics, machine vision and other innovations shows, computer-based technology generally seeps, rather than bursts, into manufacturing. The bigger the manufacturing sector the more cautious are managers to replace proven, if less than perfect, technologies and materials with new approaches. There is no particular reason to believe that any of VEC's attributes, including its ability to be controlled by remote experts via the Internet, will change that.
"We have to make numbers every quarter," said Paul Dickard, a spokesman for Ingersoll-Rand, which has been experimenting with VEC for several years. "There's always the question of which quarter you are going to sacrifice on the altar of Internet-enabled manufacturing."
Internet capability is central to the vision of virtual-engineered-composite manufacturing "cells," as the company calls its systems, serving as remote minifactories that could be set up and running within days. But that innovation, already available in different forms on other computerized manufacturing equipment, is only part of what makes VEC a unique package. The other key element, developed to keep costs down, is the use of laminated plastic skins instead of metal as the molding frames.
The skins are attached to supports inside the VEC cell and composite resins are injected between them. To give the skins the rigidity that metal would usually provide, Mr. Kirila and Mr. McCollum hit upon the elegantly simple idea of water pressure. Before the molding compounds are injected, the cell is sealed and the cavities behind the skins are filled with water.
Computers monitor the numerous variables in this "floating mold" process -- there are roughly 800 in the hull-making operation -- so that relatively unskilled laborers can handle all of the necessary work at the actual manufacturing site.
VEC is clearly innovative enough to attract many window shoppers, but the chances that it will lead to the wide dispersal in manufacturing that its inventors envision are slim. Plastics manufacturing experts say Mr. Jacobs is likely to have his hands full simply establishing the process as a reliable system in a few segments of industry best suited to it.
Those segments include fabricators like Genmar that use fiberglass and other plastic composites, face environmental restrictions and have high labor turnover because of the health risks and discomforts associated with current working conditions. Potential sites will also have lower volumes than the typical auto plant and less need for precision than, say, aircraft manufacturers. Logical candidates include other marine products like jet skis as well as bathtubs and paneling for buildings, trucks, rail cars or specialty vehicles.
"It's suited for about half the volume of the plastics composites industry," estimates Robert Locavara, director of technical affairs for the Composite Fabricators Association, a trade group for companies that make industrial components and consumer products out of fiberglass and other plastic composites.
That could add up to billions of dollars of production, but one thing is for sure: even if it comes to pass, it will not happen at Internet speed.

HEADLINE: A Learned Journal Aims to Defog Globalization

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
In the often rarefied world of foreign policy treatises, the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace is making a bet: that there are plenty of readers interested in a magazine about globalization and how it affects them.
No longer will Foreign Policy, the 30-year-old publication of the endowment, concentrate on articles about relations between governments, on military policy, or on the domestic politics of an important American ally. 
 Instead, the magazine, remade from its elegant slim size into a bigger, flashier format that resembles the celebrity magazine Talk, will concentrate on "global politics, economics and ideas."
The first issue of the remade magazine, which is in the mail to subscribers and will be on the newsstands early in September, poses the question: Would a sudden collapse on Wall Street spark a global 21st century Great Depression? Not necessarily, is the answer. The article, by Martin Wolf, associate editor of the Financial Times, goes on to delineate some likely results: a weaker dollar, a slump in international trade particularly hurting Mexico and Canada, and falling petroleum prices that would severely limit the oil boom in Russia.
Foreign Policy was founded 30 years ago, partly as an antidote to Foreign Affairs, the more staid, more establishment voice of the Council on Foreign Relations in New York.
The magazine's founders, Samuel P. Huntington and Warren Manshel, thought that an alternative voice was needed to the hawkish views of Foreign Affairs on the Vietnam War. Its initial creed, according to its opening editorial, was to re-examine and redefine American foreign policy as the United States disengaged from Vietnam. Richard C. Holbrooke, currently the chief representative to the United Nations, was its managing editor from 1972 to 1976.
By focusing Foreign Policy on globalization and the new economy, the editor and publisher, Moises Naim, is making a fundamental change from the founders' emphasis on the American role in world affairs. Indeed, the choice of Mr. Naim three years ago was quite a switch. A Venezuelan who was a trade minister of his country and who had served two stints as a senior official at the World Bank, Mr. Naim took charge of the magazine after the 17-year tenure of Charles William Maynes.
Mr. Naim -- whose interests span economics, and psychology as well as classic foreign policy -- soon revamped the magazine to make it look more like a literary publication. He livened it up with a Web site, introduced reviews of books published abroad and ran lengthy interviews with figures normally considered offbeat by a serious foreign policy publication.
The visage of Lori Wallach, a leader of the protests in Seattle last year against the World Trade Organization, beamed out from the cover of the magazine this spring, accompanied by an interview in which she excoriated Secretary of the Treasury Lawrence H. Summers and the United States trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky.
But Mr. Naim's initial revamping did not go far enough in satisfying the appetite of an audience he believes wants to know more about how globalization is going to change their lives and businesses.
He is not so brash as to try to put out a news-you-can-use publication. But in the world of foreign policy he is getting about as close as possible. "There is a lot of confusion," he said. "Globalization is changing things faster than people, countries or companies can digest or react to, A lot of the anxiety about globalization is rooted in fast-paced changes, and it's not very clear how people are going to come out of this."
So Mr. Naim is now directing Foreign Policy to readers who want an understanding of globalization without reading specialist fare. Next month, a lead article "Sushi Goes Global" describes how in just a decade a Japanese speciality has become a worldwide phenomenon involving the international regulation of the fish trade. The lead interview will be with Ray Kendall, the head of Interpol, the crime prevention agency, which has become more important in the fight against people-trafficking and other crimes that easily cross borders in the post-cold-war era.
Indeed, the rival Foreign Affairs has also gone through something of a modernization, but it remains, according to Mr. Naim, the journal of record.
His magazine's circulation, subsidized by the Carnegie Endowment, is a modest 30,000. With its new content and an extra $1 million investment by the endowment, Mr. Naim thinks he can push that up to 130,000 over the next three years.
He is not beyond attracting attention. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, this year, he gave a talk called the "Occupational Hazards of Power" in which he described how some chiefs of Washington, Hollywood and Wall Street suffer from what he called "narcissistic personality disorder." If the size of the crowd that came to hear that piercing criticism is a gauge, Mr. Naim may reach his circulation target.

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Early Advocate of Seat Belts Now Heads Safety Agency

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
SUE BAILEY, the government's new highway-safety chief, insists she is not obsessive when it comes to safety on the roads. "I'm not at all an anxious person," she says. "I'm not compulsive."
So who, then, was that young mother in Philadelphia in the early 1970's who hired a mechanic to install a seat belt for her son on the bus that ferried neighborhood children to preschool? And who, before child-restraint seats, made one of her own by cutting holes in a plastic child seat so a seat belt could be looped through it to keep her toddler daughter safe? 
 Her son, now 31 and an emergency-room physician in suburban Washington, "will tell you that he still remembers that he was the only one on that little school bus who had to buckle himself in," said Dr. Bailey, a psychiatrist, neurologist and public-health specialist who begins work today as the administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.
"I was interested way before anybody else seemed to be interested in how to make yourself safe in a vehicle," she said, recalling that three decades ago Americans rarely used seat belts, and that her neighbors "thought I was crazy" to be so concerned about her children's safety in the car. "I was probably ahead of Ralph Nader."
When the White House announced her appointment to lead the safety agency, "my family and friends were all laughing," she explained. "They said, 'This is perfect. She's driven us crazy for years about these safety issues in automobiles. Now she can do something about it.' "
Dr. Bailey will have no time to ease into her new job at the agency, which is responsible for the safety of the nation's highways, automobiles and tires.
The agency is under scrutiny after the announcement that millions of Firestone tires are being recalled because of evidence that they are prone to shredding; 62 deaths have been linked so far to separation of the treads on tires that were installed as original equipment on some Ford vehicles. The agency has been criticized by public-safety advocates for failing to properly track accidents involving the tires, and for not forcing Firestone and Ford to do more, faster.
Dr. Bailey says it is too early for her to discuss the tire recall in detail. But without making judgments about the agency's performance, she says she will review the methods used to monitor tire safety. "I'm so hesitant to speak about this because this was before my tenure," she says. "But I do want to review our ability to track in a timely fashion, which is part of how we serve the American public."
SHE is not new to controversy. During her time at the Pentagon -- she was assistant secretary of defense for health affairs from 1998 until this summer, the first woman to oversee the military health system -- she directed a program to inoculate troops against the anthrax virus, despite reports from some soldiers that the vaccine was unsafe.
She has no apologies for the program, which was scaled back significantly because of shortages of the vaccine and mismanagement at the company licensed to produce it. "I knew what we were doing was right," she said. "Anthrax is easily weaponized, it's as deadly as the Ebola virus, and you need protection. We had a safe vaccine. It would have made me uncomfortable to think that there were body bags coming back that I could have prevented."
Dr. Bailey, 57, was born Patricia Sue Bailey in Rapid City, S.D., the third of four children. Her father, a physician, dabbled in engineering, and during World War II he worked at a B-17 base in Rapid City and invented a type of compass still common in aircraft today. "By all rights, my family should be very rich" on the basis of that invention, she says. "But we're not, because he did it for the public good. I respect that."
When she was 3, the family moved to Washington, so her father could continue his engineering work at Andrews Air Force Base. Of his children, Sue was the one most likely to help her father under the hood of the car. "I was the one who worked on machinery with him, whether it was the car or the lawn mower or the furnace," she said.
She followed her father into osteopathic medicine, which emphasizes holistic treatments. She graduated from the Philadelphia College of Osteopathic Medicine and completed her residency in psychiatry and neurology at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. She worked in private practice in Washington, raising two children. She is divorced.
A lifelong, politically active Democrat, she returned home Friday from the party's convention in Los Angeles. She is an eager supporter of Vice President Al Gore. Mr. Gore, she says, will continue the economic expansion that is helping make cars safer. "It's a luxury to make policy that provides for safety," she said. "If you have a sound economy, corporations are going to be more willing and more able to embrace techniques to make cars safer."
Stepping into a car at the airport Friday night for the ride home, she fastened her seat belt. And she looked disapprovingly when she noticed that a passenger had not buckled his.
She announced -- only half in jest, it seemed -- that the car would stop until he buckled up. "You're being a danger not only to yourself but to the other people in this car," she explained, all but shaking her finger. "You could be a flying object that would endanger the driver. I'm not going to participate in this ride if you don't put that seat belt on."
The passenger hurriedly obeyed.

HEADLINE: In America;
This Is Class Warfare?

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
"This is my tranquillity," said Jose Valles. "Sitting here waiting for the bus. Because most of the time I am stressed. Why? I will tell you. Because I don't have enough money."
Mr. Valles earns his living serving hamburgers at a McDonald's restaurant in downtown Los Angeles. He's a family man. He and his wife, Lily, have two children, a boy, 9, and a girl, 6. He talked about his family's circumstances while waiting in the hot sun last Thursday afternoon for the No. 60 bus at the corner of Seventh and Alameda Streets. 
 "It's hard. It's rough," he said. "You don't have the nice kiss on the cheek or the 'Hello, honey, how are you?' when you come home from work. It's 'What the hell are we gonna do?'
"I make $5.75 an hour. That's about $240 a week. One hundred ninety dollars after taxes. You can't really live on that. Lily works in a fast-food place, too. She makes the same as me. Two weeks of my pay and two weeks of her pay every month goes for rent. Then you have to pay the fare to go back and forth to work. You gotta pay for your food. You have bills. We're still paying on the sofa.
"You see, it's stressing me out just thinking about it."
I asked Mr. Valles what he and his family did for recreation.
"We take the kids to the park."
I asked if they ever went on vacation. He looked at me as if I'd asked if his children could fly. "No," said Mr. Valles quietly. "There is no money for vacation."
The Valleses are among the millions of working families Vice President Al Gore is trying to connect with as he travels the country promising to fight for "those who need a champion, those who need to be lifted up so they are never left behind."
The Republicans have denounced this effort to reach out to working families -- to build, as Mr. Gore says, a "better, fairer, more prosperous America" -- as divisive. It's dangerous, we're told. Un-American.
Mr. Gore is "a candidate who wants to wage class warfare to get ahead," said George W. Bush.
Welcome to the intersection of greed and paranoia. We may be enjoying good times, but the wealthy are not yet wealthy enough -- at least in the view of the G.O.P. -- to accede to a little bit of help for the likes of Jose Valles and his family.
With Mr. Bush already gift-wrapping most of the nation's projected surplus, which he intends to hand over to the very wealthiest among us, it's fair to ask who's waging war on whom.
In our conversation last week, Mr. Valles mentioned politics just once. "The politicians keep saying they are going to raise the minimum wage, but nothing happens," he said. "A minimum wage increase would help everybody, not just me."
Class warfare? Let's see. The Democrats have been trying without success to raise the minimum wage -- now $5.15 an hour -- by a mere $1 over the next two years. That's a whopping 50 cents an hour the first year, and another 50 cents the year after. My goodness, is that an attack on the rich? Is that what they mean by class warfare?
The Republicans in Congress have stood in the way of this most modest of pay hikes for the nation's low-wage workers. Mr. Gore favors the increase and says he'll fight for it. If that's class warfare, we need more of it.
Mr. Bush's running mate, Dick Cheney, is getting a retirement package worth an estimated $20 million from the Halliburton Company, an energy services outfit that has a big financial stake in the policies of the federal government. No problem, said Mr. Bush.
But a tiny boost in the minuscule minimum wage would seem to be a different story.
(The radical Texas Republican Party, at its convention in Houston in June, declared that all minimum wage laws should be repealed.)
I asked Jose Valles how his life would change if he earned a few more dollars a week. He said: "I would do something nice for Lily. I would buy some clothes for the children and try to take them to a movie every now and then. My dream is to someday be able to invest in a house."
He added: "I'll tell you the truth. I would like for my kids to go to college, which I was never able to do. I'm like all parents. I would like the best for my children. I would like my children to soar."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VICE PRESIDENT;
Gore Renews Push on Patients' Rights and Drug Prices

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: MOLINE, Ill., Aug. 20

 BODY:
Comparing his increasingly populist pitch to that of Harry S. Truman, but leaving the "give-'em-hell" to his running mate, Vice President Al Gore renewed his attacks on drug companies and health maintenance organizations today and vowed to bring broader and fairer health coverage to all Americans.
At the first of four appearances today in Illinois and Iowa, all of them in communities along the Mississippi River, Mr. Gore said he would push for a patients' bill of rights to protect H.M.O. consumers and for adding a prescription drug benefit under the Medicare program. 
 "If you entrust me with the presidency, we will flat make it happen," Mr. Gore promised a crowd of about 3,000 in downtown Moline.
Both Mr. Gore and his running mate, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut, used their speeches here to draw on the Trumanesque imagery that has enthralled Democrats for more than half a century. But Mr. Gore left it to Mr. Lieberman to assail the health care record of Mr. Gore's Republican opponent, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
While Mr. Gore made only passing references to the Republicans, Mr. Lieberman cited statistics that 1.4 million children in Texas did not have health insurance, that Texas led the nation in the percentage of residents who were uninsured and that it ranked next to last in health care coverage for women.
Mr. Lieberman said Mr. Bush often responded to criticism of his state by saying, "Don't mess with Texas." But, he asserted, "when it comes to health care, it's a mess in Texas."
Aides to Mr. Bush accused the Gore campaign today of distorting the governor's health care record, pointing out that a bill he signed in 1999 was expected to add 423,000 children to the health insurance rolls by 2001. (Mr. Bush, however, had earlier fought for a less-inclusive plan.)
"The further Al Gore floats down the Mississippi, the more he drifts away from the facts on Governor Bush's record on health care in Texas," said Dan Bartlett, a Bush spokesman.
After a two-day riverboat tour down the Mississippi, Mr. Gore left the slow-moving ship and traveled by bus today so he could make all four cities on his schedule. Mr. Gore and his wife, Tipper, were rejoined by Mr. Lieberman and his wife, Hadassah, who had left the tour in Wisconsin on Friday to observe the Jewish Sabbath.
The candidates clearly have been buoyed by polls showing they received a significant boost from the Democratic National Convention in Los Angeles, and they have been received enthusiastically by sizable crowds. "I'm no expert as to what to make of it," Mr. Gore told reporters, "but it feels good."
As in his speech at the convention on Thursday night, Mr. Gore accepted credit today for the economic health of the Clinton years but said there was more work to be done. He noted, for instance, that 15 percent of Americans still lacked health insurance.
"We've got some serious problems in our health care system," he said, his voice still hoarse from his convention speech, "and we've got to fix them without undermining the good things about our health care system."
Mr. Gore said he would move incrementally toward a system of universal health care, starting with guaranteed coverage for every child by 2004. And he said the country owes its older citizens a prescription drug benefit, a proposal estimated to cost $253 billion over 10 years.
"When people have bills for pills that are more than their Social Security check," Mr. Gore said, "it is wrong for our country to put seniors, the generation that won World War II, in a situation where they have to choose between food and medicine when the drug companies have the biggest profits of any industry in America."
The drug companies, Mr. Gore said, do not support such plans because they fear that drug prices will come down. "Well, they need to come down," he said. "They need more competition." He added: "I'll be like Harry Truman. I'll tell them the truth and they'll just think it's hell."
Mr. Gore then switched targets from the drug companies to H.M.O.'s that he accuses of making financial decisions that usurp medical recommendations. "Some bean counter behind a computer terminal who doesn't have a license to practice medicine and surely does not have a right to play god overrules the doctor because the H.M.O. or the insurance company doesn't want to shell out the money, even though you've been paying the monthly premium," Mr. Gore said. "What is that all about?"
Mr. Gore's proposal for a patients' bill of rights, campaign aides say, would assure access to specialists, would guarantee emergency room care regardless of when and where the need arises and would provide either a right to sue or an alternative appeals process if insurers deny coverage.
The Gore campaign criticizes Mr. Bush's proposed bill of rights because it would cover only those Americans in federally governed health care plans, a restriction that Gore aides say would exclude 135 million people with private insurance.

HEADLINE: Harry Oppenheimer, 91, South African Industrialist, Dies

BYLINE: By MARILYN BERGER 

 BODY:
Harry F. Oppenheimer, the South African gold and diamond magnate who used his great wealth and considerable influence in the fight against apartheid, died on Saturday in Johannesburg. He was 91.
Mr. Oppenheimer was admitted to Kenridge Hospital in Johannesburg on Friday after complaining of abdominal pains and a headache, said Glen Finnegan, a spokeswoman for the family. 
 Mr. Oppenheimer for decades headed one of the world's largest multinational industrial and mining conglomerates with resources stretching from Cape Town to London to the Yukon. Called the "king of diamonds," he was also the king of gold, platinum, uranium, vanadium and copper, wielding extraordinary power over some of the world's strategic metals and minerals.
The Oppenheimer empire has been called a "Chinese puzzle" of majority and minority holdings. The bewildering complex, in addition to effectively controlling the world's supply of diamonds through the linked De Beers mineral companies, has vast holdings in banking, real estate, pulp and paper, bricks and pipe, coal and potash, locomotives and beer.
As head of the Anglo American Corporation of South Africa, Mr. Oppenheimer for a quarter of a century was the most powerful figure in his country's economy as well as one of the richest men in the world.
He became an important force in South African politics, elected to Parliament in 1948 as a member of the minority white liberal opposition. In that capacity, he spoke out frequently and consistently against apartheid, the country's policy of institutionalized racial discrimination.
In 1957, he became head of Anglo American, a mining and metals company formed by his father during World War I, and chairman of De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd. During the years he was in charge, he presided over an enormous expansion of the business. Anglo American grew to a net value of 24 billion South African rand in 1987 -- $3.47 billion at today's sharply reduced exchange rate -- from a value of 65 million rand in 1957.
Mr. Oppenheimer stepped down from the chairmanship of Anglo American in 1982 and as chairman of De Beers in 1984. But he remained active in the businesses in which his family maintained controlling interests. His son, Nicholas, became chairman of De Beers in 1998.
In his political life, Mr. Oppenheimer grounded his opposition to apartheid on humanitarian impulses, often bringing economic principles and a sort of elegant understatement to the argument.
"I've never thought that the policy of racial discrimination had been a great benefit to business," he said, "because while it may have had the effect of keeping wages low, it also had the effect of keeping labor exceptionally inefficient. I believe that apartheid is something that works against the interest of economic development, not for it."
Mr. Oppenheimer, who was of Jewish origin, championed the creation of black trade unions, and he lived to see those unions challenge the power of his mining companies. He was influential in ending an employment system that set aside certain jobs for whites only. His industrial group took the lead in creating housing near the mines for blacks, although the new housing accommodated only a small percentage of the three-quarters of a million blacks employed, many as migrant laborers, by his companies. He developed programs to educate blacks to bring them into positions of responsibility in his companies.
Franklin A. Thomas, former chief executive of the Ford Foundation, called Mr. Oppenheimer "a tireless fighter who tried to change the apartheid system from within." While he said he wished Mr. Oppenheimer had done more from his special position, he praised his efforts "to increase democracy in the workplace and to spread it beyond the workplace to communities in which people live."
The Rev. Leon H. Sullivan of Philadelphia, the framer of the Sullivan Principles, a code of corporate conduct in South Africa, said that Mr. Oppenheimer "has been a force for good, a progressive influence in South Africa, far beyond the vast majority of business leaders in that country."
Mr. Sullivan, who, like Mr. Thomas, came to urge international investors to withdraw from South Africa, and disagreed with Mr. Oppenheimer in later years, said he continued to have "the highest respect and regard for him."
Mr. Oppenheimer maintained that an expanding economy was a better environment for political change than a contracting economy and therefore remained a steadfast opponent of economic sanctions as a means of pressing the South African government to relax racial strictures.
"I'm not one of the people who think that sanctions have no effect," he said in an interview in 1987. "I think they have a very serious effect in South Africa, but I think the effect is bad in that it brings pressure to bear on people who are on your side anyhow. And it certainly doesn't force the government to change their policy."
He continued: "You know these highly nationalistic people in South Africa are extremely allergic to pressure from outside," and adding, "In fact they become very bloody-minded about this sort of thing. They're a tiresome, obstinate lot, our masters."
These "masters," the Afrikaner nationalists who controlled the government from 1948, tried to have as little to do with Harry Oppenheimer as possible. Despite the enormous power conferred on him as the head of a group of companies that that were a leading force in the South African economy, Mr. Oppenheimer was never asked to dine with the prime minister in the first 34 years of rule by the National Party, the political form Afrikaner nationalism.
In 1982, he was finally invited, along with his house guest, former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, to dine with Prime Minister P. W. Botha. By 1987, he said, he had seen Mr. Botha three or four times in the preceding year. But in the past, he recalled then: "He objected to sitting down to the same lunch table with me. You see, I was not a very popular figure with him."
And he said, "I feel that in the direct political way I was able to achieve virtually nothing except to keep what I considered a voice of common sense and humanity alive."
Mr. Oppenheimer said in the 1987 interview he believed that the growth of the economy had "made the apartheid policy more and more implausible," and that the government was moving away from it. "What they've not done is to make really significant movement on sharing political power."
A little more than two years later, Mr. Botha's successor, F. W. de Klerk, legalized antiapartheid groups and began moving toward negotiations with them for a democratic constitution.
Majority rule, Mr. Oppenheimer said, would have to come in stages, with guarantees for the rights of various groups in the country. "I think if you try to insist on having no guarantees for group rights, the effect would be that you won't get any movement at all," he said.
Mr. Oppenheimer was not someone to loudly take credit for his accomplishments and even less for his charities, which included the "usual thing" as he put it -- hospitals, the Boy Scouts, the Girl Guides, and seed money for education, especially for blacks. A particular interest was the Urban Foundation, which he helped establish, dedicated to improving the environment in which black South Africans live in the cities.
He was known for his refined sensibilities and exquisite taste. In Little Brenthurst, the palatial home in Johannesburg he inherited from his father, and in the seaside "bungalow" he built near Durban, he had a collection of Picassos, Sisleys, Goyas, Dufys, Degas and Chagalls. He was particularly fond of a Renoir he bought in London for 40 while a student at Oxford, where he developed a reputation as a generous host when he took friends on Champagne picnics.
He collected manuscripts of English poets and had a special regard for Lord Byron, whom he admired for a "curious combination of the romantic and the practical.
Mr. Oppenheimer also had a major collection of Africana, and took special delight in a private press he established to publish manuscripts. "I started about 10 or 15 years ago," he said in 1987. "I've been having a great deal of fun out of that."
He maintained a private game preserve and kept a stable of racehorses. His wife, the former Bridget McCall, was an avid bettor. Mr. Oppenheimer, who was not exactly a wagerer himself, used to be seen going down to the equivalent of the $2 betting window in Durban to place her bets.
A modest man of medium height, with a slight stammer, he spoke four languages -- English, Afrikaans, German and French. In conversation he was direct, engaging his guests with genial, but penetrating, brown eyes.
Harry Frederick Oppenheimer was born on Oct. 28, 1908, in Kimberley, South Africa, six years after his father, Sir Ernest Oppenheimer, had emigrated from Germany by way of England. Young Harry became the heir apparent of the family's business empire when a brother died. From his childhood he was prepared for the position he was to to occupy. He studied politics and philosophy at Christ Church College at Oxford, where he was tutored by Sir Roy Harrod, a British economist.
Mr. Oppenheimer volunteered for military service early in World War II and became an intelligence officer with an armored-car regiment of the South African Army. While still in the army he married Ms. McCall. She and their two children, Nicholas and Mary, as well as five grandchildren and two great-grandchildren survive him.
His father, the son of a Jewish cigar maker from Friedberg, Germany, converted to Anglicanism in the 1930's. Harry followed in his path, as he did again when, at 40, he was selected to represent the Kimberley constituency in Parliament. There, like his father, he was a voice for liberalism.
But Mr. Oppenheimer's first term, which started in 1948, coincided with the victory of the National Party led by Prime Minister Daniel Malan, which under successive leaders would rule South Africa for more than 40 years.
When Mr. Oppenheimer left Parliament in 1957 to take over the family business empire after his father died, he threw his moral and financial support to the relatively liberal Progressive Party.
Once, when a state television interviewer asked him whether it had ever occurred to him to follow another career, he responded with customarily dry wit: "I chose my father with discretion and I found myself in a certain position. And, I mean, like the prayer book says, I have sought to do my duty in the station in which it pleases the Lord to call me."

HEADLINE: Paul Bunyan Settling Into His New Cubicle

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: COOS BAY, Ore., Aug. 17

 BODY:
Zeldon Linn has worked on the railroads and in a sawmill. He has been a sergeant in the Army and a mechanic in a garage. At times for the last 15 years he has found work as a fisherman, crabbing and catching salmon in the Pacific Ocean off this struggling blue-collar town along the Oregon coast. At other times, he has found no work at all.
All of which, he conceded with a laugh the other day, seems like odd preparation for his new job, where he sits in a cubicle each day, fires up a computer, dons a headset and swings into action on the first ring of the telephone. 
 "Good morning," Mr. Linn says. "Thank you for calling MSN Technical Support. My name is Zeldon. May I have your e-mail address, please?"
For Mr. Linn and 345 other people here in remote Coos County, where the historical economic pillars of logging and fishing have been severely battered and where the unemployment rate was in the double digits as recently as last year, an improbable savior has emerged, mushrooming in a matter of months into the second-largest private employer in the county.
As high-tech companies face an acute shortage of workers in many urban areas, they have begun to branch out to areas of the country that had been passed over by the boom, bringing jobs and training and making inroads on the "digital divide" between America's urban and rural regions.
Here in southern Oregon, the company is CyberRep.com, a Virginia concern that has contracts to provide phone and Internet services for well-known corporate clients. CyberRep workers like Mr. Linn answer the toll-free help lines for the Microsoft Corporation's MSN online service and for Barnes & Noble.com, the online division of the bookseller.
For places like Coos Bay, once the largest wood-products shipping port in the world, there are some painful twists. These are the back-office jobs of the "new economy," paying $8 to $9 an hour and offering no stock-option bonuses. There is a graveyard shift, because the help lines need to be staffed 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. Even with CyberRep set to surpass the Mill Casino, owned by the Coquille Indian tribe, as the area's largest source of private jobs, it will still represent just a fraction of the 3,200 jobs in the wood-products industry that local officials say have been lost in the last 20 years. In many cases those jobs paid, in constant-dollar terms, twice as well as the new ones.
Still, these are jobs, offering health benefits and computer skills that many workers say they believe are the perfect entry to more lucrative employment. And most of the workers, like Mr. Linn, seem grateful for the work, though they often express ambivalence about the nature of the work and the sweeping economic forces that have taken them out of the woods or off the seas and placed them in small workstations in a boxy warehouse building up the street from the local airport.
"I miss the ocean," said Mr. Linn, 43, a burly, bearded man who still wears work boots to his job. "There's a feeling of freedom you get there like no place else. Now here I am, confined to this little cubicle.
"On the other hand," he said, his face brightening, "this is the first job I've ever had where I go to work clean and I come home clean. I've never had a job where I didn't come home smelling like fish or oil."
Mr. Linn and other workers at CyberRep described the kick they get from helping frustrated or even irate callers from around the nation facing trouble with their dial-up adapters, modem connections, configuration schemes and all manner of other software and Internet problems. Some callers simply need old-fashioned help, like directions.
"I'm driving through Kansas right now," said a woman named Peggy, speaking on her cell phone, after she called Barnes & Noble's 1-800-THE-BOOK help line and reached Stella Smith, 62, the wife of a retired logger, at her workstation here. "I'm driving across the country. Do you have a bookstore anywhere near Topeka, Kan.? I'd really like to go to a bookstore."
Mrs. Smith instantly used her computer mouse to navigate the "find a store" function of the Barnes & Noble site to locate the store in Topeka and give Peggy the directions.
These jobs are not for everybody. Some who have worked around trees or at the port all their lives said they could not imagine being cooped up all day, staring at a computer screen.
"You put me indoors and I'm lost," said George Sjostrom, 59, a wiry man with a chain saw and a hard hat, who shook his head when asked if he might want to trade his job as a log-yard worker for that of a computer-support specialist.
"I'm out of my world," continued Mr. Sjostrom, who tags and sorts giant logs all day with the help of enormous claw-equipped machines that move the logs around the yard as if they were toothpicks, readying them for placement aboard ships at the nearby port or in machines that turn them into wood chips bound for pulp mills. "I wouldn't have any idea what to do with a computer. If I could figure out the 'on' button, that'd be a big accomplishment for me."
At CyberRep, though, many of the workers said they enjoyed computers and several, including Mr. Linn and Mike Armijo, 38, who lost two jobs in recent years when local mills closed, said they had initially taught themselves how to use the machines.
The jobs have their stressful aspects, perhaps chief among them the constant pressure to satisfy customers while sticking to an average time of roughly nine minutes a call.
"You walk a fine line," Mr. Armijo said. "You've got to be as caring as you can, but you've also got to get them off the phone as quickly as possible."
Workers here trade horror stories about their longest service calls -- 82 minutes here, 74 minutes there -- often involving customers who have completely fouled up their software settings in a bid to solve what began as a much simpler problem. Men are generally more difficult than women, workers of both sexes agree.
"Men are much more likely to think they know something about computers when they don't," Mr. Linn observed. "But women, I've found, are more willing to say something like, 'I really don't know, I need help.' They'll really listen to you more. So they take less time."
Several elements came together to culminate in the deal that brought CyberRep to the call-center building, which is part of the airport office park in North Bend, the neighboring town to Coos Bay. The idea started last year in the mind of John Stadter, then the chief financial officer of 800 Support, a company based in the Portland suburbs that was recently acquired by CyberRep.
Mr. Stadter grew up on the Oregon coast and had a vacation home near here, in Bandon. So, he explained, he knew something about the area and convinced his initially skeptical colleagues that there was a large, willing and able work force.
"Some of the smartest people in my high school class went to work in the woods, because that's where the big money was," said Mr. Stadter, now the general manager of Coos Bay operations for CyberRep. "And they're still around here."
The Oregon International Port of Coos Bay, which helps broker economic development deals, put together a package of tax incentives and agreed to lease the building. The local Southwestern Oregon Community College provided computer training classes.
Coos Bay's wood-shipping industry, as well as its fishing, has declined in the face of foreign competition and heightened environmental regulations. While 300 million board feet of lumber were shipped out of Coos Bay annually a decade ago, the number last year was 13.5 million, said Ingvar Doessing, the manager of a local stevedoring company and a member of the port commission.
The region, 80 miles away from the nearest Interstate, is remote by many measures. Local officials have sought unsuccessfully to attract a steel mill, a pulp mill and a fish-processing plant. They say they are thrilled to have landed a high-tech company.
"This area has never really participated in the economic boom of the 1990's," said Allan E. Rumbaugh, the port's general manager. "It certainly participated very strongly in the recession of the early 1980's. So this deal has given us a real sense of optimism that we're not the pariah we sometimes worry we are. We can attract a company to come here from out of town. That feels pretty good."
Mr. Armijo, the CyberRep support technician, expressed more caution: "It's been my sad observation that nothing lasts forever around here as a source of jobs. I've never seen anything that permanent.
"But for now," he said, using an analogy that looks back to what was once an economic mainstay, "I think it's a godsend that this company has come in here. It's kind of like a guy going fishing and reeling in a 1,300-pound tuna. It's unbelievable."

HEADLINE: Lazio Finds New Friends In Democratic Stronghold

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

DATELINE: CHEEKTOWAGA, N.Y., Aug. 20

 BODY:
Vivian and Salvatore Frisicaro were wearing Hillary stickers, but when Representative Rick A. Lazio strode past them at the Pulaski Day parade here this afternoon, they did not voice fist-waving contempt or even just grimace like the longtime Democrats they profess to be.
A few minutes later, the Frisicaros let slip a secret: they were apostates, Lazio fans who had turned against their party's Senate candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton. 
 "We need help, economically, medically," explained Mrs. Frisicaro, 69, a retired teacher's aide who said she had put on the sticker as a courtesy to a friend who handed it to her here in this Buffalo suburb. "I think she had her try when President Clinton was in, with the health-care plan. And health care is still going down the tubes."
Like the Frisicaros', the political allegiances of Erie County, a classically blue-collar Democratic redoubt in western New York, are not always predictable. The county has increasingly become one of the most crucial swing areas in New York, and if the number of Lazio backers who lined the route today on Harlem Road was any indication, Mrs. Clinton cannot assume the county is a sure thing.
The Democratic organization here in Erie County is more formidable than any in the state outside New York City, but it has faced some unexpected defeats in recent years. It lost the county executive's office last year and could not stop Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, from winning the county in both 1994 and 1998.
Both Mr. Lazio and Mrs. Clinton have identified Erie as vital to their campaigns, and although Mrs. Clinton skipped the parade, which celebrates Polish-Americans by honoring the Revolutionary War hero Casimir Pulaski, she arrived late this afternoon for a visit to an arts festival that followed the parade.
Mrs. Clinton was greeted enthusiastically as she mingled with people before taking the stage to dance a polka with her daughter, Chelsea.
She also served kielbasa at a food stand, conducting a taste test that compared the local variety with one her campaign had brought from Westchester, her new home county.
In brief comments to reporters, Mrs. Clinton did not directly address her chances in Erie, though she expressed fondness for the people of the county.
Her campaign aides disputed the idea that Mr. Lazio had a chance here, saying that wayward white, working-class Democrats like the Frisicaros would return to the fold.
"It's a swing area that it's important to win, and I'm confident that we will do so," said Howard Wolfson, a spokesman for the Clinton campaign. "We have devoted an enormous amount of time upstate. And we are the only candidate in the race to have an economic plan to bring new jobs upstate."
It also might be argued that some of those at the parade could have been smitten by Mr. Lazio because he took time to shake their hands or pose for photos with their children. Still, it was not difficult, in more than 20 interviews with Democrats at the parade to find people leaning toward him.
"He's New York State-born," said Adolph Rakowski, 62, a retired custodian who recalled that the only Republican for whom he had voted in recent years was Mr. Pataki in 1998. "I don't think that we should have a carpetbagger running. She does not know where western New York is. If she learns where western New York is, maybe we can vote for her."
Nearby was Ray Full, 79, a retired painter, who said it would be unthinkable to vote for Mr. Lazio.
Mr. Full said he had supported a Republican in the past -- Representative Jack Quinn, who has close ties to labor -- but would not do so this time. "Hillary is going to win," Mr. Full said. "Most of the time the Democrats get in around here."
Speaking to reporters after he marched, Mr. Lazio said the response pleased him. "If this today is any indication of the level of support that we have in a county that has a Democrat registration edge, we are going to do very well," he said.
Like Mrs. Clinton, Mr. Lazio also used the day to express his appreciation for the county and for Polish-Americans, though he seemed to evince a little confusion about geopolitics when he said in a short speech that he had favored Poland's entrance into the North American, rather than North Atlantic, Treaty Organization, or NATO.
Mr. Lazio and his aides continued to attack a Spanish-language radio commercial that is being sponsored by the Democratic State Committee in support of Mrs. Clinton. The commercial declares that Mr. Lazio has always voted in Congress against the interests of Hispanic people on government spending, the military's use of a bombing range in Puerto Rico and other issues.
"It is an attempt to bring out the very worst in people," Mr. Lazio said of the commercial. "It's beyond distorting the record -- it's an outright fabrication."
Mrs. Clinton dismissed his criticism and his demand that the commercial be withdrawn, saying that it was factually correct.
"National Hispanic groups have given him a zero for his voting record," she said.

LENGTH: 1027 words

HEADLINE: Defense in the 21st Century

 BODY:
The presidential campaign has embarked on an unhelpful debate between the candidates about Gov. George W. Bush's assertion that American military forces have been "hollowed out" during the Clinton administration. That is not true, and it deflects the conversation from a host of important defense issues that the candidates should be addressing. The United States has by far the world's most powerful military forces and invests more money in maintaining them and their weapons than the next 10 largest countries combined spend on their militaries. The question for Americans to consider is whether the armed forces are adapting quickly enough to fight the kinds of battles they are likely to face in the years ahead.
The paramount non-nuclear military issue before the nation is how the country's military forces should be organized, armed, trained and used. We will deal in a later piece with nuclear weapons and missile defense schemes. The United States must maintain conventional military forces of sufficient strength to defend the nation's vital interests. But war should always be the option of last resort in settling a conflict. 
 When Washington sends Americans into combat, it must do so with the intention and means to achieve victory quickly and decisively but without a wanton use of firepower. America cannot expect that all its future conflicts will be as casualty free as those of the past decade. Still, commanders must exercise military power overseas with due regard for the safety of American troops and civilian populations. Ground troops should be employed only if air power and precision weapons cannot achieve American goals.
Though the armed services have been downsized over the past 10 years and battle doctrines have been modified since the demise of the Soviet Union, the United States today still has military forces better suited to dealing with the kinds of threats encountered during the cold war than the new dangers the nation faces. That must change.
America now has some 1.4 million men and women on active duty, down from about 2.2 million a decade ago. The Army has shrunk from 18 divisions (each with roughly 15,000 troops) to 10, though it still has 470,000 people over all. The Air Force has gone from 22 air wings (each with 72 planes) to 12. The Navy has slimmed from 13 aircraft carrier groups to 12 and from a total of 528 ships to 315. Defense spending, at nearly $300 billion a year and once again rising in real terms, is now about 25 percent below the peak Reagan years, after accounting for inflation.
The nation's conventional forces are now organized on the assumption that they might have to fight two regional wars simultaneously, for example in the Persian Gulf and the Korean peninsula. Future military conflicts are possible in either region, but overlapping wars seem highly improbable. The Pentagon should be ready to fight one regional war on short notice, using ground forces if necessary, while relying on air power to give the country time to mobilize for a second conflict. One regional war would likely require four to five army divisions, five air wings and three carrier groups. In the highly unlikely event of a second war breaking out at the same time, the country should rely on mobilizing its 865,000 reserve troops, including eight reserve air wings.
To fight regional wars, the army needs lighter, more easily transportable tanks and artillery than it has today. The Pentagon needs to strengthen its capacity for airlifting and sealifting troops into battle regions. The services also should be equipped with a robust arsenal of sea- and air-launched cruise missiles, more smart weapons and airborne drones for intelligence. The Pentagon must improve the way it delivers to battlefield commanders the sophisticated photographic intelligence now available from satellites and reconnaissance aircraft.
Since the Persian Gulf war nine years ago, the largest American military operations have involved protracted peacekeeping, as in Bosnia, punitive air and missile strikes, as in Iraq, or emergency actions to halt ethnic conflicts, as in Kosovo. The future is likely to see more of these interventions, which require different kinds of training, equipment and planning than the large European land battles anticipated during the cold war. The Army, with its heavy weaponry and lack of mobility, seems least prepared to engage in these new conflicts, as seen in Kosovo. Even if a decision had been made to use ground forces, it would have taken many months to transport an effective force to the area.
The Navy and the Air Force are better adapted to the post-cold-war world. But too much of their weapons budgets are now allocated to dubious projects like the next-generation fighter plane. This is an expensive indulgence in a world where no potential rival is developing aircraft superior to America's current F-16's and F-15's. The Air Force could use the money it would save to assure a more reliable flow of spare parts and more cargo planes for airlifting troops and equipment, among other things. The Navy could devote its savings to adapting more of its submarine and surface fleet for launching cruise missiles.
Charges that the American military is unprepared to wage war are a regular feature of presidential campaigns. A more fundamental debate is needed, looking not just at time spent training for combat but also at factors like air and sealift capacity and the availability of appropriate equipment. Both candidates have usefully called attention to issues of military pay and housing and to the need to recruit and retain skilled pilots and computer professionals at a time when the civilian economy is offering attractive lures.
Mr. Bush has offered a few thoughtful and provocative ideas on defense but now needs to move beyond generalities. Mr. Gore, long a student of military issues, has seemed content to let the Clinton administration's record and policies speak for him. Both candidates have chosen running mates who are interested and knowledgeable about military issues. The two tickets should now move on to an expansive defense debate.

HEADLINE: ACCORD IS REACHED FOR MOST WORKERS IN PHONE WALKOUT

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
The two unions representing more than 86,000 striking telephone workers reached a contract agreement yesterday with the nation's largest telecommunications employer, Verizon Communications, for about two-thirds of the strikers, indicating that organized labor still has a place in the New Economy.
Although about one-third of the union locals had still not signed off on the settlement last evening, the company and the union leaders said the 15-day strike was effectively over. They said union workers in the region affected by the strike -- 12 states from Maine to Virginia and the District of Columbia -- could return to their jobs in New York and New England as soon as this morning, although workers in states such as New Jersey and Pennsylvania are still waiting for their local presidents to approve the contract. 
 The first task for Verizon will be to work down a backlog of telephone repair orders that has risen to 90,000 -- one-third more than normal -- since the strike began Aug. 6
Under the three-year contract agreement, the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers secured numerous concessions from Verizon, which is the nation's largest provider of wireless and local telephone services, with 260,000 employees around the nation.
The unions secured a 12 percent wage increase, over three years, for a work force that was already one of the best paid in the telecommunications industry. The average hourly base pay for a customer service representative in New York, $26, would increase to $29.25 in the contract's third year, for example. And in a new-economy wrinkle, each of Verizon's union workers will receive a small grant of stock options.
But the broader significance of the agreement, and the reason the negotiations have been closely watched throughout the high-technology industry, involves issues that go beyond wage and benefit concerns.
The unions have won the right to more easily organize workers in Verizon's wireless division, where fewer than 50 of the division's 32,000 employees belong to a union. The unions also secured Verizon's promise that union telephone workers will be given the opportunity to do more work in fast-growing areas like the installation of high-speed Internet lines -- an activity for which Verizon has tended to use nonunion contractors until now.
Those were key points for the unions because wireless and Internet communications are growing much faster than the conventional telephone business.
"This contract is a breakthrough not just for our members who work at Verizon but for workers throughout the telecommunications industry," Larry Mancino, vice president of the Communications Workers of America, which represents about 72,000 of the striking employees, said yesterday .
The unions also secured agreements on several other issues that reflected worker anxieties in the new economy, which is characterized by big corporate mergers and an entrepreneurial ethic in which the shorthand "24/7" -- meaning 24 hours a day, seven days a week -- symbolizes the relentlessness of work in today's economy.
Verizon was created by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of the GTE Corporation and through the formation of a wireless venture with Vodafone AirTouch of Britain. And union employees, particularly in the Northeast, had been worried about the prospect of the company transferring work to lower-paying parts of the country.
The unions, especially customer service representatives, had also sought relief from job stress brought by long periods of work with few breaks and frequent mandatory overtime.
Verizon agreed to greater job stability for union members by limiting the number of employees whose jobs could be moved to a different region to 0.7 percent of the union workers in a given geographic area each year. The measurement would be based on a geographic area as small as a county, as the unions wanted, instead of an across-the-board number, as the company wanted.
On job-related stress, Verizon agreed to give customer service representatives and telephone operators up to five 30-minute periods each week during which they can do work other than taking calls. And mandatory overtime for customer service representatives and operators would be reduced. For example, operators who are single mothers will be limited to as few as 7.5 hours a week in some areas, down from as much as 20 hours before the strike.
Verizon (pronounced Vuh-RISE-en) was under various pressures to settle the strike, which the company had apparently expected to be only a token few-day walkout. It had come at the busiest time of the year for the consumer telecommunications industry, when many students were about to return to college and would require new telephone and Internet access service.
Shortly before the strike began, the company also started a major advertising campaign to make people aware of its new name. And lately, concern over the company's earnings have pushed Verizon's share price close to a two-year low. Since the strike began, Verizon's stock has fallen more than 10 percent. It closed at $42.4375 on Friday.
"We're glad to put this strike behind us and move on," the company's chief executive, Ivan Seidenberg, said yesterday in an interview. "I would say that every one of the unions' issues was legitimate going forward. We've strengthened the fiber of our company over the long term with this agreement."
What remains to be seen is how the agreement will be viewed elsewhere in labor circles, by other big telecommunications companies and by Wall Street.
"This is one of the most wide-reaching contract settlements the industry has seen," said Jeffrey Kagan, an independent analyst of the telecommunications industry. "It'll be interesting to see whether this will result in a more qualified work force or a ball and chain around the company's leg."
The unions' right to organize Verizon's wireless division may end up as the strike's most significant outcome. The unions won an important concession allowing them to organize by card check, which permits a given work site to join a union if a majority of its employees sign cards saying they wish to do so. The process is faster and less bureaucratic than holding elections.
Under this part of the agreement, the employees at a work location would join the union if 55 percent signed up through the cards.
The wireless agreement applies only to workers in the strike region, where about one-quarter of the 32,000 employees of the Verizon Wireless division are located.
The agreement would include technicians, customer service representatives and employees who work as customer sales representatives in the wireless division's retail stores.
Making it easier to organize Verizon's wireless work force could have broad implications for the nation's wireless industry, which is one of the fastest-growing parts of the new economy and which so far has remained a primarily nonunion business.
Of course, there is no certainty that the majority of workers in parts of Verizon Wireless that are not covered by the settlement or at other wireless companies -- or in other high-growth, high-technology industries, for that matter -- are eager to unionize.
But some union advocates are optimistic.
"For us, the parallel issues are glaringly apparent," said Marcus Courtney, co-founder of the Washington Alliance of Technology Workers, a Seattle organization affiliated with the Communications Workers of America. The Washington Alliance has already organized a small number of employees at companies that include Microsoft and Amazon.com.
"This will make our efforts easier, because it shows that the largest company in a key high-tech industry is not off limits," Mr. Courtney said. "Now we can hold up this example that says, 'Your voice can be heard.' "
And as in the Verizon strike, the future of union organizing efforts in high-technology companies is not expected to focus on wages as much as on issues like job security, benefits, overtime, work-related stress and even stock options.
"The questions have been raised," said Stanley Aronowitz, a professor of sociology at the City University of New York who has studied labor issues. "In the 30's, no one took workers' complaints seriously until the G.M.'s and U.S. Steels were organized."
Already in the wireless industry, where Verizon will try to compete with other companies that are mostly nonunion, there are inklings that organizing can be viable.
At SBC Communications, which will soon operate the nation's second-largest wireless carrier in a venture with BellSouth, the same kind of card-check organizing Verizon has agreed to has been permitted for nearly three years. So far, more than 5,000 of SBC's wireless employees out of a potential 12,000 eligible are union members, the C.W.A. says.
And at AT&T Wireless, the third-largest wireless carrier, the union won the right last year to card-check organizing, although elections must be held several days after the cards are gathered -- a potential union impediment not included in the Verizon agreement.
 
THE AGREEMENT
Highlights of Contract
 
LENGTH OF CONTRACT -- Three years.
 
ORGANIZATION -- The unions will be able to organize more easily in Verizon's wireless division, and union members will have the opportunity to do more work in fast-growing areas like the installation of high-speed Internet service.
 
COMPENSATION -- A 12 percent raise over the life of the contract: 4 percent in the first year, 3 percent in the second and 5 percent in the third. In addition, full-time employees will receive 100 stock options and part-time workers will receive 50. A profit-sharing plan tied to that of the chief executive will provide payouts up to $1,000 a year.
 
JOB STABILITY -- The number of Verizon employees who can have their jobs transferred to a different region as a result of the Bell Atlantic-GTE merger is limited to seven-tenths of 1 percent each year.
 
JOB STRESS -- Customer service representatives and operators will receive up to five 30-minute periods each week in which they can do work other than taking calls.
 
OVERTIME -- Mandatory overtime is lowered for most customer service representatives and operators.

HEADLINE: For Incumbent Legislator in the South Bronx, a Primary Rematch

SERIES: NEW YORK PRIMARY/32 Senate District

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Few local political races are laced with the kind of unvarnished acrimony seen in a primary contest being waged in the 32nd Senate District in the South Bronx between an incumbent state senator who is one of the Democratic Party's most loyal soldiers and his predecessor, an ardent enemy of the party organization.
For the last four years, Pedro Espada Jr., who operates a large health care center in the Bronx, has been the principal thorn in the side of the Democratic Party organization in the borough. And Mr. Espada is now engaged in another primary battle to regain the seat he lost four years ago. 
 In doing so, he is taking on David Rosado, who acquiesced to the wishes of party leaders in 1996, when he resigned his City Council seat to run against Mr. Espada. That matchup was short-lived. Mr. Espada was removed from the ballot because of irregularities in his nominating petitions. In their last battle, in the 1998 Democratic primary, Mr. Rosado prevailed, but by just 745 votes, making his one of the narrowest victories in the state that year.
Mr. Espada, 46, is back this year in what has become a high-voltage battle filled with old grudges and bitterness. On any given day, residents in the district might run into the caravans of either of the competitors, with sound trucks blaring the names of the candidate. Posters for the candidates are in storefronts. And the candidates have been spending their mornings greeting voters at subway stations and their evenings in door-to-door campaigning throughout the district.
The Rosado campaign, for example, is operating telephone banks from three different locations. And Mr. Espada has opened three offices and has campaign workers deployed throughout the district, passing out campaign literature, T-shirts and campaign trinkets to get the attention of voters.
Mr. Rosado, 58, said the closeness of the 1998 primary was a reflection of his limited campaign activity that year. He said that he spent months suffering from a nerve disorder in his neck and that he had surgery for it before the primary. "But this year," he said, "I am out here working hard, campaigning every day and I am connecting with the people."
He defends his stewardship in the State Senate, saying he worked vigorously to create a bill, signed into law last month, that imposes harsher sentences on criminals in New York who single out their victims on the basis of sexual orientation, race, religion or age.
"I have a long record of working within the community," said Mr. Rosado, a former state assemblyman and city councilman. "I have worked on creating new housing for the people in the Bronx. I have helped people with landlord-tenant disputes. I have worked hard in the district and in Albany."
Mr. Espada, who served in the State Senate from 1992 to 1996, said he was running again because of his desire to expand economic opportunities for the residents of the district. He said he would work with the Republican majority in the Senate to bring job creation programs to the district and to increase the number of public housing units.
Assailing his opponent, Mr. Espada said: "David Rosado is not a leader. We are in one of the poorest districts in the state and Rosado is simply an instrument of the local political operation. Clubhouse politicians treat their positions as jobs. I see it as an opportunity to create new change for our community. He is an instrument of the Democratic machine."
The Espada family has had its share of tangles with that machine. The most dramatic came in 1996, when Mr. Espada was in the Senate and his son, Pedro Gautier Espada, won a special election for an open Assembly seat. But later that year, after a feud, the Espadas broke with the Democratic organization, which resulted in Mr. Rosado running against the senator, and Ruben Diaz Jr. running against the son.
Furthermore, the party organization was then successful in having both Espadas thrown off the ballot after finding irregularities in their nominating petitions.
Since then, however, the Espadas have enjoyed at least something of a political comeback. In 1997, Pedro Gautier Espada was elected to the City Council in an embarrassing defeat for the Democratic organization. And a year later, Jose Espada, the former senator's brother, was elected a Democratic district leader.
The following year saw more difficulties for Pedro Espada Jr. He was arraigned with two of his employees on charges that they had illegally diverted $221,000 in Medicaid money to his failed 1996 re-election campaign and that of his son, the assemblyman. But Mr. Espada said the charges were politically motivated since they came just a few days after he announced that he would run. The case is still pending.
The current Espada campaign has become a family affair. His son, the councilman, is the campaign chairman, and another son, Alex, is working as the field director. But the Rosado campaign has also enlisted a high-profile campaign manager: Assemblyman Diaz. Mr. Diaz won his last election by a margin so wide that he is considered one of the borough's most popular politicians.
The 32nd Senate District sweeps through the southern tier of the Bronx, and includes the Crotona, Soundview, Clason Point and Mott Haven neighborhoods. In the 1990 census, the district was 61 percent Hispanic and 31 percent black. Non-Hispanic white residents accounted for about 5 percent of the district's population.
Many Bronx Democrats expect that this year's race in the district will be close. Both campaigns say they will spend about $150,000 on the campaign leading to the Sept. 12 primary. Mr. Rosado has the support of the Bronx Democratic organization, but Mr. Espada, who employs more than 300 full-time workers in the Bronx, said he would have hundreds of campaign workers at his disposal on Election Day.
Mr. Rosado predicts that because he is campaigning more vigorously, his victory will be more substantial this year and that winning by an overwhelming majority, as he hopes to, will likely mean an end to Mr. Espada's interest in running for the State Senate seat.
"I don't think he will run again if I win big," Mr. Rosado said. "That's why I'm working so hard."
