HEADLINE: A Hollow Lesson

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
If a phone circuit goes dead and no one is on the line, does it really stop carrying sound?
In many ways, a similar question could be asked about the effective end to the strike against Verizon Communications. While the strike is important for Verizon, the walkout and Sunday's agreement with two-thirds of the union membership on strike probably will not have much bearing on the rest of the telecommunications industry. Even for consumers, the strike's effect can fairly be described as only minimal. 
 As for Verizon itself, the company will continue to be penalized to the tune of billions of dollars of market value for the strength of its unions.
When auto workers go on strike, cars stop rolling off assembly lines. When pilots go on strike, planes stop flying. But when phone workers go on strike, life pretty much goes on.
That is because modern networks are largely automated. Incidents of vandalism cut service to a few thousand customers here and there. Two striking workers who were nearly electrocuted were accused of trying to slice a phone line on Long Island last week. But in a backhanded testament to the power of the machines, those figures paled beside the hundreds of thousands of Verizon customers who lost long-distance phone service last week when an obscure piece of equipment failed in New Jersey.
By Sunday, Verizon, the company created by Bell Atlantic's acquisition of GTE, had a backlog of about 92,000 outstanding requests for repairs. That figure was perhaps twice normal, implying that about 46,000 of Verizon's 25 million customers in the strike region were having problems they would not have otherwise had.
That works out to fewer than 2 of every 1,000 customers. Of course, for each of those customers one problem was one too many, and those figures do not include the thousands of people who were stymied in attempts to sign up for or change phone service.
Verizon's success in serving almost all of its customers during the strike does not mean that people are unimportant in modern communications. Without the thousands of managers that filled in for the strikers, the extent of the service failures would have been far greater. A network as extensive as Verizon's requires extensive maintenance, and that requires many people.
Largely, however, lower-level employees are needed because customers want to talk to people. Most customers do not want to sign up for new phone service online. Customers with billing questions want a person on the line right now -- not an e-mail response tomorrow.
During the strike, Verizon's directory assistance was largely disabled because the people who answer calls were on picket lines. If voice-recognition software is ever ready for prime time, Verizon will surely prefer to lay off thousands of operators. But while Verizon's unions would certainly block such a move, consumers would probably complain, too. During the strike many consumers have borne the inconvenience of using a phone book, the mark of an old economy if ever there was one.
In the big scheme of things, the effect on consumers of the strike and its partial settlement was and will be quite small. And much the same could be said of the deal's effect on the rest of the industry, even though the unions appeared to win almost everything they had asked for.
For one thing, while the wrangling over the unionization of Verizon's wireless unit was viewed as a referendum on unions' power in newer industries, the deal that was reached in the end was not all that different from those already in place at some other major wireless operators.
"In terms of wireless, it seems as though what they're talking about in terms of union organizing might be similar to AT&T," said Burke Stinson, an AT&T spokesman.
Eric W. Rabe, a Verizon spokesman, even ventured that his company had made a better wireless deal than had SBC Communications, the No. 2 local phone company after Verizon. "The wireless deal that we made, from the union point of view, is more restrictive than the deal SBC already had in place," he said.
The expedited organizing that Verizon agreed to covers only a quarter of the wireless unit employees.
In any case, the main reason the Verizon deal is not a harbinger for the rest of the industry is that Verizon's unions are stronger -- perhaps a lot stronger -- than those at any other phone company in the nation, largely because of Verizon's Northeastern geography.
"I think that Verizon has the toughest unions, so it's very difficult to extrapolate from what happens here to the rest of the industry because Verizon is in a pretty unique position," said Eric Strumingher, a telecommunications analyst at PaineWebber.
BellSouth, Qwest, SBC, Sprint and WorldCom declined to comment on the settlement.
The other companies have nothing to gain by becoming involved in what would be considered a debacle for most of them. The fact is that under Sunday's deal, with its limits on overtime and its limits on job movements, Verizon ultimately has less control over its own business than does just about any big communications carrier.
"The most important thing is the pace at which they can adapt to change in the industry and innovate and capitalize on the new growth opportunities," Mr. Strumingher said. "If the Bells didn't have unions, it's worth a lot."
This month, just as the strike was starting, Verizon announced new projections for its future revenue and earnings growth. Mr. Rabe said the strike and the new deal would not alter those projections.
But unionization nonetheless carries a big price on Wall Street.
The price of a stock is often calculated in terms of a multiple of the company's expected per-share earnings. For instance, Verizon's shares closed at about $42.81 yesterday, up about 69 cents, meaning that they are worth 14.63 times the company's expected per-share earnings of about $2.93 this year.
Yesterday, Mr. Strumingher said unionization was probably costing all of the Bell companies "at least five" multiple points. If Verizon's stock were trading at an earnings multiple of 19.63 rather than 14.63, each share would be worth $57.44. Over all, Verizon would have a market value of about $156 billion, not the $116 billion it currently has.
All else being equal, Verizon's earnings multiple probably suffers "a couple of points" relative even to SBC or BellSouth, said Mr. Strumingher, because of its strong unions and the presumed drop in productivity they cause. Just two points of earnings multiple costs it about $16 billion in market value.
None of this will come as a surprise to Verizon's senior management. They know it all too well. Now, there is nothing they can do about it.

HEADLINE: In Reverse, California Acts To Cap Some Electric Bills

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 21

 BODY:
With electricity rates doubling or tripling for some consumers in San Diego, the California Public Utility Commission took a step back from the recent deregulation of the market today and narrowly voted to cap electric bills for some residential and business customers in that city.
The arrangement, a compromise, left many people still unhappy, and several experts said further regulations might be needed because of what some have described as price gouging in the wholesale electricity market and a system that leaped toward deregulation before sufficient supplies were available. 
 Today's decision, on a vote of 3 to 2, would reduce rates for many residents of San Diego by about 43 percent, assuring that customers who keep their consumption below certain caps would pay no more than $68 a month through the end of the year. San Diego was the first big market in California to be deregulated because its principal gas and electric utilities merged earlier to form Sempra Energy.
Loretta Lynch, the president of the commission and an opponent of the decision today, explained that the price caps would apply only to individuals who use 500 kilowatts or less a month or from 60 percent to 70 percent of customers in the city. Customers who use more than that will be charged the higher rates in the unregulated market, she said. The decision also applies only to small-business customers, those that use 1,500 kilowatts a month or less.
San Diego's mayor, Susan Golding, said one of her biggest concerns was that the plan left important users, including public schools and hospitals, at the mercy of a market that has seen prices skyrocket. Ms. Golding said that while she generally favored deregulation, it was ill-considered because the supply was clearly inadequate to meet demand, particularly at a time when the economy was booming.
"But even if demand weren't so strong, we still would be in incredibly bad shape," Ms. Golding said.
San Diego's utility welcomed today's step as a temporary measure that would be required only until new power plants come into operation, perhaps in three years or so.
"The impact of deregulation on San Diego has been just awful," said Steve Baum, the chairman of Sempra Energy, which owns San Diego Gas and Electric. "This step as a smoothing mechanism has been very helpful."
The deregulation of the $20 billion electrical power industry in the state resulted from passage of a 1996 law. But the state has suffered power shortages that led rolling "brownouts" in the San Francisco Bay area in June, in addition to the price increases in San Diego.
The average wholesale price for San Diego electricity was $117 per megawatt hour, up from $25 per megawatt hour at a comparable time last year, The Associated Press quoted a member of the utilities commission, Carl Wood, as saying.
This was not the first time that the commission had retreated slightly from its earlier decision to deregulate rates in San Diego, but it was seen as a larger move than in the past. It was also characterized as a possible prelude to more restrictions because of the soaring rates and concerns that inadequate supplies have thwarted this experiment in allowing market forces to determine prices.
Ms. Lynch said that an investigation was under way into why wholesale rates had soared and that the results of that inquiry might be used to establish other restrictions, at least until significant new supplies of electricity were built.
Gov. Gray Davis said he supported a competing proposal that would have provided a broader price cap, but which was defeated in a commission vote today.
Nevertheless, Mr. Davis said, "the action taken today by the P.U.C. is clearly a step forward."
Mr. Davis, a Democrat, also called for a thorough investigation of the wholesale market by the federal government, and added that he put most of the blame for the problems on price gouging by out-of-state suppliers of electricity.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE RALLYING CRY;
'Working Families' Becomes a Theme Meant to Attract Female Voters

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 21

 BODY:
The phrase is suddenly everywhere. In his acceptance speech last Thursday, Vice President Al Gore mentioned "working families" nine times. Party officials told other speakers to use the phrase, and they did, over and over. Now the Gore campaign is printing up signs with it and repeating it time and again on the road.
"In the name of all the working families who are the strength and soul of America, I accept your nomination for president of the United States," Mr. Gore declared halfway through his 52-minute speech in Los Angeles. 
 "It's about fighting for working families!" Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said earlier in the night.
"Imagine how strong we're going to be when we help our working families with affordable college educations and affordable health care," said Housing Secretary Andrew M. Cuomo.
While Democrats have been speaking to "working families" for years, the Gore campaign has recently latched on to the theme as a way of appealing to women. But unlike the pitch in the last two elections, directed to Volvo-driving suburban "soccer moms," Mr. Gore's appeal this time is to the "waitress mom," the working woman who not only juggles family and a job but also looks to the government for help in meeting the needs of her family.
So as his campaign has steamed through the populist heartland in recent days, Mr. Gore has talked less about gun control and abortion rights, topics more likely to appeal to the more affluent "soccer moms" and more about bread-and-butter economic issues like adding a benefit to Medicare to pay for prescription drugs and shoring up Social Security.
Mr. Gore, the son of a populist Southern senator, used the "working families" phrase in his 1988 campaign for president. And it became popular among Democrats after the Republicans swept the Congress in 1994, and the party of the little guy needed to regroup its base.
But when Mr. Gore formally began his campaign more than a year ago, he seemed more focused on busy, relatively upscale suburban parents who were snagged in traffic jams and could say good night to their children only by cell phone.
Mr. Gore tried out the concept of "working families" late last year with the slogan "Change that works for working families." It was noticeable for its double-barreled emphasis on work.
But by that time, the threat from former Senator Bill Bradley was growing and the theme did not reflect what Mr. Gore was saying on the campaign trail. Besides, it was too clunky. The slogan, along with others like "practical idealism," vanished as quickly as it appeared, as Mr. Gore slipped more naturally into combat mode with the phrase "Stay and fight!"
Then about two months ago, as Mr. Gore began drafting his speech for the convention, the phrase "working families" re-emerged. It came up in the normal course of the focus groups that most campaigns conduct, and advisers said it was tested with a so-called people meter, a hand-held device that test groups of consumers can use to register their reaction to products, or in this case, to political language.
"These are not new words in the dictionary," a top Gore strategist said. "You hear things that the candidate says, you expose people to it, there are some things that resonate more than others, you get feedback from crowds and in the course of that, the language of the campaign begins to take shape.
"There was no epiphany on these two words," the strategist said, "but there was a consensus developing in recent weeks, not just on this term but that the whole program was a powerful way of speaking to the needs and concerns of the people who will decide this election."
Behind the phrase lies an entire political strategy. The phrase, along with Mr. Gore's populist fervor, marks a broad, thematic shift, intended to energize the party's base, which polls had shown to be less enthusiastic in their support of Mr. Gore than the Republican base was in supporting Gov. George W. Bush.
Anne Brown, 34, a schoolteacher who attended the opening rally for Mr. Gore's boat ride down the Mississippi in La Crosse, Wis., said she responded to the phrase because "we know what he's talking about." Ms. Brown went to the rally with her 2-month-old daughter and her 55-year-old mother, who has lung cancer, and said she especially appreciated the Democrats' support of the Family and Medical Leave Act. "It lets you be at home with your family as long as possible," she said, adding that she was leaning toward Mr. Gore for this reason.
A top Gore adviser said: "Working women in general encompass one of the largest elements of persuadable voters in this election. One of the great accomplishments of our convention was to soften up Bush's vote and expand our scope of opportunity."
There was some evidence today that Mr. Gore's approach was having some effect. Several polls showed Mr. Gore's standing among voters improved after the convention, largely because of stronger support from women. A CNN poll showed Mr. Gore beating Mr. Bush, his Republican rival, by 20 percentage points among women. It also showed Mr. Bush beating Mr. Gore by 20 percentage points among men.
The Gore campaign believes that getting the ear of these women is a crucial first step toward getting their vote, and that as Mr. Gore wins over lower-income voters, he can advance up the economic ladder to win higher-income voters.
"They are a large bloc of voters who are anxious to see who will be their champion," said the Gore strategist. "As the vice president gains more standing with more voters, others will come -- like blue collar men -- and he'll have the capacity to talk to other groups higher up in income scale, like the wired workers."
Mr. Gore's tax cuts are aimed specifically at working families -- tax credits for college tuition, day care, after-school programs, long-term health care, retirement and investments. He is offering $500 billion in tax cuts and credits over 10 years, which might seem a lot for someone who has criticized Mr. Bush's proposed $1.3 trillion tax cut, but Mr. Gore said today on the last leg of his boat trip that his own tax cuts "will go to the right people."
A Gore adviser who helped coax the phrase "working families" from the focus-group stage to the candidate's lips explained its purpose this way: "It implies we're talking about the people who really need government to be on their side, particularly the federal government, where so many programs from retirement, security and health emanate, and the federal government would be a real partner in terms of education."
The idea of getting help for education costs spoke directly to Lou Cook, 48, a mother of three, who showed up at a rally Saturday for Mr. Gore in Dubuque, Iowa. She said that her local property taxes, which pay for her public schools, were so high that she needed help. "All of us who work for a living have to send our kids to school, pay taxes and mortgages, and we know the only way our kids are going to benefit themselves is through education," Ms. Cook said.
Although Ms. Cook and her husband together earn nearly $100,000 -- she licenses day-care centers and is studying toward her master's degree in therapy, while her husband is a lawyer -- she said she considered herself working class, and she liked the phrase "working families."
Gore advisers said they were not worried that the phrase sent a subliminal message, as Mr. Bush has charged, that "working families" was code for class warfare. They said that this tack by the Bush campaign could help Mr. Gore because it steered the conversation away from whether Mr. Bush was more likable than Mr. Gore.
"When Bush says 'class warfare,' that's a sign he's moving to our terrain," one Gore aide said. "Bush wins if we talk on his terrain about 'affability.'
"But if we move the argument from 'Kumbaya' " the aide said, referring to the good vibes engendered by the Bush campaign, "to 'fighting for working families,' Gore wins."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Teenagers Surveyed On Brand Switching

 BODY:
Teenagers said they would be likely to switch from one brand or retailer to one that supports a good cause -- if price and quality were equal -- according to the second annual Cone/Roper Cause-Related Teen Survey. The study was commissioned by Cone Inc. in Boston, a division of the Omnicom Group, and conducted by Roper Starch Worldwide in New York.
Eighty-nine percent of the respondents to the survey, which was completed in online interviews from Aug. 3 to Aug. 9, said they would be likely to switch brands to one that supported a good cause, if price and quality were equal. Likewise, 85 percent of the respondents said they would be likely to switch retailers to one associated with a good cause, if price and quality are equal. The survey was conducted with 600 America Online users aged 12 to 17. 
 Given a list of eight factors that could be considered when making a purchase, the youths said, making donations to causes and support of causes ranked behind the quality of the product but ahead of factors like price, advertising and celebrity endorsement.
The survey found that the most popular ways to find out about a company's social commitments were television advertisements, followed by school and then newspaper or magazine ads.

HEADLINE: Simple Method Found to Increase Crop Yields Vastly

BYLINE: By CAROL KAESUK YOON 

 BODY:
In a stunning new result from what has become one of the largest agricultural experiments ever, thousands of rice farmers in China have doubled the yields of their most valuable crop and nearly eliminated its most devastating disease -- without using chemical treatments or spending a single extra penny.
Under the direction of an international team of scientists, farmers in China's Yunnan Province adopted a simple change in their rice paddies. Instead of planting the large stands of a single type of rice, as they typically have done, the farmers planted a mixture of two different rices. With this one change, growers were able to radically restrict the incidence of rice blast -- the most important disease of this most important staple in the world. Within just two years, farmers were able to abandon the chemical fungicides previously widely used to fight the disease. 
 "I wasn't surprised that the system worked, but I was surprised that it worked so well," said Dr. Christopher Mundt, population biologist at Oregon State University and the one American-based author on the study, which was published in the current edition of the journal Nature. "I'm excited about the possibilities. There is a lot of potential even beyond rice."
Dr. Youyong Zhu, plant pathologist at Yunnan Agricultural University, heads the mostly China-based research team whose study now covers 100,000 acres and involves tens of thousands of farmers.
In fact, many researchers have long argued that planting a diversity of crops should lead to benefits like greater productivity and the suppression of disease, compared with single variety plantings known as monocultures. Yet the use of diversity and other ecologically based cures for agricultural ills have tended to be viewed as more politically correct than economically viable. Scientists say that this latest study shows that such environmentally friendly methods can be highly effective, even more effective, in this case, than standard chemical pesticides.
Calling the results "very significant," Dr. Alison Power, agricultural ecologist at Cornell University, said, "People have said that these kinds of ecological approaches wouldn't work on a commercial scale. This is a huge scale." She added, "We have more alternatives that are really viable than we often think about or include in our arsenal of possibilities."
Those studying natural ecosystems also welcomed the new work, saying it closely paralleled findings for the role of species diversity in reducing the incidence of disease in the wild.
"It's an important study," said Dr. David Tilman, ecologist at the University of Minnesota. "It's going to raise a great deal of interest."
The scientific hypothesis behind the study, the latest in a growing number examining the effects of biodiversity, is simple. If one variety of a crop is susceptible to a disease, the more concentrated those susceptible types are, the more easily disease can spread and the more victims it can claim. The disease should be less likely to spread, however, if susceptible plants are separated from one another by other kinds of plants that do not succumb to the disease and can act as a barrier.
Rice blast fungus, which destroys millions of tons of rice and costs farmers several billion dollars in losses each year, moves as an airborne spore -- a method of transport that should easily be blocked by a row of disease-resistant plants.
Scientists tested the hypothesis by asking farmers to plant their farms in experimental plots using two kinds of rice: a standard rice that does not usually succumb to rice blast disease and a much more valuable sticky rice known to be highly susceptible. Farmers also planted control plots of monocultures, allowing scientists to test rigorously the importance of the mixtures in the health and productivity on these farms.
What scientists found was that farmers garnered even more benefit from the mixtures than expected. Resistant plants did block the airborne spores in a field, but as more and more farmers became involved in the study, these positive effects began to multiply across the region. Not only were disease spores not blowing in from the next row, they were no longer coming from the next farmer's field either or the next or the next, rapidly damping the spread of the disease on a grand scale.
In addition, scientists found that the sticky rice plants, which poked up above the shorter, standard rice plants with which they were grown enjoyed sunnier, warmer and drier conditions than they would have in a stand of tall, sticky rice plants. These conditions appeared to discourage the growth of the fungal rice blast in the sticky rice plants.
The fact that rice blast is the most devastating disease of rice, the staple crop of most people worldwide, would alone make the study important. But scientists interviewed said there was no reason why mixtures could not decrease disease spread in other crops as well, though how powerful and useful a remedy it would be was likely to vary.
"There's already a lot of work with barley in Europe and coffee in Colombia," said Dr. Mundt. "I've seen beautiful disease reduction in mixtures of willows grown in England."
The study is of particular interest for organic farming as it involves the application of no chemicals.
"Biodiversity is an absolutely essential tool for organic production," said Dr. Martin Wolfe, director of research at Elm Farm Research Centre, an agricultural research institute. "It's an essential part of the armory." Yet, Dr. Wolfe said, even organic farmers underuse diversity, as they also have been indoctrinated in the simplicity of and seduced by the universality of monocultures.
In Yunnan province, farmers were able to harvest rice grains by hand, making it simple to gather and sell the two rice varieties separately. Some scientists argue such problems can also be overcome with mechanized harvesting. In the Pacific Northwest, where an increasing number of farmers are using mixtures of wheat to increase yields and cut down disease, growers may choose varieties that differ in useful qualities, such as resistance to disease, but that can still be harvested and sold together.
Dr. Eileen Watson, plant pathologist at the crop protection sector of Novartis Inc., which makes agricultural fungicide, said using fungicide with the mixtures could lower the incidence of rice blasts further. Dr. Watson said farmers would benefit by further delaying the day when rice blast would overcome the resistance of the nonsusceptible rice.
Researchers say the study's implications extend to prairies, rainforests and other natural ecosystems.
Just as the new study examines the role of a diversity of crops in fighting disease and in productivity of a rice paddy, biodiversity studies have been examining whether increased species number can affect such things as the health of plants in natural settings.
So far the two kinds of studies appear to support one another well. For example, Dr. Tilman and Charles Mitchell, an ecologist at University of Minnesota, have found evidence in prairie ecosystems that an increased diversity of plant species decreases the incidence of disease. As in the rice paddies, in natural ecosystems, when there is a greater diversity of plants, it is simply more difficult for the disease to spread.
"There's been quite a push by the agrotech industry to market genetically engineered crops and genetically homogeneous crops that perform really well," said Dr. Shahid Naeem, ecologist at the University of Washington. "But what's really neat about this paper is that it shows how we've lost sight of the fact that there are some really simple things we can do in the field to manage crops."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the impact of humans on global ecosystems misstated the results of an experiment in which farmers in China planted a mixture of two kinds of rice rather than one. (The same error appeared in the section on Aug. 22, 2000, but went unnoticed.) The yield rose 17 percent, nearly doubling for one variety and staying flat for the other; yield did not nearly double for both.

SECTION: Section F; Page 1; Column 3; Dining In, Dining Out/Style Desk 

LENGTH: 1227 words

HEADLINE: That New York Feeling: Squeezed;
It's not your imagination. It really is more crowded.

BYLINE: By AMANDA HESSER 

 BODY:
IT'S that special something that makes dining in New York City unlike dining in any other place.
Some call it energy. Some call it buzz. 
 New Yorkers call it crowding.
And it's not just their imagination. With real estate at a premium and an economy that's enabling more people to eat out more often, many restaurants have begun to feel like subway cars at rush hour.
A liberal building code hasn't helped. Nor has an army of designers and restaurant managers, who have finessed the art of squeezing more people into their seating plans. And now, strange as it seems, New York City restaurant crowding has become a brand of its own, sought after by restaurateurs in other cities.
Here, the public spaces in a restaurant must allow 12 square feet per person, including diners and staff. Maximum occupancy is calculated depending on the square footage, the number of fire exits, their location and their width.
This seems fairly generous until you compare it with cities like San Francisco and Atlanta, where the limit is 15 square feet per person, or even Philadelphia, where it's 13 square feet per person. Bar areas are much tighter. In Philadelphia, a bar must allow 9 square feet per person; in Atlanta, it's 7. In New York, the space is measured by counter length: 18 inches of it per person.
"We do a lot of restaurants out of state," said Warren Ashworth, a partner in Bogdanow Partners Architects, a Manhattan design firm, "and I never see a place that's packed the way some places are here."
Cramped restaurants have long been a signature of New York dining. The "21" Club, which opened in 1929, has always had its back wall of banquettes. Lining walls with banquettes increases the number of tables that can fit in a room. What's remarkable about the tables at "21", though, is how closely they are arranged. In order for diners against the wall to get up from the table, a waiter must come by and pull the table out into the room. Now, it seems every bistro in town has the same plan.
"New Yorkers are much more sophisticated, much more tolerant, and docile actually," said Jeffrey Beers, a Manhattan architect who designed China Grill and Calle Ocho. "They don't mind being bumped around a little bit; in fact, they enjoy it." That jab to the back of the head when you're taking a bite of your crab cakes might even be a sign of warmth.
David Rockwell, a partner in the Rockwell Group, whose designs include Nobu, the Monkey Bar and Vong, said: "There's a reason you're not eating at home, where you have all the privacy you need. You're eating out as much for the social experience as for a dining experience."
But New York diners are also sensitive and, as Mr. Rockwell added, designers are constantly struggling to find that elusive place between "sardines and Siberia."
Restaurateurs spend a lot of time searching for it, too. In the process, walkways get narrower, corners are maximized, and breathing room is kept at a premium.
A dining room laid out too generously can feel dead. If the tables are six or seven feet apart, Mr. Beers said, "It's difficult to get a buzz going. It yields a quiet sit-up-straight kind of restaurant."
Energy in a restaurant has become a kind of commodity. Many New York designers working in other cities have been asked to come up with a "New York feel."
"They associate that with a slightly tighter table spacing than you might get if you were following an industry standard," said Paul Bentel, a partner at Bentel & Bentel Architects/Planners in Locust Valley, N.Y. By industry standards, Mr. Bentel said, tables for four may be spaced five or six feet apart. In New York, he would reduce that to as little as 24 inches, "to get the kind of energy they associate with a New York restaurant."
Surprisingly, though, these same designers are not trying to crunch space down to the limit of 12 square feet per person. If a room is too tight, people will feel uncomfortable and won't want to come back, Mr. Rockwell said.
The Rockwell Group and Bogdanow Partners both said their restaurants average 16 to 18 square feet per person. The industry standard, Mr. Bentel said, is 20 to 22 square feet per person.
The bar area is more of a wild card -- and a tighter squeeze. The trouble with many new designs is the mingling of bar areas with eating areas. Often, they collide.
New York City building codes dictate that smoking areas at the bar can be just six feet from dining tables. Which is why in many restaurants, like Bottino and Babbo, you often feel as if you are eating in the bar and getting bumped by all the traffic flowing through it.
"In New York, you would have to say it's unavoidable in some cases," Mr. Ashworth said. But design can play a part. At Verbena, the bar has just five seats and is set into a dark area with a low ceiling. It sends out a clear message that it is just for waiting for your table, not for lingering.
Glenn Forley, a partner in Fizer Forley, which designed the restaurant, said: "A bar any larger would have probably affected the restaurant dining experience, because you would have had more of an overlap. Now, the bar is pretty much separate from the tables." The same is accomplished at Eleven Madison Park, where the bar is set off to the side in a small dim room with low ceilings.
To avoid crowds forming in more open restaurants, designers have taken to adding communal tables in the bar area, which break up crowds and form boundaries. "By definition," Mr. Rockwell said, "it doesn't allow the bar to become too much of a bar."
The new Rosa Mexicano immediately attracted a big bar crowd, making it impossible to navigate at times. Mr. Rockwell, whose company designed the restaurant, has recently added bar-height tables. "It felt just too open," Mr. Rockwell said. "And there's a lot of people, and making them a little more comfortable made sense."
It is the long and narrow restaurants with bars up front that have the most difficulty with traffic jams. At Town, a restaurant under construction in Midtown, the bar itself and the equipment behind it are very shallow. A small lounge is positioned at the end of the bar, so people will be drawn through the area rather than encouraged to linger in it. Other designers add features like a carpet or a rail to signal which areas are for circulation.
But there is only so much that can be done by a designer. The rest is up to the management to control. And if crowds get out of control, as they do in many restaurant bars, it's the neighbors who step in. New York City's Buildings Department does not have a task force out enforcing occupancy compliance. Most complaints are filed by residents to the Fire Department.
The New York Fire Department will send an officer to take a head count at the restaurant, said Brian Dixon, a department spokesman. (For occupancies over 75 or restaurants with more than 750 square feet, a sign must be posted and there is an annual inspection, including a review of the seating plan.) If the occupancy limit is exceeded, diners will be asked to leave until it is met. The restaurant can be fined a maximum of $2,500. The unlucky, randomly chosen diners go home hungry.
But in New York, where crowds are more or less praised, this series of events is rare. So rare that when the Fire Department was asked, it couldn't dig up a single case.

HEADLINE: Dispute Arises On Iraqi Debt For Oil Losses By Kuwaitis

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 22

 BODY:
A dispute pitting the United States against Russia and France over Iraqi reparations to a Kuwaiti oil company has for the first time stymied the work of a United Nations compensation commission set up after the 1991 Persian Gulf war.
At stake is a large claim of $21.6 billion submitted by the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation for lost oil and gas sales resulting from Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990, during which oil wells were destroyed or damaged. 
 The compensation commission, based in Geneva, proposed in June that the Kuwait company be awarded $15.9 billion. Russia and France objected, and no award was made.
Diplomats say the United States is lobbying to line up support for Kuwait before a vote on the issue that may be held at the commission's next meeting, late next month.
Until now, all decisions by the commission have made been by consensus on the advice of experts. The 15-member panel, made up of representatives from Security Council countries, is expected to award claims as income from Iraqi oil sales becomes available.
The disagreement adds another irritant to an already frayed Security Council consensus on how to deal with the government of President Saddam Hussein as economic sanctions imposed on Iraq after its invasion of Kuwait a decade ago drag on.
As a critical moment approaches in the efforts of the United Nations to return arms inspectors to Iraq -- a key to lifting the embargo -- the new dispute over war reparations reopens another divisive debate in a second important area, the oil-for-food program.
The program is an exception to the embargo under which Iraq is permitted to sell oil abroad to pay for the imports of essential civilian goods.
Mr. Hussein, now earning billions in oil sales thanks to the lifting of all restrictions on oil exports last year just as prices were rising, has always objected to the requirement that a third of his oil income should go to compensate the many victims of his invasion and occupation of Kuwait.
Money from the oil sales is also set aside for the Kurdish regions of northern Iraq and to help pay for the arms inspection program.
The Iraqis rejected the oil sales program entirely until 1995, because of the controls on how Iraq could spend the money. In the first few years of the program, with oil prices low and limits on how much oil Iraq could sell, the issue merely simmered. Iraq continued to demand that sanctions be lifted to relieve the hardships of people living under the embargo, but was never able to challenge the reparations plan successfully.
Now the sums being set aside for compensation are rising into the tens of billions and Iraq -- with the backing of Russia and France, both of which are owed money by Iraq and hope for more business in the future -- has become more active in opposing the payments.
In recent years the Iraq compensation commission has paid more than $8 billion in claims, mostly to individuals and small businesses or other institutions hurt by the Iraqi invasion.
But the commission has now begun to process claims from petroleum companies, and the amounts being sought are significant. Last year the Kuwait Oil Company and the Kuwait Petroleum Corporation were jointly awarded $2.3 billion for the loss of equipment and other measurable assets.
This year's much larger Kuwaiti request for the loss of less tangible things like thwarted sales ran into technical objections from France, which requested a delay to have its own experts review the claim.
United Nations officials and diplomats said that the Russian objection was more political and that it raised the larger issue of the future of the claims process.
According to unofficial notes from the June meeting, provided by panel officials, the Russians said it would be unacceptable to give that much money to the Kuwaiti oil industry, whether or not the claim was sound, while Iraqis were suffering from a trade embargo.
The Russians then said that they would like a review of the level of Iraq's contribution to the compensation fund from its oil revenues. The money now goes into an escrow account in Paris managed by the United Nations, and any change in its allocation would have to be made by the Security Council.
Diplomats said they expected Russia to raise the issue next month, when all aspects of policy toward Iraq will be open for debate.

HEADLINE: Text of Fed's Statement

 BODY:
Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to leave short-term interest rates unchanged:
The Federal Open Market Committee at its meeting today decided to maintain the existing stance of monetary policy, keeping its target for the federal funds rate at 6 1/2 percent. 
 Recent data have indicated that the expansion of aggregate demand is moderating toward a pace closer to the rate of growth of the economy's potential to produce. The data also have indicated that more rapid advances in productivity have been raising that potential growth rate as well as containing costs and holding down underlying price pressures.
Nonetheless, the committee remains concerned about the risk of a continuing gap between the growth of demand and potential supply at a time when the utilization of the pool of available workers remains at an unusually high level.
Against the background of its long-term goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the committee believes the risks continue to be weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Financial Issues Jump, but Others Are Mostly Lackluster

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stock prices were mixed yesterday after the Federal Reserve left short-term interest rates unchanged.
The Fed's decision to keep the federal funds rate on overnight loans between banks at 6.5 percent had been widely expected. Still, stocks of financial services companies, which stand to benefit if interest rates stabilize or start to fall, were the standout performers.
"This is what the market wanted to see," said Jonathan Olesky, head of block trading at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The view is that we are now in a friendlier rate environment."
Indeed, after reading the central bank's so-called policy directive, analysts said that the Fed was not likely to prove threatening to stock investors, at least for the next few months.
"Given what we know today, the consensus view is that the Fed has finished raising interest rates for the year," said Edward Yardeni, chief global economist and investment strategist at Deutsche Bank Securities.
Led by J. P. Morgan, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 59.34 points, or 0.5 percent, to 11,139.15. The Nasdaq composite index gained 5.06, or 0.1 percent, to 3,958.21. But the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 1.35, or 0.1 percent, to 1,498.13.
Before the Fed made its midafternoon announcement, major market gauges were all solidly higher. But selling set in after the news was reported.
"We had the potential for a pullback no matter what the Fed did because the market has had a good month," said William Meehan, chief market analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald. "It is too early to say the Fed is done for the year, but unless we get really bad inflation numbers, I suspect the Fed will be on hold until after the election."
Financial service stocks, especially banks, did well.
J. P. Morgan rose $3.56, to $148.50. Chase Manhattan gained $1.56, to $52.50, while Citigroup advanced 69 cents, to $77.31, and Wells Fargo rose $1.19, to $45.56.
Technology stocks were mixed.
Nortel Networks, a component of the S.& P. 500, gained $2.13, to $83. Intel managed its eighth consecutive gain, rising 6 cents, to $72.13. And Microsoft rose 63 cents, to $71.25.
Cisco Systems fell 69 cents, to $64.81, however. Qualcomm shed $2.38, to $56.63, and Dell Computer dropped $1.31, to $37.44.
AMR, the parent of American Airlines, gained $1.19, to $33.81, after Goldman, Sachs lifted its third-quarter profit estimate.
But forest products companies fell after Morgan Stanley Dean Witter lowered profit estimates for this year and for 2001.
International Paper fell 44 cents, to $32.31. Weyerhaeuser dropped $1.31, to $46.88, and Temple Inland fell $1.25, to $43.69.
Medtronic had a bad day, falling $3.13, to $49.69, after the world's largest pacemaker manufacturer reported quarterly sales that fell short of expectations.
But most biotechnology stocks moved higher.
Amgen closed at $69.06, up $1.81. Genentech gained $6, to $171. Chiron rose $1.63, to $50.13. And Millennium Pharmaceuticals closed at $115.14, up $3.20.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Mixed
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices were mixed yesterday after Federal Reserve policy makers left interest rates unchanged and warned about the risks of faster inflation.
Treasuries did not get a lasting bounce because "the Fed hasn't uncovered its next move," said William Fitzgerald of Nuveen Investments in Chicago. Still, investors may buy on the notion that the Fed is near the end of its cycle of rate increases, even if it is not finished, he said.
"Many investors believe the Fed usually raises rates one time too many," he said.
The 10-year note rose 1/32, to 99 27/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.77 percent from 5.78 percent. The 30-year bond slipped 2/32, to 107 22/32. Its yield was unchanged at 5.71 percent.

HEADLINE: Fire Forces Limits in Access to Montana Counties

BYLINE: By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: DENVER, Aug. 22

 BODY:
With some of the summer's worst wildfires burning vast stretches of Montana, Gov. Marc Racicot is preparing to restrict access to at least 16 counties in the western part of the state, a decision that would put some of Montana's most popular recreation areas off limits until the fires are brought under control.
"It is an extremely serious situation for us to be addressing it in these terms," Mr. Racicot said today in an interview, referring to an announcement he expected to make on Wednesday. "It's so incredibly difficult for people who rely, in so many ways, on this area for recreation and their livelihood." 
 Montana is one of several Western states in which officials have taken unusual precautionary measures because of wildfires that have now consumed 4.1 million acres in 11 Western states, and some 5.7 million acres in the entire country.
Gov. Jim Geringer of Wyoming last week declared the state of Wyoming a disaster area because of wildfires and drought. On Monday, the Forest Service closed the Selway-Bitterroot Wilderness Area, a part of Clearwater National Forest in north central Idaho, and the Bridger-Teton National Forest in Wyoming.
The expected decision by Mr. Racicot could include as many as 19 counties, which would effectively reduce access to the entire western third of the Montana to all but those who live and work in areas that fire officials have determined are not in any immediate danger. It would also bring to 28 the number of counties he has restricted access to this month, after an order two weeks ago to shut off all or part of 9 counties in central Montana. The Bureau of Land Management has already closed federal land it controls in those counties.
The restrictions are intended to minimize the risk of injury by wildfires that have been spreading rapidly by persistently dry weather conditions and, for the most part, temperatures in the upper 80's and low 90's. Mr. Racicot's orders have and are expected to have exceptions for some recreational areas. And several major national parks, like Yellowstone and Glacier, remain open.
But limiting movement in areas like the Lolo National Forest and the Bitterroot National Forest, is one of several unusual elements that reflect the seriousness of wildfires that are making this one of the worst years in decades for the number of fires in the West -- 20,364 by this morning, with 79 large fires still burning across almost 1.4 million acres in nine Western states.
Resources have been so strained that for the first time, fire management teams from other countries are assisting. Two supervisory teams from Canada are at work, and a team from Australia is expected.
"That's unprecedented," said J. D. Coleman, a spokesman for the Northern Rockies Coordinating Center in Missoula, Mont. "Never have we been stretched so thin that we've had to bring in fire management teams from other countries."
Howard Parman, a spokesman for the National Interagency Fire Center in Boise, Idaho, said the firefighting force included 20,000 to 25,000 people, with about 1,200 more soldiers expected to arrive later this week to join about 2,000 others.
But the fighting force is made up of more than veterans of past fires and even scores of retired firefighters who have joined the efforts. Officials at the fire center estimate that as many as 9,000 college students may be on the lines, many of whom will have to leave in the weeks ahead to return to classes. And in Wyoming, 42 prison inmates are working alongside professional firefighters as part of a program that has been in effect since the 1960's.
"These are inmates who are about to be released or who have earned the right to less security and are not a threat to society," said Melinda Brazzale, a spokeswoman for the Wyoming Department of Corrections. "They are professionally trained by another firefighter and go out and fight fires all over Wyoming and in South Dakota."
Ms. Brazzale said the program had proved beneficial to the inmates and the state, which had saved more than $125,000 this year by using them.
"That's a savings to federal and local agencies," she said. "It's also a real benefit to the inmates to learn a saleable skill."
In addition to personnel needs, firefighting efforts this year have been compounded by the growing number of private homes that have been built inside forest areas, a trend that Governor Racicot and other officials said reflects the nation's vibrant economy. Many of the houses are owned by retirees; others are second homes.
"They have completely changed how we go about fighting fires," Mr. Coleman said. "So many people have come out West to burrow into woods, draws and creek beds. They like being a modern-day pioneer. But now we have to protect their homes, and with the volume of fires and their complexity, it makes for such an unpredictable situation."

HEADLINE: Havel Urges Multinationals to Heed the 'Voices of the People'

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: PRAGUE, Aug. 22

 BODY:
President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic, the host of the annual meeting of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund here next month, said today that international development organizations "should listen more to the voices of the people" for whom they fashion programs, showing more respect for local cultural traditions.
Issues of poverty and housing "must be solved taking into account the human dimension, and not just the interests of investors," Mr. Havel said in an interview with a small group of reporters. 
 The United Nations, too, he said, "should do everything to make people see it as their own organization, representing everyone, not as some sort of club of governments and diplomats."
Mr. Havel will travel to the United States to attend the millennial summit meeting of the United Nations early next month. As an institution, he said, "it should have more power and a smaller bureaucracy." Then he laughed. "Anyone with experience of power knows one of Parkinson's famous laws," he added, "and when two people on my staff say they need a third, soon there's a fourth and a fifth."
The fund and bank meetings here, from Sept. 19 to Sept. 28, have become a target for groups opposed to globalization and multinational capital. Mr. Havel said he welcomes the debate, but hopes it can be a philosophical and substantive one, without violence in the streets.
Globalization by itself is "morally neutral," Mr. Havel said. "It can be good or bad, depending on the kind of content we give to it." He cited the spread of information about human rights as a good use of globalization. As a negative, he cited "the spread of silly sitcoms or even more stupid commercials," which give a false picture of human life.
"These commercials say a lot," he said. "A handsome man with a great tan and strong muscles is running on a beautiful beach with blue sky in the background. A beautiful girl is running toward him and they are happy because they just ate some vitamin or drank some beverage. The stupidity of this world, which is offered to us as human happiness, should be analyzed."
Casually dressed in tan jeans and an open shirt, Mr. Havel, 63, looked fit after a vacation in Portugal, where he bought a summer residence to spend time after he leaves office in 2003. An hour before the interview, sirens went off throughout Prague in memory of the 72 people who died when the Soviet Union invaded Czechoslovakia 32 years ago on Monday.
Mr. Havel urged the news media to pay more attention to the substance of the debate than to security aspects , and he urged his countrymen to have a more worldly vision.
"It is a great privilege for this country to have the meeting here," he said.
People "often forget what it looked like here before the fall of Communism," he said. "How gray life was, how gray streets were, how the sign for a fruit shop was the same all over the country." But now, "every little shop has a different facade, and we are renewing a lot of local tradition." That, he said, was also a kind of answer to globalization and to "this unifying pressure of the dictatorship of consumption and commercials and those supermarkets that are destroying the city suburbs."
Today, Mr. Havel addressed a local controversy that has had international attention. Last month, Pavel Dostal, the Czech culture minister, wrote an article that appeared to ridicule the concerns of Orthodox Jews over a 13th-century Jewish cemetery discovered in downtown Prague during excavations to rebuild an insurance company.
The government worked out a plan with local Jewish leaders to encase the remnants of the cemetery in concrete, while allowing the company to build both below and above it. But the plan has been criticized.
"I do not know why the Prague Jews imagine dance or theater must be specifically excluded above the skeletal remains that their ancestors sold," Mr. Dostal's article said. "But even if so, it is strange that it did not bother the Prague Jewish community for 522 years that such things happened above the destroyed cemetery -- not until now. It's like the doctor showing up after the funeral, after the funeral more than half a millennium ago."
Today, Mr. Havel said: "Of course I cannot bear responsibility for all the clever or pseudo-clever comments of any of the individual ministers. The important thing for me is that this government has the will to seek a solution."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: When Funds Abroad Fill a Void at Home;
Financing Latin America's Start-Ups

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

 BODY:
StarMedia, one of the biggest and most successful Internet companies in Latin America, has branch offices in seven countries and millions of subscribers throughout the region. But its headquarters are in New York. Its $450 million in financing came from investors in the United States. Its stock is listed on the Nasdaq but not on any exchange in Latin America.
El Sitio, another Internet service provider with millions of Spanish- and Portugese-speaking users in Latin America, also raised money by selling shares on the Nasdaq. But El Sitio is not traded on any stock exchange in the region where it does most of its business. 
 And when Yupi Internet Inc. raised start-up money, it too bypassed local financial markets in the Latin American countries it serves, seeking investors in the United States instead. Yupi's plans for further expansion through a stock offering were postponed in April when the Nasdaq nose dived, but the company intends to sell shares to the public only in the United States, not Latin America.
The Internet revolution has definitely come to Latin America. But whether the businesses and jobs created by that revolution have helped the region begin to wean itself from economic dependence on the United States and other outsiders is considered a matter of debate.
"This keeps us more dependent on outsiders all the time, but the fault is ours," said Paul Singer, a professor of macroeconomics at the University of Sao Paulo. "It is a deficiency which should be resolved."
Companies like StarMedia and El Sitio contend that they are not only truly Latin American but also helping create a pan-Latin market because Latin America's 500 million people are their main audience. These companies also say they would not even exist if they had sought to raise start-up money in the countries where their customers live and work.
But critics contend that these companies have unwittingly helped create a kind of cybercolonialism in which the major architects of the region's Internet access are foreigners, backed by foreign funds, with offices in foreign lands, just like in the old days.
There is widespread agreement that the remote-control companies and off-shore financing that made them possible underscore the persistent weakness of Latin America's financial world.
"Yes, we do have a dependency on the more sophisticated foreign equity markets," said Jorge Errazuriz a partner in Celfin, one of Chile's largest investment banks, and a member of the board of the Santiago Stock Exchange. This "inferior position," he said, means that "the real initial impulse for developing fiber optics, telecommunications and the Internet will have to come from the equity markets up north."
It is not just start-up companies that are diverting strength from the domestic stock exchanges and extending dependency. When an aggressive international corporation like Telefonica of Spain purchases phone systems in Argentina, Brazil and Peru, it deprives local exchanges of some of their biggest companies. After such acquisitions, the local companies are removed from the domestic stock exchanges, while Telefonica stock is listed only in Spain and the United States.
The Latin American exchanges have been hit hard. Over the last decade, for example, the number of listed domestic companies on Brazil's main exchange dropped about 18 percent, from 581 to 478. In Argentina the decline was even steeper, nearly 30 percent, with local companies on the exchange dipping to 129 from 179.
"It's very troubling to see these markets, which are already weak, get weakened further," said Roger S. Leeds, director of the Center for International Business and Public Policy at the Paul H. Nitzke Center for International Studies at Johns Hopkins University. "And I don't think that's at all healthy for the development of the private sector."
From Mexico to Argentina, political leaders in the new Latin America have promised to improve the standards of living in their countries by unleashing private enterprise and completely engaging in the global economy. But while the biggest Latin companies already have access to the money they need to expand on either the local or international markets, small and start-up companies, which generate most new jobs, often face an impossible dream.
Even when local money is available, taking a company public on a Latin American exchange can be more trouble than it is worth. Most local exchanges lack the pool of capital and investors willing to take the kind of risks a big regional Internet company needs to start up. Besides, some require years of operating experience before a company's stock can be publicly traded, and in some instances they must show real profits, which few Internet start-ups are able to do.
Latin America's economic development has always depended heavily on outsiders. Big corporations -- many of them from the United States -- set up branch plants in Central and South America that provided jobs and some growth. But they did little to develop a financial and economic self-sufficiency.
The newest Latin American companies operate, in effect, the same way, critics like Professor Leeds contend. "There are benefits to the local economy in terms of jobs and investment," he said. "But the benefits to the local financial sector are zero."
Coming to the United States to raise money is not unique to Latin America, not even for Internet companies. Jesse E. Reyes, vice president for global product management for Venture Economics, a private equity research firm, said that Israeli and French Internet and software companies had raised generous amounts of capital on Wall Street lately.
The difference, he said, is that they enter the United States market not just to raise money but to sell their products and services here. Their growth then translates into profit that is repatriated and re-invested in their home countries.
The Latin companies that raise money here, by contrast, are not doing that.
"If you look at it from the Latin American businessman's point of view, if they can take American money and get in on the ground floor of a terrific opportunity, then so what does it matter?" Mr. Reyes said. "But the sociologists might say, 'Isn't this just another example of American colonialism?' "
The companies that have successfully crossed borders to raise funds certainly do not see it that way.
"What our inability to raise capital in Latin America says is that you cannot shift 500 years of monopoly control and monopoly orientation all at one time," said Fernando Espuelas, chairman of StarMedia. "Until very recently, if you wanted to finance a company in Latin America you got a bank loan, at 30 percent interest, and for a very short term. Obviously you'd never be able to finance an Internet company that way."
Born in Uruguay and raised in Connecticut, Mr. Espuelas realized early on that Latin American investors, especially wary of risk, would not support his dream of creating a regional Internet company.
Basing his company in New York reinforced its identity as truly regional, Mr. Espuelas said, and giving it an English name helped win over American investors. He knocked on the doors of nearly 50 American venture capitalists. Even hearing a sophisticated New York financier refer to Latin America as "that blob there below the Rio Grande" did not dissuade him.
With flawless English and a cool confidence, he won over big backers, including Chase Capital Partners, and raised nearly $100 million in private capital.
Then in May 1999, StarMedia issued its initial public offering on the Nasdaq, raising $110 million. A subsequent offering in October raised another $200 million. StarMedia stock, which first sold for $15, escalated to more than $60 at its peak.
The American investors who bought in early and sold at the peak enjoyed the kinds of gains that would have gone to Latin investors had it been possible for StarMedia to go public in Latin America.
Mr. Espuelas said he was aware of the drawbacks but felt that the region could eventually overcome the cycle of dependency.
"I'm already reinvesting money into companies in Latin America," he said, though he declined to name his investments. "Our success is demonstrative of what can happen but also of the challenges and the road that remains to be travelled."
While small local companies will continue to struggle, StarMedia's early success set loose a herd of regional Latin companies that beat a similar path to the doors of American venture capitalists
El Sitio, based in Buenos Aires, raised $130 million in its public offering in December. Impsat Fiber Networks, an Argentine telecommunications company in Wilton Manors, Fla., went public on the Nasdaq with a $195 million offering in February.
Guillermo Jofre, chief financial officer of Impsat, said the lack of adequate financing was one of the most severe limitations Latin America faced. "Right now there's simply no significant amount of local financing available in Latin America," Mr. Jofre said. "And this presents a big handicap when compared to most other countries."
But the global marketplace for capital has its drawbacks, too. Yupi Internet, a Latin American Internet service company based in Miami, planned to go public in the United States last spring. Then the Nasdaq crashed.
"We filed our initial public offering in January and we were completing our road show on April 14, the day of the debacle," said Oscar Coen, president of Yupi. That day the Nasdaq lost 355 points, its worst session ever to end its worst week ever. Yupi may have been in some trouble anyway because it was comparatively late to a market already served by StarMedia, El Sitio and others. But when the Nasdaq went into a tailspin, the company's executives and backers changed plans.
"We realized that it was in the best interest of the company to postpone the I.P.O. until there was a more favorable environment," Mr. Coen said.
Like many other companies, both American and foreign, Yupi's I.P.O. remains postponed. The delay has meant that Yupi has not expanded as rapidly as originally planned, Mr. Coen said. Yupi will not open shop in Paraguay or Uruguay, while Chile, he said, "is borderline." Yupi has also pared its advertising budget.
America Online Latin America, a spinoff of the original America Online, is also finding it tough to raise money in the United States. The Latin venture between AOL and the Cisneros Group of Venezuela originally filed its initial public offering in January but had to wait until earlier this month to move ahead. The 25 million shares were sold at $8 each and raised $200 million for the company, which is based in Ft. Lauderdale, Fla.
Still, a long line of Latin American start-ups is waiting to make the trip to the United States. "That is clearly the final objective for most of us," said Marcos E. Galperin, president of Mercado Libre, an Internet auction site in Latin America. He started his company less than a year ago, with American backing. One of his earliest investors was an American financier who addressed Mr. Galperin's M.B.A. class at Stanford University.
"From day minus one on this project I knew we wanted to get funding in the U.S.," Mr. Galperin said. "For us, it's a big stamp of approval."

HEADLINE: Explorer Tires Had to Carry A Heavy Load

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 22

 BODY:
The Firestone tires that have been failing on Ford Explorers have fairly low weight-carrying capability for a vehicle of the Explorer's size, particularly at the low inflation pressure recommended by Ford Motor, publicly available technical specifications for the tires and the Explorers show.
Officials at Bridgestone/Firestone have said several times over the last two weeks that the recalled 15-inch tires are losing their treads at high speeds partly because drivers are overloading their vehicles. But this can be easy to do in an Explorer: its recommended maximum payload for passengers and cargo is 750 to 1,310 pounds, depending on the model. Four people, plus luggage, can exceed the lower end of that range, particularly if they use the roof rack and the rear cargo area. 
 The Explorer is at least as heavy as any of its main rivals in the midsize sport utility market, and has been several hundred pounds heavier in some model years, notably 1996, the vintage that has produced the most crash claims. Yet Ford's rivals typically use either larger tires or recommend higher tire pressures.
Increasing a tire's size or its pressure allows it to carry more weight safely, provided that the maximum pressure recommended by the tire maker is not exceeded.
The Chevrolet Blazer, for example, uses the same size tires as the Explorer. But General Motors recommends that the tires on all its midsize sport utilities be inflated to 35 pounds per square inch, compared with just 26 for the Explorer.
As a result, the combined weight-carrying ability of the Blazer tires is 1,100 pounds greater than the Explorer tires. The recommended maximum payload for a Blazer is 930 to 1,330 pounds, which four adults and their luggage are less likely to exceed.
The Honda Passport, Nissan Pathfinder and Mitsubishi Montero Sport have the same recommended tire pressure as the Explorer. But the Passport and the Pathfinder use larger tires, with 16-inch diameters, allowing them to carry more weight. The Montero Sport has 15-inch tires that are slightly smaller than those of the Explorer, because they are slightly narrower, but Mitsubishi recommends that customers raise the rear tires' pressure before carrying heavy loads -- a recommendation that Ford has not made for the Explorer.
Ford has chosen larger tires with higher pressures for its next generation of Explorers, which will go on sale in January. The new tires, chosen several years ago, will be able to carry considerably more weight than the current ones, and will give the new Explorer a recommended payload of 1,100 to 1,500 pounds.
Ford officials defend their choice of the recalled tires, saying they meet tire industry guidelines for carrying weight. Ford also questions Bridgestone/Firestone's assertion that overloading has contributed to tire failures in the United States, although the automaker acknowledges that tires did fail on Explorers overseas that became overloaded when owners installed third rows of seats and used the vehicles as shuttle buses.
Ford also contends that with the Explorer or any other truck, it is the responsibility of owners to check weight labels posted on the inside of the doors and then limit the weight put inside, with particular attention to not putting too much weight at the back of the vehicle. "It provides you on the label the gross vehicle weight rating -- you can't load it so that you exceed 3,000 pounds on the rear axle either," said Lee Carr, a vehicle dynamics engineering consultant on the Explorer and former Ford engineer to whom Ford referred questions on the Explorer tires.
But safety experts have long questioned how many sport utility customers think of their vehicles as trucks, much less check the weight ratings on the label. Mr. Carr acknowledged that people who switched to Explorers from cars might not be accustomed to checking weight ratings.
Jon Harmon, a Ford spokesman, said the best evidence for the adequacy of the current tire size and pressure lay in the performance of Goodyear tires that were installed on nearly half the Explorers built in the 1995, 1996 and 1997 model years. Goodyear has not had any reports of problems with these tires, said Bill Hopkins, Goodyear's vice president for global product marketing and technical planning. Mr. Harmon said Ford had received just one report of a tread separation involving a Goodyear tire on an Explorer, but the incident did not result in any injuries.
Ford officials have been consistent in pointing to quality problems in the Firestone tires, while contending that their design decisions did not cause the failures. Reluctant to antagonize their biggest customer, Firestone officials have said little to question this.
But John Lampe, an executive vice president of Bridgestone/Firestone, said this evening that concerns about the tires' ability to carry the Explorer's weight safely had been one reason for the tire maker's recommendation two weeks ago that Explorer owners begin inflating their tires to 30 pounds per square inch. Ford has since said that a range of 26 to 30 pounds is acceptable.
Ford's decision on Monday to temporarily close two Ranger pickup factories and an Explorer factory, to make more replacement tires available for Explorers, reflected the fact that the Ranger and the Explorer still use the same tires.
The Explorer was introduced as a variation of the Ranger in late 1990, and was an immediate best seller. Over the years, the Explorer has grown bigger and heavier, because many people choose practically every option, including four-wheel drive even if they plan no off-road driving. Yet most Explorers still share the tires of a small pickup that weighs half a ton less.
A decade ago, Ford executives expected only a few customers to choose four-wheel drive, and were taken by surprise that most drivers want the option, which adds 220 pounds to the vehicle's weight. Ford makes the key components for the four-wheel-drive systems at a factory in Bordeaux, France, that has been so backlogged that the automaker has maintained a charter fleet of jets for years just to ferry them to its Explorer assembly plants in Louisville, Ky., and St. Louis.
"It's a nice problem to have," said Steve Von Foerster, the chief program engineer for the Explorer. "People want it so bad that you have to rent your own fleet of 747's." With a profitable model, airlifting heavy auto parts is cheaper than shutting down the assembly plant, but an automaker does it only as a last resort, after greatly underestimating demand for an option.
Vehicles need tires that can support considerably more than their own weight plus the payload because they lean on the tires on one side when going around curves, and because the weight of cargo and passengers is seldom evenly distributed.
A typical Ford Explorer weighs 4,000 to 4,400 pounds. Four 15-inch tires of the type and inflation pressure now being recalled can support a total of 7,012 pounds at a pressure of 26 pounds per square inch, according to the tire industry's Tire and Rim Association guidelines. At a pressure of 30 pounds per square inch, which Firestone now recommends, the tires can support a total of 7,525 pounds.
By contrast, the similarly sized Chevrolet Blazer weighs roughly 4,000 pounds or a little less. It has the same size tires but, because of a higher inflation pressure, the tires can support a total of 8,112 pounds.

HEADLINE: Invoking Suffragists, Mrs. Clinton Courts Women Upstate

BYLINE: By WINNIE HU 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Invoking the legacy of the suffragists at every turn, Hillary Rodham Clinton sought today to portray herself as a champion of women and working families and to bolster her support in this city, where Susan B. Anthony once fought for the right to vote.
Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic Senate candidate, toured Anthony's red-brick home, boasted of her own efforts to promote women's issues like breast cancer and child care, and even appeared with Ruth Dyk, 99, who once marched alongside the suffragists and likened Mrs. Clinton to them. "If I've learned one thing, it's this: New York needs a woman's touch," Ms. Dyk said while endorsing Mrs. Clinton. 
 In her latest campaign swing through Monroe County, a key electoral county, Mrs. Clinton seemed determined to show women that she was their candidate. At a meeting with union members, she said she was a working mother like many of those in the room. "I know what it's like when you have to worry about whether or not you're going to make it to that school play because you're in one of those interminable meetings," she said to laughter and clapping.
Some polls have shown Mrs. Clinton in trouble with various pockets of women who vote, particularly white women, and she has sought out issues to shore up support. At the same time, her Republican opponent, Representative Rick A. Lazio, has aggressively pursued these same groups of voters. Just last week, for example, he visited the Women's Rights National Historic Park in Seneca Falls, the birthplace of the women's suffrage movement.
Although she never mentioned Mr. Lazio by name, Mrs. Clinton today repeatedly tried to distinguish herself by stressing her plan for economic development in upstate New York and her support of issues traditionally important to women, like education and health care. She also advocated a woman's right to abortion, and further pledged that she would never vote to confirm a judge who would try to make abortion illegal. "I want you to know my opponent does not have the same view of reality, the same vision of the future, the same positions on the issues," she said.
Mr. Lazio also supports the right to an abortion but is opposed to a form of late-term abortion and is against public financing for abortions.
Despite Mrs. Clinton's efforts to focus on substantive issues, several women continued to bring up personal details about President Clinton's extramarital affair in the White House that led to his impeachment.
Linda Lowenstein, a registered nurse, said that she intended to vote for Mrs. Clinton but that many of the women who are her friends would not. "I think the issue is the problems with Bill," she said. "I think, unfortunately, some women can't forgive her for not leaving him."
Nora Bredes, director of the Susan B. Anthony Center for Women's Leadership at the University of Rochester, said that Mrs. Clinton's candidacy might make some women uncomfortable because it reflects their own struggles to be both leaders and nurturers in a modern world.
And while Mrs. Clinton was surrounded by a number of women today, some of her most effusive supporters were men. Dominic Noto, a retired railroad worker, could not wait to line up at the Marketplace Mall to shake her hand. "She's a strong woman, because she stuck by him," he said. "A lot of people wouldn't have had the courage and the strength. I told her that four years from now, I'll vote for her for the White House."
