HEADLINE: Opposition Precedes Arrival of Teams at New Coney Island Stadium

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The city's new Coney Island stadium for a minor-league Mets franchise will cost up to $8 million more than previous estimates, and the project continues to provoke bitter sniping between its biggest booster, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, and its most vocal opponent, Howard Golden, the Brooklyn borough president.
At a ceremonial groundbreaking yesterday on Surf Avenue, where construction of the 6,500-seat ballpark is well under way in the shadow of Coney Island's storied parachute drop, Mayor Giuliani said the city would spend as much as $39 million on the project -- more than 25 percent above its previous budget of $31 million. 
 Mr. Giuliani defended the additional cost, saying it was necessary to ensure its completion by opening day next June. That deadline, a year earlier than previously set by the city, means the Coney Island stadium, like a counterpart on Staten Island, will be completed before the mayor leaves office at the end of 2001.
The Brooklyn stadium has been a longstanding matter of contention between the mayor and Mr. Golden, who for years strenuously promoted a grander sports and recreation complex for the site. And yesterday's ceremony brought them no closer together. Several top City Hall aides and Guy V. Molinari, the Staten Island borough president, joined Mr. Giuliani at the ceremony, but Mr. Golden was not invited and did not attend.
"It is unfortunate that the city administration continues to implement a sweetheart deal that offers little economic benefit to Brooklyn but is a windfall to professional baseball," Mr. Golden said in a statement released immediately after the event. "Taxpayers deserve more for this huge public investment than an outrageous deal."
The Coney Island and Staten Island minor-league ballparks, which are being paid for with more than $100 million in city money, have been championed by the mayor to foster economic development in the boroughs outside Manhattan. The Staten Island stadium, budgeted at $71 million and under construction along the St. George shoreline, just west of the Staten Island Ferry Terminal, is to be used by a minor-league franchise of the Yankees.
Although the Staten Island project will be the most expensive minor-league ballpark in the country, it has caused little upset, while the battle over the Brooklyn stadium has consumed Mr. Golden for more than a year. He has also maintained that its price is too high and that the caliber of baseball it will bring, with a single-A minor-league franchise, to the home of the Brooklyn Dodgers, is beneath the dignity of the borough.
Asked why Mr. Golden was not invited to the event, Mayor Giuliani angrily replied: "Why wasn't he here? Because he is against this project. I can't imagine why."
Under terms of a 20-year lease agreement between the city and the Mets, the minor-league franchise will pay up to $520,000 a year, based on attendance, for use of the stadium. While the current home of the Mets' minor-league team in Queens sometimes draws fewer than 1,000 fans, the mayor said that he hoped a new stadium would attract larger crowds, and that if the stadium were at least half full for each game next year, he would be satisfied. In addition to lease payments, the city would receive half the advertising revenues that are generated by the franchise.
But the mayor also sought to dismiss the points raised by Mr. Golden and other critics who say that the Coney Island project will provide a windfall for the Mets. He insisted that it would lead to sweeping economic development along the neighborhood's tawdry beachfront and commercial blocks.
"This ballpark will do for Coney Island what Disney did for 42nd Street," he said, referring to the investment by the Walt Disney Company, backed by city tax incentives, in a Times Square theater and store in the early 1990's. He said the city would prompt further Coney Island development by paying for a Little League field close to the new stadium, for repairs on the rusting framework of the parachute drop, and for incentives to lure new stores to the blighted quarter-mile stretch of Surf Avenue between the stadium site and the historic Nathan's hot dog emporium.
But Mr. Giuliani declined to say which of those projects, if any, would be completed before he left office.
In an interview, Michael Carey, the president of the city's Economic Development Corporation, which is in charge of the stadium projects, said that the cost of the Coney Island field had grown because advancing its deadline meant bringing in more workers and materials at a time when both are in short supply.
He said the city and the Mets had agreed to seek a corporate sponsor for the stadium, embracing a model of corporate support established by several professional sports organization around the nation as well as on Staten Island. Although no such sponsor has been found, Mr. Carey said he expected a company to pay for the right to include its name in that of the new Coney Island stadium, and that the arrangement would probably yield as much income as the $400,000 a year that the Richmond County Bank has agreed to pay to have the field in St. George named the Richmond County Bank Ballpark.
Mr. Carey also said that the city and the Mets would select a name for the minor-league team from ideas submitted by the public.
One suggestion was made immediately yesterday at the ceremony by Joan Hodges, the widow of Gil Hodges, the former Brooklyn Dodger first baseman and Mets manager. "I respectfully submit the name of Gil Hodges," said Mrs. Hodges, whose presence was apparently intended by City hall to evoke the splendor of professional baseball in Brooklyn.
Mayor Giuliani, who followed Mrs. Hodges to the microphone, was effusive in his praise of her husband, who died in 1972, but stopped short of seconding her nomination. Without referring to the naming process of Coney Island's new club, he said that Mr. Hodges "truly deserves to be in the Hall of Fame," an honor not yet bestowed.

HEADLINE: Peter Cooper Village Owner Accused of Fraud on Wiring

BYLINE: By TINA KELLEY 

 BODY:
A Manhattan assemblyman accused Metropolitan Life Insurance Company yesterday of seeking to overcharge residents of Peter Cooper Village for $30 million in new wiring, saying the insurer stands to earn huge amounts from telecommunications companies for making the improvements.
The insurance company, which owns the 2,200-unit Peter Cooper Village, on the east side of Manhattan north of 14th Street, has asked the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal for approval for the increased assessments, which, under law, would remain as rent increases after the new electric, cable, phone and Internet wiring is paid for. 
 The increases would amount to $135 a month for a one-bedroom apartment and $170 for a two-bedroom apartment. The average two-bedroom apartment rents for about $1,000, according to a list of rents for one of the buildings in Peter Cooper Village.
The tenants association has protested the increases in a letter to the state housing agency, and, with the assemblyman, Steven Sanders, a resident of Peter Cooper Village, suggests that the insurance company's application is fraudulent because it does not mention the money it may get from companies like RCN and other cable companies.
"The question is, did it really cost them $30 million, or was there an offset from income they incurred from RCN?" said Jack Lester, the lawyer for the tenants association, who said many of the residents were elderly and living on fixed incomes.
"This may be enough to force some of them out," he said.
The apartment complex, built after World War II to house returning veterans, was designed to be affordable for middle-income residents, and in recent years the apartments have been highly sought after as rents increased rapidly elsewhere in Manhattan.
Mr. Sanders said that while tenants were being asked to pay for the wiring improvements, Met Life and RCN have a marketing agreement that provides Met Life with what he believed was "several millions of dollars" for the actual wiring, plus a percentage of every new contract for a subscriber in Peter Cooper Village. The agreement includes a clause preventing the parties from speaking about it, he said.
"We are contending they seriously omitted a significant revenue," Mr. Sanders said of the insurer. "We are suggesting that the actual cost to Met Life is substantially less than what they are purporting it to be, because they have failed to indicate on their application what we believe to be millions of dollars of revenue generated."
Mr. Sanders said that a landlord who is untruthful in an application for a rent increase after completing major capital improvements could lose any chance of being reimbursed for the work and could face major damages.
He learned of the cable installations after a tenant asked him why a box in the front closet had an RCN logo, since the tenant had not subscribed to any RCN services. He said there was no mention of the cable and telecommunications wiring in the insurer's application for the increase.
Jennie Morgan, a spokeswoman for the insurer, declined to answer questions about the proposed increase.
"We are a fair landlord, we play by the rules and we have filed a legitimate application" for an increase based on major capital improvements, she said. "Other than that, there's nothing I can say."
An RCN spokeswoman also did not provide any information on the two companies' arrangement.
Dan Irizarry, deputy press secretary for the state housing agency, would not comment on the specifics of the application.
Many of the tenants at Peter Cooper Village have lived there for decades. "The overwhelming majority didn't want the wiring, and don't want to pay for it," said Al Doyle, president of the tenants association.
"It's very hard on us," said Shirley Ehrlickman, who describes herself as an elderly resident of Peter Cooper Village. She pays $907 a month in rent for a one-bedroom apartment, and expects an increase of $140.
"The rent is going up, the cost of medication is going up, everything in the city is costing more including food, so you can see it's a hardship on the older population," she said. "To be perfectly honest, I've been seeking an apartment with a lower rental, but it's very hard to find a lower rental."

HEADLINE: Effort to Recruit Minorities Falls Short in Trooper Class

BYLINE: By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Despite a well-advertised effort to bring more blacks, women and Latinos into the New Jersey State Police, only 15 of the 105 cadets scheduled to enter the academy next month are black or Latino, and just one is a woman, according to statistics released by the agency today.
Early this year, the agency settled a discrimination suit filed by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People by agreeing to scrap several requirements that many black applicants considered discriminatory. The state also pledged to make aggressive attempts to advertise and recruit in black and Latino neighborhoods. 
 But in releasing the recruitment numbers today, the state police superintendent, Carson J. Dunbar Jr., said he was disappointed that the agency's attempt to diversify its ranks would leave the percentage of minority troopers virtually unchanged, at 14 percent. About 3 percent of the 2,800 current troopers are women, Mr. Dunbar said, so the new class actually represents a decrease in the percentage of women.
Mr. Dunbar said the strong economy was partly to blame for the lackluster results, because many female and minority applicants had found better-paying jobs and decided not to finish the screening process.
He also acknowledged that the agency's reputation remained tarnished in many black and Latino neighborhoods because of the Justice Department's highly publicized investigation into discrimination by troopers and the state's admission that some officers had engaged in racial profiling for years -- problems that preceded his appointment last year.
"I wish I could tell you there's a quick fix for this problem," said Mr. Dunbar, who became a New Jersey trooper himself in 1973 and was the only minority officer in his class. "The real answer is, it's going to be a long process."
He refused to specify what racial breakdown the force ultimately hopes to reach, saying that he did not want to give the mistaken impression that the state police were adopting a quota system. New Jersey's population is about one-third minority, however, and in the settlement with the N.A.A.C.P. the state agreed to try to broaden the demographics of the force.
Some elected officials said they were dismayed that the state had failed to deliver on its promise to increase minority representation on the force.
"The state police have missed a golden opportunity to change its institutional image," said Leroy J. Jones Jr., a Democratic assemblyman from Essex County. "Clearly, they need to reassess their approach and re-examine who they are using as consultants in recruiting more minorities into the ranks."
Some current troopers have also complained that the state lowered its physical fitness requirements for new recruits, in an attempt to help female applicants. During the last two years, the state eliminated its pull-up, broad jump and vertical jump requirements, and applicants who fail the physical test may now take it repeatedly until they pass.
Mr. Dunbar defended the less stringent requirements, saying they still allow the state police to winnow out those applicants who are physically unsuited to perform the job. The state police also worked with several consulting firms to revise the application process and add screening that tests candidates' temperament and decision-making abilities.
"It's not just about strength, it's about what kind of person you are," Mr. Dunbar said.
The state police are scheduled to begin a new recruiting drive next year and will work with the National Organization of Black Law Enforcement Executives and the National Association of Women in Policing to try and expand the pool of female and minority candidates. The state police may place more emphasis on reaching out to women's sports teams, Mr. Dunbar said, and will continue to recruit at schools and community events in minority neighborhoods.
But he said that his own experience in law enforcement recruiting, for both the State Police and the F.B.I., had taught him not to expect quick results.
"It doesn't happen that rapidly," he said. "What I would like to see is steady increases."

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Law Firm Is No Longer Lonely in Refurbished Tower on Times Square

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Five years after moving to Times Square in 1990, the law firm of Proskauer Rose was still the only tenant in the 41-story tower at 1585 Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets. "We had been in two buildings on Park Avenue, and suddenly we found ourselves virtually alone in the wild West," said Alan S. Jaffe, chairman. "It was very, very lonely here."
Lonely, but not uneventful. Soon after moving into 11 floors, the law firm sued the developers and lenders, contending, among other things, that the paving outside the building was unfinished, the facade incomplete and the elevators in need of repair. And when improvements still were not made, the firm withheld its rent for about six months. 
 While all that was going on, the recession hit and the bottom rapidly began falling out of the market for office space in New York; the building at 1585 Broadway alone was losing $1.9 million a month. As a result, in December 1991, the development partnership, 1585 Broadway Associates, controlled by David S. Solomon, filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.
Things settled down after Morgan Stanley, the financial services company (now Morgan Stanley Dean Witter), bought the building at auction for $176 million in August 1993 and moved in two years later.
Ten years still remain on Proskauer's original 20-year lease, and the 125-year-old law firm -- even now the building's only tenant other than Morgan Stanley -- has embarked on a top-to-bottom refurbishing. Three months ago, it remodeled the entire 19th floor, and next month it will begin refurbishing the rest.
The makeover of the 19th floor, which housed the firm's law library, resulted in 7 large conference rooms and 49 offices for lawyers, plus work stations and offices for secretaries, legal assistants and support staff members. All that was accomplished without adding to the 365,000 square feet that the firm already occupied.
It was able to do so by relocating the library to the firm's existing space in the subbasement, space that had been used by accounting department employees, by a messenger department and for record storage. But Proskauer employees do not refer to the underground space as a subbasement, much less a cellar. "We refer to it as a concourse," Mr. Jaffe, the chairman, said, clearly savoring his choice of euphemism.
In fact, this is no ordinary sub- -- whoops, concourse. For starters, it is flooded with light: light from lamps, from recessed ceiling lights, from concealed lights within floor-to-ceiling frosted-glass panels built into the walls, and from light reflected from the polished stainless steel in which the three four-foot-square concrete pillars are sheathed. To add to the brightness, light is reflected from the various woods, including oak and anigre, that were chosen partly for that purpose. The concourse also houses separate men's and women's locker rooms for employees who pull all-nighters or want to freshen up after working out in nearby gyms.
The library has been incorporated into a new high-tech research center, an area that also includes training rooms, conference rooms, the records department and rooms where documents that bear on a particular case can be consolidated for easy access.
The research center has space enough for 34 lawyers at any one time to be able to plug in their personal computers and surf the Internet. In addition, 14 staff members help with research, on the Internet and among the library's estimated 60,000 books, journals and other periodicals. The researchers serve not just Proskauer's 420 lawyers in New York but also the 130 or so in the firm's other offices, in Newark, Washington, Los Angeles, Boca Raton, Fla., and Paris. "This is bigger than some college law libraries," said Kit Hartnett, director of library services within the research center.
The concourse was designed by Gensler, the architectural firm. But Hal Plott, director of administration for Proskauer, said it was the firm's idea to relocate the library underground and to change the overall name to research center. "We wanted a name that better reflected its purposes," he said. The remodeled concourse and the 19th-floor makeover cost a total of $4.5 million.
From his office, Mr. Jaffe said, "We thought when we moved here that the redevelopment of Times Square would take place back then, but the recession interfered." Since then, he added, Times Square has become a corridor for legal, financial and informational services firms. And Proskauer employees no longer feel like pioneer settlers.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
BUSH SAYS GORE ERRED IN CALLING TAX CUT TOO BIG

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: ST. LOUIS, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas aggressively defended his sweeping tax-cut proposal today, saying it was both responsible and easily affordable in light of federal surplus projections. Mr. Bush produced an assortment of figures to show that the plan would not require cuts in government spending.
"I've got to do a better job of making it clear," Mr. Bush told reporters in a surprising admission aboard his campaign plane. 
 The remark came just a day after Vice President Al Gore, suddenly resurgent in the polls, held an extensive discussion of his own suggested tax cuts, which are less than half the size of the ones proposed by Mr. Bush.
Mr. Bush pointed to projections by the Congressional Budget Office that the federal government would run a surplus of about $4.6 trillion over the next 10 years, a figure that includes the Social Security surplus. He said voters needed to know that the projection represented money left over even after an expected growth in government spending of about $3.3 trillion.
He also said that after setting aside the Social Security surplus to shore up that program, he would have roughly $2.3 trillion for tax cuts, new spending and debt reduction. Mr. Bush's proposed tax cut would cost $1.3 trillion over 10 years.
As soon as voters understand that, he said, "People will buy into the tax-relief package even more."
"I'm not changing my opinion on it," he added, a defiant declaration that, like his comments to reporters about the surplus and tax cuts, was largely unprompted. "It's the absolute right thing to do for America."
Mr. Bush's uncharacteristic decision to revisit calculations that his campaign had previously outlined seemed to be an acknowledgment of a potentially troubling political reality for him. Many public opinion polls show that American voters, by and large, are not hankering for an enormous tax cut.
And Mr. Gore, who has proposed only about $500 billion in tax cuts over the next decade, has been hammering the Texas governor on the issue, repeatedly claiming that Mr. Bush's plan unnecessarily coddles wealthy Americans at the expense of fiscal prudence.
Mr. Gore said on Monday that Mr. Bush's tax cut would plunge the country into deficits, and today, in a speech in Milwaukee, the vice president added that it would "wreck our good economy and make it impossible to modernize our armed forces and keep them ready for battle."
The burden on Mr. Bush to convince voters that his tax cut is affordable was clear not only in his remarks today but also in those of Representative Ray LaHood, Republican of Illinois, who talked with reporters after a Bush rally in Peoria, Ill. Mr. LaHood had introduced Mr. Bush at today's event.
Mr. LaHood said that while "there's some appetite" among voters for Mr. Bush's suggested tax cuts, "I think he should also be talking about, 'I want to be able to pay down the debt, too.' I think that is problematic for people."
When Mr. LaHood was asked if Mr. Bush's proposed tax cut was too large, both politically and practically, he said merely that it was "an ambitious proposal" and that "Congress will have some say about it."
"It's very ambitious," Mr. LaHood added. "There's no doubt about it."
During 14 months of campaigning, Mr. Bush has repeatedly said that he is committed to paying down the federal debt, but more often, when he talks about tax cuts, he simply tells people that he wants to return their hard-earned dollars to them. It is a pledge that draws roars of approval from his Republican base.
While some of the numbers that Mr. Bush and his aides used today for surplus and growth projections had been rounded off, they were essentially valid, in line with estimates from the Congressional Budget Office, and some economists and political analysts consider Mr. Bush's tax cut to be reasonable.
But others note, among other criticisms of his plan, that if he succeeded in enacting the tax cut, it would be extremely difficult to take it back and raise taxes if the projected surpluses did not materialize.
Mr. Bush and his advisers, for their part, say Mr. Gore is the candidate who is potentially endangering the economy by outlining significantly more new spending than Mr. Bush has.
Today, they cited a report released recently by the National Taxpayers Union, a conservative group, that estimated that Mr. Gore's spending programs over the next 10 years would exceed the surplus, at least if Mr. Gore did not touch the part of that surplus generated by Social Security taxes, as both he and Mr. Bush have promised.
The Bush campaign's concern about accusations that the governor's tax cut is too large was evident both today and on Monday in the aggressiveness of its responses to criticism by Mr. Gore.
Karen P. Hughes, the communications director for the Bush campaign, said Mr. Gore had gone "completely overboard" and grossly distorted the substance and effect of Mr. Bush's proposal.
Mr. Gore was "trying to muddy the waters," Ms. Hughes said. "He doesn't want the American people to know how much money's available."
She also said that while Mr. Bush was calling for tax cuts for Americans at every income level, Mr. Gore's plan, directed more specifically at less affluent Americans, would leave 50 percent of taxpayers, totaling 50 million people, without any tax relief.
Mr. Bush's plan would reduce federal tax rates across the income spectrum, lowering the highest rate to 33 percent from 39.6 percent and the lowest rate to 10 percent from 15 percent.
The back-and-forth between the Bush and Gore campaigns about tax cuts, spending and fiscal responsibility reflected a larger aim: each candidate wants to be seen as the more prudent steward of the economy, an issue forever at the top of many voters' concerns.
Mr. Bush's advisers have long reveled in how well Mr. Bush did in polls that asked voters which candidate they trusted more on the issue. But some of the recent surveys that showed Mr. Gore getting an enormous -- and possibly temporary -- bounce out of the Democratic convention also indicated that voters had at least temporarily reassessed his ability to manage the economy.
In a CNN/USA Today/Gallup poll released on Sunday, 50 percent of adults surveyed said Mr. Gore would better handle the economy, while 40 percent said Mr. Bush would. Before either party's convention, a poll by the same organizations showed Mr. Bush with a 47 percent to 40 percent lead on the issue. The margin of sampling error was four percentage points.
On the question of which candidate would better handle the federal surplus, Mr. Gore led Mr. Bush by 48 percent to 41 percent in the recent poll. In the one before the conventions, Mr. Gore trailed Mr. Bush, 38 percent to 49 percent.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE MILITARY DEBATE;
Reluctantly, Cohen Is Joining Tug of War Over U.S. Might

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Ever since President Clinton appointed William S. Cohen secretary of defense in 1996, Mr. Cohen, the only Republican in the cabinet, has repeatedly claimed to represent the bipartisanship needed to manage matters of national security.
Now he finds himself -- by all accounts reluctantly -- at the center of a highly partisan debate over the state of the American military. And it has left him in a highly unusual position: defending the administration while at least indirectly underscoring some of the Republican criticisms leveled against it. 
 On Monday, Mr. Cohen, who represented Maine in the Senate, launched what amounted to a pre-emptive strike against criticisms by Gov. George W. Bush that the Clinton administration was responsible for a weakened, overextended military.
Appearing only hours before Mr. Bush at the annual convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars in Milwaukee, Mr. Cohen noted not only the budget increases approved by Mr. Clinton, including the biggest pay increases for service members in a generation, but also the fact, rarely mentioned by the Bush campaign, that defense budgets started falling rapidly as the cold war ended. That was when another Bush was president and the governor's running mate, Dick Cheney, was secretary of defense.
The cuts that followed, Mr. Cohen went on to say, reflected a strong bipartisan demand for a "peace dividend" now that the United States no longer faced the Soviet Union.
"My constituents from Maine were demanding it, as were people around the country," Mr. Cohen said.
Vice President Al Gore, who appeared before the group today, offered his own, more partisan defense of the country's military preparedness. Thrusting defense issues to center stage in the presidential campaign for a second day, Mr. Gore went so far as to say that Mr. Bush's repeated attacks on the state of the military "for political advantage" threatened to undercut American credibility in the world. Page A18.
Mr. Cohen had offered a rebuttal, of a sort, to the criticisms that Mr. Bush has repeated throughout his presidential campaign and accentuated since the Republican convention three weeks ago.
Without mentioning Mr. Bush by name -- or for that matter Mr. Clinton or Mr. Gore -- Mr. Cohen launched a lengthy, detailed defense of the nation's armed services, contending that they remained strong and ready and proved it in last year's war against Yugoslavia.
At the same time, however, Mr. Cohen left open the need for improvement, suggesting that more work, and money, was needed to meet the pressures on an ever busier military engaged in operations from the Persian Gulf to the Balkans -- something Mr. Bush said he intended to rethink, if elected.
"We can always do better," Mr. Cohen told the veterans, "and national security is certainly a subject matter that is open to debate and improvement. Hopefully that will be the case whatever administration comes in next year."
Mr. Gore, in his appearance today, made that point in a more overt, more partisan, more full-throated way.
"That's not only wrong in fact," Mr. Gore said of Mr. Bush's contentions, "it's the wrong message to send to our allies and adversaries across the world."
Mr. Cohen's remarks, by contrast, have been more subtle -- and more conflicted.
While his remarks defending the armed services have sought to counter some of Mr. Bush's criticisms, they have also highlighted shortcomings in spending and readiness that have long been the subject of complaints from Republicans in Congress and even some uniformed leaders.
As a Republican surrounded by Democrats, Mr. Cohen has always been an oddity in Mr. Clinton's cabinet. He caused a minor stir when he told Barbara Walters in April that he and his wife, Janet Langhart Cohen, a Democrat, would "in all probability" vote for different candidates.
Mr. Cohen later said, "I indeed did not surrender my Republican credentials when I agreed to serve in the administration."
Now, he simply declines to say whom he plans to vote for.
Long before he accepted Mr. Clinton's offer to be defense secretary, Mr. Cohen had a reputation as an independent willing to cross party lines to build consensus, particularly when it comes to defense. Aides in the Pentagon said he took seriously the president's willingness to choose a Republican, hoping to renew a bipartisan spirit with his colleagues who control the House and Senate.
Mr. Cohen once said in an interview that he had never sat through a purely political meeting with Mr. Clinton and his advisers; the discussions had always been on the substance of the issues. The political discussions, presumably, began after he left the room.
Mr. Cohen's success as a bridge to the Republicans has been mixed.
Working with the Joint Chiefs of Staff two years ago, he persuaded the administration to agree to a $112 billion increase in defense spending over six years. He has also been the leading administration advocate for building a limited national missile defense.
On the other hand, Mr. Cohen has failed to win over Republicans in many areas, like closing more military bases, and Republican criticisms of Mr. Clinton's defense policies have only intensified in Mr. Cohen's years as secretary.
In May, Mr. Cohen invited Mr. Bush to the Pentagon for a briefing on the state of the nation's strategic nuclear arsenal after Mr. Bush pledged to reduce the number of American nuclear warheads. The invitation was curtly rebuffed.
However proud Mr. Cohen is of his accomplishments at the Pentagon, he is clearly reluctant to weigh in to the political debate over them now that the campaign is in full swing.
He winced when asked at a news conference at the Pentagon on Friday to respond to Mr. Bush's criticism that morale in the ranks was low. When reporters cornered him on Monday to ask about Mr. Bush's remarks, he began by saying, "Well, I want to keep my comments strictly on the facts and the record and to stay out of the politics as much as possible."
A White House official insisted that no one had asked Mr. Cohen to respond to Mr. Bush's criticisms, although Mr. Cohen's remarks clearly indicated that he had the criticisms in mind.
As for the Gore campaign, "when we think of somebody who can speak for the vice president or the Democratic Party on military issues, Bill Cohen is not the first name that pops in our head," a Gore aide said today.
In fact, when Mr. Gore's campaign aides sought a defense expert to brief reporters on the issues the vice president raised today, they had to reach back to Mr. Cohen's predecessor as defense secretary, William J. Perry.
Mr. Cohen was added to the list of Monday's convention speakers relatively late, defense officials said today, and only because his wife was receiving an award from the veterans.
"I am not here as a Republican," Mr. Cohen himself said on Monday. "I am not here on behalf of the Democratic administration."
Mr. Cohen's posture reflects the fine line walked by men and women in uniform, who are prohibited by law and by policy from participating in overtly political events and thus carefully couch any discussion of political points as strictly factual.
Still, Mr. Cohen's defense of the armed forces -- including noting the increase in weapons procurement and highlighting pay raises that officials said have led to rising re-enlistment rates -- are seen by some as an effective counter to the Republican critiques.
"They can't assail Cohen," one person in Mr. Gore's campaign said. "He's a great surrogate for us. No one can accuse him of politicizing the debate."
But that argument has a double edge.
When Mr. Cohen says that more can be done -- and spent -- his words support arguments made by Mr. Bush's supporters.
The same thing happened when the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, rebutted Mr. Bush's assertion in his speech in Philadelphia accepting the Republican presidential nomination that 2 of the Army's 10 divisions were not ready to fight a major war.
General Shelton said that was not true, then pointed out that President Clinton's approval of a $112 billion budget increase fell far short of the $148 billion the chiefs had said they needed.

HEADLINE: Charles R. Pierce, 78, Lilco Chief Who Championed Shoreham Nuclear Plant

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Charles R. Pierce, a former chairman of the Long Island Lighting Company who championed the disputed Shoreham nuclear power plant only to see the project upend his 34-year association with the company, died on Monday.
He was 78 and lived at Lloyd Harbor, near Huntington, N.Y. 
 A precise cause of death has not been determined, according to Peter Connell, the director of the Connell Funeral Home, which is handling the arrangements.
After serving as a bomber pilot in World War II, Mr. Pierce obtained a law degree from Columbia University and in 1949 joined Lilco as a young recruit in the utility company's legal division. He steadily rose through the ranks and was named president and a director in 1974. Four years later, he was selected chairman.
Over the years, Mr. Pierce earned a reputation for smoothing the way for power plants that local residents did not want in their backyards. But it was the Shoreham project that rapidly became most associated with Mr. Pierce.
The project, in Shoreham, 55 miles east of Manhattan on the North Shore, had been undertaken before Mr. Pierce even rose to the level of president. It was originally scheduled to begin operation in 1978, at a cost of $77 million, but delays and numerous cost overruns plagued the project.
By 1982, with resistance to the project growing, Mr. Pierce took to the airwaves with a series of strongly worded radio commercials in favor of Shoreham. The advertisements lasted almost two years and brought Mr. Pierce widespread public recognition.
In defending the project and its cost overruns, Mr. Pierce had long attributed Shoreham's problems to regulatory, construction and financial requirements that he considered unnecessarily stringent, as well as to design changes resulting from "the lessons learned from Three Mile Island." That was the site of a nuclear power plant accident near Harrisburg, Pa., in 1979.
Mr. Pierce's tough stance on the Shoreham controversy, which included a refusal to compromise with critics of the project, began to cause some Lilco directors discomfort. In 1984, Mr. Pierce and other managers most identified with Shoreham resigned under pressure.
Four years later, the magnitude of the Shoreham debacle became clear. The plant never opened, yet the project lifted electric rates, monopolized the talents of hundreds of engineers for more than a decade and drained more than $5.5 billion from the economy. And in the end, it destroyed Lilco, a company where failure was long considered impossible. In May 1998, the Long Island Lighting Company went out of business after 87 years.
Mr. Pierce is survived by his wife, Virginia; two daughters, Theresa Kelly and Janet Duncan; and one son, Charles R. Jr.

HEADLINE: Still Inflation-Wary, Fed Lets Rates Stand

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Reassured by evidence that wage and price increases remain under control despite robust economic growth, the Federal Reserve voted today to leave interest rates unchanged but warned that it might raise them later in the year if inflation creeps up.
The decision displayed the Fed's confidence that the economy is gradually moving onto a path of slightly more modest, though more sustainable growth, but suggested as well that the central bank is not yet sure that its campaign of rate increases is complete. 
 The task of bleeding off any inflationary pressure without ruining a business expansion is a tricky one under any circumstances. It has become especially complicated in this cycle because, many think, some old rules have been rendered obsolete by the changes that technology and globalization have brought to the economy.
Analysts and policy makers are increasingly certain that the economy is capable of a substantially faster pace of noninflationary growth than it was a few years ago, though there is considerable debate in and outside the Fed about where the new tipping point might be and how close the economy is to it.
As it often has in recent years under its chairman, Alan Greenspan, the Fed chose today to be patient but at the same time to offer reassurances that it would move quickly at the first sign of a threat from inflation.
"Recent data have indicated that the expansion of aggregate demand is moderating toward a pace closer to the rate of growth of the economy's potential to produce," the Fed's policy-making arm, the Federal Open Market Committee, said in a statement.
Nonetheless, the panel said, "the risks continue to be weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future."
The decision means that the Fed is likely to remain on the sidelines for the duration of the presidential campaign. The central bank's policy makers are next to meet on Oct. 3. But the bank has, over the years, tried to avoid taking any action on interest rates in the weeks leading up to Election Day -- which falls this year on Nov. 7. The Fed's first meeting after the election is on Nov. 15.
The outcome of today's meeting had been widely expected by analysts and investors, and there was muted reaction in the financial markets after the announcement at 2:15 p.m. Stocks finished slightly higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at 11,139.15, up 59.34 points. Bonds were little changed.
Today's decision left the Fed's benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks at 6.5 percent, where it has been since May, when the central bank raised the rate by half a percentage point. The Fed held rates steady at its subsequent meeting in June.
It also left unchanged, at 6 percent, its discount rate -- the interest rate charged on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system.
The central bank has pushed the federal funds rate up 1.75 percentage points in six steps since June 1999 in an effort to tamp down inflation pressure without snuffing out what earlier this year became the longest business expansion on record.
Some analysts said it was now unlikely that the Fed would raise rates again this year. Others said inflation remained a threat and that it would be a mistake to count the Fed out.
"As intoxicating as a soft-landing scenario is," said Carl Tannenbaum, chief economist at LaSalle Bank in Chicago, "we have to remain sober for at least another couple of quarters before we allow ourselves to imbibe of it."
In the second quarter of the year, the economy grew at a 5.2 percent annual rate compared with a 4.8 percent annual rate in the first three months of the year.
Those figures were well above what many economists think can be sustained over the long run without igniting a spiral in wages and prices. While it remains a moving target, the economy's noninflationary speed limit now seems to be around or just below 4 percent.
Yet inflation has edged up only slightly from very low levels, in large part because the strong economic growth has been accompanied by a surge in business efficiency, or productivity, which improved at a 5.3 percent annual rate in the second quarter.
Even as companies find themselves paying more to attract workers in a tight labor market, where unemployment is at 4 percent, and more for raw materials and equipment, they are cutting costs in other areas or improving efficiency by investing in new technology.
Within the Fed, there is a long-running debate about whether productivity improvements can continue to outrun inflation pressure. In keeping rates unchanged today, the Fed seemed to be deferring the matter rather than trying to settle it.
In its statement, the Federal Open Market Committee noted that economic indicators were showing "that more rapid advances in productivity" had forced economists to revise upward their estimates of how fast the economy could grow without igniting inflation. At the same time, the committee said, productivity improvements have been "containing costs and holding down underlying price pressures."
But the policy panel suggested that productivity improvements were not a panacea and that the combination of low unemployment and strong growth still had to be viewed as inflationary, especially to the degree that strong demand for goods and services outstripped the economy's ability to keep up.
The committee, the statement said, "remains concerned about the risk of a continuing gap between the growth of demand and potential supply at a time when the utilization of the pool of available workers remains at an unusually high level."
To some degree, the inflation warning in the statement was intended to keep analysts and traders from concluding that the Fed was signaling an end to this series of rate increases.
In interviews in recent months, several Fed officials said they hoped to keep Wall Street somewhat off balance to prevent another sharp run-up in stock prices. Within the Fed, the wealth generated in the stock market is regarded as a primary driver of consumer spending and overall demand, and another strong rebound on Wall Street, it is feared, could push demand up to a level that would inevitably fuel inflation.
But Fed officials no doubt have other, more fundamental inflation worries on their minds. Oil prices remain quite high, and although their effect on overall consumer prices so far has been somewhat muted, high oil prices could still feed through the economy and accelerate inflation.
There is also concern among some Fed officials that the combination of 4 percent annual growth and 4 percent unemployment will inevitably lead to wage increases that will outstrip productivity gains and put upward pressure on prices.
Mr. Greenspan told Congress last month that he did not think the Federal Reserve would have to drive unemployment higher to prevent inflation. But some of his colleagues -- including Laurence H. Meyer, the Fed governor most closely identified with the school of economists who see a tight link between unemployment and inflation -- are not so sure.

HEADLINE: METRO BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Steve Strunsky

 BODY:

NEW YORK
 
MANHATTAN: PAPER PRIMARY PROTEST
The City Board of Elections refused yesterday to reprint ballots for the Sept. 12 primary that now omit Green Party candidates, and will force party voters to choose their nominees on paper ballots. Green Party candidates will be on voting machine ballots everywhere else in the state. Craig Seeman, the party's state election coordinator, said that it would sue the city in federal court and that the board's claim that there is no room on ballots for the Green Party candidates was unacceptable. The Senate candidates include Al Lewis, above, who played Grandpa on "The Munsters"; Mark Dunau, a farmer from Hancock, N.Y.; and Ron Dugger of Manhattan, a former newspaper publisher. (NYT) 

MANHATTAN: UNEMPLOYMENT PHONES QUIT
An automated service that allows unemployment recipients to claim benefits over the phone was out of order for 27 hours in New York City starting Monday morning, the State Department of Labor said yesterday. Hundreds of recipients who use the telephone system, called Tel-Service, may have been inconvenienced by the disruption, which was caused by a malfunction in a mechanism that routes calls, said Betsy McCormack, department spokeswoman. But, she said, the service was back by noon yesterday, and no one will lose benefits. Nina Siegal (NYT)
 
QUEENS: SHOOTING ARREST
A man was arrested Monday night in a fatal 1998 shooting at a Queens tavern, the police said. The man, Miguel Valerio, 30, was arrested in Chester, Md., after the authorities received a tip. The police said they believe that Mr. Valerio, who worked at a tavern in Sunnyside, followed Francis O'Loughlin, 32, into the bar's bathroom on Sept. 5, 1998, and shot him once in the head. Elissa Gootman (NYT)
 
ALBANY: RECORDS ON HIP SOUGHT
New York State's attorney general, Eliot L. Spitzer, has asked medical groups to supply information about cleaning contracts, building leases and political donations related to their work for the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York. Mr. Spitzer's office and the State Insurance Department have been investigating HIP, a nonprofit company that insures many city workers, and its chief executive, Anthony L. Watson, and whether HIP spent millions on executive perquisites and contracts for board members and friends of Mr. Watson. HIP has said it is cooperating with investigators. Christopher Drew (NYT)
 
NEW JERSEY
 
TRENTON: NO EXECUTION, NO PAROLE
A defendant convicted of capital murder who avoids execution faces mandatory life in prison without parole, under a law signed yesterday by the president of the State Senate, Donald T. DiFrancesco, left, who was acting as governor. The law was inspired by Thomas Trantino, who was sentenced to death in the 1963 murder of two law enforcement officers in Lodi, but was spared when the death penalty was declared unconstitutional. The death penalty has been reinstated, but Mr. Trantino, 62, is not subject to the new law and remains eligible for parole. (NYT)
 
MAURICE RIVER: SEX-OFFENDER JAIL WELCOMED
After months of resistance from Woodbridge Township, a 300-bed prison for sex offenders will be built 100 miles south, in Cumberland County. In exchange for $825,000 a year from the state once the prison is operating, Maurice River has agreed to accept the $20 million prison. Last year, the state decided to build the prison in the Avenel section of Woodbridge, on the grounds of East Jersey State Prison and next to the Adult Diagnostic and Treatment Center, which houses sex offenders during their prison terms, but Woodbridge challenged the decision in court. Maurice River, population 6,654, already has two medium-security prisons, which, combined, are its biggest employer. Andrew Jacobs (NYT)
 
TRENTON: TEST SCORES RELEASED
New Jersey officials released a new round of standardized test scores yesterday for public school students in the fourth and eighth grades, but would not disclose the results for fourth-grade language arts literacy. In the writing section, students' scores were so low that the State Education Department's Language Arts Literacy Assessment Committee will review the test scores and the grading. The test, known as the Elementary School Proficiency Assessment, was taken by 80,000 fourth graders during the 1999-2000 school year. The fourth-grade science scores did not change significantly from the previous year, with 57.3 percent ranked as proficient. Fourth graders improved in math, with 49.6 percent in the proficient category, up from 47.5 percent. The state's 75,000 eighth graders in public schools scored well in science and language arts, with more than 80 percent ranked proficient or advanced proficient . In math, 67.3 percent demonstrated proficiency, up from 68.5 percent. (NYT)
 
HOLLAND TOWNSHIP: BODY IDENTIFIED
A body pulled from the Delaware River on Saturday was identified as a Pennsylvania man who drowned last week after trying to ride the high water caused by the recent heavy rains, the Hunterdon County medical examiner's office said. The man, Charles Weaver, 58, a high school guidance counselor from Riegelsville, Pa., fell out of his kayak Aug. 15 in the Musconetcong River. (NYT)
 
TRENTON: 3 LEAVE PAROLE BOARD
Three more members of the State Parole Board have stepped down or taken leave, following the resignation of its chairman. The board has been under pressure to explain a backlog of cases and has been under investigation by the state in connection with favorable treatment for inmates with ties to organized crime. Robert Egles, the board's executive director, took a leave of absence; another member, Peter Loos, asked not to be reappointed; and another member, Joseph Ferrera, resigned. Records have been seized from Mr. Egles and the chairman of the 11-member board, Andrew Consovoy, who stepped down on July 28.(NYT)
 
CONNECTICUT
 
NEW HAVEN: SUITS AGAINST MALL PLAN
Make it 16. That's the number of lawsuits filed by opponents of New Haven's plan to build a $500 million mall just east of downtown. Yesterday, a suit was filed in Superior Court in Hartford by Westfield America, owner of a mall in Milford, claiming that the State Office of Policy and Management illegally approved $28 million in tax breaks for the project's developer. Dean Pagani, a spokesman for Gov. John G. Rowland, said Westfield simply wanted to stymie potential competition. The project is expected to add $7 million in annual property taxes and 3,000 jobs to New Haven's limping economy. Opponents say it will destroy downtown businesses. Paul Zielbauer (NYT)

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
International Paper Going to Connecticut

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
International Paper has agreed to move its combined world headquarters from Purchase, N.Y., to Stamford, Conn., ending a fierce competition between Connecticut and New York for International, the largest maker of paper and forest products in the world.
Connecticut officials and a spokesman for International Paper said yesterday that a verbal agreement was reached after state economic development officials offered a generous package of incentives. 
 International has been in Purchase since 1986, but in June, it bought Champion International Corporation, which is based in Stamford. International will move its 120 headquarters employees from Purchase to the Champion headquarters building 12 miles away in downtown Stamford.
Before the acquisition, Champion had about 375 employees in Stamford. About 265 have been told that their jobs will be eliminated. About 50 more have been given jobs with International, although most of them are to be transferred elsewhere.

HEADLINE: California's Move to Limit Power Rates Hits Resistance

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 22

 BODY:
Mounting political concern over what many are describing as deregulation run amok in the electricity market in San Diego prompted a major but inconclusive battle in the State Assembly today over a bill that would place a broad cap on power costs in the city.
The state utility commission narrowly approved a partial rate cap on Monday for San Diego, the first city in California to be deregulated, but many people said they believed it was too little to help people hit with bills that have doubled or tripled in just a few months. 
 By late tonight the Assembly had not voted on the bill, which the State Senate has passed, 28-0. The bill was facing great resistance because of the expected costs to the state, perhaps many hundreds of millions of dollars.
Several legislative aides said late in the day that it appeared that supporters of the measure simply did not have the votes to pass it and that its fate was unclear.
Nevertheless, the subject of skyrocketing power rates in San Diego, a virtual guinea pig in a pioneering state program, has suddenly become a source of enormous concern because of the unexpected rate change.
Deregulation was undertaken because the Legislature believed it would offer an antidote to what were already exceptionally high power rates in the state, roughly 50 percent above the national average.
Under the deregulation plan, passed in 1996 with the expectation that it would be phased in over many years, utilities had to sell off their generating plants and then purchase power through a state-controlled exchange. San Diego was opened before other cities because of a merger of its utilities to form Sempra Energy.
But many critics have complained that the market was opened before there was a sufficient supply of electricity available, skewing prices upward.
The strong economy and the added burden summer air-conditioning have accentuated the steep jump in wholesale power rates, which have been passed along to consumers.
Many people in the state, including Gov. Gray Davis and the chairman of Sempra Energy, have accused some wholesalers of price gouging, and the governor has written President Clinton, urging him to start a federal investigation.
"Time is of the essence, Mr. President," the Mr. Davis wrote in his letter of Aug. 10. "San Diego consumers have paid an enormous price for deregulation in a market that no one believes is functionally competitive."
Susan Golding, the San Diego mayor, said in an interview that she basically backed deregulation, but that the timing had been so ill-planned that some sort of market intervention was necessary to spare the city a major hiccup in what had been its best economic expansion ever after suffering through a brutal recession.
"In my experience, it takes a very long time to go from a bad economic climate to a good one, but almost no time to go the other way, and that's what I'm afraid could happen here," Mayor Golding said.
"I don't think this bill is the right long-term solution, but I chose to support it because it is needed," she said.
On Monday, the state Public Utility Commission narrowly approved a measure that would cap power costs in the city, but only for small businesses and residents who use 500 kilowatts a month or less. That left many people unsatisfied, particularly since a range of important users, from public schools to the high technology companies that have remade San Diego's economy over the last decade, would feel little improvement.
That prompted the State Assembly to resume its debate of the new bill, which is sponsored by two San Diego area state legislators, Senator Dede Alpert and Assemblywoman Susan Davis.
The bill would roll prices back to their levels in June, before rates began to increase, order the state utility commission to place a firm cap on rates at that level and create a mechanism for passing along excess profits to consumers.
The bill would also mandate an investigation into the spike in rates.

HEADLINE: No Longer A War Zone, Hunts Point Gains Status;
New Services Arrive As City Improvements Lift Bronx Community

BYLINE: By JUAN FORERO 

 BODY:
Utter the name Hunts Point, residents say, and most people who do not know better think grit and grime and crime. Thoughts turn to a desolate and particularly polluted stretch of the South Bronx long associated with streetwalkers, drug dealers, rumbling trucks and a sprawling wholesale food market that offers little in the way of aesthetics.
But these days in Hunts Point, real estate agents regularly knock on Jeannette Johnson's door, offering $200,000 for the elegant century-old town house with the rounded facade where she has lived since 1951. Nearby, William Erazo watches from his window as 42 homes are constructed on a lot where junked cars were once dumped. 
 And Hunts Point is where Bob and Teresa Melendez moved with their teenage son after deciding their apartment in Pelham Bay was too small. It was a homecoming, for both had fled Hunts Point in the 1970's when the neighborhood was being transformed into a wasteland of violence and abandoned buildings.
"You can see the change, the immense change," Ms. Melendez said in her newly renovated two-bedroom apartment on Lafayette Street. "Compared to what it was in the 1970's and 1980's, it's being reborn. We don't see so much graffiti, drugs and stuff, so much garbage. There used to be so much dumping from windows. It's not like that. It's come a long way."
Since 1986, 60,000 homes and apartments have been built or rehabilitated in the South Bronx through city-sponsored programs, and fledgling businesses have begun giving once-barren neighborhoods a try.
These things have come more slowly to Hunts Point, some residents say.
Zoned for industry and the home of waste transfer stations and warehouses, scrap metal shops and the 1.9-million-square-foot Food Distribution Center, Hunts Point had not always been thought of as a place for a residential renaissance, longtime residents and business people in the area say.
But little by little, improvements have come to this sliver of a neighborhood cut off from the rest of the Bronx by the Bruckner Expressway and surrounded on three sides by an industrial park with 650 businesses. Hunts Point's 8,200 residents, most of whom live on a peninsula jutting into the East River known as the Point, are experiencing an array of improvements that have begun or been completed in recent months -- from rehabilitated housing to new park space to the arrival of services the Point never had before, like a post office.
"In the past, the exciting things that would happen in Hunts Point were things like the new Meat Locker coming to the Cooperative Market," said Paul Lipson, executive director of the Point Community Development Corporation, a community group and business incubator. "It was the Fulton Fish Market coming up here. Now there's much more for residents."
A credit union, the area's first banking service in 25 years, will open in October, across Lafayette Street from where the peninsula's first post office is being built. Groundbreaking has begun for a youth recreation center. In June, a new park was inaugurated on the Bronx River. A primary care clinic, also a first, opened last year, and a second is expected to open any week now. And the main street, Hunts Point Avenue, has seen storefront vacancies fall from 60 percent three years ago to about 25 percent today.
The cornerstone of a city-sponsored drive to add new housing is the current construction of 42 two- and three-family homes near Mr. Erazo's front porch on Bryant Street, where he once watched drug deals go down. This was an area once maligned as a war zone, shown as populated by heroin addicts and criminals in the 1981 film "Fort Apache, the Bronx."
"The fact that they're beginning to build homes around here means people are moving in who'll take care of their homes because it's an investment," said Mr. Erazo, 71, a retired salesman who has lived with his family in the house he bought in 1969.
Hunts Point is also selling itself to artists looking for cheap space, with boosters likening the peninsula to the artists' colony in Williamsburg in Brooklyn. The former American Bank Note Company building is offering up to 27,000 of its 365,000 square feet to artists. Seven painters, sculptors and other artisans have rented space since Arthur Aviles and his dance company arrived in 1998. Five others have signed leases and are moving in.
"If you're looking for ribbon and bows, it's not here; it's an uncut diamond," explained Howard T. Cash, a fine arts photographer. "The area is still basically camouflaged. So you have to seek things out. You have to be a journeyman and an explorer. You have to go and ask. But a lot of things are here."
But even its boosters acknowledge that Hunts Point remains a difficult neighborhood in which to raise a family, and wonder how much better a community zoned largely for industry can become.
"I think we're still in the stages of becoming a real community in terms of the residential area; it's not there yet," said Josephine Infante, director of the Hunts Point Economic Development Corporation, which she founded in 1988 when the neighborhood was still at rock bottom. "We're still talking about a poor community. It's not going to look like Riverdale."
Indeed, the peninsula is still saddled with an array of serious problems.
Its residents are among the poorest in the city. In the late 1990's, unemployment remained at 18 percent, and nearly half of all residents draw public assistance. Only 32 percent of children in the local elementary school passed the school board's reading test this year, compared with 40 percent citywide.
Perhaps because of the truck traffic and waste transfer stations, more than 25 percent of all children suffer from asthma, said Dr. Braulio Flores, staff doctor at Bella Vista Health Clinic on Hunts Point Avenue.
Francisco Perez, 57, a member of Mothers on the Move, a local group that has battled industry in the peninsula, said that breathing can be hard for her, too. "I myself have bronchitis and, at times, it becomes so much worse," she said. "We are waiting for a future when we'll have improvements. It's not easy to work in a community that still needs so many changes."
Hunts Point has two dozen waste transfer stations, more than in any other part of the city. Some 12,000 trucks move in and out of the peninsula daily. Warehouses and nearly 100 auto parts suppliers and mechanics provide a scrappy backdrop. A Swedish company is proposing to build a natural gas-powered plant there to produce electricity.
Yet, Mr. Perez and others who have long called for a tighter rein on industry say the Hunts Point of today is far different from the one they knew just a few short years ago. Crime has fallen to the point where there has not been a single homicide in the peninsula this year.
And the Hunts Point Economic Development Corporation is pushing a far-reaching plan that will spend $2.3 million to build medians and plant trees and flowers in streets considered too wide and foreboding for a residential neighborhood. The plan also calls for limiting truck routes to a select number of streets, with color-coded signs and the threat of fines discouraging truckers from taking shortcuts through residential streets.
Signs of renewed life are most apparent, residents say, amid the peninsula's eclectic mix of brick row houses and tenements.
Kristina Hosch, who with her husband, Eddie Torres, owns several Bronx apartment buildings, went into Hunts Point four years ago to inspect city-owned buildings that were being offered to investors. On that first day, Ms. Hosch recalled, she requested a police escort to tour buildings infested with drug dealers. Today, the four buildings they own have been renovated and painted, with well-lighted hallways, working intercom systems and polished tiles. Recent renovations have left apartments with new hardwood floors, windows and appliances. Tenants have flocked to fill the 172 apartments in the buildings.
"I never thought it would lose the Hunts Point stereotype and that you'd have the eagerness to get into the buildings," she said. "Now, we're seeing the transformation. As soon as people look at the apartments, they want to rent, the same day."
Michael Faust, another developer, decided two years ago to buy a 20-unit building that had been gutted. Now, he is to begin $2 million in renovations financed with loans sponsored by the City Department of Housing Preservation and Development. The hope, said Mr. Faust, whose company has rehabilitated buildings in neighborhoods like Fort Greene in Brooklyn that have become chic, is that the peninsula will undergo a similar revival.
"This has been one of the untainted or untouched communities," Mr. Faust said, "and now people are going there to fix up, and I think it's a good low-income or moderate-income area that's up and coming."
It was not always that way, even on the peninsula's most charming street, Manida, with row after row of elegant, brick homes.
Jeannette Johnson should know, having seen Manida Street at its best in 1951 when she and her husband, the bandleader Buddy Johnson, first moved in. Then came the 1960's and 1970's, when drug dealers took over, the garbage piled up and her neighbors fled.
These days, though, Ms. Johnson gets unsolicited visits from real estate agents who want her home, a handsome, two-family brick structure with fine moldings and elegant touches. "They want to buy the homes here now," said Ms. Johnson, whose son, Woodrow, a teacher, lives in the second-floor apartment. "You would never think they would want to buy homes in Hunts Point. But now, they're offering $245,000."
Hugh Coley, a real estate broker with Century 21 Future Homes, is among those who have made a point of staking out homes on the peninsula.
"Five years ago, I mean they were selling for $30,000, $40,000, $50,000," he said. "That was just the way the market was at that point. No one would want those houses down there. But now, there's talk about businesses moving into the area, and people are looking for investments over there."
Ms. Johnson explains that while she may some day move, for now she is happy.
"Where else can you get a two-family home like this?" she said. "You walk out, it's nice out here. You can park your car out front. It's clean. It's quiet. It's good."

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
An Eastern Fantasia, Asleep for a Century

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS 

DATELINE: CLAVERACK, N.Y.

 BODY:
TREND-WATCHERS, take note: Lockwood de Forest may be big. Very big.
De Forest, a turn-of-the-century artist and designer who rose to eminence, then sank into obscurity, is now on the brink of rediscovery. A Manhattan gallery recently featured some of his oil sketches. A desk embodying his design philosophy is part of an exhibition on Orientalism at Williams College in Massachusetts. The Indian-style interiors he championed are being echoed by hip designers like Muriel Brandolini and Lulu Kwiatkowski. And in this Hudson River Valley village two hours north of New York City, furniture and architectural elements he produced have been brought together by the filmmakers Ismail Merchant and James Ivory in what must be his first one-man design show since the 1893 World's Columbian Exhibition. 
 Scion of a New York clan whose family tree blossoms with myriad lawyers and the occasional flamboyant -- a great-uncle was the painter Frederic E. Church, and a great-niece was the Warhol superstar Edie Sedgwick -- Lockwood de Forest was a pivotal member of Associated Artists, a short-lived design firm founded by Louis Comfort Tiffany.
Its specialty was self-conscious splendor, exotic interiors that were one part ABC Carpet & Home, one part "Arabian Nights." Brass lanterns hung from stenciled ceilings. Persian carpets were flung over harem-style balustrades. Fireplaces glimmered with Moorish tiles. And thanks to a woodcarving studio that de Forest discovered in Ahmadabad, on the Arabian Sea coast of India, his trendy ensembles for clients like the Baltimore & Ohio Railroad heiress Mary Garrett and her lover Martha Carey Thomas, a president of Bryn Mawr College, incorporated exquisite teak furniture and architectural fittings that resemble petrified lace.
The eight chairs, two tables, chest of drawers, fireplace surround, two doors, two settees and standing screen in "Lockwood de Forest" at the Merchant and Ivory Foundation exemplify the top-dollar exoticism that was de Forest's hallmark in the 1880's, the high point of a fitful career that ended when he died in 1932 at 82. Rendered in cinnamon-colored teak with delicately chiseled foliate and geometric designs -- there are a couple of cast-iron firebacks, too -- most of the pieces come from the collection of David L. Petrovsky, who owns an eponymous antiques shop in nearby Hudson.
On a recent visit, Mr. Petrovsky gazed wide-eyed at the feet of a gleaming armchair produced by Indian woodcarvers working under de Forest's direction. "Look at those," he said. "They look like garlic bulbs with toenails." Eye-catchingly odd, yes, but no more so than the bizarre finials higher up: the heads of impassive Hindu deities surmounted by sawtooth tiaras. The show, which closes Sept. 4, is one of several marking the 10th anniversary of the Merchant and Ivory Foundation, an arts organization founded by the Oscar-winning filmmakers. Its headquarters are in red-painted gristmill buildings near their Greek Revival house, which have been turned into exhibition and performance spaces.
"We've never had a show like this," said Mr. Ivory, whose latest film, an adaptation of Henry James's "Golden Bowl," starring Uma Thurman, will open this fall. "But a couple of months ago, David suggested it, and Ismail and I thought, 'Why not?' De Forest's work is very intriguing, and both Ismail and I are fascinated by everything to do with India, for obvious reasons."
Lockwood de Forest was not the only American aesthete of his time who fell under the spell of India, a country that became a pop-culture influence after Queen Victoria became its empress in 1876. But the largely self-taught artist, designer and architect was the most passionately pro-India Yankee of his time, the American equivalent of John Lockwood Kipling, father of the empire-thumping poet and curator of a museum in the Indian city of Lahore (now in Pakistan) in the days of the British Raj.
Just as the elder Kipling's scholarship led him to create widely admired Indian-style rooms -- a dining room at Queen Victoria's Osborne House on the Isle of Wight and a billiard room for her son the Duke of Connaught at his country house in Surrey, Bagshot Park, now the home of Prince Edward -- de Forest's passion for the Mogul art and architecture of the subcontinent led him to install similar spaces from Ithaca to San Francisco.
"The 1880's were his glory days," said Roberta A. Mayer, an art historian, who lives in Hopewell, N.J. De Forest's work was exhibited to acclaim at the Colonial and Indian Exhibition in London in 1886, and at the World's Columbian Exhibition seven years later, attracting an impressive array of clients: the steel king Andrew Carnegie, the transportation magnate Charles Tyson Yerkes, the hotelier Potter Palmer, even Mark Twain.
Though he did not have a hand in its design, a stylistically related desk by Associated Artists is featured in "Noble Dreams, Wicked Pleasures: Orientalism in America, 1870-1930," an exhibition that runs through Sept. 4 at the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute at Williams College in Williamstown, Mass. Made of satinwood, brass, pewter and leather, it embodies everything that Associated Artists and de Forest stood for in the late 19th century: Eastern exoticism conjured for Western millionaires.
De Forest visited India on his honeymoon in 1879, a nearly two-year trip that he turned to his economic advantage, keeping his eye peeled for objects and inspirations that would benefit Associated Artists. In Ahmadabad, he met Muggunbhai Hutheesing, a philanthropist whose woodcarving studio would become crucial to de Forest's career. The studio was only a small component of a family fortune built on some of India's largest carpet and textile factories, as well as on opium trafficking.
Unlike European Orientalists, many of whom looked upon Asia and the Middle East with colonialist superiority, de Forest wanted to help the cause of Indian woodworkers and preserve traditional Indian arts and crafts, which were being forgotten in the wake of brightly varnished knockoffs being made in Paris. His equally enthusiastic wife, Meta, had her couturier transform cheap Indian cottons into dresses that were the envy of her friends -- until they learned of the fabrics' "lowly" (i.e., non-Western) provenance.
"Having committed themselves as to the beauty of the material, it was difficult for them to crawl out of it with either grace or success," Lockwood de Forest gleefully recalled. "We had a fine chance to rub their ignorance in, which we often enjoyed doing." By directing Hutheesing's carvers to copy or adapt centuries-old details from mosques, temples, tombs and mansions -- designs that were used in de Forest's interiors, furniture and accessories, including a wall bracket at Olana, the house of Great-Uncle Frederic -- one small part of India's artistry could continue to flourish, albeit reinterpreted in costly Western settings.
Part of him had a romantic response to all that beauty, but he was pragmatic, too, Ms. Mayer said: "He wanted to make his art into a legitimate profession, a way to create beauty and make money at the same time."
Unfortunately, de Forest's Indian experiment appealed to a fickle audience too conscious of fads to be loyal to his narrow vision. By the turn of the century, his romantic rooms were passe, a victim of the Francophile chic popularized by Elsie de Wolfe and Ogden Codman Jr. By 1908, he had sold his stock of moldings and furniture to his old friend Tiffany and retired to Santa Barbara, Calif., where he spent much of his remaining life quietly painting. (His son, another Lockwood, would become one of the state's great landscape designers.)
Apparently, not one de Forest interior survives intact, and even the bits and pieces remaining are not completely appreciated. His teak room for Andrew Carnegie, for instance, still occupies its second-floor spot in the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, the former Carnegie mansion, though its furniture was sold long ago and its carvings are obscured under temporary exhibition walls. As for de Forest's furniture, no one knows precisely how much was produced, a mystery that deepens when it becomes clear that none was labeled or marked, thus making it difficult to distinguish it from the often fine copies produced by competitors.
But it does show up periodically, often misidentified, at auctions and other, less likely, places. In 1995, Mr. Petrovsky discovered a seven-piece suite of furniture in a consignment shop in New Canaan, Conn. He says that Mitchell Wolfson Jr., founder of the Wolfsonian museum in Miami Beach, recently bought more than 100 pieces of carved teak, each a different pattern and individually numbered, apparently a set of samples that the artist used to guide the Ahmadabad carvers.
Even with the uncertainty, some of Lockwood de Forest's magic lingers. A house he designed in Baltimore is now an Indian restaurant called the Brass Elephant. His furnishings for Mary Garrett are scattered throughout several rooms in the Bryn Mawr alumnae house. As for the brick town house that de Forest built for himself at 7 East 10th Street between 1886 and 1888, once heralded as the most Indian house in America, it is now the Bronfman Center for Jewish Student Life at New York University. Its extraordinary lacelike interiors have suffered over time, but its teak-bedecked facade, like that of the elaborate Burmese-style Ava apartments next door, is splendidly unaltered, an incongruous reminder of a trendsetter who once reigned in a city that too often forgets.
The Lockwood de Forest exhibition is open for the next two weekends, Aug. 25 to 27 and Sept. 1 to 4, at the Red Mills gallery, on Route 23 just east of Patroon Street in Claverack, N.Y. Hours: 1 to 5 P.M. Free admission. Information: (212) 586-6014.
