HEADLINE: For 'Miss Saigon,' Light at the End

BYLINE: By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
THEY call it the Nightmare. That is how the crew refers to the sequence in which the metal embassy fence drops in, the helipad moves down, the sound of whipping blades intensifies, and a life-size chopper descends.
On Dec. 31, American troops will evacuate Saigon this way for the last time on the stage of the Broadway Theater, bringing to a close the musical "Miss Saigon," the sixth-longest-running show in Broadway history. After nearly 10 years, the production, loosely based on Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," will have played 4,063 performances and gone through 1,218,900 pounds of dry ice, 89,386 scene changes and 812,600 light cues. 
 "Miss Saigon" has taken in more than $1.3 billion internationally at the box office since its world premiere in London in September 1989. The Broadway production, which opened on April 11, 1991, has grossed more than $266 million and has been seen by nearly six million people.
The show spawned two United States touring companies and a Toronto production. "Saigon" has been performed in six other countries, and a new production will open in the Philippines next month, starring Lea Salonga, who originated the title role on Broadway.
The show's imminent departure is significant, and not only because "Miss Saigon" is the most technically complex show in Broadway history, or because it broke several records during its phenomenal run, like the largest advance ticket sale ($37 million) and highest ticket price ever for a musical at the time ($100). With "Cats" scheduled to close next month, the departure of "Miss Saigon" leaves just two in a crop of mega-musicals still running -- "Les Miserables" and "The Phantom of the Opera" -- suggesting that an era of theatrical spectacle may be at an end.
With musicals now costing $5 million to $12 million to mount, many producers say they would not attempt a "Miss Saigon" today. (The show cost $10.9 million in 1991.)
Written by Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schonberg (who wrote "Les Miserables"), with additional lyrics by Richard Maltby Jr., and produced by the British impresario Cameron Mackintosh, "Miss Saigon" is also a landmark in that it was the first successful musical to deal with the sensitive subject of Vietnam.
In addition, the production originally engendered considerable controversy when Sir Cameron clashed with the Actors Equity Association over casting: the union insisted on an Asian actor for the major role of the Engineer, a Eurasian pimp, while Sir Cameron insisted on Jonathan Pryce -- initially canceling the production -- and ultimately prevailed. But "Miss Saigon" has proved to be a source of steady income for Asian actors, who often find work hard to come by on Broadway.
 
Its Own Following
Those who have been with the musical the longest say they are in no position to mourn its passing. After all, most shows don't last even a year on Broadway. And "Miss Saigon" just kept on going.
"Because it was the last great blockbuster of the 80's, it had all that sort of media-frenzied hype behind it," Sir Cameron said. "Therefore, it wasn't until the dust had settled that actually the audience decided to like it for itself. To this day it has its own following."
While the production is best known for its special effects, it is the poignancy of the love story between Kim, a Vietnamese waif forced to work as a prostitute after witnessing the death of her parents in the war, and Chris, an American G.I. compelled to leave Saigon on the last helicopter out, that seems to explain why the musical has run so long.
"I think what happened was, there was an appetite for what opera has always done well," said Nicholas Hytner, who directed the show, "which is to dramatize large passions in some people set against a sweeping historical background."
In his review of the show in The New York Times, Frank Rich wrote, "For all that seems galling about 'Miss Saigon' -- and for all that is indeed simplistic, derivative and, at odd instances, laughable about it -- this musical is a gripping entertainment of the old school."
While audiences may be moved by the tale and its tragic ending, they are also awed by the element of spectacle, with sets by John Napier, lighting by David Hersey, sound by Andrew Bruce and costumes by Andreane Neofitou and Suzy Benzinger. In addition to the famous 1,700-pound helicopter (often derided as too Disneyland), the show features an 18-foot fiberglass statue of Ho Chi Minh and a real 1959 Cadillac, cut in half to fit backstage. The crew is bigger than the cast, 55 to 46. There are 375 costumes, 206 props, 45 firearms, including handguns, M-16's and AK-47's. The touring company that closed this month in Buffalo required 40 tractor-trailers.
" 'Phantom' had been the largest automated show," said Jake Bell, the show's production technical manager. " 'Saigon' surpassed that by more than double."
Experiencing a matinee from behind the scenes offers a glimpse into what it takes to make this monster of a show work its magic.
 
Busy in the Wings
The action begins a half-hour before the curtain goes up. The last of the actors enter through the stage door, sign in and head up to their dressing rooms to get into their wigs, makeup and costumes.
On the cool, cavernous stage and in the wings, the crew readies the props and scenery. Set pieces that have been left on the stage from the close of the show the night before -- like the runway for the Moulin Rouge strip club in Bangkok, where the story moves in Act II -- are moved into the wings and, in most cases, flown, which means they are strung up on chain hoists to keep the limited wing space as clear as possible. Act I sets and props are moved onto the deck -- meaning the stage and wings -- including bicycles and details for the wedding shrine: incense, candles and colorful hanging unicorns.
"It's like rotating stock in a store," said Andrew Douglas, the assistant propertyman.
Because of the tight space, large pieces of scenery must be constantly moved around in the wings to allow others to get on and off the stage. The towering Ho statue, for example, gets shifted from side to side at the rear of the stage like a pendulum clock throughout the performance. Then there are the five different beds to keep track of: Kim 1 Bed, Kim 2 Bed, Kim 3 Bed, Kim 4 Bed and Hotel Bed.
In addition there are the smaller details to account for, like the basket of lacquered vegetables (exactly what kind is a matter of backstage debate: zucchini, okra, bitter melon?), stacks of fake dollar bills, carts with hanging fish and trays of jewelry.
With so many sets rising and descending in the wings, backstage can be a dicey place to be. "Organized chaos," said Peter Wolf, the first assistant stage manager. To make room for all of the show's big bells and whistles, the theater first had to be transformed. Jack Cennamo, 61, the head carpenter, who has been with "Miss Saigon" since it began, said he and his crew spent two months tearing out walls, radiators and stairwells.
During the performance, the stagehands are particularly concerned with how the scenery moves on and off. "It's routine," Mr. Cennamo said of running the show. "But you have to pay attention."
There are 19 muslin blinds that look as if they were made of rice paper and frame the stage. Behind them is black masking through which scenery glides in and out on metal pylons that are meant to evoke Vietnam. The rising of the blinds is carried out by one of the show's three computers, which occupy a room of their own. If a computer malfunctions and the blinds don't go up, the pylons carrying the scenery rip through them and the stagehands have a problem. It has happened, but not often.
Coordinating all this, calling the cues, is Mark Dobrow, the production stage manager, who has been with "Miss Saigon" for five years. Outside the office he shares with his assistant stage managers -- Mr. Wolf and Lisa Buxbaum, the second assistant -- Polaroid pictures cover the walls, featuring every cast member who has been with the company, almost 300 over the years. Each of them signed the show's coolie hat upon leaving.
The role of Kim's son, Tam, has been played by 34 different 4- and 5-year-olds, mostly girls. "Boys, when they're 4, are not mature enough," Mr. Dobrow said. "They get bored really easily."
 
The 'Child Wrangler'
Looking after this child is a chaperone, or "child wrangler," currently Suzanne Arnold, who stays by her charge's side throughout the show. When Tam (played by Jenna La Salla and Gail A. Quintos, who alternate performances) is offstage, Ms. Arnold entertains the child in the dressing room with games, storybooks and toys. When Tam is onstage, Ms. Arnold is nearby, out of sight of the audience. When, for example, Tam is sitting on a bed (Kim 3 Bed) that is curtained off, waiting to make her entrance, Ms. Arnold sits beside the girl, telling her jokes or reading aloud.
Mr. Wolf is in charge of training the new Tams, who generally stay 3 to 10 months. Rather than explain the entire show to a 4-year-old, Mr. Wolf has given each of Tam's scenes names. So when Tam first enters by running from the bed to his mother, that is called the "Tam Run Game." When Kim shoots her cousin with a gun to protect Tam, that is the "Tam Bang Game."
The stagehands have developed joke names for some of the grown-up scenes, too. The one in which the men enter wearing sandals, for example, is called "the flip-flop boys."
In the locker room under the stage before the show, the actors playing soldiers get dressed in their Army gear, attaching their microphones, draping dog tags around their necks. Ray Santos, one of the original cast members who plays a Vietnamese customer in the first bar scene, says he values this time the most. "We make each other laugh," he said, "talk about things outside of the show."
All shows become families; this one has become a dynasty. Cast members have left and come back, borne children, married one another. Tams have grown up, and their younger siblings have become Tams.
 
'Here We Go Again'
It is nearing 2 p.m.: showtime. Gradually actors wander onto the stage to stretch and chat before the curtain goes up. Mr. Dobrow, the stage manager, stands at his podium in front of a script with marked cues, puts on his headset and announces in low tones: "We're at places. Places, please."
Then he checks in with all the other departments on headsets: automation, carpentry, electronics, sound, his fellow stage managers, the house manager who monitors the audience. Robert Billig, the show's musical director, who is conducting today and visible on backstage infrared monitors, reports on the number of substitutes in his orchestra, so the sound man knows what to expect. "Count is 12," Mr. Billig says of the subs. "One cello, two violins, an oboe, Asian flute. . . ."
Michael Harris, the house manager, reports, "House is ready."
Mr. Douglas, the propertyman, says, "Here we go again."
The show begins in Saigon, 1975, with a sequence the crew has come to refer to as "Dreamland," in which Kim and Chris meet for the first time in a nightclub. Then the show moves to Kim's hut (Kim 1 Bed), then on to Ho Chi Minh City, 1978.
The actors onstage look sharp, as if they were performing these songs and dances for the first time. But keeping it fresh is a challenge, especially for those who have been with the show the longest.
"Sometimes it's near impossible," said Alan Ariano, an original member of the ensemble. "I blank out sometimes and go on automatic: 'O.K., did I do the laundry?' You catch yourself, have to snap yourself out of it."
 
A Gold Mine for Asians
Mr. Ariano said he had supplemented his "Miss Saigon" life with a photography business, shooting theatrical head shots, and more recently with a degree in computer graphics. Knowing that no show lasts forever, and that there may not be another one immediately to follow, he said he wanted something to fall back on. "What's next for me I don't know," he said. "The nature of this business is job insecurity."
The business is doubly insecure for Asian actors, who say they must rely on productions like "The King and I" and "M. Butterfly" to get work. In this light "Miss Saigon" has been something of a gold mine, employing actors of Filipino, Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese and Hawaiian descent as well as black and Hispanic performers. "Both the professional and the public view of minority casting, nontraditional casting, colorblind casting has taken a terrific leap forward," said Alan Wasser, the show's general manager.
Mr. Ariano and Francis J. Cruz, two original cast members, attended the same high school in Chula Vista, Calif. "We've been part of an elite group that's been able to work" in the theater, Mr. Ariano said. "I don't take that for granted."
At intermission the crew prepares for the top of Act II, flying all the scenery from Act I up on the chain hoists, bringing down the Bangkok units. The act opens at a conference in the United States, 1978. Then it moves to Bangkok. Then it flashes back to Saigon when Kim remembers the American evacuation. In other words, the Nightmare.
The helicopter is the sum of six separate automated effects. The boom arm can swing from side to side; the cab can pitch up and down, move side to side and rotate; the rotor on top is a nylon rope with a rubber ball on the end that is ejected, creating the illusion of a spinning blade. At the controls is Virgil, a robot whose head turns as the helicopter lands.
When the chopper settles on the helipad, it is up to Ms. Buxbaum, one of the stage managers, to signal the live co-pilot (hidden on the pad) to come through the helicopter, motioning the rest of the soldiers to climb aboard. The 13 men who scramble into the helicopter actually drop into the hollow box of the pad, lined with two benches, handing off their rifles to a prop man as they descend. Ms. Buxbaum holds a flashlight in her mouth to light their way.
Then Ms. Buxbaum reports, "All clear" into her headset, and the helicopter rises into the eaves. "It's really cool to be onstage when the helicopter is coming down," said Eva Schegulla, Kim's dresser. "After four years I still get a kick out of it every day."
Usually this all goes smoothly. But there have been exceptions. Like the time the helicopter didn't take off. Fortunately the automation guys were able to run the machinery from a dial on the encoder, as opposed to going through the computer, controlling each effect individually. But there have been times when the helicopter didn't work at all, and for such times there is Plan B, which essentially amounts to blinding the audience with light and adding a lot of smoke. Remarkably, audiences who have experienced Plan B have apparently found it satisfying. "They think they've seen something," Mr. Dobrow said.
Initially Mr. Hytner, the director, did not think the helicopter was at all essential, though he now says he is glad it is there. "I thought, 'Oh, we don't need this,' " he recalled. "But it's not necessarily about what you need."
Once the impact of the helicopter has receded, the show returns to its human drama, as Kim encounters Chris's wife in a hotel room. Downstairs in the green room, members of the cast settle in for the matinee ritual of "Asian Treat."
It started about 10 years ago when a dresser began bringing fruit and drinks for the male cast members she attended to. This mushroomed into an exclusive group of about 14 members who take turns bringing snacks for the matinees. Only members can partake. A sign nearby explains the rules of the Asian Food Treat Club: "Anyone is welcome to be part of the club after having contributed to the festivities and having passed the requirements specified by the A.F.T.C. board of directors at the time of one's application -- just kidding!"
Today the menu includes crackers, brie and dip, and the members, from the cast and crew, dive in while the non-members eye the spread hungrily from the sidelines.
 
A New Job
In the hair room, John James, who has been hair supervisor for seven years, is putting the female cast members into their blond wigs for the "American Dream" number. Sparkly in their glittering fringe and white fishnet stockings, the women congratulate Lisa Yuen, an ensemble member, on her new job: she will be leaving "Miss Saigon" to join the road company of "The Scarlet Pimpernel."
This news is clearly bittersweet; cast members know they need to figure out what to do next, and those landing jobs before the end of the run feel lucky. But it also offers a sobering reminder to the actors who remain that the end is near. On Nov. 2, a gala featuring "Miss Saigon" alumni will celebrate the show's 4,000th performance. The New Year's Eve show will be the last.
"They're happy that she got another job, but sad that she won't be there when it ends," said Mr. James. "You can just feel that people are pulling away emotionally, trying to find what to do next and where to go next. Is there life after 'Saigon'?"
Mr. James said he was concerned about the future, too. "I'm a little worried," he said. "This is the first time I've ever had to face unemployment."
Onstage the "American Dream" number has its usual buoyant effect on the audience, particularly because of the Cadillac -- carrying a woman in a Statue of Liberty crown that lights up -- which seems to float downstage on a cloud (read: dry ice). Mr. Maltby, who collaborated on the lyrics, said that this showstopping number goes to the heart of the play.
 
On to Heartbreak
"Vietnam was a turning point in America's estimation of itself, and the American dream, which hovers over the whole show, is what was at stake," he said. "America has never believed in the American dream after that event. Prior to that we were always the good guys, and we always won. Suddenly we were the bad guys doing terrible things, and, worse than that, John Wayne didn't come riding over the hill to save the day.
"The show in its essence is about that, about the American inability to make the leap to Vietnam, to understand it and to ultimately help."
Today's matinee moves to its heartbreaking conclusion, accompanied by surging notes from the orchestra. Kitschy perhaps, but some in the audience are crying. The cast comes on for its curtain call, bowing between the billow and the bang of the heavy red velvet curtain as it rises and falls. "I think they loved it," one actor quips as she comes offstage, "and we should do it again, tonight."
Just two and half hours later -- the show runs more than two and a half hours with intermission -- all of these people will be back to do it all over again, almost exactly as they did it before. For them this is work: what they wake up and do every day except Sunday, sometimes twice a day, to feed their families, afford vacations, pay the rent. They casually head out the stage door to their dinner breaks, showing no trace of having weathered something wrenching.
The audience, on the other hand, emerges dazed, the way people do coming out of a movie in the middle of the afternoon, taking a moment to recover and re-enter their real lives, blinking in the sunlight.
 
Copter Landings
"Miss Saigon" is at the Broadway Theater, 1681 Broadway, at 53rd Street, (212) 239-6200. Performances are Mondays, Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays at 8 p.m.; Wednesdays and Saturdays at 2 and 8 p.m. Through Dec. 31. Tickets: $20 to $85 (last week of performances, $47.50 to $90).

HEADLINE: Little Action Expected From Report on Auto Fuel Use

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 24

 BODY:
A government report to be released as soon as Friday reaches few conclusions about the effects of tightening federal fuel-economy regulations for automobiles, making it virtually certain that the regulations will not be changed by Congress before the end of this year.
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican who is the chairman of the Commerce Committee, ordered the report from the General Accounting Office of Congress late last spring, when high gasoline prices were prompting outrage among motorists. But while gasoline prices are rising again now as crude oil prices increase, enthusiasm for tighter rules has faded in Congress since a Senate compromise this summer called for the National Academy of Sciences to perform a more thorough yearlong review of the issue. 
 A Commerce Committee aide who insisted on anonymity said that the committee was virtually certain not to hold a hearing this autumn on gas mileage standards, and would wait instead for the more complete report from the National Academy of Sciences. The committee is considering, however, a hearing this autumn on global warming, to which gasoline combustion by automobiles is a big contributor, the aide said.
Senator McCain has been sent a memorandum about the General Accounting Office report but has not seen the document itself, and has not had time to discuss it with his staff, the aide added.
Current fuel-economy regulations require each automaker to manufacture cars with an average gas mileage of 27.5 miles a gallon and light trucks -- a category encompassing sport utility vehicles, vans and pickup trucks -- that get an average of 20.7 miles a gallon. The Republican majorities in the House and Senate have used the Transportation Department's annual budget to bar regulators since 1995 from raising either standard. But the more lenient standard for light trucks was the object of particular scrutiny in Congress earlier this year.
The General Accounting Office report concludes that tighter standards would reduce gasoline consumption and emissions of gases that contribute to global warming, but would have an unclear effect on safety.
Cars and light trucks account for one-sixth of the emissions of global-warming gases in the United States, which in turn accounts for a quarter of the world's emissions, the report found, adding that for the cars and light trucks alone, "This amount exceeds the total greenhouse gas emissions of all but a few countries."
The more gasoline that an automobile burns, the more such gases it emits. Average gas mileage has fallen 8 percent in the United States since a peak of 25.9 miles a gallon in the 1988 model year, as many motorists have switched to light trucks from cars, the report said.
The safety effects of raising standards would depend on how quickly new rules were phased in, the report noted. A rapid increase in standards might prompt automakers to build many small, lightweight, less-safe vehicles to improve their averages, while a slower increase might cause automakers to adopt more efficient technologies instead, it said.
Gloria Bergquist, a spokeswoman for the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, a trade group, said that automakers want fuel-economy rules eliminated, not tightened.
A separate study by Friends of the Earth, an environmental group, estimates that automakers avoided $10.2 billion in gas-guzzler taxes in the 1999 model year alone because light trucks are exempt from the tax. The tax penalizes cars based on the extent to which their fuel-economy falls below 22.5 miles a gallon, with fines of up to $7,700 for a few high-performance sports cars that get as poor mileage as the largest pickup trucks and sport utility vehicles.
Friends of the Earth assumed that if the gas-guzzler tax were applied to light trucks, the tax would still be collected for vehicles getting less than 22.5 miles a gallon. Ms. Bergquist said that Friends of the Earth was wrong to ignore the difference in fuel-economy standards between cars and light trucks in calculating the taxes not paid. The auto industry opposes applying the tax to light trucks in any case, she said.

HEADLINE: Turkey Assails a Revered Islamic Moderate

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS FRANTZ 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Onur Elgin, a Turkish teenager, has no doubts about why he spent his summer vacation studying physics. In fluent English, he explains that he wants to succeed for his school, his country and the world.
Onur's high school, Fatih College, is part of a prospering Islamic community associated with Fetullah Gulen, a 62-year-old religious leader who lives in Pennsylvania. In addition to hundreds of schools in Turkey, the Balkans and Central Asia, the loose-knit brotherhood runs a television channel, a radio station, an advertising agency, a daily newspaper and a bank, all pro-Islamic and all centered in Istanbul. 
 Though little known in the United States, for many years Mr. Gulen was an unofficial ambassador for Turkey who promoted a moderate brand of Islam. He preached tolerance, meeting with Pope John Paul II and other religious and political leaders, among them Turkey's prime ministers and presidents.
But this month, after a yearlong inquiry, a state security court issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Gulen. A prosecutor has accused him of inciting his followers to plot the overthrow of Turkey's secular government, a crime punishable by death. The authorities have not tried to extradite Mr. Gulen, but the warrant sent a chill through his circle of admirers and raised anxieties among liberals who are not associated with his movement.
At the same time, the government has been involved in a highly public dispute over its attempt to fire thousands of civil servants suspected of ties to pro-Islamic or separatist groups. Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit sought the authority for the dismissals through a governmental decree, but the president, Ahmet Necdet Sezer, has twice refused to sign the measure into law. Mr. Sezer argues that the authority can be created only by Parliament. The government agreed today to submit the matter to Parliament in the fall.
The deadlock has led to some calls for the resignation of Mr. Sezer, who took office in May. It has also contributed to the almost continuous tension between hard-line backers of the country's secular order and people who advocate more tolerance of religious views and free speech.
In a written response to questions from The New York Times, Mr. Gulen recently broke a year of public silence about the accusations against him. He described the charges as fabrications by a "marginal but influential group that wields considerable power in political circles."
He said he was not seeking to establish an Islamic regime but did support efforts to ensure that the government treated ethnic and ideological differences as a cultural mosaic, not a reason for discrimination.
"Standards of democracy and justice must be elevated to the level of our contemporaries in the West," said Mr. Gulen, who has been receiving medical care in the United States for the past year and said his health prevented his return to Turkey.
Turkey's military leaders have long regarded Mr. Gulen as a potential threat to the state. Those fears seemed confirmed a year ago when television stations broadcast excerpts from videocassettes in which he seemed to urge his followers to "patiently and secretly" infiltrate the government.
Mr. Gulen said his words had been taken out of context, and some altered. He said he had counseled patience to followers faced with corrupt civil servants and administrators intolerant of workers who were practicing Muslims.
"Statements and words were picked with tweezers and montaged to serve the purposes of whoever was behind this," he said.
Mr. Gulen's explanations are unlikely to satisfy the secular hard-liners who see themselves as the guardians of modern Turkey, which was founded in 1923 by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk. For them, the businesses and schools run by his followers sow the seeds of an Islamic regime.
Some moderate Turks see such Islamic-oriented schools and businesses as an attempt to fill a gap left by government policies and discrimination. A study by the private Turkish Economic and Social Studies Foundation found that these Islamic groups appeal not only to the poor but also to strict Muslims who often feel excluded from the mainstream.
The Gulen-oriented schools teach only government-approved religious instruction, in Turkish and English. Tuition payments are several thousand dollars a year, and students face rigorous academic challenges.
"Strategically speaking, the schools are something that should be supported by the state because you have a Turkish presence in these countries," said Ozdem Sanberk, director of the Economic and Social Studies Foundation.
At Fatih school outside Istanbul, the young Mr. Elgin, 16, has no intention of overthrowing the state. His sole goal right now is learning enough physics to compete on the Turkish national academic team.

HEADLINE: Plant Orders For Big Items Have Largest Decline Ever

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
Factory orders for aircraft, electrical equipment and other durable goods showed their largest decline on record in July, government figures showed today, suggesting manufacturers may scale back production in the months ahead as the economy slows.
Orders for big-ticket items plunged 12.4 percent last month, more than reversing a June increase of 9.5 percent, the Commerce Department said. Excluding transportation equipment, orders fell 4.8 percent in July after rising 0.5 percent the month before. 
 "We are seeing more moderate growth," said Gary Thayer, chief economist at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. Rising concern based on the June statistics that "the economy would pick up again isn't true," he said.
Signs of a slowdown in manufacturing -- along with a fourth consecutive weekly increase in jobless claims -- indicate less growth and less threat of accelerating inflation.
"This is exactly what the Federal Reserve wanted to achieve" in raising interest rates six times since June 1999, said Ken Mayland, president of ClearView Economics L.L.C. in Pepper Pike, Ohio. Fed policy makers kept the rate on overnight loans between banks at 6.5 percent on Tuesday, citing slower growth and the benefits of rising worker productivity.
Manufacturing accounts for about a fifth of the nation's total economic production, employing millions of workers. A decline in orders -- usually as a result of a falloff in demand from consumers and businesses -- can cause factories to slow production.
Still, manufacturers are hardly suffering from widespread weakness in demand. Compared with figures in the month a year earlier, the value of newly ordered goods was 4.9 percent higher in July. What is more, July's drop in orders excluding transportation equipment was only the second this year.
And unfilled orders, a gauge of backlogs and whether manufacturers are able to supply goods quickly, fell just 0.3 percent last month after a 4.6 percent surge in June. Unfilled orders were 12 percent higher than they were in July of last year.
"As long as backlogs have to be worked off, production will remain solid," said Joel Naroff, president of Naroff Economic Advisors in Holland, Pa.
Analysts had expected a 7 percent drop in July orders after a previously reported 9.7 percent gain in orders for June. June's increase was the largest since a 13.9 percent surge in July 1991.
The Labor Department said in a separate report today that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits rose 4,000 last week, to 314,000.

HEADLINE: Fed Unanimous in June Vote

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 24

 BODY:
When the Federal Reserve Board's interest rate committee agreed to leave rates unchanged in June, the decision was unanimous, but many members said they might have to increase rates in the future to curb inflation, according to minutes of the meeting, which were released today.
The minutes from the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee meeting of June 27 and 28 said Fed officials saw little risk in keeping rates steady but disagreed over the prospects for inflation. 
 "Many committee members noted that, based on the currently available information, additional firming of policy could well be needed at some point," the minutes said, "though a number also expressed the opinion that less tightening probably would be required than they had thought at the time of the May meeting."
The members said they did not want to leave the impression that further policy tightening was "an unlikely prospect," but they saw only a "remote" chance that inflation would increase appreciably in the near future.
The committee met again on Tuesday and left interest rates unchanged. The Fed, however, warned that with a scarcity of workers and with demand exceeding the nation's ability to produce, there was still a risk inflation could harm the record economic expansion, now in its 10th year. The Fed has raised rates six times since June 1999 to keep inflation at bay.
At their meeting in June, Fed officials differed on inflation, but there was general concern that higher energy costs were leaking into other areas of the economy.
Some members noted that because the pool of available workers was so low, companies might raise prices to offset the higher wages and benefits they would need to pay to retain and hire workers.
Some, however, remained confident that huge gains in productivity would keep costs in check.
Committee members said tentative signs of slowing consumer demand, coupled with the strong probability that much of the effect of the recent interest rate increases had not trickled into the general economy, gave the Fed room to watch and wait.

HEADLINE: A New Kind of Neighbor

BYLINE: By Vicente Fox; Vicente Fox, president-elect of Mexico, will take office on Dec. 1.

 BODY:
The elections of July 2 brought the end of 71 years of virtual one-party rule and inaugurated my country's first experience in a democratic rotation of power. Mexico's electoral institutions, built over several rounds of gradual reform, proved their maturity and reliability. The smoothness of our transition, the civility shown by all the political actors and the statesmanship demonstrated by president Ernesto Zedillo are all reflections of our enormous transformation.
That transformation frames the message I have brought this week to President Clinton and the candidates George W. Bush and Al Gore. The full advent of democracy will complement our economic reforms, bring them to full fruition and better distribute their benefits. The fight against corruption, accountability of public officials, the rule of law and security for all citizens will provide the assurances that Mexico's partners are expecting. These are the issues Mexicans strongly raised during the presidential campaign, and they are also at the root of some doubts our friends abroad -- investors, creditors, tourists -- have harbored. My first priority after taking office will be to confront these challenges forthrightly. 
 I will also attempt to redress the age-old poverty and inequality that, despite economic gains in several regions, still plague too many Mexicans. We must accelerate economic growth, promote local and regional development and above all ensure better distribution of income. Strengthening civil society, democratizing the labor movement, giving women a greater voice and defending minorities are all steps in this direction.
As we undertake these changes, we will also engage our neighbors and partners in the North American Free Trade Agreement. Nafta and the current state of relations with the United States have been good for Mexico, and we can build on what has already been achieved. Within 25 years we envision a North American area of shared prosperity, where goods, services, capital and people can move more freely across borders.
My administration will seek to "deepen" Nafta in several ways. The first involves expanding the resources and mandate of the North American Development Bank, enabling it to finance infrastructure projects in Mexico; the second, setting up North American public and private regional funds to invest in human capital in the poor areas of Mexico where most migrants to the United States come from. Both would combat poverty and discourage undocumented immigration.
Years from now, we visualize a more ambitious economic integration as we actively pursue the narrowing of wage differentials among Mexico, the United States and Canada. In the meantime, negotiations should begin with a view toward providing humane working conditions for Mexicans already in the United States, and for exploring new and imaginative mechanisms to organize and regulate future flows. These should include institutional guarantees of the human and civil rights of Mexicans and reduction of tensions along the border. The violent deaths of my countrymen on the border are simply intolerable.
Finally, I believe that the changes wrought in Mexico by the election will provide an impulse to greater effectiveness in the war on drugs. We need to stop the blame game. The drug trade is driven by both supply and demand and can only be dealt with through international cooperation. As a first step, we should eliminate the sources of gratuitous tension. The yearly ritual of United States certification of other countries' cooperation in drug enforcement strains our relationship and diverts valuable political and diplomatic resources. It should be replaced by an international mechanism to evaluate the efforts of all countries in the drug war.
Mexico is ready to do business with the United States. We want to maximize the "democracy bonus" of good feeling generated across the world by our July 2 elections, in order to significantly increase direct foreign investment in our country and to engage Washington in bold negotiations.
The onset of democracy in Mexico provides the best chance in a generation to build a forward-looking agenda that moves beyond stale debates. I am sure we can set this process in motion during my meetings this week and move ahead decisively early next year, when both our countries begin the 21st century with new administrations.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Flat in Reaction to Drop in Durable Goods Orders

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Bond prices were flat yesterday after the government reported a larger-than-expected drop in orders for durable goods in July, suggesting that the Federal Reserve may hold off raising interest rates again this year.
By late in the day, the price of the 10-year note rose 1/32, to 105 9/32, and its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.71 percent from 5.72 percent on Wednesday. The 30-year bond rose 8/32, to 108 16/32. Its yield fell to 5.66 percent from 5.67 percent. 
 The 12.4 percent plunge in durable goods orders last month was the largest on record and surpassed economists' expectations.
Maury N. Harris, chief economist at PaineWebbber, said the "orders data are consistent with our forecast for G.D.P. growth to slow in the third quarter to 3.3 percent at an annual rate after 5.2 percent growth in the second quarter." He said the numbers were consistent with forecasts that the Federal Open Market Committee, which next meets on Oct. 3, will remain on hold indefinitely. "Nevertheless, one should not overreact to the weakness in these numbers."
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Fleming Asset Management, said, "Signs of a moderating economy, coupled with faster productivity growth that is helping to suppress inflationary tendencies, has given the Fed some breathing room in its quest to maneuver the economy into a soft landing."
"Furthermore," Mr. Fine said, "the proximity of the presidential election makes it highly unlikely that any change in policy would be instituted at the Oct. 3 F.O.M.C. meeting. Thus if the Fed should deem additional tightening necessary, a clearly debatable point both inside and outside the F.O.M.C., the Nov. 15 meeting would appear to be the earliest conceivable date for further action."
While the Fed is still very sensitive to the potential for inflation in a vibrant economy with a 4 percent unemployment rate, Mr. Fine said, the Fed will remain on hold for an extended period of time unless economic growth picks up or inflationary pressures become threatening or both. He says neither appears imminent.
With the Fed expected to adhere to an unchanged monetary policy, bonds are likely to trade in a range, Mr. Fine said.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of the fixed-income department at the J. W. Genesis Financial Corporation in Boca Raton, Fla., also saw the bond market's lack of reaction to yesterday's data as a sign that it is trading well ahead of itself.
"I think this economic slowdown is not as strong as what Treasury rates are telling us," he said. "You just can't put a pen to paper to justify the current rates."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
Up From the Ashes of a Cuban Cigar Case

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
TWO years ago, on a sultry August morning, Ken Aretsky was playing golf in Southampton and riding high indeed. That regrettable public unpleasantness at the "21" Club was long behind him (more about that later). He was loving his life as the doting father of two small children (more about that later, too). And he was basking in critical accolades for having created two successful new Manhattan restaurants, Patroon and Butterfield 81 (much, much more about that later, as well).
That's when the phone call came: the United States government was charging him with violating the Trading With the Enemy Act. Such a transgression can be a felony punishable by 10 years in prison and a fine of $100,000. 
 Federal agents armed with search warrants had seized dozens of boxes of cigars from the upstairs cigar bar of Patroon, Mr. Aretsky's three-star restaurant at 160 East 46th Street. The next day Mr. Aretsky and his cigar bar manager stood in federal court, accused of buying and selling cigars made in Cuba.
In a stogie-crazed city afire with aficionados overwhelmed by an abundance of bootleg Cuban Cohibas and Montecristos, cigar worshipers bristled at the news.
Indeed, cigarophiles loudly contended that the arrest was a publicity stunt. For though the United States had imposed a trade embargo on Cuba in the early 1960's, for decades American cigar smokers had hidden Cuban stogies in their luggage and had had cigars mailed to them from London tobacconists.
But officials said they were following up on a violation of federal law. Customs agents had tracked a large illegal shipment of Cuban cigars to a house in Connecticut. A raid there had revealed a list of clients that included Mr. Aretsky, his manager and five others, who were arrested.
"It was devastating," said Mr. Aretsky, now 59, in his first interview since that time. "I was shocked. I suppose some people think that notoriety is cool, but I didn't, and neither did my family. It was rough for them. I worried about the future of my business."
Mr. Aretsky had never had a brush with the law before. He grew up at 504 Grand Street on the Lower East Side, took over his father's seltzer-gas supply business, sold it, then made a 1972 success of his first restaurant, Truman's, in Roslyn, N.Y.
After a stint in Manhattan as a stockbroker (one co-worker was the future domestic diva Martha Stewart) he opened the thriving Upper East Side saloon, Oren & Aretsky. He followed that with Arcadia at 21 East 62nd Street, which flourished until the lease ran out in 1997.
In 1987, Mr. Aretsky was asked to turn around that power-lunch dinosaur, the "21" Club. He amended the food and attracted a devoted, less geriatric following. His genial presence was marked by his signature wardrobe, for which the word "dapper" is hardly dapper enough.
BUT after eight years at the helm, "I still had no equity position in the restaurant," he said, adding that he was fired in 1995 after a dispute with the owners. He sued for breach of contract, but says the case is in limbo because the company that hired him filed for bankruptcy last year.
Mr. Aretsky jumped back on the horse immediately by opening an American bistro, Butterfield 81, then opened his competitor to "21," Patroon, which won three stars from The New York Times, in 1996 and again in 1998.
By then Mr. Aretsky was enjoying mature fatherhood. He and his third wife, Diana Lyne, a former Tiffany & Company senior vice president who is a consultant there, had two children, Grace and Eugene, now 7 and 6. (He has two grown children from his first marriage.)
And then federal agents came through the door. Mr. Aretsky acknowledged that "Cubans were sold here with my knowledge," he said on a recent afternoon in the former cigar bar, now a banquet space.
"Clearly we did something wrong and were punished accordingly," Mr. Aretsky said. The United States attorney's office in Manhattan says he ultimately pleaded guilty to two misdemeanors and paid a $5,000 fine. He was sentenced to serve 200 hours of community service.
What Mr. Aretsky never anticipated was that he would become so passionate about his court obligation, as he journeyed to the city's inner-city high schools, mentoring students and working with teachers.
He is doing so through the auspices of a 10-year-old nonprofit group called C-Cap, which promotes restaurant careers among inner-city students. "I'm trying to get these kids interested in working as line cooks and pastry chefs and managers," Mr. Aretsky said. "There aren't enough bodies to fill all these jobs, and restaurants need these kids' tremendous energy."
Mr. Aretsky's supervisor, Richard Grausman, founder and president of C-Cap, said, "Ken has put his whole heart into this," referring to the group that reaches out to 2,200 students a year. "Ken has been wonderful with the kids and the teachers."
And now, this August, Mr. Aretsky is about to embark on a new multimillion-dollar restaurant venture on the Upper East Side. "It'll be a fabulous neighborhood American brasserie," he said, name and location to be revealed "imminently."
What of his missionary work with students? "It's a new world to me, something I knew nothing about," he said. "I hope to keep involved with these kids for the rest of my life."

HEADLINE: Hedge Fund Founder Charged With Defrauding Its Investors

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
Michael W. Berger, a hedge fund manager, was charged yesterday with defrauding 300 people who invested about $575 million in his fund.
Mr. Berger was charged with securities fraud and fraud under the Investment Advisers Act. He pleaded not guilty and was released on bail of $75,000 cash and a $100,000 bond secured by his home in the Hamptons. 
 Mr. Berger, an Austrian citizen, was also required to surrender his passport. His attorney, Sara Mogulescu, declined to comment.
Mr. Berger, 28, was the manager of the Manhattan Investment Fund Ltd., which bet that Internet and high technology stocks would decline at a time that they rose.
Federal prosecutors from the United States attorney's office in Manhattan said that Mr. Berger reported annual fund earnings as high as 27.4 percent in 1997, when his company lost about $400 million.
Prosecutors charge that Mr. Berger hid the losses from investors and from auditors by creating fake financial records and passing them off as the fund's actual returns. When auditors from the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche asked for additional records to confirm Mr. Berger's reports for 1999, prosecutors said, Mr. Berger fired them.
Earlier this year the Securities and Exchange Commission sued Mr. Berger and his management company for overstating the fund's holdings and using misleading account statements to raise more than $350 million from investors since 1996.
The S.E.C. froze the assets of the fund and the court appointed a receiver to review the figures. Peter H. Bresnan, the S.E.C.'s assistant chief litigation counsel, said when the fund was frozen about $35 million remained. Some investors had removed about $140 million, leaving overall losses of about $400 million, he said.
Mr. Bresnan said that for the most part the fund did not attract small investors. "These were institutions and high-net-worth individuals predominantly from outside the United States," he said.
According to prosecutors, investors had to contribute at least $250,000 to participate in the fund.
Mr. Berger opened his hedge fund in August 1995, and began to market it overseas in April 1996. Prosecutors said that he marketed the fund by predicting downturns in certain areas of the stock market; for example, in a March 1998, letter to investors, Mr. Berger predicted that "economic momentum should deteriorate." He said the most vulnerable sectors included the Internet, telecommunications and drugstores.
Prosecutors charged that the strategy resulted in tremendous losses when the value of these stocks increased. But they said that Mr. Berger was able to conceal the growing losses, and continued to attract new investors, by falsifying the fund records. According to prosecutors, the hedge fund maintained an account with Financial Asset Management, although the fund's assets were held by Bear Stearns Securities, which served as the clearing broker.
Beginning in September 1996, prosecutors charged, Mr. Berger began to falsify statements that were passed along to investors by the fund administrators.
According to the charges filed with the court, Mr. Berger used statements from Bear Stearns as a template, but changed the heading to Financial Asset Management. They said Mr. Berger altered the fake statements and sent them to the fund administrator. The administrator also received statements from Bear Stearns that accurately reflected the fund's performance, prosecutors said. But they said that Mr. Berger told the administrator to disregard the Bear Stearns statements because they only represented a small portion of the fund's actual holdings.
Mr. Berger wrote a monthly letter to investors that the administrator distributed along with the statements. In his March 10, 1999, letter, prosecutors said, Mr. Berger spoke of his "bearish outlook towards the market," and noted that although the market had hit a new high "an exhaustion point has been reached."
Prosecutors said Mr. Berger used the same techniques to fool the fund's auditors. They said when auditors for Deloitte & Touche requested more documentation, Mr. Berger fired them on Jan. 6 and the accounting firm withdrew its annual audit opinions for 1996 through 1998.

HEADLINE: 'Buyers' Clubs' for Medical Services Crop Up

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
A variety of new companies are beginning to offer below-market prices on prescription drugs and services like doctor, dental and eye care and medical tests.
Like buyers' discount clubs such as Costco or Sam's Club, the new companies attract people looking for a better price, in this case because they have no health insurance or because their health insurance does not cover the treatments they want. 
 Individual patients sign up, often on the Internet, and agree to pay for medical services with cash or a debit or credit card. They usually pay a small annual membership fee, and get an identification card that is accepted by a network of doctors, drugstores or other health care providers.
The drugstores and other providers join the plans -- and accept the lower prices -- to reach more customers. And doctors, eager to avoid payment delays and restrictions when patients are using insurance, accept reduced fees comparable to those they receive from managed care companies.
Because the services are so new, there are no firm statistics on how many people have signed up, or how many thousands of doctors are involved. But many self-employed people with little or no insurance find the new discounters particularly useful.
Adria Firestone, a mezzo-soprano who lives in Jersey City, said her performers' union health plan became so expensive she could no longer afford full coverage. So when she needed bifocal contact lenses before a concert in Italy, she showed her card from a company called Medisavers to a participating Manhattan optometrist. As a Medisavers member, she paid $306.68 instead of the $475 retail price.
David Wallen, a freelance entertainment writer in Los Angeles, saw a Web site operated by a company called HealthAllies soon after it began offering doctor's services last May. There was no charge to sign up. "They negotiated rates for me with the internist and eye-ear-throat doctor I was already seeing," he said. "It saved me half on my medical bills. It's great for people without health insurance."
Patients with insurance are using the new services as well. Patients trying to see a doctor outside their managed care network, or looking for a medical service their insurance does not cover, like acupuncture or cosmetic surgery, may now be able to find a lower price.
"We are seeing a real phenomenon," said Gail Wilensky, a health care economist and former White House official. "People are going to be able to shop and choose" from a variety of medical services including "individual providers and services they want."
The new programs are not specifically aimed at people of limited means who do not qualify for Medicaid, those often referred to as the working poor. The programs can stretch the buying power of people who can afford to pay for medical care -- including the one in 10 uninsured people who earn $50,000 a year or more.
Making discounts on health care widely available "is clearly a method for making the market work better," said Judith Lave, a professor of health economics at the University of Pittsburgh. "We are clearly better off with them than without them." But she said the services would mainly attract patients who were relatively well off, so the discounts would not solve "our macro problem" -- the 45 million people without health insurance.
Limited alternatives to employer-sponsored medical plans have existed for some time. AARP, formerly the American Association of Retired Persons, has long had a mail-order pharmacy for its members, for example. But the new companies can help people who do not have an employer or an organization to negotiate the lower discounts that are typically provided to groups.
The most recent, HealthMarket, a start-up in Wilton, Conn., led by Stephen F. Wiggins, the former chief executive of Oxford Health Plans, began listing doctors on its Web site in late July and plans to add hospitals, dental and vision care and alternative medicine next month.
Other small companies starting up or expanding discount medical services include HealthAllies, based in Glendale, Calif.; MedAdvantage in Southfield, Mich.; AmeriPlanUSA in Dallas; and Medisavers, which also offers health plans to a number of New York unions.
There are larger companies entering the business as well. In June, the Reader's Digest Association joined with Medco, a subsidiary of Merck & Company, to advertise drugstore discount cards and mail service to 50 million customers of Digest magazines, books and records, and says it may eventually offer other medical services as well.
People who join YourxPlan, the Reader's Digest-Medco program, pay $25 a year, or $40 for a family, to get promised savings averaging 18 percent on brand-name drugs by mail order, and 11 percent at 40,000 participating pharmacies. Members can also check on prices or order refills on the Internet.
Thomas O. Ryder, chairman of the Digest, said it started the business after conducting a survey of customers of its magazines, books and records. "We discovered that around 20 million did not have drug coverage," he said.
Other people find the new services through professional organizations. Melissa Wahl, executive director of the National Association for Female Executives, said the organization was recommending HealthAllies to its 135,000 members, many of whom run small businesses with limited insurance benefits.
Most of the new medical service companies hope to grow swiftly if the tight employment market eases, and if big companies begin to remodel health benefits the way they did when they replaced pensions with 401(k) plans. If companies make that change, employees would receive a set amount for their health-care needs instead of the relatively open-ended coverage they have now, and they would spend their own money if their costs exceeded the set amount.
Already, employees are shouldering more of their health care costs. The percentage of employees with fully paid health coverage has dropped sharply under managed care. In 1998, 26.6 percent of Americans had fully paid care, compared to 45.5 percent in 1983, said James L. Medoff, a Harvard University economist who studied the trend for the Center for National Policy, a nonprofit research organization.
Even the covered services in managed care are disappointing many patients. "Health plans have so frustrated consumers that some of them are ready to reach in their pocket and spend money," said Karen Donelan, a public opinion expert at the Harvard School of Public Health.
Bill McGahan, a health care industries investment banker at UBS Warburg said: "Everybody hates the current system. Employers don't like it; physicians don't like it; employees don't like it."
Indeed, out-of-pocket spending on health care services is exploding, especially for drugs. Americans spent $199.5 billion of their own money on health care in 1998, by the government's latest count, up 38 percent since 1990.
Of that amount, consumers spend $30 billion annually on alternative medical treatments like acupuncture, said Prof. Regina Herzlinger, a health care expert at the Harvard Business School. Professor Donelan said that a recent survey by Harris Interactive found that 15 to 20 percent of Americans who have health insurance were already spending their money for extras.
To capture some of that spending, the online discount health plans offer services and products that many health plans do not cover, including expensive, heavily advertised drugs like Claritin for allergies, life-style products like Viagra for male impotence, and laser surgery to correct nearsightedness.
Express Scripts said it was adding more than 500 members each week to several new drug card programs it started this summer with groups like Seniority America, which sells services to people over 50.
As with much of what is available on the Web, the information provided by the new medical companies is not always screened for reliability or accuracy. The Web sites provide only limited information about the doctors in their programs, and many rely on outside organizations that have been approved by the National Committee for Quality Assurance to vet doctors' credentials.
"Consumers on their own looking for quality information about doctors are at a real disadvantage," said Barry Scholl, a spokesman for the quality assurance committee, whose main function is to set standards and accredit managed care plans. Yesterday, legislation in California that would have regulated the discount companies was defeated. Consumer advocates and some medical groups said the law would have been too lax.
At HealthAllies.com, the listings on doctors include their addresses, fees, the number of patients they see each day, and whether they are board certified in their specialties. The company promises savings of "10 to 50 percent on the things insurance doesn't cover."
On HealthMarket, Mr. Wiggins's start-up, consumers can get information, including professional profiles of doctors, fees and full charges for dozens of treatments. Individuals pay $29 a year, $49 for families, plus a transaction fee for each service.
Doctors said they liked the prompt frustration-free payments and increased patient flow. Dr. Stephen B. Meisel, a radiologist who is chief executive of Medfocus, a national chain of 1,800 medical imaging centers, said the services were "a great idea."
"When we sign up with insurance companies or employers," he said, "we give them a good value because they provide patient volume. We offer the same range of fees for HealthAllies.com. The patients are getting a big break." For example, he said, a magnetic resonance imaging scan, or M.R.I., in New York City would cost "50 percent off the retail price."

HEADLINE: ON BASEBALL;
Showalter Is Feeling Arizona Heat

BYLINE: By Murray Chass 

 BODY:
The Arizona Diamondbacks didn't know when they were well off. They certainly didn't know their place. Win a division championship in their second season of existence, will they? Yeah, we'll teach those uppity Southwesterners.
The Diamondbacks come to Shea Stadium tonight for a three-game series with the Mets, two and a half games from the spot they held in the National League West at the end of last season and four and a half games behind the Mets in the wild-card race. They arrive not only in danger of failing to repeat their postseason visit but also surrounded by questions about their manager's future and their own. 
 "We're fighting off the wolves," Jerry Colangelo, the team's managing partner, said yesterday.
The wolves, in this instance, have press passes, the kind that entitle a holder to call for the dismissal of a manager. Manager Buck Showalter has his critics, but he is also the same fellow who presided over the fastest-ever division championship.
"I've chosen to take the high ground," Showalter said in a telephone interview, discussing the criticism he has recently endured. "I have a pretty good idea of what the agenda was there. I don't think it's worthwhile to address it. It happens to everybody. It's part of the job description. I live with it."
Showalter's managerial style invites scrutiny; it's easy to criticize. But his insistence on controlling everything that goes on in the clubhouse is part of the intense attention he pays to details, a characteristic that endeared him to George Steinbrenner until they underwent a messy divorce following the 1995 season.
Showalter is old school. He has been criticized for having coaches tell Diamondbacks players not to talk to players on the other team during batting practice, but players once upon a time were fined for fraternizing with their opponents. Umpires would sit in the stands during batting practice and note the numbers of players from opposing teams who talked to each other. The numbers would go into the league offices, and fines would be levied.
This is a different era, in which players are buddies, they earn millions more than their managers and they think they should have the right to do what they want, just like children everywhere. The high cost of baseball in this era has also made winning a requirement for continued employment. Sometimes even people who don't have a dollar invested in a club feel free to tell the owner what to do.
"When I first got here, I saw criticism of Jerry," said Showalter, who has two years left on his seven-year contract. "I said to myself, if they go after him, it's going to happen to all of us. We live in a what-have-you-done-for-me-lately world. Your job as manager is to win championships. If you don't or you're not moving in that direction, you're going to get questions."
The Diamondbacks, despite injuries to key players, have only four fewer victories than they had in the same number of games last season, but the San Francisco Giants have six more victories, accounting for the teams' reversal in the standings.
The 1999 Diamondbacks won 100 games, 35 more than their expansion counterparts. It was the biggest improvement, one season to the next, in baseball history. The division championship came with it. Given the grumbling in the desert, it was too much too soon. Maybe the Diamondbacks' followers would have prefered the loveable-loser kind of expansion team, as the Mets were in the early 60's.
Colangelo spent freely on creating a contender. Now even his economics have come under scrutiny. Much was made recently of a loan the Diamondbacks secured, with the assistance of Major League Baseball. The loan was reported to be for $20 million, which Colangelo said was incorrect.
Whatever the amount, the Diamondbacks won't be filing for bankruptcy anytime soon.
"If you look at what's happening on the financial landscape," Colangelo said, "with banks merging and consolidating, with our banking relationship, we needed to restructure some debt. We had to move some money over. That's what we're talking about here."
Then he added, referring to the Marlins' decimated 1997 World Series winners: "This is not a Florida. We don't have a for-sale sign up. We'll be just fine."
But they will be finer if they can overtake the Mets for the wild card or the Giants for another division title. Injuries to key players and poor production from others have undermined the Diamondbacks' defense of their title. If they don't gain a postseason spot, will Showalter's job be in jeopardy?
"I don't dwell on those things," he said. "You do the best job you can do and be yourself. I have a lot of confidence in our organization and they do in me. You try to have a thick skin. It's a challenge managers have to overcome."
Colangelo was initially perceived as giving Showalter a lukewarm endorsement to continue as manager, but yesterday he said: "Buck and I are fine. Buck knows that he is my manager. We invested a lot of money in a contract with him. We believe in him. He's made a major contribution. Why should I be responsive to a speculative story and give the so-called vote of confidence? It's insulting to be put in that position. He's my manager until he isn't. He knows he's accountable like everyone else and he accepts that."

HEADLINE: Despite Soaring Prosperity, Poland Still Isn't Sure of Itself

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BIALA RAWSKA, Poland

 BODY:
In the last 10 years, Urszula Malinowska and her husband have transformed their lives, turning a tiny farm and orchard into a wood-processing factory that employs 35 people.
In 1991, after failed farming ventures, they bought a used American machine to cut timber, a Wood-Mizer, and created a business of turning timber into lumber for the building boom that has transformed this area near Mszczonow, some 35 miles southwest of Warsaw. 
 Now, they have $500,000 a year in revenue, produce their own power and heat from the waste wood and sawdust, and are planning a more modern plant to work on more expensive woods for higher-profit furniture.
Mrs. Malinowska, at 48, could be a billboard for the new market economy that has taken hold in Poland, the largest and most successful economic transformation in central Europe. She is the active boss of one of two million small and medium-sized private enterprises in a country of 42 million people.
But like many Poles, she is not especially happy with the way things are, and she is likely to vote for the reformed Communists of the Democratic Left Alliance in parliamentary elections expected next spring, dumping the more conservative Solidarity alliance.
To Mrs. Malinowska, the changes have come with mixed blessings. "The great satisfaction is that we've built something new, and without permission from anyone," she said, as her workers took large pine logs and began to turn them into lumber.
"As owners, there is a great feeling of responsibility, and we work from 6 to 6," she added. "But there is a sense of achieving one's goals."
Still, she said, "there are lots of problems." Small businesses don't get much help from the state; the tax laws are complicated and contradictory; there is an effective state monopoly on the supply of lumber, given the difficulties of trade with Russia, Ukraine and Belarus; and with Poland still outside the European Union and membership probably four years away, she feels that "our Western partners take advantage of our weaknesses."
The sourness is widely felt by Poles, whose rapid progress is nonetheless falling behind their own expectations. While young people are full of confidence, many Poles still have a deep fear of being marginalized, of falling behind, both as individuals and as a nation striving to join the rest of Europe as an equal, said Jacek Kucharczyk, deputy director of the Institute of Public Affairs, an independent Polish research organization.
"Poland is a country doing better than it feels -- it's doing better than it thinks it's doing," Mr. Kucharczyk said. Polls show that more than 50 percent of Poles think it's a better country than 10 years ago, and only 30 percent disagree, he said.
But change is still frightening to those who are over 40. And the current Solidarity government's big reforms -- to decentralize and streamline health care, education, pensions and provincial administration -- have caused enormous anxiety.
With more to lose, there is also a growing concern about personal safety and crime, and a feeling that the police are not keeping up with the problem.
Even the prospect of joining the European Union has raised considerable fear -- not just among the many farmers who fear European competition, but also among those who worry that Poland will give up some of its precious identity, after centuries of struggle to shape and preserve it.
What is the Polish nightmare? "To be the Mexico of Germany: proud, important, too big to fail, but deeply unbalanced next to a neighbor that is too rich and too big," one European ambassador said.
Poles are more pessimistic these days, said Halina Binczak, economics editor of the respected daily newspaper Rzeczpospolita. In polls, only about 8 percent of Poles think the reforms are going well. Five years ago, she said, 60 percent of households had trouble making ends meet. Today, it's some 40 percent. "Yet five years ago, people were more optimistic than now," she said. "Our aspirations are rising faster than our possibilities. People are less satisfied with what they have, even though they have more."
Yet the signs of new prosperity are all over Poland. In Mszczonow, a small town of some 6,000, there are scores of new shops -- bakeries, groceries, hardware stores, hairdressers -- that did not exist 10 years ago. The town has streetlights now, put up four years ago. A special kind of apple is being grown by farmers that feeds good, tart concentrate into blended juices; there is one large industrial park, called Europark, already in operation, with another soon to open.
On this main route near Warsaw, there are hundreds of trucks from all over Europe and the former Soviet Union. Servicing them are large gas stations, looking like modern palaces, with their cafes and small grocery stores attached. (And in a sign of the growing traffic, numerous prostitutes line up at intervals along the roadway.)
The roads are crammed with new cars. Poles have bought more than 500,000 new cars each year for the last four years, reflecting the prosperity and an explosion in consumer credit, but posing dangers for more inflation, already at 11.6 percent in July, a two-year high.
And they use their cars to shop at huge supermarket complexes in the suburbs, where Ikea rubs up against KFC and McDonald's and Carrefour and Geant superstores.
But for all this wealth, the infrastructure lags far behind. Warsaw traffic is bad, and there is barely a subway system, with only one short line. The telephone system, reluctantly changing from a state monopoly, is inefficient, compared with the Czech Republic's or even Romania's, and expensive.
There are few highways, and the two-lane roads -- effectively three-lane, with expensive cars zooming around buses, trucks and the little old Polski Fiats that can't go much over 60 miles an hour -- are often seamed and channeled, with heavy traffic punishing roadbeds built for less booming times.
Road fatalities are consequently a major issue, with large green and black signs displaying the number of dead and injured at particularly bad spots. A billboard campaign shows wrecked cars with large, one-word slogans: "Autoagresja" and "Autodestrukcja."
Like its roads, Poland's politics are messy and crowded, still driven by the ideologies of the battle, 20 years ago, against Communism: Reformed Communists versus the Solidarity coalition, which itself is a very broad church of some 30 parties. Although its roots are in a trade union, Solidarity is center-right in politics. Some of the best-known intellectuals associated with Solidarity, like Bronislaw Geremek, the historian and former foreign minister, formed the Freedom Union, further to the right. And then there are farmers' parties and some Roman Catholic parties that veer toward ultranationalism, exemplified by Radio Marya, a radio station supported by a vocal minority of Poland's priests.
But as everywhere in the former Soviet-bloc countries, patronage and corruption still play too large a role in politics, with parties and ministers often getting kickbacks from businesses and lobbyists for contracts or favors.
The Polish government itself asked the World Bank to look into corruption last year, and was told that the main problem is graft among legislators, ministers and judges.
Economically, everyone agrees, Poland's biggest problem is the deficit in the current trade account -- with imports, fed by new prosperity and credit, growing more rapidly than exports. The gap is now almost 8 percent of gross domestic product, said Ms. Binczak of Rzeczpospolita. The government has to do more, she said, to support exporters with credits and tax breaks or risk a currency crisis and a reduction in foreign capital flows that finance the budget deficit.
Even so, Polish exports have at least quadrupled in the last decade, with more than 70 percent of exports going to countries of the European Union and only 10 percent now going to Russia, said Witold M. Orlowski of the Independent Center for Economic Studies. The economy is growing an average of about 5 percent a year over the past several years, and the government estimates $12 billion this year in foreign direct investment, after last year's record $8 billion -- a serious vote of confidence by hardheaded foreign businesses.
Some diplomats and analysts are concerned that the minority Solidarity government, facing likely elections in the spring over the 2001 budget, will increase the budget deficit too much with populist spending, to try to fight slowly rising unemployment, estimated at 13.5 percent this year. But Ms. Binczak and others believe that the fundamentals of economic policy are set, in part by the markets and the pressure to join the European Union, and that the politicians will not want to disrupt them too badly.
"The overwhelming sense is that the Poles are going in the right direction," a Western ambassador said. "This is no longer a grimy little East European country trying to keep its head above water, but a country taking its place in Europe."
Agriculture remains the biggest structural challenge to a modernizing Poland -- and to its entry into the European Union. Some 25 percent of Poland's workers live in the poorer countryside, many of them on small farms. But of the country's 2.1 million farms, only half sell significant amounts to the market. The other half belong to subsistence farmers, whom no one wants to suddenly move into the cities. The European Union will help, but wants to contain the size of the subsidies.
Farmers, protected by socialism, are the ones most concerned by the new Poland, which they see as a land of high taxes, falling farm prices and rising prices for fertilizer, fuel, seeds and machinery.
In Skorzec, a tiny village about four miles south of Ciechanowiec, two farmers, Czeslaw Bojar, 59, and his neighbor, Kazimierz Murowski, 64, stopped work to chat and complain.
"When I bought my first tractor, under Communism, it cost 27 pigs," Mr. Murowski said. "Today, it costs 100 pigs." He stopped to scratch. "It's not that we liked Communism, but life was better for us then."
Mr. Bojar has six sons and worries that his farm, roughly 25 acres, will not be big enough for all of them, and that some will find themselves in the cities, unemployed. As for the European Union, he said: "I can't know the future, and people disagree. But when we join the E.U., it will be like a bulldozer and break down all the walls, and then who knows?"
Mr. Murowski said everything was comparative. "I remember how it was after the war, with everything destroyed and nothing to eat," he said. "Well, it's better to be poor in peace than rich in war."
Still, the farmers have cars, heat, telephones and television, a big change from 15 years ago, they admit, and their neighbors, with a new roof and siding on their house, are off working in Belgium, earning good money.
"When we were a Communist country, they said we'll be in heaven one day, and now they say it'll be even nicer that we're not Communists anymore," Mr. Bojar said. "And we, we still hope it will be better than it is."
Karol Szyndzielorz, a former journalist turned businessman, put it simply. "Poles cannot believe it, but it's true," he said. "Poland is now a lucky country."
